54 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1996


Uganda;
Amnesty Calls For Release Of Schoolgirls By Rebels


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

London - Amnesty International today strongly condemned the recent abduction of schoolgirls by the northern Ugandan armed opposition Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) and called on the group to immediately release all captives.

Thirty schoolgirls abducted on 9 October from St. Mary's College in Aboke are reported to be among scores of captives in the hands of the LRA, despite military intervention by the army, the Ugandan People's Defence Force (UPDF). The raid on the school continues the pattern of LRA deliberate assaults on civilians which have intensified over the past three months.

"The abduction of the girls from Aboke is the latest in a series of attacks on schools by the LRA and demonstrates yet again that the rebels are blatant in their disregard for the human rights of the very people on whose behalf they claim to be fighting," Amnesty International said. 

Since the massacre of 115 Sudanese refugees at Achol- Pii in July, LRA troops have been responsible for scores of other deliberate killings and hundreds of abductions, often of schoolchildren. Many captives are tortured and those who try to escape risk being shot. Abducted girls are at risk of rape. Children are forcibly recruited into the LRA's ranks or are used to carry equipment and looted property.

The LRA has bases in Sudan and is reportedly supported by the Sudan Government. The LRA troops holding the girls taken captive are reported to have crossed the Sudan border. Amnesty International is calling on the Sudanese authorities to take action to ensure that captives are freed and returned safely to Uganda.

Although the UPDF have often stepped in to free rebel captives, their own responsibility for human rights abuses is helping fuel the violence in northern Uganda. On 16 August two of the most senior army officers in Gulu town threw four alleged LRA members to a lynch mob. After one man was killed, the soldiers drove to the main barracks, picked out a seriously wounded rebel suspect, drove to another part of Gulu and threw him and the two others to the crowd.

The army has exonerated the officers concerned, who remain at their posts, claiming that they were overpowered. However, as yet there has been no genuine impartial judicial inquiry charged with establishing the facts and recommending appropriate action. Amnesty International's information -- which comes from a wide variety of independent sources -- contradicts the army's version of events.

One of those murdered was a young man taken captive by the LRA only the day before. His parents are reported to be seeking compensation from the army. Another was a tailor with no known connection with the rebels.

"It is difficult to understand how the authorities believe that local people can have confidence in the armed forces if soldiers, especially senior officers, are allowed to murder with impunity," Amnesty International said.

"However severe the abuses of the LRA, nothing excuses violations by the UPDF or failure by the authorities to take decisive action to prevent or properly investigate UPDF violations."

Amnesty International is calling for a judicial inquiry into the killings on 16 August and the army's response. As an interim measure, the worldwide human rights organization is calling on the parliamentary Defence and Internal Affairs Committee investigating the causes of the insurgency to take a detailed look at the Gulu incident.

Journalists and human rights activists have on occasion been threatened by both the LRA and members of the armed forces. Amnesty International is also calling on the Ugandan authorities to ensure that journalists and human rights activists working in the north are able to carry out their work in a responsible and professional manner without curbs on their freedom of expression.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1996


Zaire;
UN Security Council Calls for International Response


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

United Nations - The Security Council has said that it was gravely concerned at the deteriorating situation in the Great Lakes region, in, particular eastern Zaire, and at the effect which the continued fighting was having on the inhabitants of that region.

In a Presidential statement on Friday, the Council President, Ambassador Nugroho Wisnumurti of Indonesia said the Council underlined the urgent need for a comprehensive and coordinated response by the international community to prevent any further escalation of the crisis in the region, adding that the Council called for an immediate cease-fire and a complete cessation of all fighting in the region.

Calling on all States to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of neighbouring States in accordance with their obligations under the UN Charter, the Council urged all parties to refrain from the use of force as well as cross-border incursions and to engage in a process of negotiation.

The Council said it agreed with the Secretary-General that the situation in eastern Zaire constituted a serious threat to the stability of the Great Lakes region. "It is convinced that the complex problems at issue can only be resolved through early and substantive dialogue. The Council urges the Governments of the region to pursue such a dialogue without further delay in order to defuse the tension," the President of the Council said. 

Reiterating that the present situation in eastern Zaire underlined the need to organise a conference on peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region under the auspices of the UN and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), the Council called on the Secretary-General to ask his Special Envoy to promote the convening and to encourage the adequate preparation of such a conference on an urgent basis.

TEXT OF SECURITY COUNCIL RESOLUTION

The Security Council is gravely concerned at the deteriorating situation in the Great Lakes region, in particular eastern Zaire, and at the effect which the continued fighting is having on the inhabitants of the region and condemns all acts of violence. It underlines the urgent need for a comprehensive and coordinated response by the international community to prevent any further escalation of the crisis there.

The Security Council calls for an immediate cease-fire and a complete cessation of all fighting in the region. The council calls on all States to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of neighboring States in accordance with their obligations under the United Nations charter. In this connection, it urges all parties to refrain from the use of force as well as cross-border incursions and to engage in a process of negotiation.

The Security Council, in the light of the letters of the Secretary General to the President of the Council (S/1996/875 and S/1996/878), and the information received from the High Commissioner for Refugees, and the Assistant Secretary-General for Human Rights regarding the situation in eastern Zaire, is particularly concerned at the humanitarian situation and the resulting large-scale movements of refugees and displaced persons.

It fully supports the efforts of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and humanitarian agencies to alleviate the suffering. It calls on all parties in the region to allow humanitarian agencies and non-governmental organizations to deliver humanitarian assistance to those in need and to ensure the safety of all refugees as well as the security and freedom of movement of all international humanitarian personnel. It underlines the urgent need for the orderly voluntary repatriation and resettlement of refugees, and the return of displaced persons, which are crucial elements for the stability of the region.

The Security Council agrees with the Secretary-General that the situation in eastern Zaire constitutes a serious threat to the stability of the Great Lakes region. It is convinced that the complex problems at issue can only be resolved through early and substantive dialogue. The Council urges the governments of the region to pursue such a dialogue without further delay in order to defuse the tension. The Council calls upon all states in the region to create the conditions necessary for the speedy and peaceful resolution of the conflict, and to desist from any acts that may further exacerbate the situation. In this context, the Council welcomes all regional efforts aimed at defusing tension in the region, in particular the announcement of the meeting of regional leaders scheduled for 5 November 1996 in Nairobi, Kenya.

The Security Council fully supports the initiative of the secretary-General to dispatch to the Great Lakes region a Special Envoy to consult with all concerned in order to establish the facts relating to the present conflict; to develop as a matter of urgency a plan to defuse tension and establish a cease-fire; to promote a process of negotiation; and to submit advice on the mandate to be given to a United Nations Special Representative, including on the size and structure of a United Nations political presence which, in consultation with the governments and parties concerned, will he established in the Great Lakes region.

The Council also considers that the Special Envoy should he provided with adequate staff and logistic resources in order to carry out his mission. The Council also expresses the hope that the mediation efforts of the Organization of African Unity and the European Union will complement those of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General.

The Council calls upon all governments and parties concerned to cooperate fully with the mission of the Special Envoy, and to contribute to the search for a comprehensive solution to the problems facing the people of the Great Lakes region. Given the urgency of the situation, the Council expresses the hope that the Special Envoy will travel as soon as possible to the region and provide early information on the situation there.

The Security Council reiterates that the present situation in eastern Zaire underlines the need to organize a conference on peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region under the auspices of the United Nations and the Organization of African Unity. To this end, it calls on the Secretary-General to ask his Special Envoy to promote the convening and to encourage the adequate preparation of such a conference on an urgent basis.

The Security Council will remain seized of the matter.

56 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 2, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
VEEP MIYANDA 'ZAM-FOOTS' FOR SOCCER


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Vice President Godfrey Miyanda was among hundreds of Lusaka residents who walked in the scorching heat in order to raise money for cash strapped national soccer team which is about to engage in major Africa and World cup series.

Brigadier-General (RTRD) Miyanda, wearing the popular ''chipololo t-shirt'', flagged off the fundrising walk from Toyota Zambia Limited - north end of Cairo road and proceed to Kafue round-about before making a left turn to join the Independence Avenue. 

Many firms and individuals made pledges to the soccer team which was expected to leave on Wednesday for the first world cup qualifying round to be played on November 10.

Gen Miyanda, who constantly diverted from the official speech, reminded the gathering that he was a former strikerand gave a catalogue of some of his team-mates.

He later donated K500,000 to the team whilst in camp that would help them sort a few things before they leave.

The "sweating" marchers then turned right when they were near the mosque robots to join Church Road adjacent to Fairview Motel. They later, turned left at the Fire Brigade offices to join the Great East Road before proceeding back to the starting point, taking precisely 45 minutes.

Others who participated in the walk included the soccer national team, local soccer clubs, chipolopolo soccer fans and the police brass band and junior youth girls club.

Conspiciously missing from the fund-rising walk were national team coach Roald Poulsen and Chipolopolo patron William Harrington.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 2, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 4 on Eastern Zaire (11/02)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Nairobi - Heavy fighting continued in and around Goma, easing late afternoon with persistent press reports that Rwandan troops have entered the town in support of rebel forces and in response to Zairean shelling.

The Rwanda Foreign Minister did not challenge allegations of a Rwandan incursion during an interview this evening. The BBC reported late Saturday afternoon that there were indications that the most of Goma had fallen to Tutsi rebels and that Zairean troops had fled the town. 108 aid workers and 11 foreign journalists were evacuated by road to the Rwandan border town of Gisenyi and were granted transit status by Rwanda.

They should arrive in Nairobi on a WFP chartered Hercules today (Saturday). Local Zairean aid workers did not join the evacuation, and had continued limited relief activities on Friday. In terms of the looming humanitarian crisis - which has been described as "apocolyptic" - Goma is critical, holding the largest concentration of Rwandan refugees (estimated by the UNHCR at 717,000). 

Zairean armed forces Chief of Staff Eluki Monga Aundu criticized the central government for not giving his troops the means to fight the on-going war. He added that his troops would continue to fight and would not stop at the Rwandan border but would continue beyond in a counter-offensive. He also claimed that Bukavu and Goma airports were still in Zairean army control.

Fighting has dispersed most of the refugees on the "northern axis" of Goma. There were more reports today that Katale camp (202,000 Rwanda refugees) had dispersed. This has not been officially confirmed by UNHCR. Territorial gains by the rebels now include most of the border between Zaire, Rwanda and Burundi, and a border post on the Ugandan frontier. Far to the south, PANA reports the arrival by boat of 1,000 refugees in Zambia.

Rwanda's ambassador to Zaire, Antoine Nyilinkindi, resigned Saturday, saying he disagreed with his government's position regarding Zaire, adding that Zaire was a victim of Rwanda's aggression.

The President of the UN General Assembly, Razali Ismail (Malaysia) issued a statement rebuking the international community for its impotence in the regional crisis, saying he felt guilt at the "feeble" response. He said the United Nations "should be in mourning" not only for the "enormous human catastrophe" unfolding in the Great Lakes but also for the "evaporation of the international community's ability to respond effectively". Other critical reactions included British aid agency Oxfam which said (Friday) that the regional crisis was more than a humanitarian disaster - "it is the tearing up of the Geneva Convention" - and that refugees and the displaced were being denied protection by the international community as well as the warring parties.

On Friday, the Security Council called for a ceasefire and an end to "trans- border incursions" saying they were "a serious threat to the stability of the Great Lakes region". The statement made no reference to international military intervention, but supported a UN political presence. Those calling for foreign intervention now appear to include South Africa, voiced by Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo (Friday) - "it is no doubt our unanimous view that the international community must take urgent measures, through the UN and regional organisations, to ensure peace and calm is restored". Moreover, South Africa is "reviewing" an $18 million arms deal with Rwanda due to the current crisis, according to Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad.

US State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said on Friday that the UN "is in the lead politically and from the humanitarian point of view", but said a State Department offical would visit the region next week. He said that the US is "working very cooperatively with France" for a regional African conference. European Union ministers have been invited to meet in Brussels next Thursday to discuss emergency humanitarian support.

UN Special Mediator Raymond Chretien's trip to the region will not take place until after US presidential elections (November 5) - he is expected to arrive in Kinshasa on November 8 and Kigali November 11, having said his first priority is to arrange a ceasefire. Chretien told reporters he would also stop in Lausanne to see President Mobutu before leaving for the region. According to the French daily Le Monde (Friday) Mobutu is unable to return to Zaire because of the effects of radiotherapy, and quoted medical aides saying that cancer had spread to his bones. This has not been officially confirmed by Lausanne's University Hospital.

There are reports of increasing political discontent in Kinshasa - BBC reported looting of property belonging to Tutsis. Reuter reported several hundred protesters marching to Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo's offices and calling for his dismissal. Kengo (whom opposition groups are associating with the eastern Zairean crisis by virtue of his being part Tutsi) defended the Zairean army as having "the means" to defend the country and publicly complained of being made a "scapegoat". Amnesty International has released a report expressing concern for human rights abuses against ethnic Tutsis in Kinshasa - reporting families removed from their homes by the Zairean security forces - and detailing the arrest of three human rights activists. The report says there is growing violence against and forced deportations of those associated with the crisis in eastern Zaire - primarily ethnic Tutsis, but also ethnic Hutus, and other sympathisers.

The Tutsi rebels are fighting as part of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire, a political alliance of four opposition parties (Democratic Alliance of the People; Popular Revolutionary Pary; National Resistance Council for Democracy; Revolutionary Movement for the Liberation of Zaire). In a letter, attached to the ADFL (Congo-Zaire) manifesto, spokesman Laurent Kabila describes the party as "an instrument of radical change". The ADFL declares there are "no longer solid, stable or credible institutions in Zaire" and says it decided "to put an end to this state of affairs".

On Friday the Zairean government said it had decided to deport Rwandan and Burundian refugees "progessively and by force". In a statement issued after a cabinet meeting it declared it would not take part in any meeting on the crisis in eastern Zaire "so long as the aggressor has not left Zairean soil". Calls by the transitional parliament to sever diplomatic links with Uganda as well as with Rwanda and Burundi has widened the international dimensions of the conflict. Uganda denied any involvement today.

Nairobi, 18:45 GMT 2 November 1996 (ENDS)

Africa News


November 3, 1996


Zambia;
Former President Raises Concerns on Zaire Fighting


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP president, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, has expressed concern at the on going fighting in neighbouring Zaire saying he was willing to mediate.

Speaking at a press briefing at Inter-Continenatl Hotel in Lusaka Dr Kaunda said he was prepared to mediate in the civil strife that has led to wide- spread fighting between the Tutsi-ethnic minority Zaireans, Banyamulenge and Zairean soldiers on the borders of Zaire and Rwanda. 

He claimed that already there have been requests from Burundi appealing to him to intervene in the matter that has resulted in many Zairean border towns falling into the hands of the rebel army.

He said he was ready to work alongside his old friend, Dr Julius Nyerere of Tanzania in dealing with this matter.

59 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 3, 1996


Zambia;
CUSA ON CONTINENTAL PROGRAMME


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Kafue - The Credit Union and Societies' Association (CUSA) Zambia is among other credit organisations in Africa elected to participate in the programme called Africa Revitalisation Programme (ARP) 2000 to design and develop policies, products and services to make them more competitive in the financial market and satisfy credit union members expectations.

This was disclosed in kafue yesterday by CUSA-Zambia acting managing director, Mr Robby Chilupula, when he opened the annual general meeting of the Nitrogen Chemicals of Zambia (NCZ) savings and credit union at social centre. 

Mr Chilupula said NCZ credit union is one of the ten (10) credit organisations in Zambia out of 500 that had been chosen to pioneer the African revatilisation programme.

Under the programme activities to be undertaken include providing savings and deposit accounts savings withdrawals and shareholding accounts.

Meanwhile NCZ credit union members took their board members to task for allegedly helping themselves to large chunks of loans while shareholders receive peanuts.

They charged that despite the credit union share capital increasing from k54 million to k62 million in the last 12 months services to shareholders were shody promptimg several resignations by members.

Board chairman, Mr Sylvester Kalunga parried the charges saying withdrawing shares was not the solution as this affected levels of investments. He said shareholders were at liberty through their supervisory committee to dictate to the board better ways of improving services.

Mr Kalunga said the board was working out a programme to intensify member education and plans were underway to increase funding from 5 to 10 per cent of surplus funds to ensure the success of the programme.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 3, 1996


South Africa;
ANC on Arrest Of ANC North West Province Bookkeeper


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg - Statement by the chairperson of the African National Congress of the North West Province: re the arrest of the ex-provincial accountant/bookkeeper of the African National Congress of the North West Province Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk, 1 November 1996.

Following an internal investigation by the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province and the South African Police Service (Commercial Branch) of Klerksdorp, warrants for the arrest of Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk and for the search of his house have been implemented by members of the South African Police Service (Commercial Branch) at Klerksdorp.

Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk over the period during his employment as the Provincial Accountant/Bookkeeper of the African National Congress of the North West Province defrauded the African National Congress of hundreds of thousands of rands - including local government election money.

Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk during his employment made irregular and unauthorised use of AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS cheques and money - i.e.:

To buy two motor vehicles for himself amounting to R180 000-00 (one hundred and eighty thousand rand) both motor vehicles were recovered by the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS. 

To buy worthless shares from a family members and transferred it in the name of the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province.

To draw cash cheques to the amount of ten thousands of rands which are unaccounted for.

To draw other cheques to the amount of hundreds of thousands of rands which are unaccounted for and of which a number of cheques already were traced back as cheques used by him to his own benefit, and.

To pay salaries to people irregularly and unauthorised employed by him at the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS's Provincial Offices in Klerksdorp.

Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk shortly before his official suspension, alleged that he was attacked on his way from Mmabatho to Klerksdorp near Hartbeesfontein and that all the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province's financial books and supporting documentation were taken by the attackers. This allegation by Mr J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk is completely devoid of all truth as the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province and the South African Police Service (Commercial Branch) Klerksdorp are in possession of statements in support of the fact that no such attack has taken place.

Mr J.P (Hannes) Broodryk after his final dismissal by the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province irregularly and unauthorised used AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS cheques - money -i.e.

To purchase goods from a well-known retailer in Klerksdorp to his own benefit who even issued a company cheque to Mr. J.P. (Hannes) Broodryk as change on a AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS cheque; and

To irregularly and unauthorised pay money into the bank account of his wife, Mrs C.F. Broodryk, to which nor he nor she was entitled to.

Mr. J.P (Hannes) Broodryk throughout his period of employment have failed to fulfil his duties and responsibilities as the Provincial Accountant/Bookkeeper for the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province despite various demands by the Provincial Treasurer, Mrs M. Modiselle, and the Secretary General, Mr N. Duma as well as the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS Head Office in Johannesburg.

Presently an external audit is performed by a well-known and respected company in the North West Province as to determine the exact extend of the mal administration of the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province's money by Mr J.P (Hannes) Broodryk during his time of employment. This audit is expected to be completed shortly.

As chairman of the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province, I will take all steps necessary to ensure that all reasonable legal and other steps and processes are taken to criminally charge and civilly recover the AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS of the North West Province's money.

The internal investigation and the investigation by the South African Police Service (Commercial Branch) of Klerksdorp continues and the press will be updated on the progress.

Mr Popo-S. Molefe (CHAIRPERSON OF THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS OF THE NORTH WEST PROVINCE).

Africa News


November 3, 1996


South Africa;
ANC Says Hani Killers Don't Qualify for Amnesty


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC has taken note of the application for amnesty for the murder of ANC-SACP leader Chris Hani submitted to the Truth Commission by Janus Waluz and Clive-Derby Lewis.

The ANC reiterates its view that the prerogative of deciding on any application for amnesty resides within the jurisdiction of the Truth Commission. The ANC respects decisions of the Truth Commission within the confines of the law.

However, we wish to underline that at the trial it emerged that Clive-Derby- Lewis and Janus Waluz were motivated by factors completely extraneous to the peace process that was underway.

Furthermore, the two have never contended that they murdered Chris Hani in furtherance of any political objectives of any known political organisation. As a matter of fact no political organisation associated itself with their actions.

In addition the murder of Chris Hani was completely disproportionate to any concerns Waluz and Derby-Lewis may have had against the ANC and its allies.

It is therefore our contention as an organisation that section 20 of the Truth Commission Act which defines acts with political objectives and sets out the prerequisites for granting amnesty, does not envisage the granting of amnesty to individuals such as these.

In this regard, the ANC will support any efforts by the family of Chris Hani to oppose the application. We wish to reiterate, however, that the ANC and its allies will respect the determination made by the Truth Commission on this and other matters.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O Box 61884, Marshalltown, 2107, 1 November 1996.

LANGUAGE: English

South Africa;
ANC Welcomes Verdict in De Kock Trial


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC welcomes the sentence handed down on former police officer Eugene De Kock by the Pretoria Supreme court. Although the sentence meted out cannot be a substitute for the valuable lives lost, it nonetheless fits the long list of crimes committed by the accused.

The ANC expresses its wish that the verdict and the sentence will serve as one of those historic deterrences against those who may now or in the future contemplate committing crimes against humanity. The ANC also hopes it will send a clear message to those who continue to commit crimes like murder, car- hijackings, rape and others. 

It is the conviction of the ANC that those who conspired, aided and abetted the commission of such crimes as De Kock would themselves face the same fate.

In this regard, the National Party government bears the primary responsibility for acts committed in defence of the repugnant system of apartheid by the CCB, Vlakplaas Unit, Koevoet and others.

We insist that the activities of such units were not the work of rogue elements within the security establishment, but part of an overall strategy to undermine the ANC and the broad liberation movement.

Now is the time for National Party leader FW De Klerk to come clean. in the spirit of reconciliation and peace, by taking the nation into his confidence and confess the sins of successive National Party governments.

We reiterate the call by families of many victims for full disclosure on all hitsquads activities and revelation of graves of those murdered and those who disappeared.

The ANC calls on the Attorney's-General to follow up on details and clues provided by Eugene De Kock to ensure that all those implicated in similar heinous deeds including massacres, assassinations, train violence and the current taxi violence must be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884. Marshalltown, 30 0ctober 1996.

Africa News


November 4, 1996


Nigeria;
Amnesty Launches Nigerian Campaign in South Africa


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

London - An Amnesty International delegation led by Secretary General Pierre Sane is in South Africa between 4 and 9 November 1996 to mark the first anniversary of the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa and launch a worldwide campaign on human rights in Nigeria. The delegates will also be discussing Amnesty International's concerns about the current human rights situation in the Great Lakes region. 

During the visit the delegates will meet representatives of the South African government, non- governmental organizations (NGOs) and religious communities. The South African government has been one of the most active African governments working for human rights improvements in Nigeria, and the South Africa-Nigeria Democracy Support Group (SANDSG) is an important NGO coalition network.

The delegation is in South Africa following prolonged but unsuccessful efforts to visit Nigeria itself. The Nigerian authorities have failed to respond to repeated requests for visas for the delegation. Amnesty International first wrote to the High Commissioner in London asking for a meeting regarding this visit in July 1996. In August it wrote to the Minister of Foreign Affairs. In September visa applications were submitted. No official response has been received to any of these approaches.

The delegation, which was to have included Mme Danielle Mitterrand, had planned to meet Nigerian government officials, representatives of human rights organizations and other individuals. Amnesty International has throughout been willing to discuss with representatives of the Nigerian government its plans for the visit and remains willing to discuss arrangements for a future visit.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Zaire;
Cease-Fire Provides Opportunity To Act


BYLINE: Refugees International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Washington, DC - A million Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire are now without international protection and assistance as a result of the withdrawal of all humanitarian NGOs and UN agencies from Goma. Will the international community come to their aid in time to avert the deaths of tens of thousands?

Today, with the announcement by Tutsi rebels of a unilateral three-week cease-fire the international community may have its best opportunity to ensure that thousands of lives are not unnecessarily lost. 

Ideally, an international military force would secure humanitarian corridors in Zaire, but realistically this will not happen quickly. Meanwhile, what can be done is to organize a civilian operation along the Zaire-Rwanda border to deliver short-term emergency assistance and access for refugees to return to Rwanda.

To staff such an effort, the UNHCR should rely on a combination of its staff, volunteers drawn from humanitarian NGOs, Rwandan civil servants seconded from the ranks of border prefectures, and paid contract workers-- including former camp residents. Teams composed of individuals from the aforementioned groups could be posted at regular intervals along the route to provide emergency assistance, information, and, most of all, moral support to those heading home.

Assuming that the cease-fire holds, this plan could be implemented within days, and it will have to be, since by all accounts the supplies of food and water available to the displaced camp residents will last no longer than a week. The virtue of this plan is that it is quick, but it should not detract from efforts to organize and deploy an international security force.

Persuading the refugees to return home will not be easy. Their leaders, who exercise a great deal of influence over refugee decision making, have long decreed that it is too dangerous to go home and that many will be arrested or killed. The voices of Hutu refugees who have returned home safely need to be heard. Perhaps a credible Hutu spokesperson will step forward to break the deadlock.

Indeed, human rights abuses persist in Rwanda and immediate corrective measures should be taken. But the bottom line is that the only way for most refugees to avoid life-threatening peril will be to return home before disease, lack of food and fighting result in tens of thousands of deaths. For most refugees, repatriation is the best available choice.

For some time, the international community has been pressing Rwanda to begin trials for those accused of human rights abuses and to relieve inhumane overcrowding in the prisons. In a good faith gesture, it would be especially helpful if Rwanda started civilian trials and military court proceedings for Rwandan military officials charged with human rights violations. Similarly, the international community should also insist that the international tribunal seated in Arusha begin trials immediately.

If massive repatriation does occur, the Government of Rwanda will require more financial and humanitarian assistance. Though much reconstruction has taken place during the last two years, much more remains to be done to accommodate new returnees.

For more information, contact Refugees International -- 2639 Conn. Ave, NW, Washington, DC 20008 Phone: 202-828-0110 Fax: 202-828-0819 www: http://www. clark.net/pub/ri.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Zambia;
VOTERS CARDS TO BE REDISTRIBUTED


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - All uncollected voters' cards were today sent to 4,610 polling stations in the country, the chairman of the Electoral Commission Bobby Bwalya said.

Justice Bwalya, who was speaking today at a Patriotic Rescue Monitors (PAREMO) seminar in Lusaka said that all uncollected voters' cards have been sent to respective polling centres for collection by the owners.

He urged all those who have lost their voters' cards to hastely collect voters' certificates from the elections office or polling stations so that they could participate in the November 18 elections. 

Justice Bwalya also revealed that the Electoral Commission had also instructed the national registration department to give national registration cards to those who have lost them so that they could participate in the elections.

He urged the PAREMO monitors not to be corrupted and observe all corrupt and bribery acts which he said amount to a fine of K300,000 or imprisonment of three months or both.

Meanwhile, Justice Bwalya has warned all ministers against using state vehicles for campaign purposes because it was contrary to the just adopted electoral codes of conduct regulation.

The electoral codes of conduct regulation, which becomes a statutory instrument tomorrow only allows the President to use state utilities for campaigns.

Further, the electoral codes of conducts also forbids campaigning on the polling day failure to which can lead to three months' imprisonment or fine of K300,000.

"There will be no campaigns on the election day. The candidates from various political parties can only campaign up to November 17. The new electoral codes of conduct which was accepted by all political parties does not allow campaigning on the polling day," he said.

Clarifying further to the monitors on the events on the polling day, Justice Bwalya said it was not an offence to transport voters to polling stations as it would be easing their transport problems and also because the vote was secret.

He urged all Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) and monitoring teams in the country to work as partners with the electoral commission to achieve a goal of free and fair elections.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Zambia;
PRESIDENT CHILUBA FOR 'GREAT LAKES' SUMMIT


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba leaves for Nairobi, Kenya tomorrow to participate in a one-day summit on the eastern Zaire crisis convened by the Organisation of African Unity. 

A statement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued in Lusaka today said the summit will be chaired by OAU chairman Paul Biya of Cameroon.

Other Heads of State invited to attend the talks are host country Kenya, Eritrea, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire and Zambia.

More than 1000 Rwandan refugees fled from camps in eastern Zaire into Zambia since September because of escalating violence and increasing insecurity.

This is one of the issues to be discussed at the Kenya summit apart from the continuing crisis in Burundi.

Zambia;
'STOP YOUR INTERFERENCE' - KAUNDA TOLD


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) today called on UNIP President, Kenneth Kaunda, to stop interfering with the November 18 general elections because he was not involved in the polls.

ZDC national coordinator, Enock Chola and Kafue constituency vice chairman, Langton Sichone who had travelled all the way from Kafue to Lusaka said that police must take immediate action against Dr Kaunda for collecting voters cards from the electorate if it was indeed an offence as alleged by the police. 

Mr Chola and Mr Sichone said the inspector general of police, Francis Ndhlovu should urgently deal with this case so that elections could be conducted in a free and fair atmosphere.

"We are asking government to take action against Dr Kaunda to restrain him from conducting his exercise to grab the voters cards. Yesterday, in Kafue, he instructed his members to go flat out in grabbing the cards. We as ZDC dissociate ourselves from his action. We don't want to be used by Dr Kaunda", said Mr Sichone.

Mr Sichone said ZDC does not believe in violence but in the rule of law and urged all opposition parties taking part in the elections to work hand in hand so that the elections were conducted peacefully.

And Mr Chola urged ZDC members to report to the nearest police station anyone asking to grab the voter's card from them.

Addressing a public meeting in Kafue yesterday, Dr Kaunda instructed his party members to go from door to door, collecting voters cards as a way of forcing Mr Chiluba out of office.

Africa News


November 4, 1996


Southern Africa;
Southern Africa Achieves Record Food Surplus


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The 12 Southern African Development Community (SADC) states, which recently suffered a drought-induced decline in food production, expect an upswing in the output of the staple maize crop, after favorable rains in most of the region in 1966.

Crop production forecasts, published by the community's Food Security Regional Early Warning Unit in Harare, Zimbabwe, show that the region would this season record a combined 77 percent rise in maize production.

The unit anticipates that the region will in 1996 produce some 19.59 million tons of maize compared to 11.10 million tons harvested during the previous season. This is expected to meet the total regional consumption requirement of 19.25 million tons, including stock needs for the 1996/97 season. 

According to the unit's March forecast, the region can also expect maize surplus in the 1996/97 marketing season. South Africa is expected to produce 3.36 million tons, and Zimbabwe 54,000 tons. Even Mozambique, emerging from years of war, is expected to produce some 48,000 tons.

Almost all of the community countries had been affected by intermittent drought since their worst experience during the 1990/91 season. That drought forced many states to import food.

To guard against future droughts, the region has embarked on an ambitious food security program. This establishes a regional food reserve and proposes a 30-million-U.S.-dollar loan fund for countries needing to import food during climatic disasters.

These tasks are in addition to the unit's responsibility to provide information about the food situation in member-states, enabling food deficit countries to take appropriate steps to prevent cereal shortages and avoid famine.

In addition, the unit plans to put in place food storage, distribution and other measures to ensure food availability to all its 180 million inhabitants.

"We believe there is no reason for anybody in this region or anywhere else for that matter to sleep hungry," said Kaire Mbuende, the SADC executive secretary.

He was illustrating how transportation and distribution difficulties caused some people to go without food.

According to Mbunde, adequate logistics had already been put in place to boost food production to meet regional demand. What was now necessary was to ensure that adequate supplies were quickly moved to deficit areas, including urban centers where an increasing number of people were getting hungry.

"There is a new trend of food insecurity even among our urban dwellers both due to unemployment and because not enough food is made available for all to afford," he said.

SADC countries agree they need to expand irrigation to boost food production, in the wake of recurrent droughts in the region.

Other regional projects, intended to ensure more food is produced and security among SADC states, include the Harare-based Southern African Center for Cooperation in Agricultural Research and Training and the Regional Inventory of Agriculture Resource Base.

The center, established in the 1980s, is involved in agricultural research and training of agricultural experts. It also awards research and travel grants to such specialists in the region.

The Regional Inventory and Agricultural Resource Base works at the national and regional levels. It is intended to provide background information for agricultural land use and other planning purposes.

A SADC proposed blueprint, adopted several years ago, on the growth of agriculture and food security in the region during the next 20 years, has recommended that apart from research on the traditional cereal staples such as maize, more work be done on wheat, rice, potatoes and oilseeds. It says there is also need for further research on fruits, vegetables, dairy and poultry.

It recommends increased use of the region's irrigation potential and more research on the response of various crops to fertilizers, as well as development of improved agricultural implements.

Under the program, SADC farmers are also being advised by local and regional policy research institutes to adopt sustainable agricultural production methods involving successful management of the various natural resources.

SADC comprises Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 4, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Mexico Blasts U.S. Over Anti-Cuba Law at Harare Summit


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Mexico castigated the United States Sunday for what it said were unfair unilateral actions with extraterritorial effects, and it urged the Group of 15 developing countries to counter that policy.

"Mexico has already passed a law of its own as an antidote to the unilateral actions taken by the United States of America and its discriminatory practices with Cuba which is affecting relations of other countries," Mexican Foreign Minister Jose Angle Gurria said.

He was speaking of the law passed recently by the United States on Cuba, which affects the trade relations of third countries. 

His comment was to plenary on the first day of the G-15 summit in Harare, the Zimbabwe capital. Gurria is leading the Mexican delegation at the summit which is discussing the state of the current international trade relations.

He asked other G-15 member countries to consider adopting Mexico's measures to maintain its right to trade with Cuba.

Mexico, Canada and the United States have signed the North American Free Trade Agreement, known as NAFTA. Canada has also threatened action against the U.S. ruling.

Chairing the plenary session, President Robert Mugabe said: "We feel that it's wrong for a state to transfer its hatred of another country and make it affect its relationship with a third country and force countries with a relationship with Cuba to stop relating with it."

He said G-15 countries would study the Mexican response.

During the same session Mugabe criticized the United States for refusing to endorse the second-term candidacy of the Egyptian, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, as the secretary-general of the United Nations. Mugabe also said such actions defeated the whole idea of democracy and respect for the sovereignty of other countries.

"The United States of America has always sought to impose its will on everybody else. They are passing this to us as a general attitude and we must resist," Mugabe said.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Sithole Trial Postponed Indefinitely


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The high court on Monday postponed indefinitely the treason trial of Zimbabwean opposition politician, Ndabaningi Sithole, after defence lawyers said they were not ready because the state had given them little time and information to prepare for trial.

Sithole's lead attorney, Tendai Biti of Honey and Blanckenberg, made a plethora of applications when the trial was due citing the state's refusal to give the defence more information and sworn statements of the 16 witnesses to testify against sithole.

Among them are two members of the Zimbabwe National Army who allege that they were recruited and trained in Mozambique as bandits to fight the Zimbabwean government under Chimwenje, the rebel group allegedly led by Sithole.

"We want to know when those persons joined the army," Biti told Justice James Robertson Devittie, sitting with assessors Nicholas Puwai and Major Misheck Nyandoro. 

Biti also said the defence wanted transcripts of last year's trials of two Chimwenje operatives, Commander Simba "Bosongo" Mhlanga and William Amakonya, the man caught preparing to spring an ambush against President Robert Mugabe's motorcade on August 18 last year.

"These are the two men, plus the driver, who purport to have had direct intercourse with the accused. Naturally this court as well as the accused person would be entitled to have a look at the transcripts," Biti said as Sithole, 76, wearing a navy blue pin-stripe suit and floral tie, sat dozing in the dock.

The veteran politician is the leader of the small ZANU (Ndonga) party and was at one time a colleague of Mugabe in the then Zimbabwe African National Union during the struggle for independence in Zimbabwe before he was deposed as leader in the early 1970s.

His wife, Vesta, sat among some 30 supporters who filled the public benches in the huge mahogany-panelled A-Court, one of the more prestigious courtrooms at Mashonganyika Complex in the capital, Harare.

Twenty-seven years ago, Sithole walked into the same building to answer charges of plotting to murder rebel Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian Smith and two of his ministers. He was convicted and sentenced to six years in prison.

Mhlanga and Namakonya are serving 15 and 12-year jail terms respectively.

Biti also challenged the state's decision to prosecute Sithole under three different charges--that he recruited people for illegal military training, kept arms of war and conspired to assassinate Mugabe.

He said the three charges could be compounded into one of committing or attempting to commit acts of terrorism in contravention of a section of the law and order maintenance act.

Prosecuting Sithole under the three charges would be exposing him to " double jeopardy" given that two of the charges carry life imprisonment terms, Biti argued.

He also challenged the constitutionality of a section of the law and order maintenance act which requires the accused to prove beyond reasonable doubt his innocence, while a section of the constitution required proof on balance of probabilities.

Noting that the trial may not be held this year because of the expected delays, Biti applied for a further relaxation of Sithole's bail conditions, particularly the return of his passport and the 50,000 zimdollars(5,000 US dollars) still being held by the courts. Sithole was arrested in October last year.

The bail sum was slashed from 100,000 zimdollars (10,000 US dollars) after Sithole said he wanted money to pay for his legal fees, and Biti argued that the remaining 50,000 zimdollars was immaterial given that the court still had Sithole's million-dollar house as surety.

Justice Devittie said he would announce his decision on the applications next Monday, after Abel Gotora of the attorney-general's office objected to the demand for more information on the witnesses, the compounding of the charges and relaxation of the bail conditions.

He said he did not object to some of the matters being referred to the supreme court but the state would be reluctant to give details on some of the witnesses because Sithole might interfere with some of the witnesses.

He also argued that there was a possibility that Sithole might abscond if his passport were to be returned.

"The allegations against the accused are of a very serious nature. In fact, the state has been very understanding in agreeing to have him have part of his bail back," Gotora said.

He also accused the defence of springing a surprise by making applications without informing the state, adding that he suspected that the defence was indulging in delaying tactics.

"Justice is not a hide-and-seek game, as it were," Gotora said. But Biti objected, saying it was a personal attack.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


East Africa;
Museveni, Bizimungu In Preliminary Talks


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda met Sunday in Mbarara, south of Kampala, ahead of a regional summit on Zaire as the fighting in that country entered its fourth week.

Bizimungu travelled to Museveni's country home in Rwakitura by road.

Tuesday's regional summit in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, to discuss the crisis in eastern Zaire, is expected to be attended by the leaders of Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, and Cameroon, the current chairman of the Organization of Africa Unity. 

The summit will try to stop the fighting and ease the plight of more than a million refugees whom foreign aid workers have had to abandon.

Zairean Prime Minister Kengo Wa Dondo has been invited to represent President Mobutu Sese Seko, who is recovering from cancer surgery in Switzerland.

The European Union envoy to Zaire, Aldo Ajello, met with Zairean leaders in Kinshasa over the weekend and is due to meet Museveni before the Nairobi summit. O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim is also expected at the summit.

Zaire last week ruled out negotiations with its neighbors Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda to stop the fighting. Kinshasa accused these countries of complicity in helping Zaire's ethnic Tutsi rebels, the Banyamurenge.

"The government will not undertake any negotiations, will not participate in any regional conference while part of our national territory is occupied by foreign forces," Kengo is reported to have told an emergency session of Zairean parliaments last week.

However, the three countries have denied the accusation and called on the warring parties to desist from any action that could escalate the conflict.

The Banyamurenge have seized a string of towns along Zaire's eastern border with Burundi and Rwanda but are said to be meeting some resistance in the eastern Zairean city of Goma.

The town was the headquarters of the world's biggest relief operation, until aid workers fled Saturday.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Central African Republic;
Former Emperor Bokassa Dies


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Former emperor of the Central African Republic, Jean-Bedel Bokassa died Sunday of heart attack, aged 75 years.

The announcement made by hospital officials in Bangui, the country's capital, was confirmed by Bokassa's relatives on Monday, according to reports reaching PANA in Dakar.

Bokassa suffered a heart attack in his Bangui home before he was taken to hospital. 

Born in 1921 in Bobangui, Lobaye Province, he was raised by a missionary and completed his early education in missionary-run schools in his country and in Brazzaville, Congo.

Bokassa joined the French army in 1939 at age 18, as a regular soldier. He attended the Military Preparatory School in Saint Louis, Senegal, from 1947- 48 before going for further training in 1950 at the military Training Center at Chalons-Sur-Marne in France.

As a company sergeant and later Warrant Officer, still in the French army, Bokassa fought in the French Indo-China war of 1945-54. He won service campaign medals: the Legion d'Honneur Francaise a Titre Militaire, Campaign medals for the Second World War and Indo-China such as the Croix de Guerre.

He became a second Lieutenant in 1958. At his country's independence from France in 1960, President David Dacko asked Bokassa to set up the Central African Republican Army.

In 1962, Bokassa was transferred from the French army to that of the Central African Republic with the rank of a major.

As a colonel and Chief of Staff of National Defence, Bokassa took power in January 1966 in a coup on New Year's eve.

A general, marshall and life president, Bokassa amended the constitution in 1976 and was crowned emperor on Dec. 4, 1977 in Bangui.

He was overthrown in 1979 by the French army while abroad. The operation, code-named Barracuda, followed the massacre of school children in Bangui.

Former President Dacko, who returned to power and restored the republic, was in turn overthrown two years later by the army, led by Gen. Andre Kolingba.

After eight years in exile in Cote d'Ivoire and France, Bokassa returned home in 1987, in disguise. However, he was arrested, prosecuted and sentenced to death.

He was pardoned, then released by President Kolingba soon before the latter relinquished power to Ange-Felix Patasse who won multiparty elections in the country in 1991.

Bokassa openly supported a section of the army which staged two failed mutinies in early 1996 in Bangui.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Business and Finance;
British Agency Donates K126 Million To Capital Fund


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - The British Overseas Development Agency (ODA) has donated K126 million to the Zambia Venture Capital Fund (ZVCF) to enable it boost administrative facilities and handle more business enquiries.

Officially presenting two Peugeot 405 cars and office equipment, British High Commissioner to Zambia, Patrick Nixon, said the ZVCF was one of the Commonwealth Development Corporation's exciting projects. 

"The ZVCF came up as a way to help the private sector. It is one of the ways likely to reduce the dependence of the Zambian budget on foreign assistance and should be encouraged," he said.

The ODA donation is expected to help with funding for 1997.

ZVCF Board chairman, David Phiri, said he was grateful for the genuine help from the ODA.

"This is the type of investment Zambia should be aiming for," he said.

ZVCF general manager, Tladi Ramushu, said the Fund had received more than 200 inquiries from businessmen since its inception but only two projects have been approved so far.

"We have to be highly selective of the projects and three more are in the pipeline," said Ramushu at the handover ceremony yesterday.

ZVCF is a 10-year closed end fund. This means that it will be wound up and liquidated 10 years following commencement of operations. Meanwhile, the Fund identifies viable projects which need financing and buys equity, becoming shareholders in the project.

The investors in ZVCF are the Commonwealth Development Corporation, the European Investment Bank, The German Investment and Development Company, and First Merchant Bank Zambia Limited.

Date of Issue: October 29, 1996


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

74 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 4, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 5 on Eastern Zaire (11/04)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Nairobi - UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, called on Sunday for humanitarian aid corridors to be set up between Zaire and Rwanda to enable refugees to return to Rwanda and Burundi. She said there were tens of thousands of displaced Zaireans as well as the mainly Hutu refugees from Burundi and Rwanda in need; the UN estimates more than one million civilians are fleeing fighting. Most are cut off from humanitarian aid - although local Zairean aid workers reportedly continue rudimentary relief in some areas.

According to Ogata, UNHCR has lost contact with 520,000 Burundi and Rwandan refugees since fighting broke out in the Uvira and Bukavu regions, and the vast majority of 715,000 refugees in the Goma region have fled over the last few days. She said 400,000 refugees in Mugunga and Lac Vert camps near Goma appeared to be heading for Sake (west of Goma on the northwest tip of Lake Kivu). French Consul Patrick Lumes, Goma, was reported (Sunday) as saying more than a million people were huddled in one Lake Kivu bay in "appalling conditions". 

Ogata said Assistant High Commissioner Sergio Vieira de Mello would leave Monday (today) for Rwanda and Zaire to discuss with officials how to ease the crisis. She emphasised "this may be a final appeal to all those involved in this terrible conflict or it will be too late".

UN officials, diplomats and NGOs met in Kigali on Sunday to discuss emergency strategies, including humanitarian corridors. A key issue is whether the corridors will be supply or repatriation corridors - depending on the stance of Rwanda (who wants Hutu "exiles" back inside Rwanda) and Zaire (who may consider it "support" to the rebels, or a violation of sovereignty). Corridors may be established with different functions, for example, those with a repatriation function may allow rudimentary supplies or be exclusively for refugee movement.

There are continuing contacts between the Rwandan government, aid agencies, donors, UN officials and diplomats on ways to mitigate the humanitarian crisis and facilitate aid. Further discussions will take place today. In Nairobi (Sunday) NGOs and UN representatives met to discuss emergency relief strategies, and individual agencies are planning to establish emergency offices in Nairobi and elsewhere to coordinate response and set up programmes. UNHCR says it has requested satellite images to assist in identifying the whereabouts and situation of the refugees.

Groups of Burundian returnees have been arriving back in their country of origin. About 11,000 have arrived at Gatumba during the course of last week, displaced when the Uvira camps were taken by rebels early on in the fighting. Another 12,000 returnees arrived over the weekend, who have been registered by the Burundian army as having returned to the northwestern province of Cibitoke (which is mainly controlled by Hutu Burundian rebels). Of the 11,000, 700 have moved back to their home areas with the assistance of the government and aid agencies; 400 went to Gatumba town; and 300 moved to Bujumbura-Rurale. Action Contre le Faim (ACF) reports 17% severe malnutrition among 600 under 5s at Gatumba. This is one of the first indications that some of the dispersed refugees are arriving in a state of malnourishment - under 80% weight for height is classified as moderate by aid agencies).

DHA IRIN was informed that stocks of food already available in the region are estimated to be 78 days' worth, using half rations for two million people. UNICEF said a plane (arranged through DHA's Military and Civil Defense Unit) carrying 30 tonnes of medical supplies was leaving Copenhagen for Uganda's Entebbe airport, and more supplies would follow. Access points for emergency supplies are Kigali (previous stocks exist in anticipation of refugees returning), Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya. Burundi is also a possible access point, although presently gripped by regional sanctions following the July coup. The Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee had refused the passage of any food aid through or to Burundi, but relaxed conditions on October 21st to allow for displaced Burundians - it therefore stands as a possible land route. The Rwandan government has refused since April 1995 to allow food to pass through Rwanda to refugee camps in eastern Zaire, which held many of those implicated in the 1994 Rwandan genocide.

Aid workers in the region have noted the following impediments to operations: aid vehicles and logistical equipment have been looted and commandeered; the relief structures have been destroyed; air drops are impracticable because refugees are scattered; chronic fuel shortages and poor road access and continued fighting. Refugees are faced with hostile geographical terrain as well as fighting - mountains, volcanic ground and forests, often in torrential rain. There are continued reports of bodies washed up on the shores of Lake Tanganika.

Laurent-Desire Kabila, identified as head of the rebel coordinating committee, called on Sunday for aid organisations to return to eastern Zaire. He declared Bukavu and Goma, the two main towns of eastern Zaire, under rebel control, and said they planned to re-open Goma airport. Kabila said on the BBC (Monday) that Kiliba airstrip, servicing Uvira, was available. He said there was famine and continued population movement.

Nairobi, 09:55 GMT, 4 November 1995

(ENDS)

LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
