Africa News


November 5, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Doctors Resume Strike As Leader Is Arrested in Harare


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The chairman of Zimbabwe's Hospital Doctors' Association, Farayi Jiah, has been arrested and junior doctors in Harare said Tuesday they are resuming their strike to protest against the police action.

Jiah, who is co-chairman of the unified Civil Service Negotiating Committee, was arrested around 1030 p.m. (2030 GMT) Monday at his home at the Parirenyatwa Hospital Doctors' Residence and charged with contravening the law and order (maintenance) act.

From the Highlands Police Station, where he is being held, Jiah told the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency that he was arrested by officers from the Criminal Investigations Department, whom he accused of denying him his right to call a lawyer. 

"I think the arrest has to do with the strike by nurses and doctors," he said.

Jiah, who is on leave and is conducting a study on AIDS, has been accused by several government officials of instigating the nurses into striking. He is to appear in court soon.

Nurses and doctors went on strike on Oct. 21, pressing for better salaries and working conditions.

But the junior doctors returned to work three days later, meeting a government deadline to avoid dismissal.

Government announced that those failing to return to work by Oct. 29, would be fired.

However the majority of nurses, estimated at 2,000, ignored the ultimatum and are now demanding their terminal benefits.

Acting Public Service, Labor and Social Welfare Minister Nathan Shamuyarira said Monday the Public Service Commission -- which approves all civil service hiring -- had been instructed to send letters of dismissal to all nurses who failed to return to work Oct 29.

"It is the commission which should know how many nurses have been dismissed, " he said.

Meanwhile, several hospital wards, including the outpatient departments, at Harare Central, Parirenyatwa and Chitungwiza hospitals remain closed. There have been reports of people dying in and outside the major referral hospitals.

Senior nurses have also threatened to strike, complaining they can no longer cope with the pressure of work.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Blantyre - A roundup of the latest news from and about Malawi.

MP GIVES VERBAL BASHING TO PRESIDENT

Opposition deputy for Karonga South, Kamunga Mwafulilwa, on October 27 took a swipe at President Bakili Muluzi for failing to install electricity into people's houses and public social facilities in his area in keeping with his promises.

In his address to the gathering at the commissioning of Wovwe mini- hydroelectric power station in Karonga, the Aford deputy told the president that he had not connected power to hospitals and schools in the area as he had earlier promised. Muluki had told the people in the area that he would not commission the power station until he had connected all the major public utilities with power in the area. 

The MP also accused the ruling party of trying to gain political mileage of a project that had been implemented by the previous regime. After speaking in the vernacular, angry UDF officials had to grab the microphone from Mwafurilwa when he wanted to translate what he had said in Tumbuka into English for the benefit of the Germans who were present at the function. The project was funded by Germany. A visibly angry Muluzi called on the MP to respect him saying his remarks were uncalled for.

THREE KILLED IN AMBUSH

Four unidentified gunmen on October 27 shot dead three people, including a woman, when they ambushed a Chibuku Brewery van in Nkhata-Bay, northern Malawi. Police said the ambushers were apparently after cash. It is believed the victims where unauthorised passengers.

MYSTERY SURROUNDS SOURCE OF MONEY

Nobody in the UDF government wants to disclose the source of a K70 million fund that government has allocated to the Youth Loan Scheme. President Muluzi launched the scheme in August, but fell short of disclosing the source of the money as was expected of him.

Both Muluzi's economic advisor Kalonga Stambuli and Principal Secretary for Youth, whose ministry will oversee the implementation of the project, said they were ignorant of where the money came from apart from merely saying that it was a grant.

TRIBUNAL ACCUSED OF FAVOURITISM

Over 900 people from Mangochi, south Malawi who were victimised by the former regime and now want compensation, have accused the National Compensation Tribunal of favouring certain people in processing claims for compensation.

Cyril Siliya, spokesman for the people, most of them from Moto village, home of the late Masauko Chipembere who rebelled against Dr Banda during a 1964 cabinet crisis, said there were a lot of irregularities in sums of money paid out to victims, with some getting more than others.

He said while some people with political connections got hefty sums of money of up to K400,000, none of the victims from his district had been given more than K20,000. However, legal assessor and spokesman for the tribunal Viva Nyimba, said the payments being made now were only temporary and that the victims would be given real compensation when the tribunal had assessed the claims.

ELEVEN POLITICAL PARTIES FORM COUNCIL

Eleven political parties, most of which fought together with the ruling UDF under the Common Electoral Group, have formed a united council to enable them to speak with a common voice.

The formation of the group comes in the wake of growing dissatisfaction by the parties who feel the UDF has abandoned them in spite of their vital contribution in the fight for democracy.

The parties claim that the UDF is now eating the spoils of that fight alone, having completely forgotten the rest of the parties in the CEG.

TRIBUNAL COFFERS DRY UP

Funds for paying victims of Dr Banda's 30 year autocratic rule dried up end of October, dashing the hopes of thousands of people who had submitted claims for an early compensation. The new government set up the tribunal in 1995 to investigate claims by victims and compensate them for the victimisation.

For 1995/96, the tribunal had requested K100 million (6.6m) but was only given 25% of that amount. Tribunal spokesman Viva Nyimba, confirming that hundreds of victims are being turned back empty-handed because there were no funds to pay them said, however, there was no need for anxiety as the government would soon replenish the coffers.

DRUGS PRICES LIKELY TO DROP

The price of drugs, which today is very prohibitive even if one were on a medical scheme, is likely to fall following recommendations that a special committee set up to probe the high prices for drugs in the country has recommended to government.

The committee comprising representatives from the health and finance ministries and pharmacy and poisons board identified surtax and customs duty as the main cause for the high prices for drugs in the country. Surtax ad customs duty currently stand at 20% and 10%, respectively.

CHILDREN DIE IN MEASLES OUTBREAK

Nine children have died of measles in Mulanje, south Malawi during the past two months prompting health workers to set up a vaccination campaign. District Primary Health Officer in Mulanje, Veronica Limwado, described the situation as serious but said it was gradually calming down.

Five deaths occurred in September while the other four were recorded in October, out of over 131 cases reported in July. Officials said they are stepping up the vaccination targeting a population of 5,000 children aged between six months to 15 years.

PARLIAMENT ACCUSED OF BLOCKING 8000 JOBS

Presidential Economic Advisor, Kalonga Stambuli is deadsure that a whopping 8000 jobs are out there in the informal sector waiting to be grabbed - if only the stalled parliament convened to amend the Customs and Taxation Act. This bill, once amended, argues Stambuli, would usher in handsome investments to the exporting industry. He said that "it would provide incentives that would make this landlocked country competitive to foreign investors".

Stambuli, who thinks it is the opposition who are in the wrong for the failure of parliament to convene says they (the opposition) might think they are punishing the president by boycotting parliament, "but it's the ordinary man who is now suffering." MCP and Aford are boycotting parliament in reaction against the president's appointment of cabinet ministers from the two parties without their consent which they view as being calculated at weakening them.

Nebert Nyirenda, Investment Promotion Manager at Malawi Investment Promotion Agency (Mipa), says his organisation is looking forward to the Finance Minister - who has been studying the recommendations - tabling the bill before the house anytime it convenes. "We were given a picture that if all goes well it (the bill) would be tabled in parliament. It is expected that if the bill was passed, investments would by March next year have created the 8,000 jobs for unskilled labour.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Business and Finance;
Tobacco Buyers Threaten To Dump Malawi Leaf


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Blantyre - As the war rages on between tobacco growers largely under the umbrella of the Tobacco Association of Malawi (Tama) on the one hand, and the government and Tobacco Control Commission on the other over intermediate buyers, Malawi's main tobacco buyers have threatened to stop buying the country's tobacco because they are dissatisfied over the low volumes produced. In spite of an increase in volumes this year, international buyers have voiced concern that for several years now, Malawi has failed to meet their desired threshold.

Tobacco sales this year registered an average 18.4% increase over last year's production due to a mix of factors among them higher volumes and better quality. The crop, dubbed Malawi's green gold, raked in a handsome K3, 553,620,000 ($236,908,000) in 1996, which was K552,285,000 over last year's production. The lowest hit were burley, which dropped from $190,228,000 in 1996 to $149,814,000 in 1995, flue-cured ($34,959,000) which went down by $2, 479,000 over last year's volumes and Northern Darkfired ($9,486,000 in 1996) from $12,730,000 in 1995. 

Prices also varied with some leaf fetching higher prices per kilogram than others. In spite of the lower volumes, Fluecured was the most highly priced at an average of $2.29/kg ($1.85 last year), Burley gained by an average $0. 13/kg over last year, while Northern Darkfired and Southern Darkfired got stuck at the same $1.70/kg. Sun Air on the other hand took a leap by $0.40/kg.

Data was not immediately available from the Tobacco Control Commission to compare with prices in other countries such as Zimbabwe. Tama's Executive Secretary, Dr. Gabert Thyangathyanga, an optimist through and through, says his organisation is poised to fight and eliminate intermediate buyers (IBs) until the last soldier is gone."IBs are thieves. They connive with tenants to steal from the farmers," charges Thyangathyanga. Intermediate buying, for a very long time a monopoly of the government-owned Agricultural Development and Marketing Corporation (Admarc), which had the sole prerogative of controlling prices, was introduced on the behest of the International Monetary Fund under the economic liberalisation policy.

The system is aimed at achieving equitable pricing of the crop to enable the tenants and the smallholder farmers, who were recently also allowed to grow burley and who could not hitherto benefit from the highly priced crops because they were limited to one buyer, that is Admarc, irrespective of the price the firm offered. There are now 3,000 intermediate buyers. However, Thyangathyanga says the system was imposed on the farmers overnight and without their say so and is aimed at destroying the tobacco industry, an evil he says his organisation will fight to the end.

Tobacco Control Commission General Manager Dr. Godfrey Chapola says his firm as a regulatory body only implements policy and does not take sides. He says government took the decision in the national interest, but the aim was not to damage the tobacco industry as claimed by Tama. "That would be suicidal. Dissatisfaction in a normal setting is normal. What is important is economic development and equitable distribution of income," says Chapola.

Independent analysts within the commission say government may lose the battle to Tama on IBs because of its unsteady representation during meetings. They argue that the growers would like to keep IBs out the system, not because they are thieves as Thyangathyanga alleges, but because the IBs offer more competitive buying prices to tenants and thereby reduce the farmers' chances of ever exploiting the tenants. "With IBs around, farmers can no longer cheat the tenants on prices because they will simply sell their tobacco to the IBs," one analyst said. With this competition, tenants are now able to sell their tobacco at as much as K12 to K15/kg and they are at liberty to sell or not sell to their masters.

On low volumes of tobacco, Chapola says redress lies in putting in place an equitable pricing system, facilitating access by farmers to resources, and tied to the first two - opening up the industry in order for more people to grow the crop. The analysts say many growers have over the years abandoned Fluecured and Northern-Darkfired because of two reasons: the poor price for the crops, whose price has only changed by a meagre 50 US cents over the ten years since 1988. This has obviously made the crop unattractive. The other problem is the shortage of the wood fuel the two types of tobacco require for curing. They say the problem is compounded by the eucalyptus in blue-gum species, one of the fast maturing types of trees which is not suitable for curing.

In the 1995/96 season, Malawi only managed to produce 115 million kg out of the 120 million that the buyers requested. Meanwhile, Chapola says the commission will only issue realistic and manageable quotas to growers and the total quotas to be issued will match the country's demand. Other analysts in the commission say to beat the 130 million kg that buyers have requested during the 1996/97 year, the commission will have to issue quotas for up to 200 million kg.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

116 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 10 on Eastern Zaire (11/06)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Nairobi - European Union Special Envoy for the Great Lakes, Aldo Ajello, said today that three regional foreign ministers and a representative from the Organisation of African Unity will go to Kinshasa "as soon as possible" to present the Zairean government with the decisions of yesterday's regional summit. He said they would leave tomorrow (Thursday) at the latest. Diplomatic efforts concentrate on securing Zaire's agreement to the resolutions, which include calls for neutral military intervention, the establishment of humanitarian corridors and temporary sanctuaries, and an immediate ceasefire. Neither the Zairean government or the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces (ADFL) were present at the heads of state meeting. The ADFL declared a unilateral three week ceasefire on Monday.

The regional ministers will be trying to get Zaire to agree on a ceasefire and the need for international intervention. On Tuesday evening, Zaire's Information Minister and government spokesman, Boguo Makeli, denied there was rebellion on Zaire territory, saying that Burundi, Rwanda and Uganda were the aggressors. The Zairean government has acknowledged that it no longer controls Bukavu and Goma, but has not acknowledged the civil war. It has said it will not attend any regional meetings about the eastern Zaire crisis until the "aggressors" (referring to the alleged presence of Rwandan troops) are off Zairean territory. 

According to a BBC report, a government spokesman in Kinshasa today said that Zaire would not take a position on military intervention until it was fully aware of the proposals made by the Nairobi summit. The spokesman said that Hutu refugees should return to their country of origin and territory should be restored to Zaire (implying foreign rather than domestic involvement). On the humanitarian aspect, the spokesman said Zaire was no longer prepared to accept assistance for the refugees on its own side of the border, and that aid should now be provided within Rwanda and Burundi and that refugees could pass through the proposed corridors out of Zaire.

Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda said today (Wednesday) that it was not necessary to wait for the approval of Zaire to go ahead with a proposed international force. He said it was up to the United Nations to call on Zaire to abide by the resolutions of yesterday's regional heads of states summit, and said the United Nations had the right to send in a force "with or without the agreement of the country concerned". Rwanda insists on regarding the eastern Zairean conflict as an "internal Zairean crisis". In an interview on the BBC, Claude Dusaidi, advisor to the Rwandan government, welcomed the Nairobi proposals, particularly the decision to assist separation of intimidators from the bona fide refugees. On the issue of corridors, he acknowledged the need to use them to initially feed the refugees, but said the aim should be to repatriate as soon as possible. He said an intervention force must be neutral.

Both Rwanda and Zaire seem to have accepted - to some extent - the idea of humanitarian corridors.

South African deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad said today that the South African government has temporarily suspended the sale of arms to Rwanda. President Mandela was quoted yesterday - after a personal appeal from Kenyan President Moi to suspend an 18 million arms deal - that he would suspend arms sales to Rwanda if requested by regional leaders.

International responses to the regional summit have focused on the call for military intervention. US Special Envoy Howard Wolpe called the notion of an international presence "helpful", but said the type of force envisaged needed to be discussed. British Foreign Secretary Malcolm Rifkind welcomed the idea of a multinational force and said it would be discussed at a summit on Friday with France. European Union officials also met on Tuesday in Brussels for talks on possible intervention in Eastern Zaire, and, according to Special Envoy for the Great Lakes Aldo Ajello, will meet on Thursday (tomorrow) to " harmonise the position". He said European reaction had been very fast. . Germany has raised the possibility of deploying UN military observers, particularly in the Zaire-Rwanda border. President Nelson Mandela has pledged South African support for a peacekeeping force, saying he would respond very positively to any request from the United Nations. The Johannesburg Star reports that South Africa has two fully-trained batallions ready to join any multinational peacekeeping force organised by the UN or the OAU. This is the first time South Africa has expressed a willingness to send troops on peace keeping missions. Togo has proposed a four-point ceasefire plan, saying it would prevent a "second genocide"; it is essentially the same as the decisions taken by the regional summit, incorporating a ceasefire, an neutral intervention force, territorial integrity and further talks.

French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette said that a multinational force could be deployed "in a very short time" - France has led calls for military intervention since the weekend, along with UN High Commissioner for Refugees Sadako Ogata. Spain and France have said they are prepared to participate in a force for Zair. President Jacques Chirac - whose government is now host to the ailing Zairean president - underlined French support for Mobutu by saying the president was "the man best placed to represent Zaire and find a solution to this problem". He says the force proposed by France and Spain needs the approval of the UN Security Council, would include US, European and African troops and could later be replaced by an African force with US and European backing. French support for Mobutu will be an issue for other actors in the conflict - particularly the rebels.

Other reactions include plans for a special session of the conflict prevention team in the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) next week in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia (the Central Organ of the OAU Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution is composed of Cameroon, Algeria, Comoros, Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Guinea, Malawi, Mauritania, Mozambique, Nigeria, the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, Tanzania, Togo, Sudan, Zambia and Zimbabwe). The OAU says the meeting will be attended by the countries of the Great Lakes region, and other neighbours. Former French cooperation minister Bernard Debre proposed in an interview in a French newspaper the creation of a Hutu state, comprising "a small part of Rwanda, Burundi, and also part of Kivu". Previously, proponents of creating separate ethnic states included President Moi of Kenya. An exclusively ethnic analysis of the regional conflict, including the 1994 genocide, is generally rejected by political players in the arena, who point to the fact that political groups and geographical areas are not ethnically "pure" (for example, rebel spokesman for the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo- Zaire (ADFL), Laurent-Desire Kabila is perceived as one of those leading the " Tutsi revolt", but is from the mineral-rich Shaba region in southern Zaire).

Action by Churches Together (ACT) has issued an appeal for the Eastern Zaire emergency for $4,757,947 to stockpile and deliver emergency relief supplies in Rwanda, Uganda and Kenya, from 1 November 1996 to 31 December 1997.

Eight hundred Zairean soldiers who fled to Uganda early this week returned home, according to Ugandan security sources. They reportedly commandeered canoes on Lake Edward to get back into Zaire. There is a slow trickle of refugees into Uganda, mostly women and children; UNHCR put the number at around 9,500 and say the rate of arrival has decreased this week.

An unpublished UN report on regional arms supply accusing Zaire of playing " a central role" in helping Rwandan and Burundi Hutu rebels to rearm on its territory, has been leaked to the press. According to press reports, Zaire was accused of playing a major role in "huge webs" of arms trafficking - " Zaire, or elements within Zaire, appear to continue to play a central role as a conduit for arms supplies to and military training of Rwandan and Burundese insurgents on its soil", the report says. The report, likely to be that of the UN Commission of Inquiry formed in 1995, is also quoted as saying that Hutu militia in refugee camps of Zaire, Tanzania and (previously) Burundi were funding arms purchases from "the sale of relief goods donated by international humanitarian organisations". The Zairean government denied these allegations on Tuesday night. After the 1994 Rwandan genocide, international human rights organisations drew attention to arms supplies to fugitive Hutu extremist groups in neighbouring countries. Paradoxically, at the time of declaring a ceasefire, the rebel groups - reportedly well armed - had managed to seize up to 300 kilometres of border territory in two weeks and resistance from ex-FAR and Interahamwe militia appears to have been minimal.

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


117 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 9 on Eastern Zaire (11/06)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Nairobi - Regional leaders on Tuesday called for the UN Security Council to take urgent measures to ensure the establishment of safe corridors in Eastern Zaire, and create temporary sanctuaries by deploying a neutral force. The Summit expressed "grave concern" at the deteriorating situation and the threat posed to peace and stability in the entire Great Lakes region. Immediate needs were listed as a strictly observed ceasefire; commitment to the territorial integrity of Zaire, national boundaries and an end to cross- border incursions; and commitment to the inalienable rights of all people within internationally recognised territorial boundaries. This has been interpreted to refer in particular to the Banyamulenge's right to Zairean nationality. The leaders also called for intensification of efforts towards voluntary repatriation of refugees to Rwanda, and separation of "the intimidators and bonafide refugees", referring to the exiled extremist Hutus from the Interahamwe militia and the former Rwandan army, who have controlled refugee camps since perpetrating the 1994 genocide. 

Attending the summit hosted by President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, were: Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Isaias Afewerki of Eritrea, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Ferdinand Oyono, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Cameroon, representing President Paul Biya, current Chairman of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU). The talks were also attended by OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim and former Tanzanian president, Julius Nyerere, mediator for the Burundi peace process. Burundi complained it was not invited even though it is an affected neighbour. There was no representative from Zaire.

The decisions of the regional summit are seen by many as significant as they represent a regional consensus - excluding Zaire - in favour of military intervention. President Daniel arap Moi said it was important to get international backing for the decisions. Response from the Zairean government will be critical to implement the decisions. There was also no representation from the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo- Zaire (AFDL). Until yesterday, Rwanda rejected any sort of military intervention - and points still have to be clarified on the type of corridors created.

There will be important clarifications to be made on how some of the decisions are implemented - like temporary sanctuaries, and how to separate bonafide refugees and the intimidators. Previous resolutions undertaken on separation have failed to take effect. Resolutions to intensify efforts towards voluntary repatriation to Rwanda must also be seen in the context that an extremely small number of the refugees have returned voluntarily to Rwanda to date, despite the considerable dangers and hardships now faced inside Zaire. The OAU has been asked by the leaders to "closely follow up the implementation" of the decisions, and work with the UN Secretary General.

Some international aid workers are seeking to take advantage of the ceasefire and cross into rebel-held towns of Goma, Bukavu and Uvira. Yesterday (Tuesday) journalists were allowed across the border at Goma but given restricted access by the rebel ADFL. Some aid agencies are today seeking access to Eastern Zaire and in particular to the huge numbers of refugees who are believed to have gone west of Goma, into the interior (there were about 700,000 around Goma before fighting dispersed them). Efforts will be made to gain access to Mugunga camp, west of Goma town. One aid agency reports that Mugunga has been calm over the last couple of days, that there are still supplies of medicine left at the hospital, local aid workers are trying to distribute existing food supplies, and there is no fuel left for the hospital generator.

Local aid workers have continued to operate to the best of their ability, and some aid organisations believe that if the ceasefire holds they can make contact with local staff and begin assessment and rudimentary operations in affected areas. Aid workers in Nairobi say they are "unclear" about whether it is possible to successfully negotiate access with permission from Kinshasa - evacuated aid workers are hoping to return to Zaire through Rwanda. Nairobi is being used as a temporary meeting and coordination centre for some humanitarian organisations involved in the crisis, but Rwanda is a key operational base. No food has been delivered for more than a week to eastern Zaire, and existing stocks are believed to have been distributed by local staff - or looted. Agencies believe that although much (if not all) has been looted - like vehicles, radios, generators etc - the equipment is likely to remain in the area because of fuel shortages and rebel restrictions. There have been contradictory reports about the level of discipline among the rebels, and is mostly speculative or incidental because contact has been so limited. Access to Uvira and Bukavu is also limited, and information is mainly emanating from press reports in Goma.

UN Special Envoy Raymond Chretien has arrived in Nice, France, and plans to meet President Mobutu of Zaire - said to be recuperating from cancer treatment and due to return to Zaire "in the next few days". UNHCR's Assistant High Commissioner Sergio Vieira de Mello is expected to hold talks in Kinshasa today.

The World Food programme says it is providing food to an emergency shelter in Kigoma, Tanzania, for the 4,600 refugees (mainly Zairean nationals) who have arrived since the weekend - and say thousands more are reportedly on their way. It says it has enough food in northern Tanzania to feed some 20, 000 refugees for one month. WFP say the refugees are arriving in "relatively good condition". However, Action Contre le Faim (ACF) has reported 14% severe malnutrition among under fives at Gatumba (Burundi).

Nairobi, 6 November 1996, 09:50 GMT

(ENDS)

Africa News


November 6, 1996


Zambia;
ZAMBIA WINS RARE PRAISE FROM US


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - United States deputy ambassador to Zambia, Stevenson Mcilvaine has commended Zambia for embarking on successful economic reforms.

He said it was very encouraging to note that in the past five years Zambia has taken remarkable economic reforms which will eventually lead to a complete diversified economy. 

Mr Mcilvaine said this when he officiated at the launching of the new IBM pc 100 personal computer by the Woodgate Computer Services in Lusaka today.

He said with the privatisation of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) next year, Zambia would be welcoming American business and economic development support.

Mr Mcilvaine also commended the Woodgate Computer Services for introducing the IBM pc 100 specifically designed for Africa, saying it would greately aid information sharing between the west and developing countries like Zambia.

Speaking earlier, IBM Central Africa chief, Gavin Stanley said the pc 100 was specifically designed cheaply for Africa because Africa was not as wealthy as the west where a variety of choices could be afforded.

Woodgate Computer Services managing director, Leo Lungu said the new pc 100 pentium launced today was faster, cheaper and bigger than the pc 100 launched in November last year.

He said the company would next Friday, November 8, launch the pc 100 in Kitwe on the Copperbelt.

The new features packaged machine is priced at US$2,300 inclusive of all Zambian taxes and duties, plus 12 months carry in full parts and labour warranty.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

119 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Zambia;
CARDS ON SALE FOR US$25?


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Chipata - Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) in the Eastern province has uncovered a scam in which voters' registration cards are being bought by opposition UNIP for as little as K30,000 or about US$25.

Area chairperson, Joseph Musuka said it was wrong for the would - be voters to surrender their cards because doing sowould disenfrancise them. 

He disclosed that uncomfirmed reports reaching his office suggested that some would- be voters in Kasenengwa parliamentary constituency were allegedly selling their voters cards at K30,000.00 ( thirty thousand kwacha).

In an interview in Chipata today he reminded people in the province that their vote was power and that they would defeat the democratic principle if they fell prey to politicians who wanted them to surrender their voters cards.

Mr Musuka appealed to the affected people to report those who had asked them to surrender their cards to the authorities concerned as such politicians were infringing their right to vote for a candidate of their choice when Zambians go to the polls on November 18 this year.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Congo;
Diarrhea Epidemic Kills 12 In Congo


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - A diarrhea epidemic has killed 12 people in Boko-Songo, about 300 kms (186 miles) south of the Congolese capital, Radio Congo reported Wednesday. 

In all, 57 cases of diarrhea have been reported in the area since Nov. 1. Eight deaths were reported between Nov. 1 and 3 and the epidemic made people flee the area.

The diarrhea manifests itself with such severity that the affected person can go into a comma and die in 30 minutes, according to medical sources quoted by the radio.

The water from a river crossing the village is suspected to be the cause of the disease.

In 1994, a diarrhea epidemic killed about 10 people in the same area.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Mazrui Urges Pan-African Emergency Force For Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Professor Ali Mazrui, the celebrated African author and scholar of humanities, said Tuesday that the time had come for Africa to establish a continental force, along the lines of Kwame Nkrumah's idea of an African High Command.

"We (Africans) need institutions for pacifying each other," he said. "In this direction, I ascribe to Nkrumah's vision for a sort of a pan-African emergency force which can be deployed swiftly to avert the kind of genocide we are helplessly witnessing in Africa today." 

He said the force should be functionally Ppan-African and must be free from the control or manipulation by external or non-African interests.

Mazrui, guest of the Pan-African Writers Association, or PAWA, was delivering in Accra the final part of a two-day lecture on "The African Condition Since Kwame Nkrumah's Fall: 1966-1996".

He said that unless a more long-term solution was found for Africa's conflicts, countries like Rwanda and Burundi "will, every few years, explode into mutual genocidal behaviour."

He described as puzzling, the genocidal crisis between the Hutu and Tutsi since they have much more in common than do any other two ethnic groups in relatively more peaceful African countries.

Speaking on an African perspective on "The Continent And The World," Mazrui launched his final presentation with a critical look at some of Nkrumah's ideas and strategies vis-a- vis what he called "Africa's four great cultural denials."

He said that Nkrumah was wrong when he said "Seek ye first the political kingdom and all other things shall be added unto you" because, Mazrui said, " the cultural kingdom' supersedes the political."

Mazrui also said that in spite of Nkrumah's zealous pursuit of African unity, he did not encourage regional groupings because he thought it could make Africans complacent about the need for continental unity.

However, Mazrui acknowledged the role which Nkrumah, together with writers of negritude -- Leopold Senghor of Senegal and West Indian Aime Cesaire -- played in rebutting Western claims that the negroid people had no history, no poetry, no philosophy or the capacity for scientific innovation.

It was through the writings of these black intellectuals, Mazrui said, that such negative stereotypes about Africa were disappearing gradually.

"So we must be vigilant," he said. "Let us now strive for the economic kingdom to consolidate the political kingdom. Let us purify the cultural kingdom to the glory and honour of especially one of Africa's greatest ancestors -- Dr Kwame Nkrumah."


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 6, 1996


Zambia-Narcotics Zambia's Drug Agents Nab Over 1,000 Traffickers


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC) seized drugs worth more than four million U.S. dollars and arrested a total of 1,332 drug traffickers between January and October 1996.

DEC spokesman Mukutulu Sinyani told reporters in Lusaka Wednesday the latest culprits included three Tanzanians and a Zambian nabbed last week in the capital with drugs valued at more than 12,000 dollars. 

The Zambian suspected drug-trafficker, who was travelling on a Malawian passport, was intercepted at Lusaka international airport as he prepared to fly out to Britain. He was found with 11 hashish cakes wrapped around his torso, legs and thighs.

The three Tanzanians, who included a woman, were arrested in a Lusaka residential area in possession of six hashish cakes.

Some 131 drug traffickers were arrested in October alone and 117 were convicted by the courts for drug-related crimes. They included 126 Zambians, a Briton, Tanzanian, Angolan and South African.

Zambia's anti-drug agents have said that the country was slowly becoming a drugs consumption centre, apart from being a major transit route for drugs to European, American and other overseas markets.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 6, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan Suspends Operations of International Red Cross


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan ordered the International Committee of the Red Cross Tuesday to stop all activities in the country, after accusing it of transporting ammunition to rebel controlled areas in southern Sudan.

The minister of social planning, Mohamed Osman Khalifa, said Tuesday that Khartoum took the decision because the Red Cross' "deviation from the principles of neutrality and the principles guiding humanitarian work."

He added that government had taken the measure only after it had become " clear beyond doubt" that the Red Cross had been involved in transporting ammunition and armed soldiers of the anti-government Southern Peoples' Liberation Army (SPLA) led by John Garang. 

As evidence of this complicity, state-run television showed Tuesday a Twin Otter light plane with the Red Cross Logo, in southern Sudan. Beside it were three Red Cross officials, five Sudanese and a number of ammunition boxes taken out of the plane.

It said that on Friday the plane, carrying the five members of SPLA landed in Gogrial province, Bahr Ghazal State, in southern Sudan.

"The pilot was surprised to see that the area was under Kerbino and not Garang and he tried to take off again but was prevented and detained," the Kerbino group told the Sudan News Agency.

The area is under the control of Kerbino Kwanyin, leader of the breakaway SPLA/Bahr Ghazal Group which, in April, signed a peace agreement with the Khartoum government.

The group named the people on the plane as John Early, a Canadian, the pilot; Moshin Raza, a Kenyan co-pilot, and Mary Wulthinton, an Australian nurse. It also gave the names of the five SPLA soldiers.

A delegation from the International Red Cross mission in Khartoum and Kenya later visited the scene Nov. 4 and was shown on the national television meeting Kerbino Kwanyin.

But neither Khalifa nor Kerbino have spoken about what happened to the planes's passengers and crew or the plane.

The United Nations is involved in a relief operation, code-named Operation Lifeline Sudan. Helping the world body are a number of humanitarian relief organizations caring for civilians in the war-affected areas in southern Sudan. The International Red Cross is one of the organizations working in this operation. Anti-government forces have been fighting Khartoum in the south since 1983.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 6, 1996


East Africa;
Regional Summit Calls For A Cease-fire In Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: Sam Mugo, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - A regional summit of African leaders on the crisis in eastern Zaire has called for an immediate cease-fire in the troubled area to enable diplomatic efforts to achieve lasting peace.

In a communique issued Tuesday at the end of a one-day summit in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, the leaders reaffirmed their commitment to territorial integrity of Zaire and called for an end to cross-border incursions.

The summit, chaired by Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi, brought together the Presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Isaias Afeworki of Eritrea, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia and Ferdinand Oyono, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Cameroon, representing President Paul Biya, current chairman of the Organisation of Africa Unity (O.A.U.). 

Also participating in the summit were the O.A.U. secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, and the former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere, Facilitator of the peace process. Zaire and Burundi did not take part.

The meeting expressed concern at the deteriorating situation in the area and the threat posed to peace and stability in the entire Great Lakes region.

It reaffirmed the inalienable rights of all people within the internationally recognised territorial boundaries.

The leaders also called for more effort in helping Rwandans return home voluntarily. To ensure the success of this effort, the summit called for the implementation of the long standing decision to separate the intimidators and the bonafide refugees.

The summit called upon the United Nations secretary-general to work closely with his O.A.U. counterpart in the establishment of temporary sanctuaries and safe corridors for victims of the conflict.

Reaffirming the commitment and readiness of the sub-region to end the conflict, the leaders said that the setting up of safe corridors would make it easier for humanitarian aid to reach the refugees and for their return home.

The summit directed the ministers for foreign affairs of Kenya, Tanzania, Ethiopia and the representative of O.A.U. Chairman to follow up the decisions of the Summit closely. The foreign ministers were mandated to visit Zaire to convey the decisions of the summit.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 6, 1996


Science and Health;
AIDS Patients Turn To Traditional Herbs


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabweans infected with HIV/AIDS are increasingly turning to traditional healers whose herbs are affordable and some of which have been proved to reverse some of the symptoms.

Dr Barbara Sibanda, who runs a clinic which combines traditional and conventional medicine, said in an interview there was a noticeable increase in the number of patients who preferred traditional medicine.

Early 1996, Gordon Chavunduka, president of the 40,000-strong Zimbabwe National Traditional Healers Association, confirmed the ability of certain herbal medicines to reverse some of the AIDS symptoms. 

That confirmation received wide coverage in the local and international media, resulting in increased numbers of HIV-infected people visiting traditional healers.

"Traditional medicine can alleviate the symptoms of HIV/AIDS. It stops the coughing, diarrhoea and vomiting. When they come here, they also regain their lost weight," said Sibanda, adding that most of the patients would have been discharged from hospitals to die at home after entering the terminal stages of the disease.

Apart from alleviating AIDS symptoms, the clinic also treats asthma, epilepsy, infertility, external cancer and ulcers.

Prescriptions were affordable because the herbs were readily available in the bush unlike expensive imported modern medicines. Also, unlike modern medicine, traditional herbal use did not result in side effects because it was natural, she said.

She also noted that there had been a gradual appreciation of herbal medicine over the past 15 years. Before that, 75 percent of Zimbabweans, like elsewhere in Africa, had drifted away from herbal use due to colonial inspired prejudice.

She said the current trend was that 50 percent of 40 to 50 patients treated at the clinic a day sought both types of treatment.

"That trend changed because of government support and recognition of traditional healers. People are now realising that they have to go back to their roots," she said.

Sibanda said because of the increase in the number of patients and demand for herbs, the clinic would soon establish a herbal pharmacy.

Health and Child Welfare Minister Timothy Stamps said the pharmacy was a good idea, in line with the trend in the rest of the world where people were turning to herbal treatment.

He encouraged further research on the healing properties of indigenous trees and plants.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 6, 1996


Business and Finance;
G-15 Group To Resist New WTO Issues


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The group of 15 developing countries have resolved to resist attempts by rich nations to introduce labour and other social issues under the World Trade Organisation (WTO), and have agreed to work out a common position before the WTO ministerial meeting in Singapore in December.

Outgoing G-15 chairman and Zimbabwean President, Robert Mugabe, told the closing session of the G-15 summit in Harare that the group also expressed concern at the recent enactment of national legislation and other unilateral measures with extra-territorial effect.

Although he did not name any country, it was apparent he was referring to the recent controversial law passed in the United States meant to curtail the activities of companies doing business with Cuba. 

Mexico, a member of the G-15, expressed concern at the U.S. attitude and called on group member countries to condemn the American action.

"These measures violate the accepted norms of international law and constitute a serious threat to the sovereignty of nations," Mugabe said. "The future of the world trading system, the legitimacy of the WTO and the prosperity of both developing and developed countries depend on the respect by all nations for established principles and rules of international jurisprudence."

The summit, which was the sixth since the founding of the group in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, in 1989, took a critical view of the current world trading system, considered skewed in favour of the rich. It also focused on ways of ensuring continuity of the group, which in the past has been plagued by poor attendance, as it sought its relevance in a fast-changing world.

Mugabe said the Uruguay Rounds of trade negotiations which culminated in the formation of the WTO in December 1993 had raised much hope for the poor countries who expected more support from the international community.

"The WTO agreements that emerged from the Uruguay Round failed to meet some of these expectations. Nonetheless, we committed ourselves to abide by the rules, meet the challenges and explore the opportunities arising from the birth of world trade organisation," Mugabe said.

Incoming chairman and Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, echoed the group's dissatisfaction with trade arrangements between the rich and poor nations, adding that G-15 members responsible for trade should meet and take a common stand before the WTO meeting in singapore.

"We must close ranks and rededicate ourselves to the cause of the developing countries...The G-15 can be relevant if we want it to be," Mahathir said.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Zambia;
DELAYED RAINS IMPAIR POWER GENERATION


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Livingstone - Electricity generation at Victoria Falls power plant in Livingstone has slumped to dangerous levels following a corresponding drop in levels of water on the Zambezi river.

Operations Senior Engineer, Abraham Sashi, said in Livingstone today that the delay in the start of a normal rain season has created grave concerns since the falling water levels might create real problems for the company and consumers in the City of Livingstone and adjoining communities. 

Mr Sashi noted at normal times the water level on the Zambezi is 1198 cubic metres per second but that this has fallen to 126.68 cubic metres per second.

"We are generating 44 megawatts of electricity instead of the normal capacity of 108 megawatts due to drastic fall in water flow on the Zasmbezi, '' Mr Sashi said.

He said the plant usually exports electricity to Namibia and Botswana and this has not been disturbed by the fall in power generation as Livingstone consumed less megawatts. Livingstone town averages power consumption of only 12 megawatts.

Power export to Botswana is two megawatts while Namibia imports three megawatts from Victoria Falls plant. This, Mr Sashi said, was not disturbed as the 44 megawatts being generated covered the figures for local consumption and export. There is no load shedding yet.

"Last year we went low to 37 megawatts in power generation but we fear it might go beyond that in months to come this year. The water situation is not all that healthy. We are likely to fall down further than last year,'' he added.

Water levels are, however, expected to rise steadily once normal rainfall was recorded in most parts of Zambia including areas from which the river draws much of its volume of water.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambia Should Stop Dabbling In Treasury Bills


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - Until the government stops dabbling in the treasury bill market, businesses will continue to find it costly to borrow money, warned Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) chairman, Mark O'Donnell, yesterday.

Speaking at a meeting to discuss Zambia as an emerging market at Lusaka's Hotel Intercontinental yesterday, O'Donnel said the private sector is competing with the government for funds.

"The government is winning because it offers more attractive terms through treasury bills," O'Donnell said. 

The meeting, focussing on the EU-funded Trade and Enterprise Support Facility (TESF), and attended by a number of business organisations, observed that there was a cash squeeze currently which has disqualified a large number of individuals from participating in loan financing through international agencies such as the International Finance Corporation.

Lusaka economist Meebelo Mutukwa agreed that most people were "cash strapped" and that the level of actual investment in Zambia was very low.

Chairman of the Hotels and Catering Association, Gaudenzio Rossi, said financiers demand for security proved to be an impediment in sourcing funds.

"The auctioneers selling property and bailiffs who are grabbing goods daily are an indication of the situation people are in," Rossi said.

But Zambia Venture Capital Fund general manager, Tladi Ramushu, and another emerging markets specialist on the panel, Bruce Bouchard, said it was necessary that applicants for loans or equity financing contribute something to show their seriousness towards the venture.

"The problem with the market in Zambia is that it is still in its infancy and financing is difficult to source," Bouchard said.

O'Donnell pointed out that most businessmen now preferred to deal in United States dollars to protect themselves against inflation and moreover, could also gain the benefit of real interest rates.

And the European Development Fund will now support small to medium scale enterprises which qualify to benefit from the third phase of the European Community's Structural Adjustment Facility.

The Trade and Enterprise Support Facility (TESF) is part of ECU16.8 million set aside for economic reforms and specifically aimed at assisting the private sector.

According to general manager of the Zambia Venture Capital Fund, Tladi Ramushu, the TESF will not directly provide loan or equity funding to projects but aims at improving access by businessmen to project finance through the traditional lending institutions.

Project proposals from businessmen will be reviewed by selected commercial and merchant banks, the Development Bank of Zambia, and the Zambia Venture Capital Fund.

The proposal will then be submitted to TESF for assistance with funding up to 70 per cent of the pre-investment work required to produce a "bankable" document (project proposal).

But some businessmen fear that the TESF funds will continue to cater for the same categories who have received help before.

"There are a number of businessmen with brilliant projects who just do not have the means to raise even a quarter of the 30 per cent base capital required. What Zambians now need is a facility that will be able to widen the industrial base, otherwise they will continue to fund the same people who have received aid year after year," said Ben Bwalya of Siana Enterprises.

LANGUAGE: English

Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Striker To Join Leicester After Congo


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Former Konkola Blades striker, Dennis Lota, finally leaves for Leicester after next Sunday's World Cup encounter against Congo.

The dimunitive striker disclosed in an interview yesterday that all the hurdles that had precluded his much-publicised move to the English premier division side have since been overcome. 

"I am leaving after next Sunday's game," Lota, whose transfer has not been without controversy, enthused.

He, however, said that he has yet to sign the contract forms.

"I will sign them when I get there (Leicester)," the free scoring player claimed.

In what has come to be known as the "Lota Saga", Konkola sold the player to South Africa's premier division side, Witbank Aces, for a paltry R40,000.

Before even kicking a ball, Witbank decided to sell the player, first to some Swiss side and laterLeicester United.

But this somewhat stirred a hornets nest and the unfolding saga claimed a few scalps at Konkola Blades and Anchor House.

Africa News


November 7, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Coop Rescued With Maize Money


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - Over one billion kwacha intended for the purchasing of maize by the Food Reserve Agency (FRA) has been diverted, on the instructions of the government, to the bailing out of the Southern Province Marketing and Cooperative Union(SPMCU).

And the Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) has questioned the government's directing of the autonomous FRA to buy SPMCU's storage sheds at a cost of K1.1 billion in a bid to enable the limping organisation to clear its debts with Finance Bank.

"It is hard to understand how FRA should be directed to make this purchase at a time when considerable stocks of maize still remain unpurchased in villages and risk being damaged by the rains, particularly since the FRA already has enough storage capacity and is in fact renting out storage sheds to other agents," complained ZNFU president Ajaye Vashee in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday. "Does the government think that extra storage is more important than buying maize?" 

Vashee also accused the government for compromising the autonomy of the FRA.

"For the third time, since its inception, the autonomy of the Food Reserve Agency has been compromised by government, in this last case in a manner which has blatant political implications," Vashee carped. "If the FRA is to develop any credibility it must be seen to be acting in an autonomous and non- partisan manner. The potential involvement of FRA with SPCMU at the direction of the minister does nothing to enhance standings of any parties involved."

On Monday agriculture minister Suresh Desai appointed a new board at SPCMU comprising businessmen, cooperators and farmers.

Among the new appointees on the ten member board are Michael Beckett a Choma Farmer, Bates Namuyamba a former Member of Parliament and Naik Nalendra managing director of Standard Sales Limited of Choma.

But ZNFU is wondering why SPMCU has been singled out "for this special treatment" and which of the other struggling co-operative unions FRA will be called on next to assist.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Zambia;
Faults, Frauds And Votes


BYLINE: Bright Mwape, Column, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Lusaka - It is very difficult to advance an argument of electoral fraud ahead of actual voting. There is a danger that such an argument will always be dismissed as speculation, malice, lies or sheer fear of the unknown.

Until people have actually voted and glaring irregularities experienced rather than talked about, people will tend to be sceptical about these exposures.

It is principally this position which makes the UNIP boycott of elections a subject of heavy attack by those opposed to their view. 

I suppose for instance, that those opposing the UNIP stand would rather wait for November 18 and 19 to witness a mass uprising from defrauded would be voters.

Wait for those who would have failed to vote because their names are omitted, misspelt or displaced to another constituency.

The argument of a credible electoral process however transcends partisan parameters. Public confidence in an electoral system begins with a clear and acceptable electoral process. Putting together the issues raised about our electoral process, there is a case which needs the attention of the Electoral Commission, political parties and the government.

There are over 20, 0000 voters on the Nikuv register who potentially can vote twice or on whose names a second person can easily vote.

These are people entered in the registers more than once.

Central province alone has more than 7, 000 and the Copperbelt has over 16, 000.

The case may be the same or worse elsewhere. Then there are several genuinely registered voters who will not find their names on the registers at polling stations because they have been displaced to alien polling stations which they may not know about until after November 18. Mwembezhi and Nangoma constituencies in Mumbwa and Kapiri Mposhi are such areas. To this add the confusion of dead registered voters and those who have willingly surrendered their voters cards or been coerced into so doing by political parties. All this within a register of a meagre 2.3 voters and out of whom only 1.3 have voters cards.

This is the scenario which must produce a legitimate government come November 18.

I was amazed that Voters cards are indeed rubbing off so easily. I have seen several! Agenda for Zambia president Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika never lied after all when he first made this revelation some time ago. Now Nikuv which has made us believe these cards cannot be forged and are being printed in America is easily recollecting any faded cards and within the precincts of Mulungushi Hall can reprint your details on them or even change the details in under five minutes! I am aware of over 40, 000 blank voters cards still with elections office and Nikuv - but for what use and by whom?

And to add to the confusion government must announce that it will issue voters certificates to anyone claiming to have surrendered their cards to UNIP or other such conmen.

I suppose that most, if not all, say 500,000 voters who have surrendered their cards did so voluntarily. Who then will answer the government call to go and line up for voter certificates? I cannot imagine that all these people surrendering cards are as dull as we want to project them- people who did not know what they were doing when they let go their cards.

If government however, managed to replace all of these voters it could only mean that indeed, all these people were coerced in one way or other to give up their cards or that government is taking its chance and these can not be the real voters!

All these issues about the register definitely can not just be UNIP and ZDC or Lima Party propaganda. It is never too late to correct a wrong like this but it can be too late to quell the fire once it starts.

In the wake of all this, the most insulting thing to the people of Zambia is to be told through Bobby Bwalya who in any case wants to be irritatingly atangonising, that their 'independent electoral commission' has no independent power to review these complaints and investigate them.

Bwalya has also the cheek to say he cannot see ghost voters or double entries in his own register. But that is precisely the problem. The electoral commission has been too lazy to have the sacrifice and patience of one Masautso Phiri to read the register name by name, NRC by NRC and Voters card number by voters card number. That is why its Chairman Bwalya is still blind to the glaring blunders of his register.

If his commission has no power prior to elections to resolve these issues and restore some confidence in the electorate who has? Zambians know that it is even worse to hope to redress this situation after elections. Elections must not be held for their own sake. It is the process which is even much more important than polling day.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Zambia;
Chiefs Shun Polls


BYLINE: Matsauso Phiri and Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Lusaka - Chiefs have joined UNIP's boycott of the November 18 presidential and parliamentary elections.

The Royal Foundation of Zambia (RFZ), grouping most of Zambia's traditional rulers, in a petition after meetings of the organisation in three towns decided not to take part in the elections unless amendments they have suggested are made to the Constitution.

They have also demanded that a constitutional meeting takes place in Kabwe on November 12 and that the election date be postponed to December 18.

RFZ chairman, chief Chamuka, who released the petition dated November 1 to President Frederick Chiluba , said the foundation's meetings in Kasama, Monze and Kabwe had resolved to boycott this year's elections because of the constitution which discriminates against them. The petition is also signed by his secretary chief Malembeka of Ndola rural. 

"The Royal Foundation of Zambia reject the MMD imposed 1996 Constitution entrenched in the hybrid presidential centralist state system of government as total tyranny over the traditional tribal kingdoms," the petition reads in part.

The release of the petition follows a call by Mpezeni, the paramount of the Ngoni people of Eastern Province, for chiefs in other parts of the country to champion their people's demands.

"We are chiefs because of the people. We cannot do what people do not want. Power is the people and what people don't want chiefs too don't want," Mpezeni said in an interview in Lusaka on Sunday.

And Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president Alfred Zulu, said this development means that a wider segment of society is now boycotting the elections.

"This means the elections will just come to an end and if they are boycotting, it will be a serious predicament. This sends the last nail in the coffin. The chiefs are a very important institution and if they boycott because they don't move long, they will move a large ethnic grouping with them," Zulu said.

He advised the MMD government to stop the elections.

And Inter-party Alliance chairman, Roger Chongwe, has supported the demands by the chiefs.

"Chiefs have a right to participate fully in the affairs of the country. The 1991 Constitution has a provision for the creation of of a Chamber of Representatives," Chongwe said in an interview yesterday.

The Royal Foundation is demanding that the elections be postponed to December 18 to allow for all parties to participate and the establishment of a federal system to embrace all the citizens as opposed to what they claim is the unicameral hybrid presidential system of government.

"The Royal Foundation demands extension of the election date to December 18, 1996 to allow all political parties who did not lodge Nomination papers to take part," chief Chamuka demanded.

The chiefs are also demanding a bicameral legislature comprising the National Assembly and that the House of Chiefs be transformed into a chamber of representatives.

They are also asking government to convene a consultative constitutional dialogue to which representatives of the governments of United States, Germany and Britain are invited.

And while President Chiluba will lead the government and MMD delegation, 27 chiefs, who are members of the foundation , will represent the country's 279 traditional chiefs. The Royal Foundation also suggested that Churches, the Law Association of Zambia and other civic institutions be invited.

They say this meeting be chaired by the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team(ZIMT) and should be held in Kabwe on November 12, 1996 to address the question: "Does the 1996 Constitution stand the test of time?"

And ZIMT have welcomed the foundation's proposal saying they have always been willing to sponsor any meeting meant to resolve the outstanding constitutional and electoral issues.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 7, 1996


United States and Africa;
Bill Clinton's Re-Election Welcomed By Zambians


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - Bill Clinton's re-election as United States President for another four year term, beating Republican rival Bob Dole and Ross Perot, has cheered Zambians and Zimbabweans.

The results announced yesterday have cheered politicians in Zambia and the Southern African region.

In his re-election speech Clinton applauded Dole and Perot's campaign and pledged to work with them. He added that there was no longer time to talk but to act towards the development of the country. 

Clinton scooped the majority vote recording 51 per cent followed by Dole's 41 per cent and Perrot's nine per cent.

And Clinton's arch rival, Dole, yesterday conceded defeat but also pledged to continue serving the people.

"I going to sit back for a few days but I am going to stand up and do what is best for America," Dole said.

In Lusaka, Clinton's re-election has been hailed.

"Bill Clinton's party, the Democrats, have values and ideals that are close to UNIP's. It respects minorities, the underprivileged and so this victory should cheer UNIP," said UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda's press aide Muhabi Lungu.

Lusaka Central Independent parliamentary candidate and former commerce minister Dipak Patel said Clinton's re-election would favour Africa more than that of a Republican candidate.

"This is good for Africa. He has a positive attitude for this continent and I hope he also remembers that Africa is not just South Africa. We welcome his victory," Patel said.

Zimbabwean High Commissioner to Zambia, Tirivafi Kangai, giving his personal view of Clinton's victory also praised the Democrats' consistent position towards Africa.

"We (Zimbabwe) have had a very good relationship with the US. We've had very good rapport, especially with the democrats. I for one worked closely with Andrew Young at one time, we got good support from the Jimmy Carter administration. Though out our struggle the democrats were very supportive so the victory is good for us," Kangai said.

It was difficult to get a comment from the Zambian government as the chief government spokesman, information minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, and President Frederick Chiluba's press aide were said to be out of town.

The Republicans have generally taken a hard line on supportive effort to the rest of the world especially third world countries and have been pushing the democrats to cut further all USA aid to these countries.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Tunisia;
Ruling Party Symposium Calls for Mediterranean Charter


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Tunis - The eighth international symposium organized by the RCD on the economic globalization in the Mediterranean concluded November 5 after two days of presentations and discussions by a large number of Tunisian and foreign officials and experts.

Participants discussed the strategic importance of the Mediterranean region and the necessity to implement various measures to consolidate cooperation and partnership between countries on both flanks. 

Symposium participants called for a number of initiatives, which included the creation of a Mediterranean security and cooperation organization, a fund to assist large and medium size projects, and a bank for development and investment.

Participants also proposed the adoption by Mediterranean countries of a charter for the protection of immigrants between countries north and south of the Mediterranean, the promotion of channels of cooperation between the political parties of the region, and the creation of a permanent structure to promote dialogue and partnership between Mediterranean countries to be headquartered in Tunis.

Organized by the Constitutional Democratic Rally (RCD) to commemorate the ninth anniversary of the November 7 1987 change in Tunisia, the symposium was opened November 4 with a speech by president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali and delivered by Prime Minister Hamed Karoui.

In his speech, president Ben Ali said that an open, safe, and developed Euro-Mediterranean region is "dependent upon the development of our countries, their internal stability, and the relationships of cooperation and complementarity they establish between each other."

"The active integration to globalization means order at home," he said, stressing the need "to coordinate the national economic policies to sustain co-development, to educate and sensitize young generations about their Mediterranneaness" through education and culture and "respect for each other's national cultural specificities."


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


Morocco;
King Hassan Reveals Contacts With Polisario


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - King Hassan of Morocco confirmed the existence of " direct contacts" between his country and the Polisario Front in an address broadcast on radio and television on the 21st anniversary of the Green March which led to Morocco's annexation of Western Sahara in 1975.

Both Morocco and the Polisario Front claim the former Spanish territory. 

The Moroccan leader revealed Wednesday evening that the talks lasted two days and were led by Crown Prince Sidi Mohamed, assisted by Interior Minister Driss Basri.

He added that he was ready to personally meet the Polisario delegation. But "only when preliminary contacts have borne fruit", he said.

"At any rate, the palace gates remain open", the king said.

In his ten-minute speech broadcast by Moroccan satellite television monitored in Tripoli, King Hassan said the first contacts took place at the request of Polisario.

The next talks will be part of the UN plan to solve the issue of Western Sahara, which Morocco describes as the "only guarantee for the future of peace in the region".

In 1975, Morocco and Mauritania shared the former Spanish colony of Rio De Oro and Saguia El-Hamra, following an agreement signed in Madrid with Spain. The war which was immediately started by the Polisario Front forced Nouakchott to renounce it claims and leave the whole territory to Morocco.

In 1984, the Sahraoui Arab Democratic Republic (RASD), proclaimed in 1976, was formally authorized to sit at the OAU, which admitted it as a member in 1982. Morocco immediately left the continental organization of which it was a founding member.

King Hassan mentioned in his speech current reforms in his country, stressing that regionalization offers an ideal framework for the expression of the specific aspirations of all families in the kingdom.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


136 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 7, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa Suspends Arms Sales To Rwanda


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The South African government has suspended all arms sales to Rwanda until peace and stability have returned to the Great Lakes states of Central Africa.

Making the announcement at a media conference in Pretoria Wednesday, South African Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad said the decision had been taken after high level consultations with the leaders of the Great Lakes region. At the same time there have been reports of cross-border raids into Zaire by Rwandan armed forces.

Pahad confirmed that the decision to suspend the arms sales to Rwanda had already been conveyed to Kigali, but there had been no response to date.

He said the National Conventional Arms Control Committee would review the entire situation once stability had been re-established and things were back to normal in Central Africa.

He denied that South African arms had fuelled the fighting between Tutsi rebels and the Zairean army in eastern Zaire.

He said that only a few armored cars had been sent to Rwanda in terms of the 18.5-million-U.S.-dollar September arms deal between the two countries, and there were no indications that these vehicles had been used in the current conflict.

He also said that at this stage, the South African armed forces were not in a position to play a role in an African peacekeeping force. In any event, the United Nations Security Council still had to decide at its meeting later this week on whether or not a peacekeeping force should be sent to the region.

Should the Security Council decide on such action, Pahad said, South Africa could consider sending troops, but only if approved by the Organization of African Unity.


LOAD-DATE: November 13, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
