Africa News


November 13, 1996


Tunisia;
Tunisia Expresses Surprise at Intervention Force


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Tunis - Tunisia raised questions about the agreement concluded recently between France, Spain, Portugal and Italy to create a rapid intervention military force, especially in the southern Mediterranean region.

In a review of Tunisia's foreign relations at the weekly cabinet meeting chaired by president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, November 11, Mr. Habib Ben Yahia, Minister of Foreign Affairs said the aggreement "was reached without prior consultation with the countries of the southern flank of the Mediterranean." Mr. Ben Yahia said this "initiative's objectives raise questions and astonishment. It is incompatible with the tradition of dialogue and coordination which Tunisia wants to establish between both flanks of the Mediterrenean."

"Such initiatives must take into account the requirements of international legality and the principles enunciated in the United Nations Charter, particularly the independence of S tates, their sovereignty and their territorial integrity," he added.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Tunisia;
Tunisia Growth Projected for 5.7%


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Tunis - Tunisia's economic growth rate is expected to reach 5.7% in 1997, according to official statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Development. 

In an expose about the preparations for the next Economic Development Plan (1997-2001) presented at a cabinet meeting November 11, Mr. Taoufik Baccar, Minister of Economic Development, said that Tunisia expects to achieve an economic growth rate (at the constant prices) of about 5.7% while the price index will be capped at 4.2%.

Mr. Baccar added that the volume of Tunisian exports is expected to be higher than imports which would improve the overall trade balance.

Tunisia's economic growth rate in 1996 is expected to be between 7.5 and 8%.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Church Takes Lead In Caring For Disadvantaged Children


BYLINE: Dingaan Mpondah, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

Harare - It is estimated that by the year 2000, Zimbabwe will have about 600,000 HIV/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) orphans as the deadly disease continues to take its toll. This is in addition to those who have lost parents as a result of other circumstances. Already, the rapidly rising numbers of children in orphanages has severely strained resources and ability to care for the unprecedented numbers.

Most of the early institutions like schools, hospitals and orphanages in this Southern African country were started by missionaries upon their arrival in the 18th Century. For example, Morgenster Press, Zimbabwe's first privately-owned printing press (although commissioned by the government) was established by the then Dutch Reformed Church - African Reformed Church, at Morgenster Mission in Masvingo Province in the 1890s. 

Most of the educational material in the major local language, Shona were printed at Morgenster until Mambo Press (Catholic), Longmans, College Press and other printing houses came in and took over.

Mathew Rusike Children's Home, situated about 10 kilometres east of the capital Harare, is another of the early institutions. Begun in 1950, the home is the brainchild of the late Rev. Mathew Rusike of the Trinity Methodist Church and his wife Rudo, from Kadoma (Midlands).

Its beginnings are thus; One day Rev. Rusike came across two crying children, a girl and a boy aged about four and three years respectively. They were scantily dressed and obviously hungry and seemed to have been abandoned. He took the children home, eventually integrating them into his family.

Soon afterwards, the Rusikes received more and more children in similar predicaments. However, Rev. Rusike's meagre income eventually failed to cope with the demands of the "extended" family.

It was at this stage that the Methodist Church came to the couple's rescue. The children were moved to a large Methodist church farm next to the Epworth Theological College, thereby establishing the Mathew Rusike Children's Home. Although it started with only a few children, the home now caters for about 140 whose ages range from two to 16 years.

There is a lot of mobility at the home with those completing primary school at the institution's schools being sent elsewhere for secondary education. However, this home does not accept children below the age of two years. These are referred to other centres such as the government-run Chinyaradzo Children's home in Highfield, Harare.

Mathew Rusike is at present unable to accept all the children needing a place there because of lack of space. At the time of filing this article, the home was undergoing extensions to enable it accommodate more children.

The Church of Christ missionaries have also embarked on an ambitious project to establish a community of up to 1,000 orphaned and abandoned children, being integrated into families with both parents who have up to four children of their own.

The project called Khayelihle Children's Village (KVC), was started by Paul and Karen Reyman, along the same lines as the Mathew Rusike one in 1992. The two were moved by the plight of AIDS and other orphans and abandoned children in Zimbabwe.

"In particular, we were shocked by the projections that by the year 2000, there would be more than 60,000 AIDS orphans," says Paul Reyman. "We felt we should do our part to alleviate the problem," he adds.

Khayelihle, local Ndebele language for Good Home will most probably be the only home of its kind in Zimbabwe. Its history actually began with 11-year- old Precious Moyo. Her mother died of an undisclosed illness last March in Mutare, eastern Zimbabwe, prompting the young girl to move in with her grandmother.

Precious was so abused by her grandmother in Bulawayo, that some elders of the Church of Christ had to take her away.

Twelve-year-old Carlos Mpofu moved out of his Mzilikhazi family home, also in Bulawayo, to live out in the streets because his single and unemployed mother could no longer afford to provide for her four children.

Precious and Carlos are now "brother and sister" leading normal lives as part of a foster family of eight children in a modest house in Matsheumhlope, one of Bulawayo's affluent suburbs. The Church of Christ aims at seeing these family models of Khayelihle grow and grow, and according to the Reymans, "the sky is the limit."

In 1992, Paul and Karen approached church elders and other prominent people in their society to participate in the establishment of a children's home.

By 1994, Khayelihle Children Village was registered as a welfare organization chaired by Matabeleland Water Trust co-ordinator Kingsley Dube. The trust, a non-governmental organization, seeks to pump water from the Zambezi River to drought-prone Bulawayo.

The Clover Nook Charity Foundation, United States, pledged US$100 million (Z$ 1 billion) while the Church of Christ in Australia and New Zealand have also pledged yet undisclosed financial assistance.

"We had difficulties getting land around Bulawayo but in the end we landed a $50,000 (US$5,000), 50-year-lease on a 2,090 hectare plot on Olive Tree Farm," says Reyman.

Incidentally, Olive Farm, 50 kilometres south of Bulawayo, is where a group of missionaries were murdered in Zimbabwe's brief post- independence war in 1987.

Construction of K.V.C. has already begun and in 10 years' time according to its board of directors, the centre will have built modern houses for up to 10 children each, including pre-schools, a skills training centre, clinics and shops.

The community is expected to be self-sufficient as there is abundant water for crop production, cattle ranching and other agricultural activities.

Additional cottage industries would also be set up to ensure adequate jobs for the community.

"We want to create a complete community for abandoned children. The idea is to keep the children here when they grow up and start their own families. There should be enough resources to expand the community," says Reyman.

The first group of about 150 children, including the family in Matsheumhlope, are expected to move to the farm at the beginning of 1997.

"We hope that by then we will have built houses at least. It would be too early to build schools but we intend to integrate the children into the local community so they will go to local schools and clinics," he explained.

KVC board chairman Kingsley Dube hopes the Department of Social Welfare would help in identifying the needy children. However, any children, particularly AIDS orphans, are eligible to benefit from the project and are encouraged to contact KVC officials.

Matabeleland North provincial governor Welshman Mabhena, commenting on this exciting new development in his constituency says; "I truly think this will be one of the most significant contributions to the social and economic development of Zimbabwe."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zaire;
Intricate Designs In Ongoing Crisis In Zaire


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Nairobi - Zairean leader Mobutu Sese Seko, 66, has suddenly left the Swiss holiday report of Lausanne, where he has been staying since last August while receiving treatment for prostate cancer.

His departure on November 4 came one day after a Swiss parliamentarian questioned his luxurious lifestyle at the Lausanne resort where he lived in a $2,000 per day suite, at a time when Zaire is in chaos following the rapid advances of ethnic Zairean Tutsi Banyamulenge rebels.

The rebels with the support of the Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) have seized most of Eastern Zaire. Rwanda has denied the involvement of the RPF on Zairean territory. 

Mobutu has now moved to his luxury villa in Nice, southern France where he will be staying for the next few days before returning to Zaire. However, observers say the Zairean President is unlikely to return to the capital Kinshasa, but will go to his palace in Gbadolite in Equator Province, from where he will manipulate events at home.

Mobutu is recovering from cancer and may not be in a position to make a dramatic difference to the situation at home. In Kinshasa, thousands of students have taken to the streets to demand the removal of the reformist Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo, who is part- Tutsi, charging that he has done little to stall the swift advances of Tutsi rebels in the East.

The brutal Zairean Army Chief of Staff, General Eluki Mongi, went out of his way to blame Kengo for the mess in the East. However, many liberal minded Zaireans are impressed by General Eluki's charges against the premier since his troops have performed very poorly indeed in confronting the uprising in the troubled area.

Reports from North and South Kivu Provinces in the East which are largely under rebel control, told of Zairean troops more inclined to loot and run away at the slightest encounter with the Banyamulenge rebels. General Eluki who, like Mobutu comes from Equator region, has been careful not to blame his president for the mess despite the fact that the Army had no money while Mobutu paid holiday resort $1,400,00 in advance for himself and his entourage for their three month stay in Switzerland.

Eluki praised the Transition Parliament of Zaire which is currently under the control of Mobutu supporters for the "patriotic support of Zairean sovereignty" in the face of Rwandese backed rebellion in the East.

And as emotions run high against the Tutsi uprising in the East, angry Zaireans turned their wrath on Zaireans of Tutsi origin. Many are now in hiding or have fled across the river Congo into neighbouring Congo-Brazaville.

Fleeing Tutsis are paying as much as $3,000 for the privilege of being taken across the river by canoe away from harm in Kinshasa where the Transition Parliament has already voted to sack all Tutsis from the Armed Forces and the Zairean civil service.

Neighbouring Congo announced on November 5, it will allow Tutsis with Rwandese passports to enter Congo on transit to Rwanda, but will not allow Zairean Tutsis into its territory "because Congo lacks facilities for the maintenance of refugees," said a government statement.

Except for students and youthwingers who are roving in Kinshasa advocating tough action in the East, most Zaireans are less concerned because life is very difficult for them generally and there is no time for political distractions. There are however unconfirmed reports that Tutsis are being targeted in the central Zairean town of Lubumbashi. Their properties are being broken into and looted.

Etienne Tshisekedi, the hardline anti-Mobutu Member of Parliament who lost his job as Prime Minister in the early 90s after he called Mobutu "a monster", surprised many observers when he asked the Zairean public to contribute to the war kitty. Cynical observers believe Tshisekedi made political capital out of military reverses in the East.

Goma, the last important town to fall into the hands of rebels, was the centre of international relief activities until a combined force of Rwandese Army and Tutsi rebels seized it early November. The local Red Cross in Goma say they buried 400 corpses, casualties of the fighting and looting. There are reports that a number of Zairean troops have defected and are fighting alongside the rebels.

The sprawling camps in Goma that housed 500,000 Hutu refugees who fled Rwanda after the 1994 genocide are now empty. The refugees have been pushed deeper into the Zairean hinterland and are reported to have no food or water except what they can forage.

But France is feverishly trying to have the refugee camps in Eastern Zaire reconstituted. She has put forward a plan in the United Nations Security Council, urging that UN peacekeepers - meaning mainly the French - should move in "and restore order." The plan envisages the formation of "havens of safety" for the refugees whom aid agencies say will die in tens of thousands if nothing is done to save them.

A similar plan has been adopted by seven Great Lakes regional states meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, under the chairmanship of Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi. The heads of state of Zambia, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Rwanda, Kenya and Uganda called for the deployment of a neutral peacekeeping force and an immediate ceasefire. They called for temporary sanctuaries within Zaire to facilitate humanitarian assistance which would be delivered via " safe corridors." A notable absentee at the summit was Zairean Premier Kengo Wa Dondo who had earlier indicated he would attend.

But Rwanda, while endorsing the peace formulas of the regional heads of state, remains entirely opposed to the entry of the French into Zaire under any guise. The Rwandese say France is not a neutral party to the conflict.

Rwanda's Foreign Minister Anastasio Gasana, repeated the old charge that France's "Operation Turquoise" in south-western Rwanda mid- 1994, actually helped countless Hutu perpetrators of genocide to escape and subsequently use the camps in Eastern Zaire as a launching pad against the Tutsi-led regimes of Rwanda and Burundi.

At the United Nations, Germany has also opposed France's idea of re- establishing refugee camps in Eastern Zaire under a new name, Sanctuary.

Observers believe that Germany's doubts are the result of a leaked report compiled by senior United Nations staffers, illustrating in detail that a number of regional countries and France, far from working for peace, have actually been arming extremist Hutu forces with the aim of overthrowing the Tutsi led regimes in Rwanda and Burundi.

The internal report told of relief food given by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) being sold by recipients in the camps and a "war tax" being levied on these sales. The "war tax" was then used to buy weapons.

The report further showed that far from being the aggressed party, Zaire may have been the real aggressor since Kinshasa as well as the refugee camps were the hub of massive clandestine activities against Rwanda and Burundi.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Wole Soyinka Artistically Seeks Pressure On Nigeria


BYLINE: Odhiambo James, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

Nairobi - The "Beatification of the Area Boy" is a critical play which satirizes present day Nigeria and its military regime. The life of the common man is one of frustrations and the struggle for one's basic needs is a nightmare.

The latest of Wole Soyinka's theatre pieces currently doing the rounds in Europe and America, the play aims at sensitizing the international community to take stern action against this West African country and coerce the military regime to respect the citizenry.)

Exiled since 1994, Wole Soyinka the Nobel Prize laureate for literature has never stopped criticising the incumbent regime in Nigeria. He has time and again, called upon the international community to impose sanctions on Sani Abacha's military regime so that Nigeria can encounter genuine democracy which has been elusive since the Babangida era. 

his time, Wole Soyinka, a master playwright in collaboration with Jude Kelly have directed The Beatification of the Area Boy. With a cast of about 20 artists from Nigeria, Britain and Switzerland, the play is a beautifully crafted piece of theatre that takes what it needs from Western dramatic conventions and then does what it wants to do to commemorate and commiserate with the daily life of Nigerians.

On the surface, it is a straight slice of life, eavesdropped and reported one day in the vibrant and violent, and cruel and colourful life of a street corner in post-oil boom Lagos.

The criticism of the regime is carried out with a light touch. There is humour. However, the underlying message is serious. A critical look at the cast interprets these issues well. The judge who is demented sees a new dawn, void of the oppressive military regime. Mama Put, a petty businesswoman in the street adjacent to La Plaza shopping centre ekes out a miserly living but she has bitter memories of the Biafran war where she lost her brother.

The whole play revolves around Sanda. The organizer of the area boys. He is the oga (the chief), the security officer of La Plaza shopping centre, a learned man with university education. Rather than become unemployed, he opts for the job of a security officer and organizes the area boys to eke out their living too by posing as guards for vehicles of bigshots who come to shop at La Plaza. Occasionally, they pilfer some valuable items from these vehicles.

In a more subtle manner, Sanda is the kin pin of all the activities which take place around La Plaza. A raging crowd would wish to lynch a man who made someone's genitals "disappear" using magic (juju). They believe that this mutilation is 'contagious'. But somehow, Sanda intervenes to calm the situation.

In a marriage ceremony conducted at La Plaza instead of Misenyi, (a former girlfriend during their university heydays being married to the army chief), the bride to be offers the traditional calabash to Sanda during the occasion. This is an instance of dramatic irony. It creates commotion and confusion during the ceremony, prompting the army top brass to leave, obviously feeling humiliated but ready to charge back and revenge. Sanda reorganizes the area boys and devises a strategy to ward off the impending disaster to be carried out by the military officers.

The play has a grim setting on the poor Maroko quarters. Maroko, home to about one million inhabitants was razed down by the military to put up a shopping centre, La Plaza. Genuine documentary evidence prove that in the mid- 80's, Maroko was indeed a residential area for over one million people but it was razed down by the military during the Babangida regime. The residential area was reduced to ashes.

The economic situation is ridiculed when "Big Man" shopper comes on stage on a bicycle to purchase a neck-tie from "Trader". Everybody marvels and wonders why 'an iron horse' in the present day oil rich Nigeria where once upon a time, all the average income earners owned motor cycles. What is wrong with Nigeria? Where has all the oil they mine gone to? A bicycle song infused at this juncture in the play displays the satire in quite a humorous manner.

The grim situation of economic mismanagement and political anarchy where the common man is frustrated and social degradation is rampant, is not only a problem in Nigeria but in most African countries, remarked Camara, among the audience during the performance at Forum Meyrin Theatre in Switzerland on September 17,1996.

Why did Soyinka pick on beatification in a connotation sense and why an area boy for the honour?

The Nigerian playwright gave the following explanation; Beatification in the Catholic and Islamic context is when people organize a religious ceremony to bestow honour on a person who lived an exemplary dignified life. "I adopted this for my play. The area boy who is beatified organizes those around him well. He creates with his gang some order within the already chaotic situation. A moral way of living within the common citizenry."

Soyinka continues to elaborate that he had to emphasize that for these people in the low strata, everything is dislocated and nothing functions efficiently. The striking of crude oil has brought nothing of gain to the people. "My play is a ritual and at the same time a macabre Nigerian dance," he adds.

The Beatification of the Area Boy was jointly produced by West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (England) and Nawao Produktion Zurich (Switzerland). Produced mid-this year, the play was first performed at Theatre Spektakel in Zurich from September 3 to 6. It did its rounds in Geneva, Bern, and Basel last September. It was performed in Berlin, Germany from October 2 to 5 and was scheduled for other shows at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, New York in the United States from October 9 to 13.

Unfortunately, no show had been scheduled for Africa. This is ironical. The piece displays the African problem but the genuine Africans who encounter these problems do not have the opportunity to witness this grim situation.

The play which fuses the modern Western forms of art and music with African art forms is a critique not only for Nigeria but also for Africa. Wole Soyinka has used the pen and his deft fingers to communicate a subtle message. The international community, especially in Europe and America should take up the cudgels to fight against the deterioration of human rights in Nigeria and indeed Africa.

The late Ken Saro Wiwa sensitized the Ogoni community to fight for their agricultural land, already rendered useless by oil exploration. Worse still, they were denied their share of the crude oil which was extracted and exported from Ogoniland while successive military regimes relished the giant portion.

Wole Soyinka, in a style different from that of executed leader of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP), is subtly out to sensitize the international community on the genuine reality in Nigeria. The poverty and oppression of the majority and the opulence of those at the helm who rule by the barrel of the gun.

The Beatification of the Area Boy is a serious play which can be assessed from various angles and facets. It interprets a genuine Nigerian situation which is also true and relevant to other nations in Black Africa.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Challenged To Turn To God For Lasting Peace


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) - African nations have been challenged to turn to God for effective solutions to the difficulties facing the continent today.

"In many instances, we have mistakenly imagined that the solutions to the many social, economic and political problems facing us today lie within our military strength rather than on God. And results have been terribly bad," lamented the co-ordinator of Kenya Prophetic Destiny, a group of Christians concerned about the problems facing this country.

"We should stop thinking that guns, among other military strength, would yield the urgently needed solutions to the problems facing our continent today," Rev. Omondi stressed. 

He urged African countries that are not facing calamities similar to those experienced elsewhere to turn to God as they have surely learnt some lessons from the civil strife, harsh economic conditions and political instability among other problems prevailing on the continent.

"We have so much to learn from countries such as Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire, to mention but a few. We must not lose sight of these while we continue to pray to God to intervene in the people's sufferings," Rev. Omondi added.

He told the breakfast prayer gathering which was attended by a group of church leaders and ministers, journalists and politicians that the Kenya Prophetic Destiny would organise a national day of repentance and reconciliation on November 9 in the Kenyan capital.

"We have been concerned about the recurrent conflicts affecting the African continent in general and Eastern Africa in particular," said pastor Omondi, in a press statement, issued at the breakfast meeting.

Recent prophecies and pronouncements in the local and international media, and an apparent mood of anxiety and uncertainty confirm that all may not be well in Kenya, the Kenyan pastor noted in the press release which he jointly signed with Bishop William K. Tumising of the Deliverance Church, Rev. Daniel M. Seruwanga (PACLA II), the Most Rev. Manasses Kuria (Jehovah Jireh Christian Homes for Street Children and Families) and Rev. Ambrose A. Nyangao (Parklands Baptist Church).

The statement described members of the Kenya Prophetic Destiny as " Christians, called by God, to see, hear, touch and feel the pain and anguish of our nation. We are called to identify with an acknowledge the sins and the wicked ways of this nation, to be humbled and broken by the weight of our iniquity, and turn back to God in prayer, repentance, remorsefulness and reconciliation."

The group functions under the auspices of the Pan African Christian Leadership Assembly (PACLA II) follow-up committee.

The statement concluded by quoting from 2 Chronicles 7:14; "If my people, who are called by my name, will humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven and will forgive their sins and will heal their land."

Addressing the same gathering, retired Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) Archbishop Manasses Kuria, said; "We cannot claim not to be party to the African nations that need to be healed. We have shed blood amongst our brothers and sisters during the height of the land clashes (1991/93). We definitely need to call God to intervene."

Opposition legislator Njenga Mungai, whose Molo constituency in the Rift Valley Province was seriously affected by the politically motivated ethnic land clashes, welcomed the churches' idea of setting aside a day for national prayers for this East African nation.

"This is a wonderful idea and we look forward to participate. I hope all of us -- church leaders, Christians, the ruling party KANU (Kenya African National Union) and the Opposition, will find time and joy to attend the occasion," said Mr. Mungai.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Sudan;
Red Cross Suspends Field Work In Sudan


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

NAIROBI/GENEVA (APS) - The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has instructed all its field staff in Sudan to discontinue their humanitarian activities until all personnel seized when the agency's aircraft was impounded in Southern Sudan have been released.

A press release issued by ICRC headquarters in Geneva on November 6, said two pilots, a nurse and five patients returning home from an ICRC treatment facility in northern Kenya were still in the hands of a breakaway faction of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) rebels by late last week.

The pilots are Canadian and Kenyan, the nurse is Australian while the five patients are Southern Sudanese. 

The seizure of the plane, ICRC personnel and five patients occurred at Wuorok in Southern Sudan, 800 kilometres from the capital Khartoum, on November 1.

It has been confirmed that fighters loyal to Commander Kerubino Kwanyin Bol, a rival of Colonel John Garang of the mainstream SPLA were responsible for the seizure. Commander Kerubino is now allied with the Khartoum authorities, having signed the "Peace Charter" in Khartoum last July.

Following the seizure, Sudan accused ICRC of helping Col. John Garang's SPLA, charging that the ICRC had "violated humanitarian principles and its own mandate." The government charged that the five patients were rebels being helped to return to the theatre of operations in the South.

Mr. Ali Sadiq, spokesman for the Sudanese Embassy in Nairobi, told APS that the government had "incontrovertible evidence" that the plane had ferried the fighters with their guns and 20 boxes of ammunition.

"We are very disappointed to see the people we trusted so much involved in a conspiracy against the people of Sudan," said Mr. Sadiq.

But an ICRC Sudan delegate in Nairobi Nick Sommere, denied that the agency's plane was carrying guns and ammunition. "We know what we put on the planes. There were no guns and no ammunition," he told APS.

He said he was surprised by the charges emanating from Khartoum "since they know very well that the job of the ICRC is to care for the wounded in conflict situations."

Sommere reiterated that the ICRC is neutral in the conflict and had two hospitals catering for the war wounded in Juba, Southern Sudan and Lokichoggio in Turkana, north-western Kenya.

"We make no distinction. A wounded person whether from the government side or one who belongs to the rebel factions is given medical treatment without prejudice," he told APS.

According to Mr. Sadiq, his government authorities had confirmed that following the incident at Wuorok, all work by the ICRC in Sudan had been banned "till further notice."

The statement from ICRC headquarters described the charges by the Khartoum authorities as unfortunate "and entirely without foundation."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 13, 1996


South Africa;
Protests Continue As South Africa Adopts Abortion Law


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

CAPE TOWN (APS) - South Africa's controversial abortion- on-demand bill passed its final hurdle to becoming law on November 5, when it was adopted by a majority of the 90-member Senate, passing it with a 49 to 21 vote, despite continuing protests by the country's Roman Catholic church.

The controversial Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Bill, which is regarded as one of the most liberal abortion laws in the world, is expected to be signed into law soon by President Nelson Mandela.

The bill was piloted through the Senate, parliament's upper house, by Mandela's ruling African National Congress (ANC) and opposed by the National Party (NP), the Zulu-nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) and several smaller opposition parties. 

As it did when the bill was passed on October 30, when a total of 209 members voted for, 87 against and five abstained, the ANC which holds 252 seats, did not allow a free vote on the bill, while the NP and IFP allowed their members to vote according to conscience or belief.

The bill, which allows women and girls to have abortions performed in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, and in the first 20 weeks in certain circumstances, has also been widely opposed by religious groups.

Thousands of Roman Catholics, armed with messages of support from Pope John Paul II and Nobel Prize laureate Mother Teresa, held marches in South Africa's major centres on November 2 to protest the bill.

Opposition political groups, including the NP, the small liberal Democratic Party (DP) and the radical black Pan-Africanist Congress (PAC) allowed their members to vote freely on the measure, while the ANC insisted that its members vote in favour.

As a result, a number of ANC members of the Roman Catholic Church, which steadfastly opposes abortions, decided not to attend the October 30 vote.

Every year, more than 250,000 women, mainly black, have illegal "backstreet" abortions performed, and of these, at least 425 die in South African hospitals as a result of infections and bleeding, according to official figures.

Until now, only about 1,000 women have been raped are victims of incest, or whose pregnancy poses a danger to their lives, have qualified each year for legal abortions in South Africa.

The NP attacked the new document, however, for allowing teenage girls to have abortions performed without first consulting their parents or guardians.

Passing of the bill, originally set to occur on October 29, was delayed at the last minute by the NP, which offered half a dozen amendments to be considered.

The amendments were voted out later on October 29 at a hastily summoned meeting of the parliament's health committee, prompting a walk-out by two NP committee members.

NP spokesman Sheila Camerer warned her party could decide to challenge the bill in South Africa's Constitutional Court.

The DP supported the bill on the grounds that hundreds of thousands of South Africans are unable financially, or physically, to care for unwanted children.

Religious groupings, including the Roman Catholic Church, Dutch Reformed Church and various Islamic groupings had staged vocal anti- abortion protests the previous week in a last-ditch effort to prevent the bill's passing, but without success.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zaire;
Demos In Kinshasa Amid Pressure On Mobutu To Return


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

KINSHASA (APS) - Some 10,000 Zairean stormed into the streets of the capital Kinshasa on November 5, demanding the resignation of Zairean Prime Minister Kengo Wa Ndondo over the crisis in eastern Zaire, where government forces are battling Tutsi rebels.

The demonstrators, most of them students, riding in hundreds of commandeered vehicles streamed down Kinshasa's main avenue, chanting slogans calling for the resignation of the Prime Minister.

They accuse him of bungling the crisis after the Zairean authorities admitted on November 4 that they had lost control of eastern Zaire's two key towns of Bukavu and Goma.

"We support the armed forces" battling Tutsi rebels in eastern Zaire, the demonstrators shouted as the jammed trucks rumbled down June 30 Boulevard, trailing a banner reading "Thank you France" outside the French embassy, and " We are going to see to you Belgians" outside the Belgian embassy in the capital. 

Belgium is Zaire's former colonial power, while France is widely accused of having bungled its "Operation Turquoise" during the Rwandan civil war in 1994, when Paris sent troops into Rwanda to create safe zones for displaced people, but were opposed by the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), which won the war, because of France's role in supporting previous Hutu regimes.

The students had demonstrated in smaller numbers on November 1, calling for the ouster of Kengo and railing against Rwandan and Burundian national in Zaire, as well as ethnic Banyamulenge Tutsis who have lived in Zaire for nearly 200 years. Kengo is believed to have been born of a Tutsi mother and Zairean father.

During the first protest, students looted the residence of the Burundian ambassador and roughed up some Rwandan Tutsis, but the November 5 demonstration was better disciplined.

Although no incidents were reported between the students and security forces, the unprecedented demonstration was seen as a major blow for Kengo, though he had refused to attend a regional summit on Zaire which began in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, on November 5.

Kengo had shown support for the Zairean army and said he would not attend the conference until "the aggressors" had left the east of the country -- a reference to Rwandan soldiers alleged to be helping the Tutsi rebels. Kigali has admitted to raiding Zairean territory the previous week, but says it had no troops there.

Political analysts said that if Kengo had gone to Nairobi, he would have sparked a violent reaction among a Zairean population fired by nationalist sentiment. Apart from Rwanda, Zaire has also accused Burundi and Uganda of being behind the rebels.

The previous week, the Zairean government was strongly criticised by the opposition for showing "weakness", while the armed forces chief- of-staff General Eluki Mongi Aundu complained that the army had not been "given the means to make war."

More than a million refugees from Burundi and Rwanda and displaced Zaireans are caught up in the crisis and the United Nations aid agencies warned on November 5 of an impending humanitarian catastrophe in the region.

The demonstrations came as pressure was growing on Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko to return home from Europe, where the 67-year-old is convalescing from prostate cancer surgery, and prepares to meet in the French city of Nice with UN special envoy to the African Great Lakes region Raymond Chretiene of Canada.

Mobutu, whose country faces a humanitarian disaster following fighting between his government troops and the Tutsi rebels, flew to France on November 4 from Switzerland where he had been treated for prostate cancer since August.

Diplomats familiar with the region say that if Mobutu returns to Zaire in the next few days, he would immediately take over political control of the refugee crisis from Kengo.

In particular, he is the only man who could overturn the decision to boycott any negotiations with Rwanda so long as a part of eastern Zaire is occupied by Rwandan nationals.

But the state of Mobutu's health was still unclear, with the French daily Le Monde, quoting sources close to Mobutu's doctors, as saying that his prostate cancer had spread to his bones and that his condition was too delicate for him to return home.

In Kinshasa, however, presidential spokesman Kabya Lumuna said that Mobutu would return to his country in the "coming days," raising hopes that he may be able to intervene actively to ease the crisis.

His absence from the political scene is all the more frustrating for France which has backed Zaire's incumbent despite international criticism of the country's human rights record.

Mobutu, who seized power in 1965, allowed France to use Zairean territory for Operation Turquoise, the humanitarian mission mounted by France during the genocide in neighbouring Rwanda, leaving nearly one million people dead in 1994.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Science and Health;
Uganda & UNICEF In Pact To Fortify Sugar With Vitamin A


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

KAMPALA (APS) - Uganda's Ministry of Health in conjunction with the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the main sugar producing factories have set up a national Task Force to plan and implement the fortification of sugar with vitamin A.

The move will benefit babies and nursing mothers in particular.

The Task Force is composed of the Head of Nutrition, Ministry of Health Mrs. Ursula Wangwe who is the chairlady, representatives from three sugar producing factories, the Uganda National Bureau of Standards and UNICEF.

The fortification of foodstuffs such as sugar with vital minerals and vitamin was one of the recommendations of the World Summit on Children held in New York, United States in 1990. 

For many decades now, numerous studies have indicated that giving children additional vitamin A in form of supplements has great impact on lowering infant mortality figures.

At a meeting sponsored by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children's Fund that was held in Guatemala, South America last September, delegates from Third World Nations were informed that the South American nation had substantially boosted child health through simple measures of fortifying sugar with vitamin A. Sugar is a common food commodity consumed daily by millions of children.

Vitamin A is beneficial because it helps boost the immune system. It protects the mucous membranes which form a barrier against the entry of germs which cause gastrointestinal diseases like diarrhoea and respiratory tract diseases like pneumonia, tonsils, gum diseases etc.

The Commissioner of Health Services in charge of Nutrition Dr. D. Lwamafa urged the Task Force to expedite the sugar fortification plan by working hand in hand with the sugar industries in Uganda. They should also suggest alternative foodstuffs consumed by the majority of Ugandans into which vitamin A may be fortified.

The UNICEF Uganda programme officer Dr. Van Steiteghen said the UN body had consented to import the initial consignment of vitamin A premix preparation for fortifying sugar on a pilot basis. Uganda would however have to build its own factory to make vitamin A in bulk once the pilot programme is over.

Dr. Van Steiteghen was happy that Uganda would be the first country in Africa to implement the fortification of sugar with vitamin A. The fortification plans would be implemented in such a way as to ensure that consumers do not take an excess of this vitamin.

Natural sources of vitamin A are milk, butter, greens and yellow fruits like mangoes and carrots. Fish, liver and nuts are also good sources of this vitamin.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


276 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Rwanda;
Rwanda's Low Income Women Lead In Financial Networks


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

NAIROBI (APS) - Despite the 1994 genocide that left Rwanda totally devastated, this Central African country has one of the leading financial networks for low income women in Africa.

This was revealed by the Africa regional coordinator of the Women's World Banking (WWB) Ms. Phyllis Wanjiku Kibui, during the opening of the WWB biannual global meeting here from November 4 to 8.

In an interview with APS, Ms. Kibui said the Rwandese women through their financial trust body, Duterimbere (go forward) had remarkably mobilised themselves into groups in order to become self-sustaining. 

Speaking to APS, the President of Duterimbere Vinantie Rukarugonwa, said her organization has a membership which increases by ten per cent every month throughout the country. She attributes this to the adverse effects of the war that left 70 per cent of the Rwandese women as widows and orphans.

Rukarugonwa noted that Duterimbere was involved in the reconciliation process to create a good economic climate and also set good ground for their future prospect of establishing a cooperative bank to support the women better.

Officiating at the opening of the meeting, Deputy Governor of the Central Bank of Kenya Dr. Nzioki Kibua, called on WWB to break the cultural and racial barriers that hinder potential women borrowers from acquiring loans.

Dr. Kibua urged WWB to empower women as investors and equip them with business knowledge to distinguish between family income and business income.

Addressing the more than 100 participants drawn from over 40 global countries, WWB President Nancy Barry, said the week-long meeting will reflect on strategies of creating effective systems which give low income women entrepreneurs access to banking services, markets and information.

Barry hailed the Kenya Women's Finance and Credit Trust (KWFCT) for its leading clientele of about 6,200 low income women. She explained that WWB is targeting a total of 100 million beneficiaries by the year 2005.

Established in 1979, Women's World Banking is a United States-based non- profit making financial institution, designed to exclusively address the needs of low income women in the world by advocating for their recognition in the banking systems.

In Africa, women's financial and credit trusts have taken root in Senegal, Gambia, Kenya, Uganda, Zambia, Mali, Ghana and South Africa.

LANGUAGE: English
