285 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


United States and Africa;
White House Outlines Conditions for Sending Troops to Zaire


BYLINE: White House


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Washington DC - Statement released by spokesman Michael McCurry, November 13, 1996.

The United States has been increasingly concerned that the humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire is deteriorating. There are thousands of lives that may be at risk by reports of a recent outbreak of cholera among the refugee population along the border and deeper now into Zaire. We've been working urgently to define the role a possible security force could play in a larger humanitarian operation in eastern Zaire.

Part of this process has involved extensive consultations with the government of Canada, which as I think many of you know, has offered to lead a multinational humanitarian force. The United States welcomes Canada's offer to lead the multinational force. It's a move that will clearly demonstrate the will of others in the international community to assume a fair share of the burden for the operations that we project will be underway to save lives in Zaire. 

The President reviewed our efforts to address the situation in Zaire this morning in a telephone call with Prime Minister Chretien. The conversation was around 11 o'clock this morning, lasted about 15 minutes. It really was a culmination of several days of work that have involved National Security Adviser Anthony Lake and others, working through the question of how to structure and stipulate the particulars of this type of humanitarian effort.

Last night a delegation of senior Canadian officials met with a U.S. delegation that was headed by National Security Adviser Lake, and those conversations resulted in a general agreement on the mission definition, command and control arrangements, and the duration of the mission. I'm going to walk through some of the particulars that we have now identified that will be addressed.

I'd say at first, though, to summarize it in general, the results of all the conversations that have occurred within the United States government, with those that we have consulted within the international community, and clearly the call between Prime Minister Chretien and the President, has led the President to decide that the United States is willing in principle to participate in a limited fashion in this humanitarian mission, as long as certain conditions are stipulated to.

First, we need to be able to validate some core assumptions that we made about the nature of the mission. Those regard the nature of the threat, the environment in which a multinational force would insert itself into the region, the availability of other properly trained and equipped forces so that it would truly be a multinational effort. And the consent of concerned countries in the region that would have to provide assistance in basing and routing so that the force could be effective.

Second, the mission of the force would have to be very clearly defined. The mission of the force would be both to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid by civilian relief organizations and to facilitate the voluntary repatriation of refugees by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. There is an extraordinary amount of very courageous work being done by nongovernmental organizations and others currently addressing the very desperate humanitarian situation that over a million refugees now face in the area. The principal goal is to assist them in their work and to make sure they can conduct their operations in a safe manner.

There's also, simultaneously, a need to work with UNHCR to assure that those who have fled Rwanda can voluntarily repatriate themselves to their homes. In saying that, I would also say the mission of this force would not be to disarm militants, to conduct any type of forced entry, or to police some of the operations in the refugee camps that have now been established in the border region.

Third, this force would operate as a multinational force. It would have very robust rules of engagement that military planners at the Pentagon have been exploring with their counterparts in other governments. Following, we would expect the United Nations Security Council to authorize this multinational force most likely in an effort led by Canada to bring the issue before the Security Council for their review. It would operate under Chapter 7 rules under the U.N. Charter. It would therefore not be what we would typically think of as a blue-helmet operation.

Fourth , the cost of the mission would be borne by participating states. However, there need to be additional arrangements to support the participation by African nations. We think it's very important that forces from the region be a part of this multinational force, but clearly the costs of that should not be borne by those who would be force contributors, or at least should not be borne entirely by force contributors from the region. There would have to be arrangements worked out to enlist the support of non- troop-contributing countries.

Fifth, we envision that the humanitarian mission as it has been defined and as we currently assess it would be of limited duration, about four months. We're discussing with other nations the need for a follow-on presence beyond that time to ensure that there was not a return of the conditions that have led to this current humanitarian crisis.

Sixth, the contribution of the United States as we have identified the role that we could uniquely play in such an operation would consist of airport security around the airfield near Goma, which has been a principal point of delivery for humanitarian supplies and for those who are conducting relief operations, assistance in airlifting, deploying forces to the region -- in other words, participating in establishing the air bridge to the region, airfield services, the provision of security along approximately three-mile a corridor from Goma to the Rwandan border.

And we anticipate a significant number of those U.S. troops that would be deployed as part of this mission would actually be based outside of Zaire in neighboring countries. So in total you might have a large force of several thousand -- different estimates now because we're still assessing what type of U.S. contribution would be made. But the bulk of our deployment to the region would not necessarily be in Zaire on the ground, although we would place forces on the ground in Zaire as part of the multinational effort.

As always, U.S. forces -- and I want to stress this -- U.S. forces would remain at all times under U.S. command while serving under the operational control of a commanding officer; in this case, the commanding officer would be a Canadian officer. The United States would most likely provide the deputy commander to the Canadian commanding officer. But all the troops operating in Zaire would be under U.S. commanders. In other words, the tactical command structure would be with a U.S. commander in charge of units or forces deployed and they would retain, as they always would anywhere in the world, the direct chain of command authority to the Commander-In-Chief.

Now, where are we now? We've got, as some of you know, a military assessment team that has made its way to the region. They're assessing, obviously, things like the threat environment, what the security requirements would be, what type of infrastructure would be there to support the deployment of a force. We simultaneously have a humanitarian disaster assistance relief team from USAID that is present in the region just looking at what the humanitarian needs are. They are all, as they make these assessments, feeding back information both to the Pentagon and to others in our government so we can make a rational calculation on how to structure and size the force we're talking about.

The President has directed the National Security Adviser to go meet with Canadian officials and others, most likely in New York tomorrow, to put final touches on a proposed mission. He reserves the right to review that before making any final decisions related to deployment, but again, to summarize, in principle he agrees that U.S. participation in this important humanitarian effort is vital; it reflects our humanitarian concerns about the situation that exists now in eastern Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zaire;
WFP Eastern Zaire Situation Report No. 18


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Rome - KINSHASA: Situation in town remained tense on 13 November. Joint UN mission (WFP, UNHCR and UNICEF) left this morning for Kisangani.

UGANDA: Tense situation near Kasese, leading to several thousand displaced Ugandans in Kasese, following attack allegedly by 200 Zairian troops and Ugandan dissidents. WFP staff at Kasese assessing the situation. 

GOMA: Despite three mortar rounds of shelling landing at the hospital from the area of Mugunga camp, WFP was able to complete unloading both trucks yesterday at the hospital. The UN team, including 3 WFP staff returned to Gisenyi for the night. Exchanges of artillery and mortar fire reported during the night of 13 November between Goma and Mugunga camp. Access to Goma today at 09:00 GMT is uncertain. If access possible, WFP team will monitor distribution of food already offloaded. A local Distribution Commission, comprising of UN, NGOs and local authorities, and headed by WFP, has been set up to monitor the distribution of relief items.

Food stocks prepositioned in Gisenyi, including trucks loaded with food commodities, are ready to enter into Goma once conditions permit.

BUKAVU: Access to Bukavu was denied to UN team on 13 November. WFP staff members, as well as WFP trucks carrying food commodities, are ready at the border to enter into Bukavu with the UN team should clearance be permitted today. De facto authorities not available for negotiating clearance.

UVIRA: WFP and UNHCR continue to try to make contact with the de facto authorities in Uvira to gain clearance to cross into Zaire from Burundi. UN teams are ready to enter once conditions permit. WFP has received reports that 800 to 1000 mt remains in the Uvira warehouse at the port.

BURUNDI: During a meeting with the WFP Executive Director, Ms. Bertini, on 12 November, the Prime Minister of Burundi has indicated that Burundian roads and airports can be used to transport food to the needy in Eastern Zaire and that Burundi has given its clearance to international organisations to enter from Burundi.

Approximately 30,000 returnees, mostly from Uvira camps, have arrived in Burundi during the past weeks. WFP has been assisting the returnees with food packages at the Gatumba transit centre in Bujumbura province. For those returnees who have arrived directly to the insecure province of Cibitoke (the number is estimated at 16,000), WFP will attempt to distribute food assistance tomorrow. Although this area is usually off limits to relief staff due to the high level of insecurity, WFP was able to carry out an inter- agency evaluation mission to the area on 11 November.

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION, PLEASE CONTACT WFP EASTERN ZAIRE CRISIS SUPPORT FACILITY (CSF): International Fax Line: 39 6 5228-2828 International Telephone Line: 39 6 5228-2535 Electronic Mail Address: ezaire@wfp.org


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zambia;
November 18 Polls To Go Ahead


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lundazi - President Frederick Chiluba has refuted press reports in the local media saying he has postponed the November 18 elections.

President Chiluba said as president of this country he has no constitutional powers to postpone the elections.

Speaking on arrival in Lundazi this morning where he will address a public rally this afternoon to drum-up support for his party and its candidates, he said only the electoral commission had the power to postpone the elections should need arise. 

''I am aware the Zambian people are very anxious to hear about the outcome of my visit to South Africa to meet President Nelson Mandela but all I can say now is that my counter part will speak to some people in this country and we shall see what happens. Those who say I had postponed the elections are telling lies,'' he said.

He appealed to people in the district with to continue with their election campaign and keep their voters cards safely.

In Lusaka, Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) also had its General Secretary Derrick Chitala threatening that no one will postpone the November 18 presidential and general elections without consulting the opposition parties entered into the race.

Mr. Chitala said that ZDC has spent about K6 billion on organising for this elections during the past 15 months and would not allow any person, including the President, Mr Chiluba to postpone the elections without consulting them.

They welcomed government's reaffirmed statement that elections would be held as arranged on November 18.

Vice President Godfrey Miyanda's said in Lusaka today that the November 18 elections would not be postponed contrary to what local and international media purported because doing so would be contradicting the law.

Briefing journalists in Lusaka Gen. Miyanda denied that President Chiluba promised South African President Nelson Mandela that the November 18 elections would be postponed to allow electoral and constitutional differences with the opposition political parties to be solve before elections could take place.

Gen. Miyanda said at no time during the press briefing in South Africa did President Chiluba make such a committment which could seem to undermine the independence of the electoral commission.

Mr. Chitala said not even the president could postpone the elections without first consulting the opposition because a lot of effort and money had already been spent.

He appealed to President Chiluba and UNIP president, Dr. Kaunda to resolve what he called personal differences to avoid dragging the country into civil war.

Source: ZAMTODAY


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

November 13, 1996


Zambia;
Borders To Remain Open On Election Day


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 133 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia will not close its borders before and during next Monday's general elections contrary to rumours circulating in Lusaka, the Immigration Department announced today.

The department's spokesperson, Catherine Poso, assured members of the public that the borders will not be closed and operational hours will remain unchanged.

"Members of the public are, therefore, advised to ignore the rumour going round in Lusaka about the closure of the borders," she said.

Source: ZAMTODAY

289 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 13, 1996


Zambia;
No Vote If Land Act Stays, Chief Warns


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Mapatizya - A Ssouthern Province Chief has advised his subjects not to turn up for elections on Monday in protest against the Land act.

Chief Simwatachela told his subjects that voting would be acknowledging the land act which most people had rejected. He said the land act would kill chiefdoms.

The chief said this in his closing remarks to a Zambia Civic Education Association (ZCEA) workshop held in Mapatizya.

"In Zambia there are 202 chiefs and 41 chiefs in Southern province. And all the 41 chiefs rejected that act. And for us to vote it will be like us telling them to go ahead with the act. can you imagine a chief having no land?" asked Simwatachela.

Simwatachela also told his subjects that if it were possible, all those who had voted for the land act should not be given another term in parliament.

Earlier a villager, Wankie Kaliyangile told ZCEA chairperson Lucy Sichone that he was strongly opposed to the land act which vests all land in the President because politicians come and go while chiefs who have administered land on behalf of the people are for life.

"That is what petitioners told us during the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission. They wanted power to land to be given to the chiefs because they could not trust the politicians," said Sichone.

Another villager Chizzuwa Makwembe complained that putting value on land would just put most villagers in a disadvantaged position because they would not manage the process of acquiring certificates of title.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
Court Rejects Opposition Calls To Halt Polls


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 734 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (pana) - The Zambian supreme court Thursday, dismissed as " premature" a petition filed by five opposition parties challenging President Frederick Chiluba's eligibility to run for president in elections planned for the Nov. 18.

A full supreme court bench of seven judges made the ruling on a preliminary issue raised by the court itself on whether it had powers to hear the petition before the elections, as required by law.

The opposition parties asked the court to order postponement of the elections and initiate a probe into Chiluba's nationality. 

This is in line with the new Zambian law which requires that only citizens born in Zambia of Zambian parentage qualify to run for the office of president.

The opposition claims that Chiluba and his parents do not meet the criteria.

Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube in dismissing the petition, said that it was premature, and ran counter to the provisions of the electoral law, according to which "a petition shall be filed within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in."

Four parties filed the petition on Monday. They were later joined by the Zambia Democratic Congress which also said it had doubts about Chiluba's claim to be a bona fide Zambian.

The others are the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) , of former President Kenneth Kaunda, the Liberal Progressive Front, the National Congress and the Agenda for Zambia parties.

The court also noted that delaying the right to petition was not denying the right to petition.

"To knock a presidential candidate out of the race would deprive the citizens their right to seek and form the next government since there is no provision to allow for new nominations," Ngulube said.

The court, which dismissed the petition with costs, advised the petitioners to file a suit within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in as the law required.

The lawyers for the petitioners had earlier on Thursday argued that the electoral act clearly stated that an aspiring presidential candidate must meet the requisites of the presidential qualifications and must comply before the event and not "subsequent" to the event.

The lead counsel, Edward Shawana, said the electoral act was inconsistent in that it allows a presidential candidate who does not meet all the requirements of the act to contest for presidency as he/she can only be petitioned within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in.

"To stop the applicants from filing in a petition at this stage will be denying them their constitutional rights to do so... but are denied under the electoral act," Shawana said.

On the government side, the Solicitor-General, Sam Chisulo, said the petition be dismissed because by allowing the petition it will be "impossible" to hold an election since there will always be a multiplicity of petitions.

In another development, one of the lawyers for the petitioners, Mainza Chona, disclosed to the court after the ruling that two of the witnesses they intended to call to challenge Chiluba's citizenship claims received parcel bombs earlier in the day.

The lawyer said the devices were handed over to the police who defused them.

Ngulube said the matter will be looked into if a fresh petition filed after the elections.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

291 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Egypt Puts Up Boutros-Ghali For Re-Election


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

NEW RORK, (PANA) - Egypt has formally submitted the candidature of Boutros Boutros-Ghali for re-election as the secretary-general of the United Nations.

In a letter to the president of the Security Council, Egypt's permanent representative to the U.N., Nabil Elaraby, expressed the hope that the council would reflect "the will of the majority" in its decision on which candidate to recommend to the General Assembly.

The 185-member assembly elects a secretary-general on the recommendation of the 15-member council. 

"The candidature of Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali enjoys wide support by the majority of the U.N. membership," the Egyptian ambassador said in the letter, dated Nov. 12.

"As you know, two major regional organizations, the Organization of African Unity and the League of Arab States, have endorsed H.E. Dr. Boutros Boutros- Ghali for a second full term as secretary-general of the U.N.," he added.

At a private lunch in New York on Tuesday to discuss the election procedure, the council agreed that informal consultations on the election would start next Monday.

The United States has vowed to bar Boutros-Ghali, using its veto if necessary, from a second term on accusations of not pursuing enough reforms at the world body.

But other veto-wielding members of the council--China, France, Britain and Russia--support Boutros-Ghali's re-election.

Though the secretary-general, whose current five-year term will expire on Dec. 31, is the only official candidate for the election, other names have been mentioned in recent times.

They include the UN under-secretary-general for peace-keeping operations, Kofi Annan, a Ghanaian, the president of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda and the secretary-general of the Islamic Conference, Hamid Algabid of Niger.

Meanwhile, members of the council have agreed that if the U.S. vetoes Boutros-Ghali as threatened, Africa should be given the chance to produce a list of other candidates for consideration before candidates from other regions are allowed to come in.

"The understanding is that Africa deserves a second term," a source close to the council said.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zaire;
Nearly 200,000 Refugees Could Die Within A Month


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ROME, Italy (PANA) - Some 195,000 refugees could die within a month unless there is "massive intervention" in eastern Zaire now, a ranking United Nations official said Thursday.

Catherine Bertini, the executive director of the World Food Programme, said in a news conference here that 80,000 children were affected by starvation in the region. 

"Children are particularly at risk especially those who have started breast- feeding," she said.

The refugees are fleeing the ongoing three-way fight between the Zairean army, Rwandan Hutu militia and Zairean Tutsi rebels.

Bertini, who is attending the World Food Summit, said a multinational force which is being readied for deployment in eastern Zaire will have to first separate the Hutu militia from the refugees if food delivery is to be immediate and effective.

Her agency has enough food for the 1.2 million refugees who are fleeing northward from Goma, westward from Bukavu and Uvira, and south from Uvira toward Fizi.

The problem is, she said, "there is not a clear indication of where they are".

She said that two United States aircraft from Entebbe, Uganda flying low to locate the refugees, suspended their operations after being fired on Wednesday.

However, the agency has a C-130 Hercules military aircraft standing by to begin airdrops as soon as the refugees are located and "as soon as it is safe" to conduct the operation.

The agency has food prepositioned in Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda and Tanzanian.

The assistant executive director of the World Food Programme, Jean-Jacques Graisse, told PANA that the agency could make deliveries to Bukuvu and Uvira so long as it gets permission from Burundi.

However, he said, many of the agencies vehicles have been stolen by retreating Zairean government troops.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Finance Minister Resigns Over Bank Malpractice


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Swazi Finance Minister Derek von Wissell resigned Wednesday because he could no longer clean up the mess at a state- owned bank.

Wissel, the first ever cabinet minister to resign, quit 15 hours after a reshuffle Tuesday, that relegated him to the lesser portfolio of tourism and communications. 

Rather than accept the new posting, he quit on a matter of principle.

"The only conclusion I can draw from being moved in a new portfolio is that government no longer supports the work I started at SDSB (Swaziland Development and Savings Bank)," he said in press release.

"It would be impossible for me to be part of such a government, and I have therefore resigned from cabinet with immediate effect."

He said in his pursuit of his duties at SDSB "my conscience refused to allow me to acquiesce to the abuse of tax payers' money and even corrupt practices...My actions obviously created enemies for me in so-called 'high places'."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Senegal;
Senegal Pledges Troops For Zaire Peace Mission


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegal will contribute a battalion, consisting of 500 troops to the neutral multinational force in the Great Lakes region, Canadian ambassador Wilfried-Guy Licari revealed Wednesday in Thies, 70 km (44 miles) east of the Senegalese capital.

Licari, who was attending a presentation of medical equipment, commended " the great political will" of the Senegalese government in contributing troops to the Canadian-led force. 

Besides Senegal, six other African countries--Ethiopia, Eritrea, Congo, Cameroon, Mali and South Africa--have announced their desire to contribute troops to the force to provide humanitarian assistance to the more than one million refugees in eastern Zaire.

Licari said Canada decided to take the command of the deployment operation of the neutral multinational force following "diplomatic hesitations" by the international community, adding that consultations are continuing "between various countries" for the setting up of the force.

In a cabinet meeting on Tuesday, the Senegalese government expressed its total support to the establishment of the force.

295 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Ethiopia;
Three Egyptians Appeal Against Death Sentences


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Three Egyptian fundamentalists of the opposition Gama'a Al-Islamiya, who were sentenced to death in September for involvement in an abortive attempt on the life of President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa in June 1995, have appealed to the Ethiopian federal supreme court.

A spokesman of the Addis Ababa central high court, which found the defendants guilty, was quoted by the government press Thursday as saying that the Ethiopian defence lawyer for the convicts had submitted to the court a 13- point deputation appealing its verdict of Sept. 21, 10 days after the sentence was passed. 

If the sentence is upheld by the supreme court, the death penalty will only be carried out after the final approval of President Negasso Gidada.

The three convicts had been identified earlier as Sofit Hassen Abdul Kabi, Abdul Karim Naddi and Al-Arib Sadik. They had pleaded not guilt to the charges and were tried in camera beginning April 1996.

They were found guilty of complicity in the attempted assassination of Mubarak and the killing of two policemen on duty at the time of the incident on June 26, 1995, in which three civilians were also wounded. The trio were also charged on smuggling fire arms, including grenade launchers, through the Sudan Airways office in Addis Ababa, into the country as part of the assassination plot.

The three convicts were said to be part of an 11-man Egyptian hit squad sponsored by the Gama'a Al-Islamiya, trained in Pakistan. Nine of the men entered Ethiopia with Yemeni, Sudanese and Egyptian passports to assassinate Mubarak as he flew into Addis Ababa from Cairo to attend an OAU summit.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


East African;
Zairean Troops Attack Uganda


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Zairean troops backed by Ugandan rebels Wednesday attacked the Ugandan border towns of Mpondwe and Bwera in south western district of Kasese.

Uganda's Foreign Affairs Minister, Martin Aliker told an impromptu news conference Wednesday night that a Uganda Peoples' Defence Force platoon at Karambi, seven kilometers (4.4 miles) northwest of Bwera and Mpondwe border posts had been attacked.

He said that the attackers were a combination of Zairean forces and some Ugandan dissidents trained in Zaire. However, the minister could not name the dissident groups involved in the attack. 

"We do not know the names but we are aware that Ugandan dissidents were involved" Aliker said.

He said that the raiders were repulsed and three of them were killed but " shelling has continued sporadically most of the day from the Zairean side".

Following the attack, Uganda sent heavy reinforcements to the scene from the nearby towns of Mbarara and Fort Portal.

Eye witness reports from Kasese say that the rebels started shooting at around 7.30 a.m local time before taking the customs post 30 minutes later.

Scared residents claimed that about 50 people were feared dead including the headmaster of Karambi Secondary School and some of his students.

Aliker could not explain why Zairean troops had attacked Uganda now when they are embroiled in the Banyamurenge crisis in the east of their country. " We do not know. But I think it is sheer madness for Zaire to attack us from that side. It is a diversionary attack" he stressed.

He also said that he could not confirm whether the attack was sanctioned by the government of Zaire, or it was a result of general lawlessness that is prevailing in eastern Zaire.

The minister said Uganda would not sever diplomatic relations with Zaire because they were not aware that the Zaire government had authorized the attack.

"We really sympathize with the government of Zaire because of this Banyamurenge crisis. And we are aware there is no government in eastern Zaire, so we cannot sever the ties before we have proof" he said.

The Banyamurenge rebels, ethnic Zairean Tutsi militants, launched attacks in the eastern parts of the country nearly a month ago, with the alleged backing of Rwanda and Burundi.

The Zairean government has accused Uganda, too, of helping the Banyamurenge and parliament in Kinshasa passed a resolution calling for the severance of diplomatic relations with all the three countries.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


297 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Rwanda;
Human Rights Watch Asks UN To Release Rwanda Arms Reports


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Washington - Human Rights Watch today (November 11) calls upon the United Nations Security Council to release the Third Report of the International Commission of Inquiry (Rwanda) concerning arms flows to former Rwandan government forces based in neighboring countries, particularly Zaire, Tanzania and Kenya.

Such arms trafficking is in violation of an international arms embargo. The report illustrates how members of the international community enlarged the conflict in Central Africa by supplying arms to, or failing to impede the rearming of, the perpetrators of the 1994 genocide. Human Rights Watch believes that the illicit arms trade is a major contributing factor to the ongoing conflict and humanitarian crisis in Central Africa, and consequently to the serious abuses of human rights and the spiraling civilian toll that this conflict has entailed. "Suppressing this essential report on the role of arms trafficking in Central Africa at exactly the moment when the region is going up in flames suggests that the Security Council is less interested in promoting international security than it is in covering its own failures," charged Joost Hiltermann, director of the Human Rights Watch Arms Project. 

The unpublished report, dated October 28 and of which Human Rights Watch obtained a copy, concludes that "arms have continued to flow to the former Rwandan government forces, often from or through South Africa, Angola, Eastern Europe and the former Yugoslavia, and Kinshasa, Zaire." The report also details military training conducted by Rwandan rebel forces in Zaire, and coordinated fundraising efforts among the Hutu refugee population in camps in Zaire and Tanzania for the purpose of purchasing arms.

The International Commission makes several important recommendations to the Security Council: that states producing arms and matriel introduce into their domestic legislation provisions for the prosecution of individuals who violate the international arms embargo; that Zaire prevent, as it had promised it would (in the November 1995 "Cairo Declaration"), armed groups from operating from its territory and to remove "intimidators" from the refugee camps; that the Security Council consider expanding the embargo imposed on the former Rwandan government forces to include a freeze on assets, including bank accounts, of individuals and organizations involved in raising funds to finance the insurgency; and that, if the Security Council decides to impose an arms embargo on Burundi, such an embargo be extended to Burundese insurgents as well.

To date, the international community has paid inadequate attention to the key role arms have played in emboldening rebels ensconced in refugee camps in Zaire. Despite repeated calls by the Security Council, no concrete steps for the deployment of international military observers at airfields in the region have been taken. Recommendations made by the International Commission in its second report in March 1996 to establish mechanisms in the Great Lakes region to monitor and curb the flow of arms have been neglected.

Human Rights Watch calls on the United Nations and the international donor community to undertake the following measures:

1. Publish forthwith the Third Report of the International Commission of Inquiry (Rwanda) and act upon the Commission's conclusions and recommendations.

2. Implement effective controls to enforce the international arms embargo currently in place against the former Rwandan government forces.

3. Impose an arms embargo on Burundi, and undertake steps to ensure that the embargo is enforced equally against both the government and rebel forces based in neighboring countries.

4. Extend the current term of the International Commission of Inquiry for the period of a year and, once an arms embargo has been imposed on Burundi, expand the Commission's mandate to include arms flowing to all sides in the civil war in Burundi. The Commission's term should be extended further at the end of the one-year period if its investigation and the situation in the region require this. The Security Council should also take concrete measures to ensure that member states of the United Nations cooperate with the International Commission when so requested, and provide the Commission with enhanced powers of inquiry and additional resources.

5. Take active steps to deploy forthwith military observers at airfields in eastern Zaire, as well as at airfields and ports in other countries in the region which the International Commission has found to play a role in the trafficking of arms in violation of U.N. arms embargoes, as recommended in Security Council Resolution 997 (1995) and again in Resolution 1053 (1996).

6. Encourage member states of the United Nations to take legal action against their nationals involved in arms trafficking in violation of U.N. arms embargoes, even if said individuals are operating in third countries; and, in the absence of appropriate legislation, encourage governments to enact domestic legislation to prosecute such individuals, as recommended by the International Commission of Inquiry.

7. Encourage states in the Great Lakes region to establish a regional arms register as a way of encouraging transparency about the arms trade and as a first step toward curbing the supply of weapons to armed forces engaged in human rights abuses.

8. Make the unchecked flow of arms into the Great Lakes region a priority, so at to bring about an end to the serious abuses of human rights and international humanitarian law that are taking place.

Human Rights Watch 485 Fifth Avenue New York, NY 10017-6104 TEL: 212/972- 8400 FAX: 212/972-0905 E-mail: hrwnyc@hrw.org. 1522 K Street, N.W. Washington D.C. 20005 TEL: 202/371-6592 FAX: 202/371-0124 E-mail: hrwdc@hrw.org.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 22 on Eastern Zaire (11/13-14)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Nairobi - Calls for a multinational force to intervene in eastern Zaire appear to have been answered, with the appearance of an American advance team of 40 in Entebbe, Uganda. The Security Council, however, has yet to decide on the mandate of a multinational force.

Canada says it will take charge of the multi-national force on the condition that it does not have to disarm or separate out the Interhamwe and former Rwandan forces from the bona fide refugees. The United States government has also refused to accept any mandate of disarmament. 

While the planned arrival of a force has generally been welcomed, the conditions of the Canadian and US governments regarding the mandate are seen by much of the humanitarian community to undermine calls to tackle the root causes of the problem - namely the presence of the heavily armed Hutu extremist groups, the Interahamwe and the former Rwandan forces in the refugee camps in eastern Zaire.

Herman Cohen, former senior US government official and diplomat, said in a BBC interview, there had been conflicting opinions regarding the mandate of an international force and that "the humanitarian option won out over the military one".

Statements from UN organisations - such as UNHCR - European NGOs, the European Union and Oxfam have all previously focused on the need to seperate " intimidators from bona fide refugees" in order to tackle the present crisis in eastern Zaire and restore regional stability.

The Nairobi Summit (November 5), the Security Council (November 10) and the Organisation of African Unity (November 11) also called for "intimidators" to be seperated out. The UNHCR Regional Liaison Representative for Africa said in an address to the OAU (Monday November 11) that it was essential to separate out intimidators from the bona fide refugees, and organise the orderly repatriation of refugees. He said that one issue was clear: "long term and sustainable peace and security cannot be restored in Eastern Zaire and the countries of the Great Lakes as a whole without a rapid and durable solution to the refugee crisis. He said that in order for the repatriation strategy to work "the intimidators, militants and armed militia who, it seems, may have led many of the refugees into the hills and forests surrounding the camps, must once and for all, be separated from those who are genuinely in need of our protection and assistance."

In his speech to the Organisation of African Unity, OAU Secretary General Dr Salim Ahmed Salim said "no meaningful progress had been made" to return the refugees since 1994, and the problem would continue, and possibly be exacerbated, unless conditions for repatriation were met. He said "we look back and, bearing in mind the current catastrophic situation ... one cannot but lament the failure to act more decisively when the opportunity had presented itself". He said inaction had allowed the former Rwandan Army and the Interahamwe to continue holding refugees hostage, leading to killings and counter-killings and the escalation of tension between Zaire and Rwanda.

Rakiya Omaar, co-director of London-based human rights organisation African Rights, told IRIN from Kigali she believed most of the fighting in eastern Zaire is now between the former Rwandan troops or Interahamwe militia and Zairean rebel Alliance for the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo- Zaire (ADFL). Coming from Bukavu and Uvira, she said the planned multinational military intervention was going to be "a thousand times worse than Somalia". International military intervention is Somalia was widely regarded as a failure. Omaar told IRIN that the "inevitable consequence" of a multinational intervention that refused to disarm armed elements would be violence, and a continuation of the problem - "if you are not going to disarm the armed elements, there is absolutely no purpose of coming. If a multinational force comes, it needs military and political preparation for armed engagment." She said that there was also a practical problem of separation, because it depended on a notion that there were two distinct groups, whereas the armed element were "husbands, sons, brother-in-laws and children" of the refugee mass. According to Omaar, there were immediate problems of hunger in Bukavu amongst the local population, where economic activity had been reduced to almost nothing. African Rights has said that the idea of a million people dying within weeks was absurd, and say the problem is one of "guns, grenades and genocidal ideologies, not starvation".

Since the announcement of the intentions of the multinational force, many members of the humanitarian community have expressed concern and scepticism about the mission. Some NGOs are expected to issue statements shortly. An editorial in the New York Times yesterday said "it would be reckless to throw a modest-sized international force between two larger warring armies that have yet to negotiate a cease-fire and that violently disagree about about where these refugees should be fed and settled".

US President Bill Clinton did not publicly respond to calls for the US to back a multinational force until Wednesday, after the Canadian government had said it would take command. US presidential elections on November 5th put the eastern Zaire issue "on hold", and meant that US diplomatic participation on the issue came late. Yesterday White House spokesman said arrangements for military deployment were "moving pretty quickly" because of the "urgency" of the situation, reported AFP.

The United States says it is ready to provide more aid to refugees in eastern Zaire once "mechanisms" have been set up to enable it to be delivered, US Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in Rome yesterday. He said the US had already provided a major share of the humanitarian assistance to the region.

In London, government ministers and defence officials discussed on Wednesday British participation in a possible multinational intervention force to assist relief efforts. A multinational team is due in Kigali today to discuss modalities.

The force, according to the Canadian government, is expected to be between 10,000 and 15,000 - much larger than the orignal 5,000 troops proposed by France and Spain. Botswana, South Africa, Cameroon, Chad, Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Mali and Senegal have offered to contribute, and possibly Zimbabwe.

Nairobi, 14 November 1996, 11:25 GMT

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

299 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Burundi;
Burundi: UN Humanitarian Situation Report (11/7-12)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2320 words


 

Nairobi - The humanitarian impact of the turmoil in eastern Zaire continues to spill over into Burundi. There has been a marked increase in both the number and size of skirmishes between Hutu rebels and Burundian military authorities as rebels continue to attempt to traverse the country and establish new bases of operation in existing camps in Tanzania on the border with Burundi.

Over the past week, fighting or major attacks have been reported in northern, southern and central provinces as well as in the hills overlooking Bujumbura. These attacks have displaced thousands of more people from both major ethnic groups who will require assistance from international humanitarian agencies.

Meanwhile, returnees from the former refugee camps near Uvira continue to arrive at the Gatumba transit camp 15 km west of Bujumbura. However, far fewer have returned than in previous weeks and relief workers have expressed concern about the fate of some 100,000 Burundian refugees missing since fleeing their camps in eastern Zaire last month. Roughly 140,000 of the 220, 000 refugees who fled the Uvira camps were Burundian Hutus. Only 40,000 of them have been accounted for. 

1. General

International concern over the three-year old crisis in Burundi has largely been brushed aside by the more dramatic events unfolding in Zaire. However, there are fears among the humanitarian community in Burundi that both sides of the conflict may take advantage of the situation and mount new offensives, leading to a further deterioration of general security and increased humanitarian needs.

The Third Arusha Regional Summit on Oct. 14 said that all parties to the conflict in Burundi should begin negotiations within a month. That deadline has now passed without any evidence of concrete results. Summit participants threatened to take unspecified further actions against Burundi if the deadline was not met.

The Burundian government has once again claimed that continued attempts by neighboring countries to keep Burundi isolated will be counter productive. A new meeting of regional countries to review economic sanctions imposed on Burundi is scheduled to take place November 14 in Arusha. A spokesman for Buyoya told reporters that it was "unfortunate" that the Burundian government had not even been notified that the meeting would take place, and added that it would serve little purpose unless Burundian government representatives were invited to take part. The meeting had originally been scheduled for November 12.

Despite the regional implications of the Kivu crisis, Burundian government officials have not been invited to official meetings to discuss actions needed to address the situation in eastern Zaire. Spokesmen for Buyoya have told reporters that his government would support possible international military intervention into eastern Zaire if it was for purely humanitarian purposes, but would reserve further comment until additional details were known.

2. Security

On November 11, Hutu rebels attempted to assassinate the governors of Cankuzo and Ruyigi. The attempt was unsuccessful, and neither governor was hurt. The governors, who were travelling in the same vehicle with military escort, were ambushed on RN 13 near the town of Makebuko, 30 km south of Gitega. Casualties suffered by either the attackers or the soldiers guarding the convoy are unclear. This attack against high level Burundian officials was the latest since the governor of Cibitoke was assassinated three weeks ago. Heavy fighting is now reported in Ruyigi province in a front that stretches between the towns of Makebuko and Butaganzwa.

Fighting between the military and rebels has been reported in southern and western communes in Kayanza province. Hundreds of houses and public buildings have been destroyed. There are as yet no reliable reports on the number of additional people displaced by the fighting. However, there were already over 13,000 people displaced in the province in early October. WFP reports that 8, 000 to 10,000 people are now dispersed in Matongo commune alone, while others have joined existing IDP camps that are guarded by the military.

On November 7, Hutu rebels attacked an IDP camp in Matongo commune in Kayanza. Thirty two of the camps residents were killed and 19 injured. On the same day, the nearby village of Kwizamu was destroyed, forcing the residents to flee to the town of Banga now thought to hold 1,500 affected people.

Skirmishes between the military and rebel forces were also reported just outside of Bujumbura, displacing an additional 10,000 people. Insecurity was reported in the communes of Mugamba, Muhuta, Mukike and Buyengero with at least 300 houses burned.

Skirmishes were also reported in southern Gitega and Muramvya. Rebels attacked the Gitega commune of Makebuko on November 11 but the number casualties is still unknown.

CRS reports that insecurity has forced it to temporarily suspend all activities in the diocese of Gitega. The diocese includes all of Gitega province and parts of Muramvya and Karuzi provinces. CRS is the largest distributor of food and non-food items in Gitega, distributing an average of 100 mt of WFP-donated food to 12,000 beneficiaries per month.

On November 4, the Burundian military reported that one of its soldiers was injured when he stepped on a land mine between Gatumba and the Zairean border.

3. Affected Populations

With Uvira now calm and firmly in ADFL hands, aid agencies operating in Burundi are negotiating with Burundian and ADFL authorities to cross the border and enter the town. DHA in Bujumbura is attempting to facilitate access by international humanitarian agencies. Although agencies have now been able to perform rapid needs assessments in Goma and Bukavu, ADFL forces have not permitted aid agencies to travel further south. Zairean government authorities have threatened to withdraw the rights of foreign aid organizations to work in Zaire if they struck deals with the rebels.

It has been almost one month since most of the refugees who were in the Uvira camps have received WFP-distributed food. Many are now dispersed in the hills and high plateau to the west of the town. Others have returned to Uvira and report that food and clean water are scare in the town. Significant levels of malnutrition have been reported among those who have returned to Burundi and registered at the Gatumba transit site.

As of November 11, 12,774 Burundian returnees had registered at the camp since it opened on October 29. Of those returnees, 10,616 have been transferred to their communes of origin, leaving 2,158 returnees remaining in the camp. The number of new arrivals at the camp has slowed considerably since last week. Although UNHCR registered 578 new returnees on November 7 and 369 new returnees on November 10, on most days fewer than 20 new returnees have arrived. During the first week the camp was open, between 2, 000 and 3,000 people were registered per day. With up to 100,000 Burundians remaining on the other side of the border, it is unclear if Burundian refugees are being prevented from returning or if they are refusing to return out of fear for their own security.

4.Humanitarian Coordination

On November 8 representatives from UNHCR, WFP, FAO, IFRC and MSF-Belgium travelled in an armored UN vehicle, with heavy military escort, to Buganda in Cibitoke province. This was the first visit to the province by international humanitarian agencies since the assassination of three ICRC staff members visiting the province in June.

Thousands of former Burundian refugees from the camps in South Kivu returned directly to Cibitoke without passing through the Gatumba transit site. Between 12,000 and 16,000 of them are believed to be living in fields near Buganda, 10 km south of Cibitoke town. They are now being registered by local authorities. With only the limited possessions they were able to carry with them from Zaire, few have shelter or other basic living supplies. There is no clean water or sanitation facilities and the risk of disease is high.

WFP and UNHCR are in the process of arranging distributions of food and non- food relief items to the site to begin soon. Periodic follow up visits to the site by humanitarian agencies are also planned. In a November 12 meeting hosted by UNHCR, the Burundian government welcomed on-going efforts to provide relief to returnees in Cibitoke, and asked humanitarian organizations to consider implementing broader and more permanent programs for affected populations in the province. Given security concerns, no international organization has yet agreed to do so. Three thousand Burundians from Mugina commune in Cibitoke, who had been living in refugee camps in South Kivu, are now encamped in a football stadium in Rugombo, 10 km north of Cibitoke. They have returned to Burundi, via Gatumba, over the last two weeks and have been transferred to the Rugombo site by the Burundian government with the cooperation of UNHCR. Continued insecurity in Mugina has prevented their transfer to their home commune. Although WFP and UNHCR provided the returnees with three months worth of food, jerry cans, soap, sheeting and other basic relief items, they have no access to clean water.

Given the endemic insecurity in the province, On November 9 MSF issued a statement criticizing efforts by the Burundian government and UNHCR to repatriate returnees to Cibitoke. The statement added that many of the returnees were malnourished or ill and continued repatriation of returnees to the region would make it difficult for humanitarian organizations to ensure the returnees well being.

CRS reports that it conducted two distributions in Bubanza through its local church partners. Over a thousand residents of a displaced camp in Nabubu commune were provided with food and non-food relief items. Local diocese workers also distributed food in Bubanza hospital to 215 patients.

A special UNICEF charter flight arrived November 7 from Nairobi with 330, 000 doses of polio vaccine and 440,000 doses of BCG vaccine. The vaccines have been transferred to the Ministry of Health for dispatch to rural health centers. UNICEF says that combined with current stocks, it now has sufficient supplies of BCG and polio vaccine to last four to six months.

IMC reports that it received a month supply of essential drugs for a total of 20,000 consultations at twelve health centers in Rutana and nine in Muyinga.

UNICEF reports that it has supplied ACF with 15 mt of food supplements to be used in supplementary feeding programs in health centers in Kayanza and rural Bujumbura.

5. Impact of Sanctions on Humanitarian Operations

Although humanitarian agencies were granted the right to import fuel in early September, agencies have still not received new supplies. Fuel imported from Rwanda has been in Bujumbura for several weeks, but bureaucratic delays have prevented its release from BP(Fina. Following a decision by the RSCC, all further imports will be done through Tanzania.

Reports indicate that bakeries are running out of flour with bread shortages now common in the city.

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 23 on Eastern Zaire (11/14)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Nairobi - Fierce fighting broke out around Goma overnight and continued today, raising fears that relief efforts would be further hampered.

Rebels opened up with heavy arms and anti-aircraft fire against positions west of the town, targeting a plane which may have also overflown Goma yesterday. The plane then left the area. A BBC reporter in the area said it was the worst violence since the rebels took the town. Some reports said shells were also fired from Mugunga camp near Goma. UNHCR spokesman Peter Kessler said the Interahamwe militia were ordering refugees to gather at Mugunga, in an attempt to prevent their return to Rwanda.

However UNHCR reported that 730 refugees -- probably from the Katale/Kahindo camps -- had defied the Interahamwe and crossed at Mutovu into Rwanda on Wednesday, the biggest number of returnees into Rwanda since fighting broke out last month. 

Hundreds of residents started returning home to Goma today. A journalist in Goma said that people arriving in the town from the west say that Mugunga camp is "well hemmed in" by rebel forces. The journalists told IRIN that an elite force was stationed on the west side, seemingly consisting of Rwandan soldiers. Eyewitnesses coming into the town are reporting that the view from the slopes of Nyaragongo shows life "looking normal" inside the camp, with many refugees still there. Some trade is begining again in Goma town, but there is no main crop to depend on because the expected bean crop has not yet come through. Refugees coming into Goma are described as in reasonably good shape, though with blistered and torn feet. One journalist told IRIN that rebel authorities would broadcast that refugees were arriving, presumably to try and reduce tension between the local population and the refugees. The reporter added that tens of thousands of refugees are reported to be making their way from Kahindo and Katale camps, skirting the lava fields, down towards Goma town.

According to a Reuters report today, 800-1,000 internally displaced people arrived in Goma by boat across Lake Kivu from Sake to the northwest. They reported cases of cholera, as well as fighting between Zairean Mai-Mai militia, ex-FAR troops, the Interahamwe and rebels. A BBC reporter said the Zaireans, who came with a few belongings, had spoken of appalling conditions and heavy clashes in the area.

AFP reported that Tutsi rebels turned away a delegation from Medecins sans Frontieres attempting to enter Bukavu from Rwanda. It said aid agencies had made no headway with rebels in the South Kivu area of which Bukavu is the capital. NGO reports from Bukavu described the situation as "worrying" with a possible epidemic of diarrhoea, particularly among small children.

A UN relief flight funded by Switzerland arrived in Kinshasa today, using an AN-124 aircraft supplied by Emercom (Russia) to bring 100 MT of UNICEF supplies from Copenhagen, including 10,000 blankets, medical supplies and 31 tonnes of milk and high energy biscuits. The flight was arranged by DHA's Military and Civil Defence Unit.

Zaire lashed out at the world community today, accusing it of indifference and saying any aid should be delivered to the refugees' home countries. "The refugees who live today in the east of Zaire belong to states run by governments which cannot with any excuse, duck their responsibility to accept their compatriots inside their borders," deputy premier Mutombo Bakafwa Nsenda told an FAO summit in Rome.

President Mobutu was due to meet an OAU delegation today in the southern French town of Roquebrune-Cap Martin where he is recovering from cancer surgery. The delegation is led by Kenyan foreign minister Kalonzo Musyoka.

NGOs today continued to press for disarming Hutu militias and ex-FAR troops. Oxfam said the proposed multinational force must have a mandate to carry this out. "The lessons of the last two years have been that humanitarian aid is no substitute for political action," it said. MSF said it was " disappointed" that the force was not intended to "separate the criminals" and unless this happened, it was difficult to see how the refugees could be repatriated.

CNN said in a report today that aid agencies in Rwanda felt the challenge to a multinational force was to separate genuine refugees from the armed Hutu militia and former Rwandan forces. CNN's Christiane Amanpour said aid agencies were concerned that massive quantities of aid were not the solution, but that the international community should try and "break the lock" and stop the armed groups holding the refugees hostage.

Rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila today warned of a Somali-like situation in eastern Zaire if the multinational force was "ill-intentioned" or sought to "Balkanize the country". He also told reporters in Goma that use of the local airport was "negotiable", but that foreign soldiers could use airports in Rwanda and Uganda instead. Meanwhile, reports from Zaire near the Rwandan border town of Gisenyi said the rebels had set up an FM radio station called Radio Star.

Canada has called on countries interested in contributing troops to the multinational force to meet in New York later today to discuss a "plan of action". A foreign ministry statement said participants would include Britain, France, the USA and "key aid donors". An advance team of 24 Canadian armed forces personnel, meanwhile, would head for the region today and another 250- strong military team, including doctors, engineers and communications specialists, was on standby. The US sent a team to Kigali today for discussions. The UN Security Council was expected to approve the mandate and deployment of the force by Friday.

French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette said today the force could be ready for deployment by the weekend, while his spokesman Yves Doutriaux said a European should be among three deputy commanders of the force. He added that France would "secure the airport at Bukavu". Senior government sources in Britain indicated it would send between 2,000 and 4,000 troops to eastern Zaire. Defence Secretary Michael Portillo speaking on the BBC today made no mention of numbers, but said the operation should quickly be handed over to African forces.

As a US airborne infantry battalion prepared to fly into eastern Zaire next week, two US relief teams were prevented from entering the region, according to a State Department statement on Wednesday. Zairean rebels in Goma told a Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) to return to Rwanda minutes after it had arrived, and a second group was turned back from Bukavu. A third team of military and civilian officials meanwhile, led by US coordinator for Rwanda and Burundi Richard Bogosian, was in Uganda en route for Rwanda and eastern Zaire.

The US contingent of the Canadian-led intervention force would comprise some 1,000 troops to be deployed in the Goma area and up to another 3,000 would support the operation in other countries, according to US officials quoted by AFP. The troops, who would be in Zaire for about four months, would be equipped to defend themselves under "robust" rules of engagement similar to the US operation in Bosnia.

WFP said its current stock level in the eastern Zaire region amounted to 71, 358 mt, enough to feed 1.5 million people (including 1.25 million refugees and 250,000 affected Zaireans) for about 50 days. As another potential refugee crisis unfolded in Burundi, the UN indicated supplies there were running low. There were 63 days' worth of emergency food rations left, enough for 250,000 beneficiaries. Burundi's prime minister told WFP executive director Ms Bertini on Tuesday that his country had given clearance for international organisations to enter eastern Zaire from Burundi.

UN special envoy Raymond Chretien was due in Burundi tomorrow, a UN source said, and Humanitarian Coordinator Sergio Vieira de Mello was due in Kigali today. The Deputy Humanitarian Coordinator, Martin Griffiths, is in Kampala this evening en route to Kinshasa.

Three armed raiders were killed by Ugandan troops in the Kasese area on the border with Zaire Wednesday, a Ugandan official said. Martin Aliker, Minister of State for foreign affairs, told a news conference they were members of gang made up of Zairean soldiers and Ugandan dissidents which had attacked a Ugandan military installation near the border earlier this week. He said the attackers were driven back into Zaire, adding he was unsure whether the attack had been sanctioned by Kinshasa or at a local level. WFP described the situation around Kasese as tense following the attack which reportedly involved 200 Zairean troops and Ugandan dissidents. It said several thousand Ugandans were displaced as a result of the attack.

Australia today announced a financial aid package of 2.6 million Australian dollars for the refugee crisis in Zaire, 100,000 of which will go to DHA IRIN. Other contributors to DHA IRIN since its inception in October 1995 are Sweden, Norway, UK, USA, Belgium, Netherlands and Israel.

Nairobi, 14 November 1996, 16:15 GMT

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
Election Postponement Suggestion Turned Down


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia today turned down a suggestion from South African President, Nelson Mandela, that the presidential and parliamentary elections due in the country on Monday be postponed so as to accomodate opposition United National Independence Party of Kenneth Kaunda - which opted to boycott the elections.

Electoral Commission chairman, Justice Bobby Bwalya, told reporters in Lusaka today that he had told President Mandela's emissary, Justice Richard Goldstone, that there was no law in Zambia now that would allow the postponment of the November 18 general elections unless Zambia had a state of emergency in place.

Even then, he explained, the postponement could only be made at the prerogative of the republican President. 

"We think we should not have a state of emergency. As a commission we feel the political situation does not warrant a state of emergency," he said.

He revealed that South African President Mandela had assigned Justice Goldstone, a member of the Constitutional Court of South Africa to meet Justice Bwalya - as the chairperson of the Zambian Electoral Commission to find a way upon which the elections could be postponed.

He found that there was no such law allowing the postponement and Justice Goldstone promised to report back to President Mandela.

Justice Bwalya said many political parties have already spent a lot of money in preparing for the elections and it would be unfair to postpone the elections.

The Commission, he said, has already put in place all necessary arrangements to ensure the success of the elections and assured all political parties participating in the elections that all materials needed in the exercise have already been delivered to provinces.

This year's general elections are the most heavily contested ever in the history of the country adding that there are five presidential candidates, 11 political parties with a total number of 606 parliamentary candidates.

Three candidates have been returned unopposed on the MMD ticket in Pambashe, Luapula and Sikongo constituences.

The eleven political parties are Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD) fielding 150 candidates, Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) 142, National Party (NP) 99, National Lima Party (NLP) 83, Agenda for Zambia 11, National Congress 4, United National Independence Party (UNIP).

Others are Movement for Democratic Process(MDP), two, Liberal Progressive Front (LPF), one, Real Democracy Party(RDP), one, Party for Poor People (PPP) one; and Independents, 96.

He said the grabbed voters cards will in no way affect the elections because they are only 15,000 compared to a total of 2.2 million registered voters.

Voting will commence at 06.00 hours to 17.00 hours and counting will be done at polling stations while results will be submitted to the electoral commission in Lusaka by electoral officers immediately after they are certified correct.

He warned people intending to disrupt the elections that the law will take its course and culprits brought to book.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Business and Finance;
Zambian Utility Agrees With Manufacturers


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) and the state owned Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) are approaching agreement on reducing the 50 per cent penalty charge imposed on industrial producers.

"We have had fruitful discussions with ZESCO and they have agreed to look at the manufacturing sector again. I must say that they have been very co- operative. The surcharge cannot go on at the present rate," said ZAM chairman Mark O'Donnell in an interview yesterday.

O'Donnell had earlier appealed to the government to reorganise the energy sector and assess its impact on Zambian industry.

O'Donnell said last month that about 40 big energy users in the manufacturing industry were in danger of closing operations if ZESCO persisted in imposing the 50 per cent surcharge on industry.

"Our focus is to come up with some penalty which is more agreeable to both parties," said O'Donnell.

Sports - General;
Road Racing: Road Race Championships Set


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Amateur Athletics Association (ZAAA) will this Saturday host the annual National Road Race championships in Chililabombwe to pick athletes who will represent Zambia in similar meets in Macau, Angola and Mozambique all scheduled for next month.

In a press release dated October 30, 1996 ZAAA chairman, Phil Kubombela, said the championships will commence at 11.00 hours and registration and other formalities will be conducted at the Community Development offices located opposite Konkola Stadium. 

"By copy of this memorandum, the Coaching and Technical Committees are requested to liaise with Konkola Amateur Athletics Club officials with the marking of the route," Kubombela said, adding: "The distances are Men 1, 200 metres and Women 6, 000 metres."

Participation fee for each athlete is K1,000, however teams from outside Chililabombwe are expected to make their own accomodation arrangements.

But some athletes have expressed misgivings over the ZAAA's decision to pick athletes for the three international meets during the championship , wondering what criteria will be used as only two athlete can go for each meet.

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Coach Fired: FAZ Clique Behind The Move


BYLINE: Goodson Machona and Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Lusaka - Some members of the FAZ interim committee have been named in a plot that culminated in yesterday's sacking of national team trainer, Roald Poulsen, Post investigations have revealed.

Sports ministry permanent secretary, Arthur Yoyo, announced in a press statement yesterday that "time has come for Mr Poulsen to return home to Denmark and pursue other professional career avenues".

"My ministry therefore has agreed to release the coach following the expiry of his contract at the end of October, 1996," Yoyo said, adding: "This stand has been taken with due consideration to the tasks that lie ahead for the Zambia national team, in both the Africa and World Cup engagements."

But according to the investigations, the "gang" which includes interim chairman Michael Chiti, treasurer Musa Kasonka Jr and technical sub-committee chairman Whiteson Chiti had been working round the clock to have Poulsen fired and last week Wednesday, they met at the National Provident Fund (NPF) sports club in Lusaka where they decided to replace the Dane with Profund Warriors coach Boniface Simutowe, Coaches Association of Zambia vice-chairman Lewis Shambulo, former Power Dynamos coach Jericho Shinde and either Botswana Meat Corporation football club coach Dick Chama or former national team coach Samuel "Zoom" Ndhlovu as head coach. 

Simutowe and some FAZ officials were expected to travel to Botswana on Tuesday to talk to Chama and Ndhlovu over the job.

The investigations further revealed that another trip is planned for Zimbabwe to talk to Jones Chilengi and Webster Chikabala and another to Swaziland to cajole Michael Musonda and Jani Simulambo should the Twsana- based coaches refuse to come.

But both Chiti and Kasonka Jr denied in separate interviews yesterday that there was no such a plot.

"How can I plot to remove Poulsen when I have just written to the government to renew Poulsen's contract," argued Chiti.

They however admitted that they were at the NPF club on Wednesday but denied that they had gone there to plot against Poulsen.

"Yes, we went to the NPF club on Wednesday and yes, I talked to both Simutowe and Shambulo. But my being seen with them does not mean that we were plotting against Poulsen," Chiti said.

Kasonka Jr added: "It's a total fabrication. To say just because we were there then we were plotting to remove Poulsen is unfair."

But a source at Anchor House disclosed in an interview yesterday that the item of discussion was Poulsen's fate.

"They spent the whole night plotting to replace Poulsen with Simutowe, Shambulo, and Shinde" the source said.

According to the source, Poulsen could have been fired before the match between Congo and Zambia.

Prior to the meeting Simutowe who had already been tipped for the job had been following the training of the national team at the BP Sports Club in anticipation of him taking over as coach.

And, on the day the national team left for Sudan, Simutowe and Shambulo arrived at the Lusaka International Airport as early as 07:00 hours with packed bags and ready to lead the 19-man squad to the World Cup first leg encounter in Pointe Noire.

Chiti did not deny this fact and disclosed that Poulsen had actually asked him about the presence of the duo at the airport.

"Poulsen asked me why Simutowe and Shambulo were at the airport," Chiti confessed. "I told him they were probably there to see the team off."

But the source disclosed that Poulsen was aware of the plot and that is why he arrived at the airport wearing a suit instead of the usual track suit. Poulsen was anticipating FAZ would drop him on the last minute.

Chiti did not dispute this fact either.

"I asked the coach why he was smartly dressed but he just mumbled," Chiti said.

In a desperate attempt to "kill" the story of the plot, Kasonka pleaded with The Post not to publish it.

"I am prepared to trade a story with you if you tell me your source," Kosonka pleaded.

LANGUAGE: English

Science and Health;
Italians Donate K7.5m For Cholera Eradication


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - The Italian government yesterday donated K7.5 million to the Ministry of Health to help eradicate Cholera.

Making the donation in Lusaka yesterday, Italian Ambassador to Zambia, Margherita Costa, said Zambia can eradicate Cholera if she is committed to a consistent community awareness campaign on basic hygiene. 

Receiving the donation, deputy permanent secretary for the Ministry of Health, Dr Kashiwa Bulaya, said the donation was timely as the country was approaching the rainy season.

"This is basically the rainy season when Cholera invades most of our people in the rural areas," Bulaya said.

He also noted that cholera was a preventable disease if people were well educated on conditions of hygiene.

And epidemiologist at the Ministry of Health, Dr Roy Chimba, in an interview yesterday, assured that the recent outbreak of cholera in Lusaka was under control.

A cholera outbreak recently ravaged Lusaka in which more than twenty-four were reportedly admitted at the Cholera centre where a few deaths were also recorded.

The outbreak was attributed to shortage of water in Lusaka.
