306 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
President, Electoral Commission Differ Over Postponement


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba and the Electoral Commission have contradicted each other on who, between them, has the powers to postpone the disputed elections scheduled for November 18.

The President on his last leg of the campaign meetings in Eastern Province yesterday told a campaign rally in Lundazi that he had "no powers under the Constitution to postpone an election".

President Chiluba said only the Electoral Commission had powers to postpone the elections under the electoral provisions. 

The President's remarks come amid wide speculation that the elections were going to be postponed following a consultative meeting he held with the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) chairman, South African President Nelson Mandela, on how best to resolve the country's political impasse.

At a joint press conference with President Mandela in Pretoria on Tuesday, President Chiluba indicated that the polls would go ahead but left the door open for possible postponement, saying:"For now I would say 'yes'(they will go ahead on schedule) but let's see if we can consult."

But Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda, at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday, said there was no justification for the elections to be put off. He said a lot of money had already been spent on preparations for the polls.

The Electoral Commission yesterday, however, maintained it had no powers to postpone the elections.

"We have no powers under the Electoral Act or under the Constitution to postpone elections. The only person who can do so is only the President and only when there is a state of emergency, that is when there is a war or the situation is not conducive or the whole nation is, torn to pieces," vice- chairman of the Electoral Commission, Mebeelo Kalima, told participants at a meeting organised by Rainbow Monitors yesterday at Lusaka's Holiday Inn Garden Court Hotel . "There is none at the moment and so the elections are going ahead."

But Lusaka lawyer Sakwiba Sikota, in an interview yesterday, said the prevailing political situation in the country clearly indicated a crisis hence President Chiluba's trip to South Africa.

"A state of emergency is not only where there is visible armed insurrection. It could also be in a situation where there are widespread floods or other natural calamities," Sikota said, adding: "In the current Constitutional impasse of such proportions, a state of emergency would not be misplaced."

But vice-chairman of the Legal Resource Foundation(LRF) and Lusaka lawyer John Sangwa charged that the government was only playing games over the issue. He said the issue of elections was a political one within the President's jurisdiction.

"This is a political question where the President can postpone the elections. If there is no legal framework to allow him to do that what can stop him from creating one when he is the one who announced the date of elections?" Sangwa asked in an interview yesterday.

Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) chairman, George Kunda, said the independent Electoral Commission has powers vested in them to postpone elections if Parliament is dissolved.

"The commission can postpone the elections provided that they are the ones who issued the initial statutory order prescribing November 18 as the election date," Kunda said in a telephone interview from Ndola yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
Police Say Collecting Voters' Cards An Offence


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Police spokesman Francis Musonda is insisting that people collecting voters cards are committing an offence despite opnions by various lawyers.

"We once again wish to reiterate as a police service that requesting people to surrender their voters cards is an offence under Act No 2 of 1991," Musonda said. 

Musonda's statement comes in the wake of several legal opinions that it is not an offence for anyone to surrender a voter's card because such a card was being given out of one's free will. But Musonda referred to regulations 61(b) and 62 of the electoral (registration of voters) act which he said provide that "it is an offence to be in possession of another person's voter's card or to ask or require another person to surrender his or her voter's card given to such other person in pursuance of the regulations."

The Police spokesman added: "Any person who is guilty of an offence against these regulations shall be liable on conviction to a fine or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year or both such fine and such imprisonment."

But UNIP has defied police warnings against collecting of voters cards from people and has continue with the exercise. UNIP secretary general Sebastian Zulu said people were surrendering the cards out of their own free will.

Meanshile Musonda has denied allegations by the opposition that some senior police officers are being partisan.

"These people (opposition) allege that the police are being partisan and yet part of our civic responsibility is to educate the Zambian society on their rights," Musonda said yesterday.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambian Bank Faces Collapse


BYLINE: Matsautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - The Bank of Zambia (BOZ) faces collapse unless the foreign judgment against it is set aside by the Lusaka High Court.

In a judgement passed in the English courts, Bank of Zambia has been ordered to pay Camdex US$120 million for non service of a debt advanced to the bank.

The judgment against the Bank of Zambia by the English court was finally registered in the High Court of Zambia on October 8, by Shamwana and Company in which the Bahamas based Camdex is claiming its US$120 million pay back. 

Now the Bank is pleading with the Lusaka High Court that it sets aside this judgement because implementing it would totally bankrupt the Central Bank.

Bank of Zambia has found itself in the mess after it sold to Camdex the debt it has owed the Central Bank of Kuwait since 1988. The debt was expected to mature in May, 1989 but the Zambian Central bank failed to honour it forcing Camdex to service it on their behalf.

At the time of an agreement for assignment between Camdex and the central bank of Kuwait, the debt was pegged at US$68,637,772.036 but has now increased to more than US$120m. This is the money Camdex is now battling to get off Bank of Zambia.

In an affidavit filed on October 18 in the Lusaka High Court by acting deputy bank governor Situmbeko Musokotwane under case number 1996/HP/4107 the bank argues that Camdex bought the debt knowing the conditions for the debt buy-back and that under the Paris Club arrangement, the central bank cannot treat Camdex differently.

"On the strength of the foregoing I respectfully submit that an enforcement of the judgment against BOZ will be contrary to public policy in the Republic. It is in the national interest that registration of the foreign judgment by Camdex be set aside," Musokotwane says in his affidavit opposing the registration of an English court judgment in Zambia.

He adds: "the alternative should this court be minded to find for the plaintiff, then the defendant prays that settlement should be consistent with either the Paris Club or debt buy back."

The Bank is pleading that bailiffs should not be sent to the Central Bank as this would cripple their operations.

And during the hearing in England BOZ through lawyers Lovell White Durant fought the court ruling in favour of Camdex who were represented by Baker Mackenzie but the Court of Appeal dismissed the case on April 4, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
'Full Bench' Definition Eludes Some Judges


BYLINE: Mukalya Nampito, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Lusaka - Some Supreme Court judges yesterday differed with the lawyers of the opposition parties petitioning President Frederick Chiluba's nomination in next Monday's presidential elections on what constitutes "a full bench".

Four of the five judges defined a full bench as a sitting by any uneven number of Supreme Court judges but the petitioners, lawyers argued that it is a sitting of the highest uneven number of all serving Supreme Court judges.

Deputy Chief Justice, Bonaventure Bweupe, justices Weston Muzyamba and Matthew Chaila argued that it was in order for five judges to hear the petition and the injunction because they constituted a full bench and this was in line with what they (judges and lawyers) had earlier agreed upon in the chambers the previous day.

But the lawyers for the petitioners led by state counsel Edward Shamwana, Professor Patrick Mvunga, Sakwiba Sikota and Ostoph Dzekedzeke refused to accept the court's definition, insisting that a full bench according to the Constitution meant all the judges of the Supreme Court. 

"My submission is that a full bench should mean all the judges of the Supreme Court and not what appears to have been accepted as five," Shamwana said after justices Bweupe, Chaila, Muzyamba, David Lewanika and Dennis Chirwa walked into the court room.

Justice Bweupe asked Shamwana whether a full bench did not in fact mean an uneven number of either 3, 5, 7 or 9 to which Shamwana vehemently refused insisting that the law was clear on the composition of a full bench and that there was no theory about it.

Shamwana referred the judges to Article 92 (5) and Article 41 of the Constitution which makes reference to a specific requirement of the full bench of the Supreme Court.

"This is not a theoretical matter, it is a fact. The Supreme Court consists of 9 judges. We are talking about a full bench which now is 7. Article 42 is quite clear," Shamwana said.

The five judges were supposed to hear two petitions by four oppositions parties on President Frederick Chiluba's nomination as presidential candidate and an injunction to restrain the November 18 elections from taking place before the court hears the petition.

Bweupe observed that going by petitioners definition the full bench at the moment could only be 7 because two (to make 9) had not yet been appointed and asked what would happen if one of the 7 recused himself and another was sick.

But Solicitor General, Sam Chisulo, representing the Attorney General and the Elections Commission, said the arguments being presented in court yesterday had been presented on Tuesday before Justice Bweupe in chambers. He said they (State) had asked for a full bench and the petitioners asked for 5.

Then Justice Bweupe said there had been a suggestion in chambers that the deputy chief justice should recuse himself.

"In fact it was made known to me that the other side would be comfortable if the chief justice sat on the matter," Chisulo said.

Justice Bweupe said: "Perhaps I wrongly excluded the Chief Justice but I was of the view that having been the returning officer, he would not sit in this matter."

Sikota clarified that the position of the defence was that all the judges of the Supreme Court should sit without making specific preference to any particular judge.

Bweupe,however, asked whether the Chief Justice, Matthew Ngulube who had been the returning officer could hear the case, to which Shamwana said the job he had performed was a clerical function that could have no effect on this hearing.

Another lawyer for the petitioners, Dzekedzeke, said the purpose of asking for seven judges is to emphasise the gravity of the matter.

"I cannot visualise a situation where it can be impossible to recall a judge who is on leave," Dzekedzeke said.

Justice Muzyamba then said they had no difficulties in adjourning the matter to another day whilst justice Chaila cynically added: "even to next year."

Shamwana maintained that it had been made abundantly clear that this is a national issue and what he had requested was what the law said and he submitted that it must be followed.

After a 30 minute adjournment, the five judges conceded to the definition of the petitioners' lawyers and adjourned the case to today.

"For this reason we adjourn the matter to tomorrow (today) at 09:00 hours so that I can be able to recall those who are on leave," Justice Bweupe said.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


310 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zambia;
Court Rejects Opposition Calls To Halt Polls


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1322 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (pana) - The Zambian supreme court Thursday, dismissed as " premature" a petition filed by five opposition parties challenging President Frederick Chiluba's eligibility to run for president in elections planned for the Nov. 18.

A full supreme court bench of seven judges made the ruling on a preliminary issue raised by the court itself on whether it had powers to hear the petition before the elections, as required by law.

The opposition parties asked the court to order postponement of the elections and initiate a probe into Chiluba's nationality. 

This is in line with the new Zambian law which requires that only citizens born in Zambia of Zambian parentage qualify to run for the office of president.

The opposition claims that Chiluba and his parents do not meet the criteria.

Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube in dismissing the petition, said that it was premature, and ran counter to the provisions of the electoral law, according to which "a petition shall be filed within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in."

Four parties filed the petition on Monday. They were later joined by the Zambia Democratic Congress which also said it had doubts about Chiluba's claim to be a bona fide Zambian.

The others are the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) , of former President Kenneth Kaunda, the Liberal Progressive Front, the National Congress and the Agenda for Zambia parties.

The court also noted that delaying the right to petition was not denying the right to petition.

"To knock a presidential candidate out of the race would deprive the citizens their right to seek and form the next government since there is no provision to allow for new nominations," Ngulube said.

The court, which dismissed the petition with costs, advised the petitioners to file a suit within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in as the law required.

The lawyers for the petitioners had earlier on Thursday argued that the electoral act clearly stated that an aspiring presidential candidate must meet the requisites of the presidential qualifications and must comply before the event and not "subsequent" to the event.

The lead counsel, Edward Shawana, said the electoral act was inconsistent in that it allows a presidential candidate who does not meet all the requirements of the act to contest for presidency as he/she can only be petitioned within 14 days after the new president has been sworn-in.

"To stop the applicants from filing in a petition at this stage will be denying them their constitutional rights to do so... but are denied under the electoral act," Shawana said.

On the government side, the Solicitor-General, Sam Chisulo, said the petition be dismissed because by allowing the petition it will be "impossible" to hold an election since there will always be a multiplicity of petitions.

In another development, one of the lawyers for the petitioners, Mainza Chona, disclosed to the court after the ruling that two of the witnesses they intended to call to challenge Chiluba's citizenship claims received parcel bombs earlier in the day.

The lawyer said the devices were handed over to the police who defused them.

Ngulube said the matter will be looked into if a fresh petition filed after the elections.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Egypt Puts Up Boutros-Ghali For Re-Election


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

NEW RORK, (PANA) - Egypt has formally submitted the candidature of Boutros Boutros-Ghali for re-election as the secretary-general of the United Nations.

In a letter to the president of the Security Council, Egypt's permanent representative to the U.N., Nabil Elaraby, expressed the hope that the council would reflect "the will of the majority" in its decision on which candidate to recommend to the General Assembly.

The 185-member assembly elects a secretary-general on the recommendation of the 15-member council. 

"The candidature of Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali enjoys wide support by the majority of the U.N. membership," the Egyptian ambassador said in the letter, dated Nov. 12.

"As you know, two major regional organizations, the Organization of African Unity and the League of Arab States, have endorsed H.E. Dr. Boutros Boutros- Ghali for a second full term as secretary-general of the U.N.," he added.

At a private lunch in New York on Tuesday to discuss the election procedure, the council agreed that informal consultations on the election would start next Monday.

The United States has vowed to bar Boutros-Ghali, using its veto if necessary, from a second term on accusations of not pursuing enough reforms at the world body.

But other veto-wielding members of the council--China, France, Britain and Russia--support Boutros-Ghali's re-election.

Though the secretary-general, whose current five-year term will expire on Dec. 31, is the only official candidate for the election, other names have been mentioned in recent times.

They include the UN under-secretary-general for peace-keeping operations, Kofi Annan, a Ghanaian, the president of the International Peace Academy in New York, Olara Otunnu of Uganda and the secretary-general of the Islamic Conference, Hamid Algabid of Niger.

Meanwhile, members of the council have agreed that if the U.S. vetoes Boutros-Ghali as threatened, Africa should be given the chance to produce a list of other candidates for consideration before candidates from other regions are allowed to come in.

"The understanding is that Africa deserves a second term," a source close to the council said.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


Zaire;
Nearly 200,000 Refugees Could Die Within A Month


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ROME, Italy (PANA) - Some 195,000 refugees could die within a month unless there is "massive intervention" in eastern Zaire now, a ranking United Nations official said Thursday.

Catherine Bertini, the executive director of the World Food Programme, said in a news conference here that 80,000 children were affected by starvation in the region. 

"Children are particularly at risk especially those who have started breast- feeding," she said.

The refugees are fleeing the ongoing three-way fight between the Zairean army, Rwandan Hutu militia and Zairean Tutsi rebels.

Bertini, who is attending the World Food Summit, said a multinational force which is being readied for deployment in eastern Zaire will have to first separate the Hutu militia from the refugees if food delivery is to be immediate and effective.

Her agency has enough food for the 1.2 million refugees who are fleeing northward from Goma, westward from Bukavu and Uvira, and south from Uvira toward Fizi.

The problem is, she said, "there is not a clear indication of where they are".

She said that two United States aircraft from Entebbe, Uganda flying low to locate the refugees, suspended their operations after being fired on Wednesday.

However, the agency has a C-130 Hercules military aircraft standing by to begin airdrops as soon as the refugees are located and "as soon as it is safe" to conduct the operation.

The agency has food prepositioned in Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda and Tanzanian.

The assistant executive director of the World Food Programme, Jean-Jacques Graisse, told PANA that the agency could make deliveries to Bukuvu and Uvira so long as it gets permission from Burundi.

However, he said, many of the agencies vehicles have been stolen by retreating Zairean government troops.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 14, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Finance Minister Resigns Over Bank Malpractice


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Swazi Finance Minister Derek von Wissell resigned Wednesday because he could no longer clean up the mess at a state- owned bank.

Wissel, the first ever cabinet minister to resign, quit 15 hours after a reshuffle Tuesday, that relegated him to the lesser portfolio of tourism and communications. 

Rather than accept the new posting, he quit on a matter of principle.

"The only conclusion I can draw from being moved in a new portfolio is that government no longer supports the work I started at SDSB (Swaziland Development and Savings Bank)," he said in press release.

"It would be impossible for me to be part of such a government, and I have therefore resigned from cabinet with immediate effect."

He said in his pursuit of his duties at SDSB "my conscience refused to allow me to acquiesce to the abuse of tax payers' money and even corrupt practices...My actions obviously created enemies for me in so-called 'high places'."

Senegal;
Senegal Pledges Troops For Zaire Peace Mission


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegal will contribute a battalion, consisting of 500 troops to the neutral multinational force in the Great Lakes region, Canadian ambassador Wilfried-Guy Licari revealed Wednesday in Thies, 70 km (44 miles) east of the Senegalese capital.

Licari, who was attending a presentation of medical equipment, commended " the great political will" of the Senegalese government in contributing troops to the Canadian-led force. 

Besides Senegal, six other African countries--Ethiopia, Eritrea, Congo, Cameroon, Mali and South Africa--have announced their desire to contribute troops to the force to provide humanitarian assistance to the more than one million refugees in eastern Zaire.

Licari said Canada decided to take the command of the deployment operation of the neutral multinational force following "diplomatic hesitations" by the international community, adding that consultations are continuing "between various countries" for the setting up of the force.

In a cabinet meeting on Tuesday, the Senegalese government expressed its total support to the establishment of the force.

November 14, 1996


Ethiopia;
Three Egyptians Appeal Against Death Sentences


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Three Egyptian fundamentalists of the opposition Gama'a Al-Islamiya, who were sentenced to death in September for involvement in an abortive attempt on the life of President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa in June 1995, have appealed to the Ethiopian federal supreme court.

A spokesman of the Addis Ababa central high court, which found the defendants guilty, was quoted by the government press Thursday as saying that the Ethiopian defence lawyer for the convicts had submitted to the court a 13- point deputation appealing its verdict of Sept. 21, 10 days after the sentence was passed. 

If the sentence is upheld by the supreme court, the death penalty will only be carried out after the final approval of President Negasso Gidada.

The three convicts had been identified earlier as Sofit Hassen Abdul Kabi, Abdul Karim Naddi and Al-Arib Sadik. They had pleaded not guilt to the charges and were tried in camera beginning April 1996.

They were found guilty of complicity in the attempted assassination of Mubarak and the killing of two policemen on duty at the time of the incident on June 26, 1995, in which three civilians were also wounded. The trio were also charged on smuggling fire arms, including grenade launchers, through the Sudan Airways office in Addis Ababa, into the country as part of the assassination plot.

The three convicts were said to be part of an 11-man Egyptian hit squad sponsored by the Gama'a Al-Islamiya, trained in Pakistan. Nine of the men entered Ethiopia with Yemeni, Sudanese and Egyptian passports to assassinate Mubarak as he flew into Addis Ababa from Cairo to attend an OAU summit.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


316 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 14, 1996


East African;
Zairean Troops Attack Uganda.


BYLINE: Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Zairean troops backed by Ugandan rebels Wednesday attacked the Ugandan border towns of Mpondwe and Bwera in south western district of Kasese.

Uganda's Foreign Affairs Minister, Martin Aliker told an impromptu news conference Wednesday night that a Uganda Peoples' Defence Force platoon at Karambi, seven kilometers (4.4 miles) northwest of Bwera and Mpondwe border posts had been attacked.

He said that the attackers were a combination of Zairean forces and some Ugandan dissidents trained in Zaire. However, the minister could not name the dissident groups involved in the attack. 

"We do not know the names but we are aware that Ugandan dissidents were involved" Aliker said.

He said that the raiders were repulsed and three of them were killed but " shelling has continued sporadically most of the day from the Zairean side".

Following the attack, Uganda sent heavy reinforcements to the scene from the nearby towns of Mbarara and Fort Portal.

Eye witness reports from Kasese say that the rebels started shooting at around 7.30 a.m local time before taking the customs post 30 minutes later.

Scared residents claimed that about 50 people were feared dead including the headmaster of Karambi Secondary School and some of his students.

Aliker could not explain why Zairean troops had attacked Uganda now when they are embroiled in the Banyamurenge crisis in the east of their country. " We do not know. But I think it is sheer madness for Zaire to attack us from that side. It is a diversionary attack" he stressed.

He also said that he could not confirm whether the attack was sanctioned by the government of Zaire, or it was a result of general lawlessness that is prevailing in eastern Zaire.

The minister said Uganda would not sever diplomatic relations with Zaire because they were not aware that the Zaire government had authorized the attack.

"We really sympathize with the government of Zaire because of this Banyamurenge crisis. And we are aware there is no government in eastern Zaire, so we cannot sever the ties before we have proof" he said.

The Banyamurenge rebels, ethnic Zairean Tutsi militants, launched attacks in the eastern parts of the country nearly a month ago, with the alleged backing of Rwanda and Burundi.

The Zairean government has accused Uganda, too, of helping the Banyamurenge and parliament in Kinshasa passed a resolution calling for the severance of diplomatic relations with all the three countries.


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


317 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
World Bank, ADB Against Agricultural Subsidies


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ROME, Italy (PANA) - The heads of the African Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank are opposed to agricultural subsidies currently being applied by governments in Africa and elsewhere.

In plenary Thursday at the ongoing World Food Summit, the presidents of both institutions said subsidies had contributed to lower incomes.

"Apparently well-intentioned but misguided practices" aimed at cheap food prices for urban consumers through subsidies had only exacerbated the problem of lower farm incomes, ADB President Omar Kabbaj said. 

Subsidies, he added, "contributed to the marginalization of the rural economy and to declines in the income and welfare of rural dwellers."

And World Bank President James Wolfensohn told a news conference "no country, in the long term, can live with subsidies."

Earlier he told world leaders at the summit that governments "should reduce heavy intervention in the rural economy and concentrate on creating an economic and regulatory environment that fosters agricultural growth."

Both Kabbaj and Wolfensohn said that the reduction of subsidies tended to nudge farmers to areas which are more efficient.

To compliment this, both banks have adopted new approaches to rid the poor countries of the worst types of poverty, providing mocro-financing to allow for easy credit for farmers.

Kabbaj said ADB provides micro-credit to poor and vulnerable groups and has been giving credit to national and sub-regional development finance bodies so they could, in turn, lend to small and medium-scale enterprises.

Both banks have also been working with or have policies in place to collaborate with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), who have considerable experience in implementing poverty alleviation programmes.

"We will be making further strides in this area, with the finalization of a new micro-enterprise policy which will set the framework for extending appropriate credit to the poorest groups, using financial intermediaries such as NGOs and other grassroots organizations," Kabbaj said.

"We have initially set aside some 20 million dollars (U.S) for this type of support."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


318 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Airways Fires 250 More Workers


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria airways has sacked 250 more workers less than one year after firing 720 others as part of efforts to improve the efficiency of the financially troubled national carrier.

The airline's spokesman, Chris Aligbe, said in a statement in Lagos Thursday that the 250 were sacked either for "indiscipline or declining productivity, excessive leave and absenteeism." 

The sack "cuts across the senior and junior cadre" of staff, he said.

A combination of debt burden and maintenance problem has reduced the airway's fleet from about 20 aircraft several years ago to only four operational today. Some planes were seized by creditors.

The estimated 4,000 work force eats deep into the airline's scarce revenue.

Its managing director, Group Capt. Peter Gana, has promised to sanitize the organisation by instilling discipline and reducing the work force to the barest minimum.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
Low Prices At Kenya's Coffee Mart


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) -Coffee sales at the Nairobi Stock Exchange this week reached 3.7 million U.S. dollars. 

However, the prices remained low with products in the first grade (AA) fetching 149 dollars.

In other categories such as AB, E, C and TT, products fetched average prices of between 120 and 140 dollars.

The lowest paid coffee in the ML grade managed only 10 dollars for an 80- kilogram bag, but average prices were pegged at 136.55 dollars.

The majority of clean coffee that fetched high prices was, however, sold in bulk during the auction conducted by the Coffee Board of Kenya.

November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Lagos Anti-Crime Drive Gets A Boost


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The lagos state military administrator, Col. Mohammed Marwa, has donated 150 patrol vehicles, 12 motor-bikes and other communication equipment to the joint military and police team manning security in the Nigerian economic center.

Making the presentation Thursday, Marwa expressed concern at the rising rate of violent crime in the country, especially Lagos, where four people were reported killed in a car bomb bear the airport on Friday. 

The vehicles and gadgets are to facilitate the work of the team, known as " operation sweep," in response to increasing crime wave.

To complement operation sweep, Marwa recently launched a neighborhood vigilante watch group. He has also inaugurated members of four firearms and robbery tribunals to facilitate trial of suspects.

The federal government recently provided some 340 walkie-talkies, four broad-band air-base radio and other equipment to help fight crime in Lagos.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zaire;
Tshisekedi Wants Unity Government To Tackle Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zaire's hardline opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, has said that he would want to confer with President Mobutu Sese Seko, who is recuperating from an operation for cancer in France, on the possibility of setting up a unity government to tackle the serious crisis now facing the country.

He said at a news briefing in Kinshasa on Thursday that the crisis in eastern Zaire was partly caused by the non-respect of the decisions of a national conference held four years ago by the political class. 

The conference named Tshisekedi Prime Minister but the latter was relieved of the post months later by Mobutu.

"The crisis facing Zaire resulted from the mismanagement of the country by political leaders whose sole interest is to make money," said Tshisekedi

Responding to a question on the suggestion that a separate territory to be known as Hutuland be carved out as a way of solving the ethnic problem in Burundi and Rwanda, he said "Zairians will never accept to surrender a square millimeter of their territory."

However, A local newspaper Friday accused Tshisekedi of being pro-Tutsi regarding the ongoing war in eastern Zaire, where Zairian Tutsi called the Banyamurenge have seized Zairian territory reportedly with support from the Tutsi government in Kigali.

'Soft', a privately-owned Kinshasa daily said "Tshisekedi granted to, and then withdrew Zairian citizenship from Rwandans" in 1967 when he was justice minister.

322 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Azikiwe Will Be Laid To Rest Saturday


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - All roads lead to Nigeria's eastern market city of Onitsha for the burial Saturday of the country's first president, Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe.

The event will mark the end of a week-long national funeral rites that involved several cities which were linked with the elder statesman, who died May 11. Saturday would be his 92nd birth day.

From Zungeru in the north to Lagos, Enugu and Onitsha, his ancestral home, it has been a feast of tributes to the late Nigerian nationalist, sportsman journalist and Pan-Africanist. 

A number of foreign leaders are expected at the burial.

The presidents of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Equatorial Guinea were among dignitaries that attended Zik's lying in state Tuesday in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Zik's body also laid in state in key cities in northern Nigeria where was born, in the west, where he grew up and worked, and in the east, his ancestral home.

As a demonstration of his firm believe in national unity, the three major tribes of multi-ethnic Nigeria -- the Hausas in the north, the Yorubas in the west, especially Lagos, and the Igbos in the east, have sought to outdo each other in paying glowing tributes to the former president.

The Nigerian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs in a tribute said "Zik was a detribalised Nigerian who got on very well with everyone, regardless of tribe, religion, age or social status."

Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha renamed the Abuja international airport after Azikiwe as a mark of honor.

Even in death, Zik continued to win admirers from high and low, at home and abroad.

In Enugu on Thursday, a mock parliamentary session was held in honor of Zik, the politician.

In a tribute titled "Zik, the ultimate philosopher, pathfinder," former military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida said "we have to commit Zik to the earth with pride in us that our founding fathers had not lived in vain."

"They will continue to be remembered for their great attributes as motivators, disciplined visionaries and perfect examples that we can always be," he added.

In yet another, Kenyan Historian, Ali Mazrui, says of Zik: "when he combined certificate in law, a qualification in journalism, a masters in religion and philosophy, masters in anthropology, expertise in political science, Nnamdi Azikiwe was prophecy-incarnate signifying Africa's academic versatility when given half-a-chance."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Says It Is Impossible To Postpone Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has told South African President Nelson Mandela that it is "impossible" to postpone Monday's elections since the 11 opposition parties participating in the elections have opposed postponement.

In his letter, dated 14 Nov. to Mandela which was made available to PANA Friday, he also said that the proposition to postpone the elections was totally impossible because of the "astronomical" costs incurred spent by the participating parties and in view of limited resources. 

"Postponement of the elections scheduled for next monday 18 November, 1996 is a totally impossible proposition which the principal opposition parties taking part in the elections have also said they will not accept," part of the letter said.

Chiluba maintained there is no threat to the internal security and stability to warrant a draconian move like a state of emergency, as suggested, to facilitate the postponement.

Mandela early this week held private consultations with Chiluba in Pretoria. He later sent South African constitutional court judge Richard Goldstone to explore possibilities of postponing the elections.

The opposition Zambia Democratic Congress, (ZDC) which is one of the political parties taking part in the elections, confirmed to PANA that it had refused to accept the suggestion of postponing the elections.

"We are not for the idea of extending the elections," said the party's general secretary, Derrick Chitala. "We had made it clear that we would only agree if we were compensated the money spent on elections."

Former President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party and seven other minor opposition parties are boycotting the elections.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


324 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Party Threatens To Close Polling Stations


BYLINE: Masautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) has directed its cadres to physically close down polling stations where severe anomalies will arise on Monday.

ZDC deputy secretary general, Azwell Banda, said from Mpulungu yesterday that unless the 'toothless' Electoral Commission responds to the serious anomalies identified on the register before Monday, ZDC sees no other option but "war" on November 18.

"We have spent lot of time and money over this matter, and we will not allow any fraud to take away our liberty to choose the leaders of our choice," Banda warned.

The ZDC call was made after it discovered that several voters in some polling stations have been wrongly transfered to other polling stations several miles apart. 

"The whole of Gonda Barracks which is part of Chipata Central Constituency is now appearing in Kasenengwa Constituency. This means Gonda voters will on Monday not find their names at their polling station," Banda observed.

The party has now placed election agents and 'instant reactors' in all the 150 constituencies to check out for any serious anomalies on Monday and if necessary offer physical resistance.

"We have written the Electoral Commission chairman Bobby Bwalya to ask him to give express instructions to returning officers to close down any polling station where serious anomalies will occur on Monday. If he fails to do this our instruction to our members are to do whatever it takes to forcibly close the stations," Banda said.

The Post yesterday noted more contradictions in the voters' roll with several polling stations vanishing from their constituencies.

An advert placed in yesterday's Times of Zambia by Ndola town clerk and district returning officer Emmanuel Chenda to publicise polling stations of the four constituencies in his district has exposed discrepancies in the number of polling stations in various registers produced by Nikuv.

Chenda's advert shows the number of polling stations for Ndola Central to be 36, but this has contradicted the Election Commissions-Nikuv Summary document on elections, which puts polling stations in Ndola central at 23.

Chenda's advert claims Kabushi has 43 polling station but the Nikuv Summary shows 49.

While Chenda has advertised 35 polling stations for Chifubu the Nikuv Summary has entered voters' names in 31 polling station in the same area.

Another affected area is Bwana Mkubwa where Chenda is telling the voters of 34 polling stations against the Nikuv Summary of 31.

But another document of the Electoral Commission, a white Consolidated volume of polling stations produced by Nikuv contradicts both the Summary and Chenda's advertised information.

Apart from Ndola Central which tallies at 36 the rest are startling with Kabushi having 50 polling stations, Chifubu 30 and Bwana Mkubwa 32.

And three people in Choma were yesterday found in possession of two voters cards each.

But acting Director of Elections, Joel Sikazwe, maintained "it was not possible for one person to possess two voters cards".

"That is not possible unless you can show me to prove that you have the cards," Sikazwe said in an interview yesterday.

According to investigations by The Post, Muleya Ruth has two voters cards carrying similar details but from two different polling districts and different dates of issue - voter number: 801030/0081: Reg No 113847/73/1 Name: MULEYA RUTH; Residential address: HANYANGA SINGANI SIALUMBA, CHOMA.

Polling District name: SUNTWE Box/batch No 0258/03 Date of Birth: 21/01/62 issued: Oct 96.

The other differences on Muleya's other card are the date of issue which indicates June 1996 and date of birth which appears as 16/12/60. The polling district reads TANCHI but both from Mbabala Constituency in Choma.

The other persons with two cards each are Mudenda Vaileti and Simango Elson also from the same Constituency.

Post investigations recently revealed that there were about 17,000 ghost voters due to duplication of national registration cards and misplacement of names in the voters registers.

But Sikazwe said: "I am not aware about all those anomalies. But if they are there, a person will only be allowed to vote once. It's one man one vote."

LANGUAGE: English

325 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
President Chiluba Turns Down Request For Emergency


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Lusaka - President Frederick Chiluba has turned down a request from South African President, Nelson Mandela, that he declares a state of emergency over Zambia so as to postpone the November 18 elections and accomodate opposition UNIP and former President Kenneth Kaunda.

President Chiluba revealed this during his tour of Kabwata constituency today to check on the MMD campaign progress and preparedness for the elections.

Mr Chiluba said Mr Mandela sent a fax message to him to declare a state of emergence to facilitate a possible postponement of the November 18 elections for the sake of UNIP President, Dr Kenneth Kaunda. 

In reply Mr Chiluba told Mr Mandela that there is no need for a state of emergence because there is no crisis in the country.

He reteirated that elections will go ahead as scheduled because five presidential candidates as well as more than 500 parliamentary candidate are contesting the elections.

He said government will not interfere with the electoral commission, the only organ empowered to delay or postpone elections as doing so would defeat the very democratic purpose for which it was instituted.

"It is not possible to instruct the electoral commission to postpone elections because I will be accused of political interferance," Mr Chiluba said.

On Wednesday this week President Chiluba met Mr Mandela in South Africa to discuss possible solutions to the election boycott undertaken by UNIP and its President Kenneth Kaunda.

Hundreds of Kabwata residents thronged arround Mr Chiluba who toured markets in the constituency including Kamwala market.

Security personnel had a tough time controlling masses of people striving to have a glimpsy of Mr Chiluba who urged the voters to vote for Vice President, Brigadier-Geneneral Godfrey Miyanda as area MP.

Mr Chiluba expressed disatisfaction at the state of roads in the area and other facilities which are in a deplorable state.

Mr Chiluba also met party officials in the contituency who welcomed him with ululations, songs and party slogans. He urged them to rally behind Gen Miyanda so that the MMD programme started in the area would continue.

General Miyanda, who also accompanied the president, assured Mr Chiluba that the party in the constituency was solid and voters were fully geared to vote for him and Mr Chiluba because MMD was the only party with good development policies for the nation.

Mr Chiluba told MMD cadres in the constituence that they only have today and Sunday to campaign hence the need for a vigorious approach to woo more people to vote for MMD.

He assured the nation that the elections will go ahead and they will be peaceful despite plans by UNIP to use its vigilante wing to disrupt Monday's elections.

He said alert law enforcement officers will ensure peace prevails during the elections adding that those who have boycotted the November polls are wasting their time since the country can not afford losing billions of Kwacha by postponing the elections.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Human Rights Group: 'Don't Meddle In Our Affairs'


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The Human Rights Association of Zambia has cautioned foreign countries against interfering in the internal affairs of the country because Zambians are capable of deciding their own destiny.

Human Rights Association president, Dr Dixon Konkola, said at a press briefing today that there is no need for foreign intervention because there was no crisis in the nation.

He said foreigners have no right to dictate to the country on how to conduct the elections as Zambians are mature and experienced enough to solve problems. 

Dr Konkola also described as unfortunate and undemocratic the colection of voters cards by UNIP under its leader Kenneth Kaunda.

He said Dr Kaunda should be persuaded by his political experience that the best way to change a government is by participating in the elections instead of boycotting.

Speaking at the same function secretary general of the association, Adolfas Mubanga, said law enforcement officers should respect and protect human dignity and maintain and uphold human rights during the November 18 presidential and general elections.

He said police and security personnel should be posted in the minimum number necessary and should not be positioned in such a way as to intimidate or discourage voters from participating.

Mr Mubanga also cautioned election monitors against seeking favours or being partisan adding that their role is to ensure that human rights are observed through free and fair elections.

He said their presence decreased the likelihood of intimidation and fraud.

"Neutral and objective observers do instil confidence in the electorate and thereby increase their ability to freely express their political will in the ballot booth without fear of reprisal," he said.

He said a bigger number of monitors is needed in order to gain the attention and recognition by the electorate adding that a relationship with other monitors should be created.

Mr Mubanga has called upon the voters to turn up in big numbers and exercise their democratic right by voting without fear or intimidation.

Source: ZAMTODAY

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Arts and Entertainment;
Zambia Given Ultimatum On Copyright Agreement


BYLINE: Samson Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has been given about six years after which she will be expected to vigorously implement the Trade Related Aspect of Intellectual Property (TRIPS).

Newly elected Zambia Union of Musicians (ZUM) chairman Webster Malama told The Post that the agreement which was signed by 121 countries would include blocking counterfeit goods coming into the country. 

"Zambia as a developing country has been given about six years in which it is expected to educate its nationals about the agreement because after the expiry of the grace period it would mean sanctions to any country that abrogates the agreement," Malama said.

Malama just returned from Malawi where he attended a regional seminar on Experts of copyright and Neighbouring Copyrights in the Southern African Development Committee (SADC).

"A member country is supposed to offer equal protection to intellectual properties of its locals and those of foreign artists. In Africa only South Africa has been treated as a developed nation therefore is expected to observe the agreement as of January 1, 1996," he said.

The seminar was also attended by Tanzania which is regarded as the notorious piracy "boy" in the region.

"For the first time Tanzania was represented at copyright seminar and the representatives were sympathetic with the artists of the region who had lost a lot of money through the pirated intellectual properties coming through it," said Malama

November 15, 1996


Sports - Soccer;
Big Game In Zambia Promises Sparks


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - League leaders "Mighty" Mufulira Wanderers will have their toughest hurdle tomorrow as they play Lusaka Dynamos at Woodlands stadium with play-maker, Nelson Banda and their first and second choice keepers Collins Mbulo and Peter Chilufya respectively missing from the line up because of red cards.

Wanderers have fifty-four points while their closest rivals-Zamsure , who will be away to Nkana, have fifty-two points.

But even without Banda, the likes of Bilton Musonda, Martin Chola, Vincent Mutale and goal thief, Paul Chellah, have the capacity to get the vital goals to push the Mufulira side further up on the league. 

With Allan Kamwanga, improving at the back, Wanderers trainer, George Lwandamina, will have to employ a tactic that will be able to withstand the pressure from the youthful Lusaka Dynamos side, which held Wanderers to a one- all draw at Shinde Stadioum in Mufulira when the two sides met in the first leg.

Alex Namazaba, Perry Mutapa, Aliford Mapataki and Milton Tembo are the players that have seen Dynamos rise from the bottom of the table to the number five slot and should Michael Mwanza maintain his grip in defence-God help Wanderers-a defeat wouldn't be far fetched for Wanderers.

At the same venue, City of Lusaka, with Jerry Mafripa now in full charge as coach after the resignation of Fred Nasilele, will be up against relegation- bound Lifebuoy Strikers in a game that will determine whether the Ndola side will stay in the elite of Zambia's soccer or not.

In another game which on paper promises to be entertaining, Roan United struggling to clinch a top-eight place, will host Kabwe Warriors at Luanshya's Kafubu Stadium.

With two defectors from Kabwe Warriors-John Lungu and Justin Sakala-in the line up, trainer Fighton Simukonda, can easily ease the pressure haunting his once Stylish side with a win.

But that will largely depend on the form of Warriors goalie, Davies Phiri, who on his day makes many strikers eat humble pie.

Sports - Soccer;
Zambian Football Team Using Tennis Court For Training


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Cash-scrapped Profund Warriors football club players are using a tennis court for their daily training sessions because they lack training ground as their sports complex is under renovations.

But sources say the reason the team, which was demoted to the first division from the premier league last season, is training using the hard tennis court is because of the decision by management of its former sponsors- Zambia National Profident Fund (ZNPF) to stop the soccer team from using the football pitch. 

"ZNPF managers told the players to look for another ground because the sports complex is only for social football and not competitive type. That is why the coach, Boniface Simutowe decided to start using the tennis court," said a source.

But Simutowe, in an interview on Monday, maintained his team which uses Woodlands Stadium for its league matches, will soon start using the football pitch.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Campaign Chairman Tells Off Mandela


BYLINE: Mahongo Fumbelo, Reuben Phiri and Masautso Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Lusaka - MMD's campaign chairman, Vernon Mwaanga, yesterday told off South African President Nelson Mandela over his recent role in the Zambian political impasse.

Mwaanga told the press in Lusaka that Mandela, who is also chairman of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) has no right to advise Zambia on an election postponement.

President Mandela yesterday sent a fax message to President Frederick Chiluba in a last minute attempt to persuade him to postpone Monday's presidential and parliamentary elections.

Mandela's fax appeal to President Chiluba was revealed during his press address in Durban yesterday. He also disclosed some details of the meeting between him and President Chiluba on Monday. 

President Mandela told the press that he had agreed with President Chiluba to postpone the elections during their meeting in Pretoria on Tuesday.

The South African President was addressing the newsmedia on his role in Zambia's political crisis, and especially during his meeting with President Chiluba on Tuesday.

President Mandela said the Zambian President had given him two options under which an election can be postponed and they included an Electoral Commission announcement or declaration of a state of emergency by himself.

"This then would automatically annul the elections date, which can be announced later," Mandela said.

Their discussion appreciated the legal questions and it was on this premise that President Mandela sent respected South African Judge Richard Goldstone to confer with the Electoral Commission on a possible postponement.

Mandela has repeated this position to various news organisations.

"President Chiluba reacted favourably to the suggestion that Monday's election be postponed," Mandela told the South African Press Agency (SAPA) on Wednesday evening.

He later told the South African Broadcasting Corporation(SABC) that he advised President Chiluba that the "elections would lack legitimacy" if allowed to go on in the present circumstances. He particularly pushed for a way to allow participation of the main opposition UNIP and its president Kenneth Kaunda.

The South African President reiterated the position taken by SADC at the Maseru summit and when President Chiluba visited Mandela as chairman of SADC.

But in Lusaka Mwaanga, whom President Chiluba had been using to explain his government's position on the elections to SADC and other African leaders, dismissed Mandela's effort.

"Mandela has no right to tell us to postpone an election. We have run this country for 32 years and we have the integrity and sovereignty to make our own decisions," Mwaanga said. "We cannot be given instructions like school children."

Mwaanga, who last week accused the United States and Japanese governments of funding some civic organisations to cause anarchy in the country, maintained the elections are going on as scheduled because MMD has "cleared all anxieties over elections in meetings with opposition parties".

But former Circuit Holdings managing director, Malcom Freed who is in South Africa revealed that Mandela's press address placed emphasis on SADC reaction should President Chiluba defy the subregion's plea.

"If President Chiluba will go ahead with the presidential and parliamentary elections on Monday, November 18 the SADC will never recognise the results of such an election," Freed quotes the South African President as having told the press.

Both the Zambian Independent Monitoring Team and the Committee for a Clean Campaign have described Mwaanga's comments on President Mandela as unfair.

"MMD is treating this election like a party matter. We cannot have elections without sorting out the outstanding issues," said CCC leader Ngande Mwanajiti.

ZIMT leader Gershom Musonda added: "MMD is just not serious about this election."

And Electoral Commission chairman, justice Bobby Bwalya, briefing the press yesterday following discussions he held with Justice Goldstone, said the prevailing political situation in the country does not warrant the imposition of a state of emergency.

"As a commission we feel that the present situation does not warrant the imposition of a state of emergency because on the ground the situation is peaceful," Bwalya said. "This is the most highly contested election in the history of our country."

Bwalya made the remarks after he had earlier disclosed that postponement of the elections was one of the options discussed by President Frederick Chiluba and President Mandela, as one of the solutions to resolve the current political impasse.

Earlier on Wednesday, commission vice-chairman Meebelo Kalima also said a state of emergency could only be imposed "where there was a war or the nation was torn apart".

But Lusaka lawyer Sakwiba Sikota said it was not up to the Commission to determine whether "conditions warrant a state of emergency or not".

"The fact that President Chiluba disrupted his campaign midway to travel to South Africa over the electoral process shows there is a crisis. Hence discussing the possibilities of postponement with SADC chairman President Mandela,"Sikota said in an interview yesterday.

The polls which have been boycotted by the main opposition party UNIP has attracted 150 parliamentary candidates from the ruling MMD closely followed by 142 from the Zambia Democratic Congress.

The National Party is fielding 99 candidates while there are 96 candidates standing as independents.

The newly formed National Lima Party and Agenda for Zambia are each fielding 83 and 11 respectively.

The National Congress, Real Democratic Party, Movement for Democratic Process and Poor Peoples Party have a total of 8 candidates.

Justice Bwalya also said two candidates had filed their nomination papers on UNIP ticket and symbol while one was said to have filed on the Liberal Progressive Front(LPF) ticket.

Both UNIP and LPF, who are boycotting the polls recently indicated that their members who opted to contest the elections would do so as independents.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996

Arts and Entertainment;
New Art Exhibition Opens in Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - A Student Perspective Art Exhibition opens today at the Evelyn hone College's exhibition hall.

The exhibition which is organised by Honarts, an arts students' club is being coordinated by Mwamba Mulangala, would include paintings, ceramics and sculptures. 

The centre piece was done by Mulangala and is on an old man who fought a lion barehanded with only a knife. In the morning villagers found both the man Chisono and the lion dead.

Honarts publicity secretary Dake Seleyi expects to beat the 60 per cent sales of last year and also expects more than 60 art pieces to be exhibited.

Renown entrants in the exhibition are: Angel Phiri, Barbara Mulenga, Florence Nawezi, Geofrey Phiri and Geofrey Nsama.

Zambia National Visual arts council patron Enzio Rossi is expected to officiate at the function.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Aero Zambia Fires 7 Striking Pilots


BYLINE: Joe Kaunda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - Aero Zambia has 'fired' seven of their 12 pilots after they downed tools last Friday demanding better conditions of service.

Aero's management on Monday wrote letters to the seven pilots who had withdrawn their services that the airline had accepted their "resignations" when they had not in fact resigned.

The pilots had on Thursday, November 7, written to management informing them of the strike action but suffered a rude awakening on Monday when they were greeted by letters from management accepting resignations that never were. 

"We wrote them (management) a letter informing them that we were withdrawing our labour until our conditions of service were reviewed but did not resign," one of the pilots disclosed in an interview.

Those affected are Captain George Parkingson, Captain Musaka Mudenda, and First Officers - Victor Lemba, Osward Mukuka, George Sinkala, Pereira Kopolo and Katongo.

The pilots have complained of poor salaries which they quoted as below US$1, 000 a month the failure by the airline to pay them allowances and the lack of a sound insurance policy for the pilots.

Pilots in the region are paid monthly salaries of between US$3,000 and US$5, 000.

The group disclosed that they had been promised better conditions just when the airline took off after Zambia Airways' demise but had continued working under their initial conditions a year after.

They claim they have had meetings with management since April last year but were told to "hold on" as the airline was just being established.

"In June this year we had meetings again but nothing fruitful came out. In July it was the same case and later in October we gave them up to November 7 but still nothing happened. So on Friday we wrote the letters to management informing them about our withdrawal of labour," one of the pilot who sought anonymity said, adding: "But on Monday the deputy managing director, Mengistu called us and gave us letters stating that our resignations had been accepted. "

But when contacted for comment on the matter, Aero Zambia deputy managing director, Yewondessen Mengistu, denied knowledge of the strike action and the firing of the seven pilots.

"That is news to us. Our pilots have never been on strike and everything is just normal here," Mengistu said in an interview, adding:"We only have two pilots who have resigned and we have accepted their resignations."

He disclosed that the resignations were with effect from the November 8 at 08:15 hours and his airlines would not take on any more pilots as there was adequate staff to run operations but denied to give reasons behind the resignations.

Mengistu has further denied reports about engaging Mozambican pilots to fill up the staffing gap left by the alleged strike action.

"I have already said that we have adequate staff to handle operations so there are no plans to take on other pilots," he added.

Meanwhile internal sources confirmed the Mozamairlines unchanged schedules.

"Although we are flying , it is only the four pilots that are working in fact two pilots from Mozambique joined us yesterday and this has affected our flight schedule," the aviation source disclosed.

And further commenting on the four pilots that are still flying, the fired pilots cautioned the airline not to over-work them because this could prove disastrous.

"The guys are being overworked. A tired pilot is a danger in the sky because his reflexes are impaired, anything can happen," one of the pilots warned.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
