379 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


South Africa;
World Bank Talks Back


BYLINE: Judith Edstrom, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Johannesburg - I would like to address some of the perceptions and misconceptions about the World Bank in South Africa that have surfaced recently, at times with a degree of emotional fervour.

First, what is the World Bank and what are we doing in South Africa?

The World Bank is a co-operative bank owned by its member governments. South Africa is both an owner and a client of the bank. It can call on the bank for whatever services it wants - advice, loans, training or guarantees. 

To date, the World Bank's role has consisted mainly of providing advisory services requested by agencies primarily within the government.

True to its main objective of helping to reduce poverty in its client countries, the bank has worked with the Reconstruction and Development Programme office to produce a report on key indicators of poverty in South Africa, and co-financed a household living standards survey.

We have also helped to finance a participatory poverty assessment undertaken by several non-governmental organisations (NGOs), as well as a poverty and inequality analysis under the auspices of the deputy president's office.

The bank has been one of several contributors to policy formulation in a number of areas, including macro-economics, health financing, urban basic services, land reform, small and medium enterprise development and education.

We have also provided a few small grants for early childhood development, increasing Aids awareness among teens and developing procurement reforms to assist small entrepreneurs.

The government is currently discussing with bank staff the possibility of seeking World Bank financing for some programmes already envisaged or under way in the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) to enhance industrial competitiveness and job creation.

Second, has the World Bank pressured the government into accepting our advice?

No. The policymakers with whom we have dealt seek advice from any number of sources, and draw their own conclusions as to the course South Africa should take in addressing its own development issues. Alec Erwin, the DTI minister, was recently quoted in the Mail & Guardian as confirming this. The bank provides information on what has and has not worked in other countries, rather than a single policy prescription.

Third, is there a World Bank ideology?

Once again no. The World Bank is not a monolithic organisation - our staff come from a wide variety of fields: economics to anthropology, engineering to rural development. Complex issues of development do not lend themselves to a single simple answer.

The World Bank does, however, have policy views based on the international experience that we have had the opportunity to observe and analyse.

This experience reveals that sustainable development can best be achieved when the government takes the lead in setting the rules for job-creating investment by the private sector, relying on the latter to provide the financial resources and the entrepreneurial capacity to make the most productive use of physical and human resources.

Governments across the globe have come to realise that private sector investment is required to generate the growth, the jobs and the infrastructure to improve the living standards of their populations.

Nobody denies that economic growth is a prerequisite to improved living standards - no country in the world has managed to reduce poverty and income inequality if its economy is not growing.

We have also learnt that growth is not enough to ensure improved living standards of the poor. Countries must adopt policies and programmes that aim to ensure that benefits of growth are shared among their people. While this involves providing opportunities for people to improve their own welfare, it also requires efficient, equitable and sustainable provision of services. Basic among these are health and education.

In fact, provision of education opportunities has been shown to be one of the most important, if not the most important, variable in translating growth into improved welfare. It is for this reason that the World Bank is the largest financier of social sector programmes - for health, nutrition and education - in the world, with an annual expenditure of over US$3-billion globally to these sectors.

More and better quality education is key to South Africa's transformation into a society where all of its citizens benefit from any gains on the growth front.

Fourth, does the World Bank care more about policies or people?

Government policy has a major impact on people, and so the World Bank is rightly concerned about policy issues. At the same time, much of the bank's financing goes directly into investments such as schools and clinics that provide tangible benefits to people.

Development is about people - their access to opportunity, to a voice in the matters of state and community that affect them, and to sustainable livelihoods that allow them the dignity and responsibility of ensuring their own welfare.

The most important question concerning the bank's role in South Africa is whether it contributes to actions that improve the well-being of South Africans, particularly those who have not benefited from the country's economic progress in the past.

Finally, is the cause of development better served by dialogue or by disassociation?

I am baffled by the sentiments of some groups that contact with the bank constitutes contamination and should therefore be curtailed. The bank has learnt a lot from groups with differing views.

Exchanges with NGOs and civil society groups have had a direct and positive impact on its understanding of and sensitivity to social and environmental aspects of development programmes. We seek more dialogue, not less.

It's easy to seek scapegoats for why policies or programmes do not succeed. It's much harder to find solutions to achieving sustainable development for people. We have a responsibility to put our heads together and focus on the latter.

Judith Edstrom is the World Bank's representative to South Africa


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


South Africa;
Facts Or Fiction: Book Row Hots Up


BYLINE: Max Gebhardt, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Johannesburg - The on-going row between book giant CNA Gallo and the newcomer to the industry, Facts & Fiction, is set to flare up again, with the news that Facts & Fiction is to take fresh allegations of unfair practices to the Competition Board.

The relationship between the two has been acrimonious ever since present Facts & Fiction managing director Anthony Ward left the CNA stable last year to form his own company.

Ward told the Mail & Guardian this week that he would be approaching the Competition Board with new evidence of unfair competitive behaviour by the CNA Gallo Group.

Ward said he had instructed attorneys to submit an application to the Competition Board to consider the entire structure of the book industry. "The two applications (by Facts & Fiction to the board) in the past have been met with very cursory treatment and we have instructed our lawyers to take a formal stance," he said. 

The books industry is worth an estimated R1,4-billion per annum. Facts & Fiction and CNA compete head-on in the general book market, valued at R275- million, and CNA is estimated to control 95%. CNA Gallo lifted earnings by 5% to 5,8c a share, on turnover up 6% to R703-million in the six months to September 30.

CNA has about 320 shops nationwide and Exclusive Books, part of the CNA Gallo stable, has 10 specialist bookstores. Facts & Fiction has seven outlets in Gauteng, with plans for another three in the Western Cape this year.

Industry insiders say Ward's company has not only managed to expand the market, but at the same time has captured 10% of CNA's share.

The reason for his decision to approach the Competition Board was prompted by two levels of uncompetitive behaviour, says Ward.

"On the retail level, we are faced with bullying tactics to prevent us from gaining retail space or by making it extremely frustrating to acquire any space. The other level is in terms of the whole book market where there is monopolistic and uncompetitive behaviour," he said.

Mirroring the allegations made to the Competition Board last year by Facts & Fiction, Ward says he knows of two different instances where his competitor has made attempts to prevent his company from expanding into new premises.

September last year saw the Competition Board informally investigate charges against CNA Gallo that it had allegedly tried to block Facts & Fiction from gaining retail space in the Rosebank Mall, among other centres.

Assistant director Hennie Roux, from the board, said the charges had been investigated but it had found that the matters didn't warrant a formal investigation in terms of the Act.

Ward describes the CNA Gallo Group as a bullyboy preventing everybody from playing fairly and squarely in the market.

He expressed concern at CNA's horizontal and vertical integration. Over the past 10 years Exclusive Books has gobbled up a large share of the independent booksellers, with the latest being Sheldons.

The CNA Gallo Group has the controlling share in a number of distribution, warehouse and publishing companies, including a stake in Trans South African Book Distributors (50%), Struik Holdings (46%) and Heinemann (50%).

"It is obvious that the situation is monopolistic in nature," Ward said.

On a number of occasions, he said, CNA Gallo had used delaying tactics in delivering books to his stores - an accusation backed up by other independent booksellers.

CNA Gallo director Geoff Engel, however, refuted Ward's allegations of monopolistic behaviour or unfair competitive practices. He said the company had already stood the test by the Competition Board on whether it was behaving in a monopolistic fashion.

The very fact that there are so many new entrants into the book trade and CNA's declining market share, says Engel, shows it is not hampering market growth.

"I would be happy to debate any specific points with Anthony, but he only levels broad accusations against us," he said.

According to Engel, CNA Gallo does not have the clout to influence landlords' decisions on the allocation of retail space, and none of aits stores is an anchor tenant, as is the case with the large supermarkets.

"If anything needs to be considered, it's Facts & Fiction's 50% ownership by Stocks & Stocks - a major landlord."

Even though CNA Gallo might be vertically integrated into the market, Engel says it does not have control over the board of directors or management of these companies (in distribution etc) - that rests with the partners.

"Technically we have no control over these companies," he said.

In addition, the only time CNA Gallo ever holds back stock is owing to commercial considerations, such as when a client is overdue on their accounts or over their credit limit, says Engel.

While the slanging match continues, both sides welcome the chance to see the matter finally settled by the Competition Board.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
British Aerospace Buys Stake in ATE


BYLINE: Madeleine Wackernagel, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Johannesburg - British Aerospace (BAe), a front runner in the bidding to replace the ageing Impala trainers, is taking a 20% stake in Advanced Technologies & Engineering (ATE), which supplies the integrated avionics systems for the South African Air Force's Pilatus "Astra" trainer and the Rooivalk attack helicopter.

The value of the shareholding was not disclosed, but Alan MacDonald, BAe managing director responsible for the Asean and Southern African regions, said the move fitted perfectly with the British company's aim of building global partnerships.

"We've been talking to ATE for about three years; the synergies are obvious. A memorandum of understanding was signed last week, with the intention that we will help boost the company's international marketing, as well as its skills base by giving them advanced projects to work on." 

BAe will transfer substantial contracts for systems integration work to its South African partners. It is also open to further investment: "ATE generates much of its investment itself, but if the need arises, we will support expansion with more capital."

Both MacDonald and Jean-Marc Pizano, head of ATE, stressed the opportunities the alliance will provide for black empowerment and affirmative action. "Any contract we receive," says Pizano, "can lead to a cascade of business across the breadth and depth of our extensive supplier network, which is mostly South African," thereby boosting employment opportunities and skills transference.

MacDonald was keen to stress that the link- up was not related to its bid to secure the air force contract to replace the Impala aircraft, due to be finalised by March.

"Our aim is not just to sell products to this country but also to be good corporate citizens. Obviously we hope we will win the contract, but we also believe in this country and want to be part of its future growth." He warned of the dangers of sidelining the defence industry, despite the urgency of concentrating on more fundamental needs such as health and education.

"South Africa has tremendous capabilities, but is in danger of losing those skills and technological advances built up over so many years, which could undermine the industry. And the export opportunities are tremendous. So we plan to be part of that growth."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
South Africa's Huge Property Sell-Off


BYLINE: Max Gebhardt, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Johannesburg - Eskom's Pension and Provident Fund is considering a major shake-up of its R2- billion property portfolio, according to confidential documents leaked to the Mail & Guardian.

At a strategic workshop held earlier this month by the fund's investment committee, it was proposed to dispose of a sizeable share of its property investments. In a move that is bound to catch many property analysts flat- footed, the fund is considering selling off portions of its investments in several prime retail outlets and offices in Gauteng.

But any proposed sale by the fund could encounter resistance from the unions, which feel Eskom is disregarding the National Framework Agreement (NFA) - an understanding between the government and labour on the restructuring of state assets. 

This view is not shared by Eskom management. An Eskom representative said it had on numerous occasions stated that, although not a party to the NFA, it would not unilaterally proceed with initiatives that fell within the scope of the NFA.

National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa's assistant general secretary Mbuyi Ngwenda says the union has long argued that matters of a serious nature, such as the disposal of assets, should be discussed in the restructuring transformation committee.

Eskom contends that the fund is a separate legal entity that receives its mandate from its 49 000 members.

It plans "actively to promote disposal of" Debruynpark in the Pretoria CBD, which it says is high risk and has a massive vacancy rate, and the Cresta shopping centre, where the fund is considering reducing its shareholding.

The fund's 12,5% stake in the troubled Sandton Square is also under consideration for disposal, as is its 25% investment in the Sandton Consortium and the adjoining hotels and offices, which it says it may need to dilute in order to participate in further capital expansion.

Of the fund's 20 property investments, 11 are under review for sale.

According to the document, property totals 18%, or R2-billion, of the pension fund's assets at present market values. It had achieved an outstanding 32,5% return on investments by the financial year-end in June 1996.

But there are a number of issues hampering the fund's growth, according to the document. These include a lack of new capital and the dismal future of regional shopping centres, which it says is a mature and saturated market in the Gauteng area.

The fund is forecasting up to R1,2-billion in capital requirements for a number of new investment opportunities, to be funded from the proceeds of the proposed sale of its assets. The two most significant are the Sandton Consortium and Pavilion initiatives in Johannesburg and Durban respectively, which the fund says would need an expected R900-million capital injection over the next three years, to fund retail expansion, casino and offices and a convention centre.

The committee said the fund needed to consider four broad future investment strategies: focusing on existing retail and prime offices; swapping locally with like- minded institutions to diversify risk; diversifying abroad through appropriate investment vehicles and pursuing Reconstruction and Development Programme initiatives.

According to Adriaan Nieman, property general manager of the pension fund, the document should be seen in the context of normal strategic planning. It is an overview of the property portfolio's current profile and investment philosophies and criteria.

Nieman said the board of trustees was fully representative of all shareholders, including unions, and would consider carefully the consequences of the investment committee's recommendations.

"We do not believe it would be in the public's interest to reveal the content of our confidential discussions. This leak could have a material impact on the value of the property portfolio," Nieman said.

According to Nieman, those assets under consideration for sale only comprise 3% of the total value of the fund's investments.

"We do not want the portfolio to exceed the maximum of 18% of the fund's investments and we need to focus on the future major growth nodes.

"This is a two-to-five year strategic plan and we want to expand and diversify the portfolio," Nieman said.

Arthur Els, an actuary for Ginsberg Malan & Carsans, said he expected the move might be a result of the Katz Commission's decision to levy a 17% tax on income and rental profits.

"Most pension funds have less than 10% of their investments in property because of the depressed property markets and the new tax," he said.

A Syfrets property analyst thought it was a good idea that Eskom withdraw from the property market but said it might struggle to achieve its goal. He expects the Eskom pension fund to take a capital loss on its investments, especially since many have been overvalued.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


383 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
UN In Deal With Zairean Rebels


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Goma - Ahead of heavy fighting that erupted near Goma in Eastern Zaire on November 14, United Nations relief agencies have reached an aid-distribution agreement with rebel leaders who control the area, a UN official said here on November 13.

The 10-point agreement with rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila did not mean the UN recognised rebel authority in eastern Zaire or was interfering in Zairean domestic affairs, Ben Parker of the UN humanitarian affairs department said, adding that UN officials still had to resolve with Kinshasa the problem of distributing aid from across the border in Rwanda and Burundi.

The deal comes after Zairean authorities warned on November 11 that agencies would be barred from operating on Zairean soil if they dealt with rebel forces.

Information Minister Boguo Makeli said that international organisations supporting the rebel alliance would be abetting "treason", although there were a number of issues still to be resolved, the major one being the ability to receive permission from Kinshasa to deliver goods across the border from the east. 

The aid agencies pulled out of Goma on October 24 under mortar and machine- gun fire as rebels of Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire fought retreating Zairean troops.

A spokeswoman for the UN's World Food Programme (WFP), Michelle Quintaglie, said in Nairobi that the organisation had food stocks on the border with Zaire and would be able to move in within "12 to 72 hours" of getting the go- ahead.

However, the first two truckloads of food the agency moved into Goma on November 11 remained undistributed overnight the following day under rebel guard in a stadium in the town.

Some 1.2 million refugees -- Hutus who fled civil strife in Rwanda and Burundi -- as well as thousands of displaced Zaireans have been out of the reach of aid agencies since they fled their camps ahead of the rebel advance which began a month ago on October 13.

Some aid agencies estimate that many thousands will already have died from hunger, thirst and deceases in the inhospitable Zairean interior by the time they are found in the ongoing frantic search.

But once they are found, to take in the minimum of 500 tonnes of food a day needed for the estimated more than 1 million refugees would require 32 flights a day of huge C130 transport planes and a minimum of 60 trucks on the ground to ferry the food over poor roads to the east.

There are also fears that cholera could quickly kill up to 150,000 of them unless they have access to good quality drinking water in the next few days, the International Federation of Red Cross Societies announced from Geneva on November 8.

There is an "enormous possibility" of an epidemic, said Piero Calvi- Parisetti, head of a Red Cross working group on the Great Lakes region.

"If we are unable to provide them with good quality water, we could lose 100,000 to 150,000 people very quickly," he said.

The treatment for cholera is simply water to rehydrate the victim, but it needs to be of good quality, Calvi-Parisetti stressed. Rain water is not up to scratch.

Local Red Cross offices in Zaire and Rwanda are unable to help most of the hundreds of thousands of refugees dispersed and in distress around Lake Kivu, since their food stocks have run out, he said.

The Red Cross Federation is in talks with Zairean authorities in Kinshasa to obtain approval to fly to a dozen airports west of Goma and Bukavu, but despite verbal assurances, written confirmation was not yet in hand by the time of going to press.

As long as written approval is lacking, flights to these airports will be too dangerous, Calvi-Parisetti said.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


384 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zaire;
Zaireans Brace For Unrest Resulting From Fighting In East


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Kinshasa - Residents of the Zairean capital fearing new unrest in the city stayed off the streets on November 12, the day set in a students' ultimatum for Prime Minister Joseph Kengo Wa Dondo to step down.

Students from the University of Kinshasa set the ultimatum, pressing Kengo to accept the blame for the Zairean army's military defeat at the hands of Tutsi rebels who have taken control of eastern Zaire's two provinces of North and South Kivu, triggering the flight of some 1.2 million refugees.

Despite a ban on rallies, they demonstrated to "support the war effort and the Zairean armed forces" but especially for "the resignation of the prime minister," said to be of Zairean and Tutsi parentage. 

Observers here believe that the students are being manipulated by opposition parties, who like the students are more concerned with ousting Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko, currently convalescing in the French city of Nice from a recent prostate cancer operation in Switzerland, than in military successes in eastern Zaire.

Mobutu told South African Vice-President Thabo Mbeki in Nice on November 12 that his condition since the operation is not yet fit, and that he would return to Switzerland for medical check-up before returning home.

However, Kengo, who has been prime minister since June 1994, is in fact highly regarded in the West, having managed to restore a certain degree of stability to Zaire, which was wracked by unrest in 1991 and 1993.

The students' ultimatum that he step down or "face the consequences" -- while unlikely to succeed -- has nevertheless created a tense climate in the capital.

The streets were also deserted all day on November 11 after students appealed for a day of inaction, calling on people to stay at home, not to work, nor drive around town or do business.

A week earlier, the students encountered little resistance when they commandeered hundreds of vehicles for a parade that had been banned.

Security forces' passivity rekindled fears of new unrest among residents who had begun to breathe easier since Kengo came to power two years ago.

Fear of new student unrest has led France to deploy "as a precaution" some 120 troops in Brazzaville, the Congolese capital across the Zaire River from Kinshasa.

France's ambassador to Congo, Raymond Cesaire, sought to play down the deployment, saying it was not linked to the situation in Zaire but was "part of an ordinary rotation in the countries of the sub- region."

Any intervention by the troops in Zaire would require a request or agreement by the Zairean government, informed sources noted.

Belgian and French troops intervened, with Mobutu's blessing in 1991 to help quell riots over government corruption and repression and to protect more than 20,000 foreigners living throughout Zaire.

Then in 1993, after serious mutinies in Kinshasa, Mobutu allowed only a small French contingent to intervene while banning Belgian forces.

French troops came to Kinshasa from Brazzaville to recover the remains of French ambassador Philippe Bernard, who was killed in his office by automatic weapons fire in circumstances that have still not been explained, during intense fighting between Zairean soldiers.

The troops also guarded the ambassador's residence, where several hundred foreigners took refuge.

Upwards of 6,000 foreigners living in Kinshasa, most of them longtime residents, still have vivid memories of these events. Some Europeans here expressed relief at the proximity of the French troops.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zaire;
Order Confirms Death Of Missionaries In Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Madrid - Four Spanish missionaries have been killed in Bukavu, the capital of south Kivu region in eastern Zaire, the Marxist order announced here on November 12.

A spokesman of the order Adolfo Varas said: "We consider it certain that the four died," adding that they were killed overnight on October 7 near Bukavu, capital of South Kivu province, but their bodies have not been recovered.

The missionary order first announced the incident on November 8, when it said that at least three of its missionaries had been killed in Bukavu the previous day, although it said it had not received 100 per cent confirmation or the incident. 

The Spanish Foreign Ministry has not received confirmation of the deaths through its own information channels, a ministry spokesman said.

About 50 Spaniards, mostly clergy, are still in the conflict zone in Eastern Zaire, and most want to stay on in the region.

Bukavu is among a number of eastern Zairean towns seized in the previous week by Zairean Tutsi rebels, who have lived in Zaire for nearly 200 years and at first said they were fighting for recognition as Zairean citizens, but have since said they want to topple President Mobutu Sese Seko.

On October 29, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Bukavu, Monsignor Christophe Munzi Hirwa, was also killed in the Bukavu region.

Munzi Hirwa, a Jesuit, was "caught in an ambush" in the troubled eastern Zairean town of Bukavu, and his body was found in the early hours of October 30, according to an announcement that was later confirmed in Madrid by Igancio Velasco, director of the Bureau of International Cooperation of the Order of Jesus, as the Jesuits are formally known.

In the Vatican, a papal spokesman said Pope John Paul II had been "greatly saddened" to learn of Hirwa's death, only hours after the pontiff had "begged" the international community to help the Rwandan, Burundian and Zairean populations.

"I pray that the guns fall silent, that the hatred and ethnic conflicts cease, that we stop this shameful killing of human beings and seek the path of negotiation," he told a gathering of the Catholic faithful in St. Peter's square.

According to reports, Munzi Hirwa had before his death written to the United Nations accusing Rwanda and Uganda of waging war in Zaire.

Writing to the UN mission in Bukavu, Munzi Hirwa had accused Rwanda of using the Banyamulenge Tutsi rebels to seize power in Zaire, its much larger neighbour in the Great Lakes region, according to the Belgian News Agency, Belga.

Munzi Hirwa had said the conflict in the Kivu area of Zaire was "a war by Uganda and Rwanda against Zaire," said Belga, quoting from a copy of the letter.

He had asked the United Nations to persuade the United States and other countries which he accused of supporting the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Army to act "to stop this war of incalculable human damage."

Ironically, news of the killing of the archbishop came as Pope John Paul II was appealing urgently to the world community to help the central African people affected by intense fighting in eastern Zaire, calling the situation there a "catastrophe."

As archbishop, Munzi Hirwa would have been the Vatican's chief representative in eastern Zaire.

Zaire has 17.32 million Roman Catholics among its 43.8 million people, according to 1992 and 1994 figures. Christianity has existed in the vast African nation since Belgian colonial days, which ended with independence in June 1960.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
World Bank, ADB Against Agricultural Subsidies


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ROME, Italy (PANA) - The heads of the African Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank are opposed to agricultural subsidies currently being applied by governments in Africa and elsewhere.

In plenary Thursday at the ongoing World Food Summit, the presidents of both institutions said subsidies had contributed to lower incomes.

"Apparently well-intentioned but misguided practices" aimed at cheap food prices for urban consumers through subsidies had only exacerbated the problem of lower farm incomes, ADB President Omar Kabbaj said. 

Subsidies, he added, "contributed to the marginalization of the rural economy and to declines in the income and welfare of rural dwellers."

And World Bank President James Wolfensohn told a news conference "no country, in the long term, can live with subsidies."

Earlier he told world leaders at the summit that governments "should reduce heavy intervention in the rural economy and concentrate on creating an economic and regulatory environment that fosters agricultural growth."

Both Kabbaj and Wolfensohn said that the reduction of subsidies tended to nudge farmers to areas which are more efficient.

To compliment this, both banks have adopted new approaches to rid the poor countries of the worst types of poverty, providing mocro-financing to allow for easy credit for farmers.

Kabbaj said ADB provides micro-credit to poor and vulnerable groups and has been giving credit to national and sub-regional development finance bodies so they could, in turn, lend to small and medium-scale enterprises.

Both banks have also been working with or have policies in place to collaborate with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), who have considerable experience in implementing poverty alleviation programmes.

"We will be making further strides in this area, with the finalization of a new micro-enterprise policy which will set the framework for extending appropriate credit to the poorest groups, using financial intermediaries such as NGOs and other grassroots organizations," Kabbaj said.

"We have initially set aside some 20 million dollars (U.S) for this type of support."


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Airways Fires 250 More Workers


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria airways has sacked 250 more workers less than one year after firing 720 others as part of efforts to improve the efficiency of the financially troubled national carrier.

The airline's spokesman, Chris Aligbe, said in a statement in Lagos Thursday that the 250 were sacked either for "indiscipline or declining productivity, excessive leave and absenteeism." 

The sack "cuts across the senior and junior cadre" of staff, he said.

A combination of debt burden and maintenance problem has reduced the airway's fleet from about 20 aircraft several years ago to only four operational today. Some planes were seized by creditors.

The estimated 4,000 work force eats deep into the airline's scarce revenue.

Its managing director, Group Capt. Peter Gana, has promised to sanitize the organisation by instilling discipline and reducing the work force to the barest minimum.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Business and Finance;
Low Prices At Kenya's Coffee Mart


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) -Coffee sales at the Nairobi Stock Exchange this week reached 3.7 million U.S. dollars. 

However, the prices remained low with products in the first grade (AA) fetching 149 dollars.

In other categories such as AB, E, C and TT, products fetched average prices of between 120 and 140 dollars.

The lowest paid coffee in the ML grade managed only 10 dollars for an 80- kilogram bag, but average prices were pegged at 136.55 dollars.

The majority of clean coffee that fetched high prices was, however, sold in bulk during the auction conducted by the Coffee Board of Kenya.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Lagos Anti-Crime Drive Gets A Boost


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The lagos state military administrator, Col. Mohammed Marwa, has donated 150 patrol vehicles, 12 motor-bikes and other communication equipment to the joint military and police team manning security in the Nigerian economic center.

Making the presentation Thursday, Marwa expressed concern at the rising rate of violent crime in the country, especially Lagos, where four people were reported killed in a car bomb bear the airport on Friday. 

The vehicles and gadgets are to facilitate the work of the team, known as " operation sweep," in response to increasing crime wave.

To complement operation sweep, Marwa recently launched a neighborhood vigilante watch group. He has also inaugurated members of four firearms and robbery tribunals to facilitate trial of suspects.

The federal government recently provided some 340 walkie-talkies, four broad-band air-base radio and other equipment to help fight crime in Lagos.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zaire;
Tshisekedi Wants Unity Government To Tackle Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zaire's hardline opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, has said that he would want to confer with President Mobutu Sese Seko, who is recuperating from an operation for cancer in France, on the possibility of setting up a unity government to tackle the serious crisis now facing the country.

He said at a news briefing in Kinshasa on Thursday that the crisis in eastern Zaire was partly caused by the non-respect of the decisions of a national conference held four years ago by the political class. 

The conference named Tshisekedi Prime Minister but the latter was relieved of the post months later by Mobutu.

"The crisis facing Zaire resulted from the mismanagement of the country by political leaders whose sole interest is to make money," said Tshisekedi

Responding to a question on the suggestion that a separate territory to be known as Hutuland be carved out as a way of solving the ethnic problem in Burundi and Rwanda, he said "Zairians will never accept to surrender a square millimeter of their territory."

However, A local newspaper Friday accused Tshisekedi of being pro-Tutsi regarding the ongoing war in eastern Zaire, where Zairian Tutsi called the Banyamurenge have seized Zairian territory reportedly with support from the Tutsi government in Kigali.

'Soft', a privately-owned Kinshasa daily said "Tshisekedi granted to, and then withdrew Zairian citizenship from Rwandans" in 1967 when he was justice minister.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 15, 1996


Nigeria;
Azikiwe Will Be Laid To Rest Saturday


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - All roads lead to Nigeria's eastern market city of Onitsha for the burial Saturday of the country's first president, Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe.

The event will mark the end of a week-long national funeral rites that involved several cities which were linked with the elder statesman, who died May 11. Saturday would be his 92nd birth day.

From Zungeru in the north to Lagos, Enugu and Onitsha, his ancestral home, it has been a feast of tributes to the late Nigerian nationalist, sportsman journalist and Pan-Africanist. 

A number of foreign leaders are expected at the burial.

The presidents of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Equatorial Guinea were among dignitaries that attended Zik's lying in state Tuesday in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Zik's body also laid in state in key cities in northern Nigeria where was born, in the west, where he grew up and worked, and in the east, his ancestral home.

As a demonstration of his firm believe in national unity, the three major tribes of multi-ethnic Nigeria -- the Hausas in the north, the Yorubas in the west, especially Lagos, and the Igbos in the east, have sought to outdo each other in paying glowing tributes to the former president.

The Nigerian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs in a tribute said "Zik was a detribalised Nigerian who got on very well with everyone, regardless of tribe, religion, age or social status."

Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha renamed the Abuja international airport after Azikiwe as a mark of honor.

Even in death, Zik continued to win admirers from high and low, at home and abroad.

In Enugu on Thursday, a mock parliamentary session was held in honor of Zik, the politician.

In a tribute titled "Zik, the ultimate philosopher, pathfinder," former military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida said "we have to commit Zik to the earth with pride in us that our founding fathers had not lived in vain."

"They will continue to be remembered for their great attributes as motivators, disciplined visionaries and perfect examples that we can always be," he added.

In yet another, Kenyan Historian, Ali Mazrui, says of Zik: "when he combined certificate in law, a qualification in journalism, a masters in religion and philosophy, masters in anthropology, expertise in political science, Nnamdi Azikiwe was prophecy-incarnate signifying Africa's academic versatility when given half-a-chance."


LOAD-DATE: November 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


392 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 15, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Says It Is Impossible To Postpone Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has told South African President Nelson Mandela that it is "impossible" to postpone Monday's elections since the 11 opposition parties participating in the elections have opposed postponement.

In his letter, dated 14 Nov. to Mandela which was made available to PANA Friday, he also said that the proposition to postpone the elections was totally impossible because of the "astronomical" costs incurred spent by the participating parties and in view of limited resources. 

"Postponement of the elections scheduled for next monday 18 November, 1996 is a totally impossible proposition which the principal opposition parties taking part in the elections have also said they will not accept," part of the letter said.

Chiluba maintained there is no threat to the internal security and stability to warrant a draconian move like a state of emergency, as suggested, to facilitate the postponement.

Mandela early this week held private consultations with Chiluba in Pretoria. He later sent South African constitutional court judge Richard Goldstone to explore possibilities of postponing the elections.

The opposition Zambia Democratic Congress, (ZDC) which is one of the political parties taking part in the elections, confirmed to PANA that it had refused to accept the suggestion of postponing the elections.

"We are not for the idea of extending the elections," said the party's general secretary, Derrick Chitala. "We had made it clear that we would only agree if we were compensated the money spent on elections."

Former President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party and seven other minor opposition parties are boycotting the elections.

Africa News


November 16, 1996


Zaire;
IRIN Briefing - Zaire Facts and Figures


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2414 words


 

Nairobi - (IRIN Note: This document is in no way intended to be comprehensive, but offers basic information thought to be useful to the humanitarian community during the present crisis.)

INTRODUCTION:

Zaire -- Africa's third largest nation -- is located at the heart of the continent, and has become ever more embroiled in chaos since independence from Belgium in 1960. The sprawling country has vast mineral reserves, and regions such as copper-rich Shaba and diamond-rich Kasai are virtually autonomous.

Home to 1.2 million Rwandan and Burundian Hutu refugees in the east, Zaire is now wracked by a revolt in the eastern Kivu region led by Tutsi rebels, widely believed to be backed by soldiers from the Tutsi-led Rwandan army. Refugees are again on the move, and the rag-tag Zairean army's flight from the rebels, coupled with President Mobutu's prolonged absence from the country, has demonstrated Kinshasa's growing inability to control events in the country. 

BASIC FACTS:

Area - 2,344,885 sq km, 905,365 sq miles

Capital - Kinshasa

Official language - French

Population - 41.2 million in 1993

Average life expectancy at birth - 52 years

Adult literacy - 75.2 percent

CHRONOLOGY:

June 1960: Independence from Belgium. Joseph Kasavubu proclaimed president, Patrice Lumumba prime minister. Armed mutiny five days later and Belgian chief of staff replaced by Col (later Marshal) Joseph-Desire Mobutu.

February 1961: Lumumba murdered.

January 1964: Rebellion breaks out in southern Kivu and northern Katanga (now Shaba) provinces. Within a few months the rebels were in control of the east and northeast of the country. In early 1965, the revolt was defeated by the army, assisted by Belgian troops, mercenaries and members of the Banyamulenge Tutsi ethnic group.

August 1964: New constitution establishes presidential system of government and federal structure.

November 1965: Mobutu declares himself head of the 'Second Republic', imposes five year ban on party politics.

1966: Mobutu forms Mouvement Populaire de la Revolution (MPR). Provinces reduced to eight, Leopoldville becomes Kinshasa.

1970: Presidential and legislative elections. Mobutu, as the sole candidate, elected president end October, and members of the 420-member legislative council elected from a list of candidates selected by the MPR political bureau.

October 1971: Republic of Congo renamed Republic of Zaire.

1982: Opposition movement gains momentum with formation of the Union pour la Democratie et le Progres Social (UPDS) and the Front Congolais pour le Retablissement de la Democratie (FCD), with exiled Nguza Karl-I-Bond as its spokesman.

1990: Relations with Belgium enter all time low after Brussels freezes assistance to Zaire following the killing of student demonstrators.

October 1990: Mobutu announces that full multi-party system will come into force.

1991: Opposition parties come together under the umbrella of Union Sacree and take part in a national conference in August aimed at drafting a new constitution.

December 1992: National conference dissolves itself, and is succeeded by a 453-member High Council of the Republic (HCR) with Archbishop Monsengwo as its president. It declares Etienne Tshisekedi as prime minister.

March 1993: Mobutu attempts to reassert political authority by convening a special "conclave" of political forces to debate the country's future, and a parallel administration is formed with Faustin Birindwa as prime minister.

1994: Transitional legislature, known as Haut Conseil de la Republique- Parlement de Transition, formed and Leon Kengo wa Dondo elected premier of a transitional government.

July/August 1994: Zaire's international standing enhanced after the influx of over one million refugees fleeing the civil war in Rwanda.

January 1995: International concern after an outbreak of the fatal Ebola virus in the southwestern town of Kikwit.

May 1996: Violence escalates in the eastern region of Masisi in North Kivu as Zairean forces, former Rwandan soldiers and Hutu refugees target Tutsi villagers who have lived in the region for decades. Thousands of Tutsis flee to Rwanda.

August 1996: Mobutu undergoes surgery for prostate cancer in Lausanne, Switzerland.

October 1996: Concern mounts over Mobutu's health and his leadership, as he prolongs his stay in Switzerland, and fighting between rebel ethnic Tutsis in South Kivu - known as Banyamulenge - and the Zairean armed forces engulfs the eastern Zaire region.

November 1996: Great Lakes region faced with another refugee crisis after Banyamulenge rebels oust Zairean soldiers in Bukavu, Goma and Uvira regions and thousands of people are again on the move. Kinshasa effectively rudderless.

SOME OF THE KEY PLAYERS:

MOBUTU SESE SEKO - Zaire's strongman president for three decades and arguably the one symbol of national unity, Mobutu has been absent since August when he had surgery for prostate cancer in Switzerland. He is currently in France. He came to power in a military coup in 1965 and has ruled since with cunning. In 1990 he embraced democratic reforms, but the transition has dragged on and Zaire has yet to hold elections. Mobutu has a magnificent palace at his home of Gbadolite, deep in the jungle of northern Equateur district. In recent years he has spent most of his time there, rarely visiting the capital.

KENGO WA DONDO - Zaire's half-Polish, part-Rwandan prime minister is appreciated by the West for his willingness to reform the corrupt economy. A wealthy businessman, he was a prime minister under Mobutu's one-party system but during the transition to democracy moved towards the opposition ranks. The transitional parliament elected him prime minister in 1994 as a candidate from the opposition acceptable to Mobutu's supporters, who are in the majority. His attempts to implement economic reforms reflected well on Mobutu, shunned by the West for human rights abuses and lack of democracy.

ELUKI MONGA AUNDU - As army chief of staff, General Eluki commands Zaire's biggest armed force, a ragged body estimated at around 25,000, forced by low pay to survive on what they can forage or extract from the civilian population. Eluki is from the same Equateur region as Mobutu.

BARAMOTO KPAMA - General Baramoto commands the civil guard, most feared of the military forces by the civilian population. Well-trained and fed compared to the regular army, it is used to put down local disturbances and also has a combat role. Baramoto comes from the same Ngbandi ethnic group as Mobutu.

NZIMBI NGBALE - Commanding general of the Special Presidential Division (DSP), the most disciplined, best-paid and professional of Zaire's fighting forces. Their specific duty is to assure the president's security but includes defending vital national interests. Employed by the United Nations, a contingent of the DSP was used to guard Rwandan Hutu refugee camps in the east. Nzimbi has close family ties to Mobutu.

KAMANDA WA KAMANDA - A career politician, the interior minister is a centrist allied with Kengo, having once been close to Mobutu. In 1972 he was elected assistant secretary-general of the Organisation of African Unity. Kamanda has been outspoken on getting Hutu refugees to return home, as both foreign minister and now interior minister. He is from the western Bandundu district close to the capital Kinshasa.

ETIENNE TSHISEKEDI - A onetime friend of Mobutu, Tshisekedi is now the main figure in radical political opposition to the president. He was arrested on numerous occasions before democratic reforms began. As prime minister elected by a national conference in 1992, he was shunted aside in favour of a Mobutu appointee in 1993. Tshisekedi refuses to accept Kengo's 1994 election and claims the job for himself. The opposition, and even Tshisekedi's own Union for Democracy and Social Progress Party, is divided. His origins lie in the diamond-rich Kasai region of central Zaire.

NGUZA KARL-I-BOND - Veteran opposition leader and political survivor, he has been everything from first commissioner (prime minister) under Mobutu's one-party state to a prisoner on death row. A former ambassador to the United States, he was a major player in the early days of the democratic transition. He leads the Union of Federalists and Independent Republicans.

LAURENT KABILA - A former Marxist who heads the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), dominated by the Banyamulenge ethnic Tutsis now controlling much of eastern Zaire. He says the aim of the alliance is to put an end to Mobutu's rule and eradicate corruption.

The ADFL, formed on 18 October 1996 at Lemera, South Kivu, is composed of:

* Parti de la Revolution Populaire, a Marxist-oriented group founded in the 1960s battling the government in the east. Prominent leader: Laurent Kabila, from Shaba.

* "Kissasse" rebels, who follow military commander Andre Kissasse. They include fighters from the eastern Zaire Nande tribe and Kasai. Party: Conseil National de Resistance pour la Democratie.

* Mouvement Revolutionnaire pour la Liberation du Zaire. Prominent leader: Nindaga Masusu, reportedly of Bashi ethnicity.

* Zairean Banyamulenge Tutsis from South Kivu province, joined by the Banyarwanda Tutsis from North Kivu. Party: Alliance Democratique des Peuples (ADP), leader: Deo/Douglas Bugera (from Rutshuru), prominent member, Muller Ruhimbika (Banyamulenge).

In addition, fighters within the rebel forces may include:

* Ethnic Luba dissidents from southeastern Kasai province.

* Shaba fighters drawn from 500,000 people who fled government terror in the southeastern Shaba province to Kasai in 1992.

* Zairean army deserters.

* Elements from the Mai-Mai and Bangilima North Kivu Zairean militia - although they have reportedly fought on both sides of the conflict.

ECONOMY:

Main Exports - Copper, coffee, diamonds, cobalt, crude oil; mainly to the USA, EU and Japan.

Main Imports - Refined petroleum products, heavy machinery, food and fuels; mainly from the USA, EU and Japan.

Economic Performance Profile

Indicator

GDP per capita (] --------------------------------- 198

Real GDP growth (%) --------------------------------- -8.5

Inflation (%) --------------------------------- 2870.5

Unemployment (%) --------------------------------- 39.2

Capital Investment --------------------------------- 8% of GNP

(Sources: IBC USA Licensing Inc.,1995; Reuters; AFP; AP; New African Year Book 1995-96; Europa-Africa South of the Sahara 1996; Countries of the World Yearbook 1997)

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 16, 1996


Tunisia;
Tunisia and Germany Sign Three Financial Agreements


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Tunis - Three financial agreements were signed, November 15, between Tunisia and Germany, as part of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's state visit to Germany.

The agreements, worth 40 million Deutsche Marks, included three loans payable over a 30-year period, with favorable conditions and a 10-year grace period.

The first loan, worth 10 million Deutsche Marks, will finance the elimination and processing of industrial waste. The second loan, worth 20 million Deutsche Marks, will be used to improve efficiency in water management. The third loan, worth 10 million Deutsche Marks, will finance a project of drinking water for rural areas. 

The agreements were signed by Mr. Habib Ben Yahia, Tunisian Minister of Foreign Affairs and Mr. Klaus Kinkel, German minister of Foreign Affairs.

Meanwhile, at the conclusion of his three-day state visit to Germany, President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali expressed his "deep satisfaction" at the positive results of his visit and "the promising prospects" it has opened for Tunisian-German relations.

President Ben Ali expressed his appreciation for the warm welcome and hospitality of his German hosts, especially president Roman Herzog and Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

He also indicated that he was deeply moved by the enthusiastic welcome of the Tunisian community living in Germany. President Ben Ali was very warmly greeted by thousands of cheering Tunisians in both Bonn and Berlin.

The city of Berlin was the last stop of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's three-day state visit to Germany.

President Ben Ali visited yesterday Berlin's City Hall where he was warmly greeted by a large crowd of Tunisians living in Berlin and in neighboring towns. The President was welcomed to the City Hall by Mrs. Christine Bergmann, Vice Mayor of Berlin.

In remarks before Berlin city officials, and members of the Tunisian delegation, President Ben Ali said "the collapse of the Berlin Wall ... remains particularly engraved in the memory of Tunisians because it took place at the same time as our country was undergoing the the reforms which were launched following the Change of November 7, 1987."

Addressing his German hosts, President Ben Ali said that "the cultural richness of your city's history makes Berlin today a place of dialogue and understanding, and a bridge linking two worlds who, in the recent past, were rivals."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

395 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 16, 1996


Tunisia;
Ben Ali Says Food is a 'Fundamental Human Right'


BYLINE: Tunisia Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Rome - In a speech delivered at the World Food Summit currently held in Rome, President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali said "the right to food is closely linked to the right to life, and is, therefore, one of the fundamental human rights."

Prime Minister Hamed Karoui, who delivered President Ben Ali's speech to the Food and Agriculture Organization-sponsored (FAO) Summit said "securing the right to food is one of the most important duties of the State and a priority responsibility of the international community." 

In a speech he delivered before the FAO in Rome in 1991, President Ben Ali called for the establishment of an international charter of solidarity to end hunger in the world.

In a ceremony held November 14, Prime Minister Karoui presented the FAO with a ceramic painting depicting traditional fishing and farming scenes as a gift from President Ben Ali to the international organization.

Note: Full text of President Ben Ali's speech to FAO Summit is available at Tunisia Online website: http://www.tunisiaonline.com/news/FAO_speech.html.

LANGUAGE: English
