396 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 17, 1996


Zaire;
Emergency Update No. 27 on Eastern Zaire (11/16-17)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Nairobi - As thousands of people resumed their trek across the border into Rwanda this morning, doubts were cast on the need to deploy a multi-national force in Eastern Zaire to aid refugees. As of last night a human tide of some 200,000 people had crossed the border into Rwanda. UNHCR believes that as many as 300,000 more may be on the way.

The Rwandan Government and Zairean rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila both said on Saturday that there was no longer any need for sending an international force to Zaire. Kabila, apparent head of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire, said the "job they wanted to do here has been done by us". On Thursday rebels ousted militia and former Rwandan troops from the camp of Mugunga, 15 kilometres west of Goma. This sparked off the mass exodus back to Rwanda. The US Government has said that it will continue to prepare for an international humanitarian mission to Zaire but that it will not make a final decision for several days. The European Commissioner for humanitarian aid, Emma Bonino also cast doubt on the usefulness of a multi-national force if "it could not disarm warring factions". Bonino blames "American reservations" for delaying the decision - approved by the UN Security Council on Friday - to deploy the Canadian-led force. 

Canada, meanwhile, has voiced determination to proceed with the mission. " Planning continues on track", said Foreign Ministry spokesman, John Bell. He said that despite the mass return of refugees, the humanitarian crisis remained. Hundreds of thousands of people still in Zaire were stranded without food, water or shelter. Yesterday AFP reported that planes carrying 24 Canadian soldiers were held up for some hours in Kenya pending the permission of the Rwandan Government to land in Kigali. The soldiers had been deployed to install the Goma headquarters for the Canadian commander of the force, General Maurice Baril. General Baril is due to travel to Germany on Tuesday to meet other military officials involved in the mission. This morning aid agencies were struggling to cope with the sheer mass of people arriving at the border. UNHCR has described the return as the "largest and swiftest" homeward movement of refugees in memory and said that it had mobilised all available staff and resources to meet the needs of the returning refugees. Most new arrivals appear to heading towards the official transit posts in and around Gisenyi but aid workers report that streams of refugees can be seen in the hills heading directly for their former homes. The first 50 buses laid on by UNHCR were due to start ferrying people to their home villages this morning from Nkamira some 21 kilometres from the Gisenyi border crossing. Doctors treating sick children said that their biggest problem so far was diahorrhea and vomiting. A Merlin official said that many children were badly dehydrated and in a state of collapse. In Goma, relief officials said that they feared a cholera epidemic. Some 25 confirmed cases amongst refugees have now been reported from the Goma hospital.

Attempts are being made to provide high protein biscuits to the new arrivals but aid workers in Gisenyi said that distribution is difficult because of the extraordinary numbers of people. WFP announced yesterday that it would begin to distribute food rations once the refugees are back in their home communes.

The High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata said yesterday that she was delighted at the mass return. She stressed, however, that the big challenge for the international community and UNHCR was "to reintegrate returnees in conditions of security". Ogata said that UN Human Rights Field Officers would work closely with UNHCR Field Officers to monitor the returnees in their home communes. AFP has reported that observers in Gisenyi have said that they are concerned about the strain of the mass return on Rwanda's fragile political foundations.

Human Rights Watch/Africa yesterday stressed that any new camps established for refugees in Zaire must exclude anyone bearing arms, including the ex-FAR and militia. Failing to separate out armed elements, said the organisation, would simply repeat the mistakes made in 1994.

So far there has been no agreement on access to the 500,000 or so Rwandan and Burundian refugees scattered in south Kivu. Aid workers are reported today to be continuing attempts to reach them.

Renewed fighting broke out yesterday between rebels and Zairean forces around Sake northwest of Goma yesterday and there was speculation that Zairean troops may be planning a new offensive in the next few days.

Burundi's leader Pierre Buyoya said Saturday that Hutu rebels displaced by the fighting in eastern Zaire were travelling across Burundi and setting up bases in Tanzania. Buyoya said that he was concerned about the clouded relations between Burundi and Dar-es-Salaam.

Relief agencies in Burundi, meanwhile, sent food, medecines, plastic sheeting, blankets, jerrycans and water purification tablets to Cibitoke province - the scene of some of the most intense fighting in Burundi - on Saturday for the 20,000 or so Burundians who have returned to the northwest from eastern Zaire. UNHCR reported that only one refugee turned up at Gatumba transit camp near Bujumbura yesterday. Altogether some 13,500 have crossed at Gatumba and most have been resettled in their home communes. Up to 20,000 more have returned spontaneously to Cibitoke.

Nairobi, 17 November 1996, 11:15 GMT

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Nigeria;
The Pinnacle of Fraud


BYLINE: Ademola Adedoyin, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Lagos - For the very top echelon of the Nigeria Police Force, one assignment has become very urgent in t he past few weeks: Tracking down a little know man by name Chris Iyayi. Until recently a zonal head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in Port Harcourt, Rivers State, the environmentalist is believed to be currently cooling his feet in England after allegedly setting the Central Bank of Nigeria back by over N600 million. CBN's loss, according to police investigation, was Pinacle Commerical Bank's gain. The bank's executive chairman before now was Macaulay Iyayi, elder brother to FEPA's Iyayi.

Sources informed Theweek that Sani Abacha, the head of state, has waded into the matter by instructing the Sam Aluko led National Economic Intelligence Committee to dig into the issue. The head of state is said to have also instructed Ibrahim Coomasie, the inspector-general of police, to do everything possible to bring all the culprits to book. In compliance with the head of state's directive, the Federal Investigation and Intelligence Bureau is said to have been liaising with Interpol, the international police, on how the younger Iyayi could be repatriated back home to face the law. 

Information available to Theweek indicates that the scheme to defraud the CBN by the Iyayis may have started far back as July 1994 when Chris started the zonal office of FEPA in Port Harcourt. He had rented Pinacle Commercial Bank's property for office and residential purposes. With that, a business relationship was effectively established between FEPA and Pinacle, where Macaulay, the elder brother, held sway.

For FEPA to be able to carry out its task of a pollution-free environment, an account was opened with the Port Harcourt zonal office of the Central Bank. FEPA's Port Harcourt zone account number with CBN was 485. For this account, according to Evans Aina, director-general of the agency, believed to have been detained, the mandate given by the headquarters to CBN is that the limit of authority of Iyayi and his co-signatory is N50,000. Tony Ede, CBN's chief image maker, however told Theweek that no such mandate was given to the bank.

Whoever may be telling the truth the Iyayis soon set to work in Port Harcourt. Documents available to Theweek showed that without clearance from the headquarters, the younger Iyayi between December 12, 1993 and August 7, 1996 issued a total of nine CBN cheques amounting to N1.115 billion in favour of Pinacle Commercial Bank. Further investigation revealed that the CBN actually credited eight of these cheques, amounting to N620 million, to Pinacle while the last one for N495 million was stopped.

Pinacle Commercial Bank, in whose favour the "dud cheques" were drawn, presented them to the CBN through the clearing house process and received full value for the eight cheques. By the time the CBN woke up from its slumber, Pinacle, through gross abuse of the clearing process, had overdrawn on its account to the tune of N786 million.

Giving the background to the big scam, Paul Ogwuma, CBN governor, in a letter to Abacha, dated September 9, 1996 said that "CBN in Port Harcourt unwittingly collaborated with FEPA officials while believing that he was assisting a federal government agency in a legitimate transaction." That may be so. But the manner in which the deal went raises some questions which could lead an investigator to concluded that rather than collaborate unwittingly, Udanoh, the CBN Branch Controller, may have actively abetted a crime. For one, it baffles observers that after Iyayi had issued two of such cheques, each for N100 million on the 12th and 15th December 1995, and drawn by PCB, Udanoh wrote to FEPA's Iyayi last January 10, asking him to explain issues relating to cheques. What this implies is that by last January, Iyayi's cheques had become suspect. It is however surprising that between that month and April 8, six similar cheques to the tune of N420 million issued by Iyayi were cleared by PCB at CBN. This Udanoh acknowledged in his letter to Iyayi dated June 3, 1996. Said he: "we are surprised that from the date of our letter under reference January 10 to April 8, 1996, we have received some more of your cheques amounting to N420 million.

The million naira question is: why did CBN honour those Cheques? The question becomes more relevant when it is realised that FEPA never had up to N2 million at a time in its account 485. The view in financial circles is that it was not enough that, as he told the CBN, Chris Iyayi expected transfers to the account from FEPA headquarters. As it turned out, no money came from FEPA headquarters, as none was promised Iyayi. Financial experts are surprised that the CBN acted only after the ninth cheque for N495 million was to be drawn by Port Harcourt FEPA on August 8 in favour of PCB.

In these deals, Aina may have been left to hold the short end of the stick. Although available evidence does not indicate that he connived with Iyayi, Aina's problem may not be over very soon. In his letter of October 12, 1996 to Idris Gidado, Secretary to the Government of the Federation and chairman, FEPA Governing Council, Aina had made reference to Abacha's circular which states that directors-general will be held responsible for any financial loss in their establishments. With this circular, it may not matter whether Aina was an accomplice or not, since it has proved that FEPA as an institution has been used to defraud the federal government.

What is more, Aina's claim that the agency's mandate to CBN clearly stipulates that no zonal office can sign or draw any cheque above N50,000 limit remains a contentious issue. In a letter titled "Change of Authorised Operators/Endorsers Signatories" addressed to the Senior Manager, Mandate Office, Banking Operations Department, Central Bank of Nigeria, FEPA had appointed A.K. Yerima, Chris Iyayi, O.O. Sode and K. Ogbara as signatories to account 485. Two of the signatories, one of which must be zonal head, that is Iyayi, were authorised to sign cheques. Only Iyayi and Yerima had their signature specimens in the document.

The letter dated June 24, 1994 and typed on a plain sheet and not the agency's letterhead paper, also stated in part that for N50,000 and below, any two signatories could sign.

If this letter is genuine, what it means is that contrary to Aina's claim, Yerima and Iyayi could sign for an amount over N50,000. By press time, Theweek could not determine the whereabouts of Yerima.

Chris Iyayi, apparently aware of the seriousness of the issue at hand, has taken off. Interestingly, he is not denying issuing the dubious cheques. While replying to Udonah's letter Iyayi, in his letter dated June 14, 1996 said: "The cheques drawn in favour of Pinacle Commerical Bank were drawn with the hope that tranfers would have been made from my headquarters." Rationalising the issuing of the cheques Iyayi said further: "When I started off this zonal office in Port Harcourt in July 1994, we rented Pinacle Commercial Bank properties for office and residential purposes. We decided to purchase these properties which were fully furnished and so after negotiations, we agreed on installmental payments." He concluded by saying that it was in expectation of the transfers to the account No. 485 that he issued those cheques.

Theweek investigations, however, revealed that Iyayi was not saying the whole truth regarding PCB's property in Port Harcourt. Last September Aina had set up a two-man team, comprising A. Adegoroye, A FEPA director, and one Okoye, a principal internal auditor, which he sent to Port Harcourt to look into the fraud matter. The team reported: "Meanwhile our two years tenancy for the FEPA office block owned by Pinacle Commercial Bank expired on August 31, 1996 and the bank has written to remind the agency to renew the tenancy being N1.4 million for the next two years as per the agreement." This contrasts sharply with Iyayi's claim that the agency has brought the rented PCB properties and that it was for the instalmental payment that the dud cheques were drawn in favour of PCB.

Apparently foreseeing trouble, Chris Iyayi left Port Harcourt September 8, for Lagos with a promise to return to his base the following day. The next that was heard of Iyayi was a letter dated September 15, written from London, informing Aina that he had to make an urgent trip to attend to his "very sick son who has been hospitalised since September 3 1996."

While Chris may be out of reach at least for now, Macaulay of PCB has not been that lucky. He was nabbed by the security agents at the airport while trying to leave the country. He has since remained a guest of FIIB men at Alagbon helping them to crack the N1.115 billion mystery.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Nigeria;
Azikiwe: There He Goes In A Blaze of Controversy.


BYLINE: Louis Onyia, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Lagos - An uninformed visitor to the ancestral home of Obed Azikiwe along Okosi Road in Ogbeabu village, Onitsha, November 2 would have mistakenly thought that Emeka Azikiwe, second son of the late Nnamdi Azikiwe, was there to inspect facilities for his father's burial ceremony slated for November 16. But unknown to most people, Emeka has on that day accompanied Chuma, his elder brother, to the ancestral home where Onuorah Azikiwe, their uncle, and 18 other Ozo title holders from Ogbeabu village had gathered for a pre- initiation ceremony which would enable Chuma to take the prestigious Ozo title the next day, November 3. The initiation of Chuma into the Ozo title, according to sources, would give him an edge traditionally over other members of Zik's immediate household during and after the burial of the legend.

Elsewhere in Ogbeabu village in Inland Town, Onitsha, the Umuada Ogbeabu Ozomaocha (Zik's extended sisters) had risen from a meeting the previous week where they discussed the burial and resolved that Uche Azikiwe, wife of the late elder statesman, must not attend the burial ceremony of her late husband. "She should stay at Onuiyi Haven, Nsukka," the women said. 

Uche incurred the wrath of the Umuada on October 20. On that day she had allegedly walked out on a meeting where the Umuada had asked her to apologise to Chuma, Ofala Okagbue, Obi of Onitsha, and one other highly placed Onitsha indigene over her "abominable and libelous letter" to Laz Unaogu, Minister for Special Duties and Chairman, National Planning Committee for the burial of Zik. In the letter, Uche had disclosed the remote and immediate cause of the squabbles between her and the first son of the Owelle. She insisted that the late elder statesman should be buried at Inosi Onira Retreat contrary to the earlier announcement by Chuma that Zik would be buried at Ogbeabu, their family home. The letter by Uche, according to the Umuada, tantamounts to washing Zik's dirty linen in public.

But Uche says that she was pushed to write the letter by "Mr. (Chuma) Azikiwe's unrelented efforts to disgrace and disrespect and humiliate (her) late husband." In the letter, Uche said: "My husband's wish was that he be buried in his 'Iba' (his personal homestead) at Inosi Onira Retreat, Onitsha. That was in February 1996 at UNTH Enugu and immediately I contacted Abuja and Col. Mike Attah, the then military administrator of Anambra State, with regards to the reconstruction of Inosi Onira, Retreat which was gutted by fire in July 1994,"

Apart from the alleged insistence by the Owele that he should be buried in his own house, Uche contended that, based on Igbo tradition, which Onitsha is part of, other eminent indigenes of Onitsha such as Cecilia Arinze, Zik's sister; Akunwanne Sam Chudi, described as the alter ego to the late Owelle; Onuorah Ekpechi, private physician to Zik for over 30 years; Arthur Mbanefo and A.N.A Modebe, were of the opinion that a man is buried in his compound. The only exception, Uche said, is if the person was a failure in life and had no house of his own, in which case he could be buried in his father's house. Uche reasoned that to bury Zik at Ogbeabu is to liken him to such worthless persons in the society. According to her, the entire members of Azikiwe's household, excluding Chuma and his younger ones by his late mother, were unanimous that Zik should be buried at Inosi Onira Retreat.

In order to convince the minister that Chuma is not a credible authority as far as the site and burial ceremony of the Owelle are concerned, Uche alleged that Zik parted ways with Chuma 13 years ago when Chuma "intentionally" excluded the name of Zik from the obituary programme and other activities for the burial of late Flora Azikiwe, Zik's late senior wife and Chuma's mother. She stated further that during the quarrel between the Owelle and his son over the attitude of the latter to his father, Zik once drew the attention of Jonathan Onyemelukwe, Anglican bishop of the Niger, to the matter but nothing came out of the meeting held among the three. Uche claimed that when the mediatory efforts of the bishop failed, Chuma vowed in protest that Zik must be buried in the village at Ogbeabu whenever he died. She maintained that now that Zik is dead, to bury him the village, against his wish, would amount to according more recognition and respect to the wish of Chuma than that of Zik. "I will resist with the last drop of blood in my vein any move by Chuma or his cohorts to disrespect my late husband's wish to be buried in his personal 'Iba" Inosi Onira Retreat," Uche said.

To further justify her position, Uche pointed out that throughout the two months that Zik stayed in London clinic and the six months he stayed in the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital Enugu for treatment, Chuma neither visited nor wrote to inquire about the health of the man. "On two occasions during the lifetime of the Owelle," Uche said, "Zik in writing banned Chuma from stepping into any of his premises." She pointed out that the ban was yet to be lifted before the Owelle passed away last May 11.

The wife of the late sage argued further that the Obi of Onitsha, whom she accused of urging Chuma on, has no customary right to decide where the Owelle should be buried. The argument, according to her, is based on the fact that the Obi had no say and was not consulted to decide where other illustrious title holders from Onitsha who died before Zik were to be buried. Uche told Theweek at Nsukka that she does not speak with the press for now. However, one of her sons who spoke on her authority, mentioned Isaac Mbanefo, Odu of Onitsha, who died in 1994, and Philip Anatogu, Onowu of Onitsha who also died in 1994, as highly placed Onitsha indigenes who were buried in their personal homes without anyone asking the Obi to decide where they should be buried. Uche, speaking through her son, maintained that the decision on where Zik should be buried is primarily that of his nuclear family and nobody else's.

While accepting that Chuma, biologically is the first son of the Owelle, Uche's son argued that since he was not on speaking terms with their father for many years before he died, Chuma has no legal and customary right to decide what should be done to the remains of the elder statesman. "Moreover," he continued, "in a polygamous family (such as Zik's), decision as to where he should be buried should be that of the majority of the members of the family and not that of an individual." He said that Zik is survived by nine sons, all graduates, and that with the exception of the last two, the others are all independent. He discredited Chuma by saying that "he is not married and has never been married, while most of his younger ones are married, thus making them more responsible men who should not be brushed aside in matters that affect their late father."

Contrary to the argument by Chuma that his insistence that the Owelle should be buried in his ancestral home was informed by the culture and tradition of Onitsha people, Uche said through her son that "the same culture and tradition that Chuma is purporting to uphold bars him from participating in the burial of the Owelle since they were not on speaking terms till death." She denied a newspaper publication that she recently visited Onitsha to plead with the Umuada over the matter. According to Uche, she has no quarrel with the women or any other person in Onitsha. To her, whatever quarrel that arises over her husband's burial "is a family affair which should be handled internally."

Contradicting Uche, Maria Ikebuaku, secretary-general of Umuada Ozomaocha, told Theweek that their decision that Uche should not accompany Zik's corpse to Onitsha and should be excluded from participating in the funeral of Zik is irrevocable. Hear her: "Uche has not done what we asked her to do for insulting our king and Chuma Azikiwe, so we have decided that she should stay put at Onuiyi haven, Nsukka."

Azuka Ndiwe, another leading member of Umuada, spoke in a similar vein. She told Theweek that nothing would make Zik to be buried at Inosi Onira. Said Ndiwe: "The burial ceremony can be held at Inosi Onira but even if the government buries him there, we will exhume his body later and bury him at Ogbeabu." She argued that, were Zik a Muslim, he would have been buried long ago according to Muslim laws and custom "but here we are telling them what the culture says and they are saying no."

Neither Chuma nor Emeka would like to join issue with their step mother. Asked to comment on the preparations and burial arrangements for Zik, Chuma told Theweek at Ogbeabu that he was busy, adding though: " I am the Owelle regent."

Chuma had wittingly or unwittingly marched on the stomach of his step mother during the official announcement of Zik's death. On that day, Chuma, after officially disclosing that Zik had joined his ancestors, added without recourse to other members of the family that would be buried at Ogbeabu, the family home. The rift deepened on May 28, when Chuma suspended all condolence visits to both Onitsha and Onuiyi Haven Nsukka. Few days later, Molokwu, Uche's eldest son, countered Chuma, saying: "Chuma is not the spokesman of our family." From that moment, the squabbles among the Azikiwes became a national issue.

As the controversy deepened last wee, some Onitsha indigenes who spoke with Theweek wondered why Zik should ask to be buried in Inosi Onira when he buried Flora, his eldest wife, at Ogbeabu. Whatever may be the case, Uche's wish seems to be the government's command. Lemmy Akakem construction Company, the firm handling Zik's Mausoleum, has gone far in the construction at Inosi Onira. The troubling question is, what happens--to Zik's family and his body-- after the burial?


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


399 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Nigeria;
Flight 086: Death at Dusk?


BYLINE: Akaninyene Esiere, Theweek (Lagos)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lagos - Tragedy befell the country last week as unconfirmed reports had it that 141 people, some of them prominent Nigerians may have died in a plane crash. The entire 132 passengers and nine crew member were feared dead in an air crash involving an ADC Airline Boeing 727 in which they were traveling from Port Harcourt to Lagos was reported missing few minutes to landing time. Officials of the control tower at Murtala Mohammed Airport, Ikeja said they lost contact with the Flight ADC 086 airplane at exactly 5.05 p.m. last Thursday. 

Immediately the plane was reported missing, several search and rescue operations involving the police, the air force, officials of the Federal Airports Authority for Nigeria and the fire service went in search of the missing plane. There were fears that the ill-fated plane had crashed into any of the swampy areas surrounding Lagos. By the early hours of last Friday, the rescue operations were combing such swampy areas around Ikorodu, Epe, Sagamu and Ijebu-Ode on the outskirts of Lagos.

But by press time, there were no clues as to the whereabouts of the doomed plane. Unconfirmed reports had it that a pilot traveling on the same route as the affected plane said he sighted a ball of fire in the air around Ikorodu about the time the control tower said it lost contact with the plane. There were reports that the plane may have developed engine problem, caught fire and killed all the passengers on board.

At the Opebi, Lagos head office of ADC Airlines, officials wee hard-put pacifying hundreds of anxious Nigerians and expatriates who besieged the office to get more information about the plane crash. Officials of the airline said they were still expecting the flight manifest of the plane from Port Harcout. Unconfirmed report had it that Claude Ake, a professor and national merit award winner was in the plane, as he was scheduled as a guest to Arne Ekseldt, the Swedish ambassador. Expatriates working for Schlumberger, an oil services company, and ED&F Man LTD, a commodity trading firm, were also feared to be in the ill-fated plane.

Augustine Okon, managing director of the airline was reported as saying that an official statement would not be ready until the situation was confirmed.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


400 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Women's Bank Looks at Stagnation Of Women Empowerment


BYLINE: Florence Bamanyaki, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Nairobi - "While women themselves lament and decry the continuation of the status quo, many continue to display a distinct hesitation and reluctance to take urgent decisive actions to rectify the situation."

Such were the words of the Executive Director of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) Ms. Elizabeth Dowdeswell as she officiated at the closing of a week-long biannual global meeting of the Women's World Banking (WWB) in Nairobi, Kenya, from November 4 to 8, 1996.

Indeed if one judges by the official figures on the economic situation, very many ethnic groups in Africa would by now have starved to death because of the barren and unsustaining environment among other reasons - needless to mention persistent civil strife in some nations.

However, women, men and children survive, thanks to women's astounding ability to get organised and adapt, although there are no statistics to reflect this state of affairs. 

One should not be quick to attribute this astounding ability to the waves of women emancipation. For long before the struggles for equality began, women were already culturally expected to keep the family going, depending of course on the natural resources available.

United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM) statistics indicate that the woman is the sole breadwinner in one out of three households throughout the world. Today, for every woman living in poverty, there are about four hungry children. Thus the size of a mother's income has a direct bearing on the nutritional health of her children. The higher her income, the less the likelihood that her children will suffer from hunger and malnutrition.

Women do not always receive remuneration for what they provide - food, water, fuel, care - but as these essential commodities grow increasingly scarce they more and more often must be paid for within the cash economy. The foregoing clearly explains why life or the quality of life depends upon purchasing power.

Such is the concern of the Women's World Banking (WWB), a non-profit making financial organization born in 1979 with the aim of building businesses and economies with a human face. The human face in this respect is creating innovative systems that help poor women entrepreneurs gain access to financial services, markets and information, enabling them to build their assets and economic roles.

According to WWB President Nancy Barry, the worldwide women's body with over 50 affiliates in more than 40 countries, is the only local global network opening access to finance, information and markets for women micro and small entrepreneurs.

To become an affiliate of WWB, the organization must be a micro- finance organization run exclusively by women and the women should hold no political responsibility whatsoever.

Nancy Barry explains this criteria with the belief that most governments and political ideologies do acknowledge that women are the cornerstones of human existence, yet they still fail to give due priority and resources to devise top quality policies on women's affairs.

The Kenyan Women's Finance and Credit Trust (KWFCT) is leading in Africa with a clientele of 6,200 women. No wonder Kenya hosted the WWB global meeting which focused mainly on finding strategies of improving women's economic empowerment in Africa. The participants hoped to learn from the Kenyan experience of building financial services for her low-income women.

Other affiliates with small and growing micro-finance operations are finance trusts of the Gambia, Zambia, Rwanda and Uganda. According to the President of Duterimbere, the Rwanda Women's finance trust, Vinantie Rukarugonwa there are still constraints of institutional capacity to mobilize funds and also client connection and participation. She added that the loan tracking systems are still very poor. This, attributed to the recent genocide that left more than 70 per cent of the Rwandese women widows and orphans.

The idea of giving loans to the low-income women is an excellent one but the lack of collateral often proves a major obstacle when one wishes to increase income.

Well, what is happening is that African women are experimenting with peer pressure so that such groups can be the basis for further expansion. Some women use their monthly harvest as collateral to obtain credit fund loans. In this way, they also overcome the resistance of commercial banks to " uneconomic" small loans.

On the other hand, the trend of feminism which is being followed may endanger the African family. The message ordinary women seem to be receiving is -- "we are waging a war against men and the culture."

It seems that most women's movements are advocating something similar to dividing roles equally. This attitude is causing problems for family life. Men seem to be content with their traditional role while women are seen as revolutionary when they advance their notions. This brings tension which may have bad consequences.

General violence against women is justified on cultural grounds. Culture itself cannot be changed overnight especially in Africa, where collective responsibility as a community is well expressed through the roles defined for men and women.

Waging war against men or against our culture is a non-starter. The militant approach will generally make men defensive and this will precipitate a break down in communication. Instead, men should be persuaded to respect women as mothers of the world and persons with talents and capabilities. Women should also be encouraged to be proud of being who they are and advancing their cause as members with common objectives.

The development process has undeniably released many forces of change. It is crucial now to influence and intervene in the process to ensure that these forces create more opportunities than barriers for the poorest women to have more control over their lives and to have more choices.

Women's World Banking (WWB) is a worthwhile venture but it should begin dealing directly with the grassroots women for even better results.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


401 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Kenya;
Kenyans Call For "Change Of Heart"


BYLINE: Osman Njuguna, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Nairobi - Last September, the Kenyan government released its long-awaited findings on devil worship in the country, officially declaring that the practice was real and widespread.

The two-page government statement nevertheless drew curious reactions from a cross-section of Kenyans who publicly voiced their concern that the brief statement did not represent a full detailed report of the findings by the Presidential Commission of Enquiry on Devil Worship set up in 1994. The government statement, quoting self-confessed devil worshippers, revealed that the satanic cults practised rituals such as human sacrifice, the drinking of human blood, cannibalism and Black Mass.

Other rituals, according to the findings included incantations in intelligible languages, sexual abuse and rape, especially of children and minors, black magic, use of narcotic drugs and snakes.

However, the publication of this brief report prompted a group of Kenyan church leaders to hold prayers for the nation. Rev. Ibrahim Omondi, the coordinator of the prayers held at Nairobi's Uhuru (Freedom) Park on November 9, explained that the decision to conduct national prayers was also influenced by other factors which included a visit to a country suffering the wounds of civil strife, political and ethnic mistrust. 

Kenyan church leaders drawn from various denominations had visited the Burundian capital, Bujumbura, in 1995, where they witnessed the extent to which civil war has affected the Central African country.

"It was after our visit to Burundi, where we prayed and praised God for His mercy on the Burundian community despite the troubled time of the nation, that we decided to form Kenya's Prophetic Destiny, an organization that would facilitate the hosting of national prayers," Rev. Omondi, who is also the founder of Kenya's Dove Christian Fellowship told APS.

Their visit, he said, led them to believe that Kenya was not immune to the kind of political set-ups and problems that have brought about fighting, killings and displacement of innocent human beings in Burundi, Rwanda and other African countries.

"Issues such as tribal and racial animosity that are at the core of killings between Hutus and Tutsis in Rwanda and Burundi are already here with us. We also have corruption, mismanagement and other evil-related concerns that could easily lead our nation to what others already find themselves in," noted Rev. Omondi.

It is with such foresight that Kenyan church leaders, under the auspices of Kenya's Prophetic Destiny, a group of Christians called by God to see, hear, touch and feel the pain and anguish of the Kenyan nation, organised a day of prayers for the nation calling for repentance and reconciliation, under the theme Back to God, derived from the Book of Chronicles 7:13-14.

In his opening remarks during the prayers, Rev. Omondi noted that by coming together to pray for the nation "God, will have mercy and bring hope and healing in our land, according to His promise in 2 Chronicles 7:14 that...'If my people, who are called by my name will humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven and will forgive their sins and will heal their land."

When he officially opened the prayers, attended by nearly 3,000 worshippers drawn from various church backgrounds and beliefs, retired Anglican Archbishop Manasses Kuria, cautioned; "We will not lend a hand to name calling, the pointing of fingers, nor will we apportion blame to any individual, group of people or organisation.

"We recognise that the sins of Kenyans are our sins. We will individually and collectively repent of these sins, turn from wickedness and seek reconciliations with other Kenyans and with God," he prayed.

He pointed out that Kenyans cannot honestly claim to have fared better than Burundians, for example, "for we have shed blood among ourselves."

Archbishop Kuria, who now runs a street children's home, the Jehovah Jire Children's home in Nairobi, was referring to what were believed to be politically motivated ethnic land clashes that rocked parts of Kenya in the 1991/93 period, resulting in loss of lives, displacement of thousands of people and loss and damage to properties.

"We need to be honest and pray for everything -- the victims of the land clashes, corruption within our institutions, mistrust, tribal and racial animosity among ourselves and lack of honesty within and among ourselves, which is all contrary to what God would want us to see, feel, touch and witness," he elaborated.

The organisers had selected the prayers under three categories, namely prayers for reconciliation in the society, reconciliation with those in authority and reconciliation in the church. The prayers also took prophetic actions on concerns such as tribal, general and inter-racial tensions and the breakdown of marriages.

Leading in the prayers for reconciliation in the church, Bishop William Tumsing of the Deliverance Church prayed that the missionary instituted churches on one side and the Pentecostal ones on the other would find solace and harmony to work together.

"We feel strongly that God should intervene and help us to overcome the sin of tension between the old and new churches. We know it exists, we know it is harmful. We know God will lead us into praying for repentance and reconciliation as one of the ways to battle it out," he prayed.

Former Moderator of Kenya's Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA) Dr. George Wanjau, offering intercessory prayers asked that God would help Kenyans practice justice, humanity and honesty, and more so within the power corridors of the parliament, judiciary and the City Hall. He prayed for reconciliation with those in authority.

And dedicating prayers to reconciliation in the society, Retired Major John Seii, called for God's intervention "so that seemingly conflicting" ethnic groups can live in harmony as they did before the infamous land clashes, which gripped parts of Rift Valley and Western Provinces especially between 1991 and 1993.

"We need to call on God to come and live with us as part of our reconciliation and repentance. We need to say 'No' to tribal and racial animosity. We need to tell our leaders to stop to divide us on whichever lines,-- tribal, racial or colour," Seii prayed.

Other clergy, among them Daniel Seruwanga, Elizabeth Kamau, Wilson Mamboleo, Harry Das and Bishop James Ocholla, prayed for the end of "racial animosity" among the Kenyans of African origin, Asians and Whites.

"We need to pray to God for the end of the racial animosity that exists among us, taking into account that although we are different in various human aspects, we are all the same in the eyes of God," they observed.

Rev. Ambrose Nyangao from the Baptist Church prayed that God would sustain Kenyan families and marriages. "The fact that many families and marriages are satanically being put on trial, demands that we call God to come in and intervene for the present and future prosperity of the nation," he interceded.

Talking to APS, Rev. Omondi described the prayers as the beginning of a " long journey." He said similar session would be conducted in other parts of the country, with the aim of bringing every Kenyan into the arena.

"But the most important factor of the exercise is to first believe in repentance and reconciliation, be ready to come to God and pray, with the aim to effect change in our day-to-day life," he added.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

402 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Kenya;
Who Will Be Kenya's Next Anglican Archbishop?


BYLINE: Jeff Mbure, APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1867 words


 

Nairobi - In both secular and religious circles, the choice of a key church leader is considered crucial to the process of general developments in most countries with a large Christian following. Kenya, with a national population of 26 million people, more than 60 per cent of whom claim to be Christians is no exception to such a norm.

The Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK), closely behind the Catholic Church in numerical strength, embraces members from different ethnic groups, all of whom have significantly contributed to the shaping of this East African nation which gained independence from Britain in 1963.

The search for the third archbishop of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK) which began in earnest two years ago when the long serving head of the church Archbishop Manasses Kuria retired, has taken interesting twists including amendments to the church's constitution so that the process could be hastened for the benefit of the faithful.

As the clock ticks closer to the November 20 election date, Anglicans and adherents of other Christian denominations are eager to know who will capture the church's top seat which is also being contested by the acting head of the CPK Bishop David Gitari (Kirinyaga Diocese). 

Apart from Gitari, there are four other bishops in the race. They include Bishop Benjamin Mwanzia Nzimbi of the Kitui Diocese (Eastern Province) Bishop Horace Etemesi of Butere Diocese, Bishop Stephen Kewasis of Eldoret Diocese and Bishop Joseph Wasonga of Maseno West.

Analysts of church politics single out the ethnic factor as one of the most likely elements that will determine who will head the CPK into the 21st century.

But the 210-member electoral college of the church will not have it easy on November 20 as there are many other factors to consider in deciding who the spiritual head of Kenya's 3 million Anglicans will be.

As for ethnicity, the first archbishop of the CPK, Festo Olang came from the Luhya community while the second, Manasses Kuria belongs to the country's largest ethnic group, the Kikuyu. The Luhya, mainly inhabitants of Western Kenya are the third largest group after the Luo, neighbours in the west.

Following the exit of Archbishop Kuria in December 1994 upon reaching the mandatory retirement age of 65 years, Gitari has been leading the CPK as both the archbishop and dean, steering the church through some of its stormiest periods, especially increased calls for more dioceses.

One of the most recent incidents in the CPK circles was the handling of the long-standing enthronement and consecration of the bishop elect of Kajiado diocese, Rev. Bernard Njoroge. The issue climaxed in a reported physical confrontation between the followers of the bishop -elect and those of Bishop Gitari, during which Rev. Njoroge was hurt.

Another was the case of the former bishop of Mount Kenya South Diocese, Bishop George Muiru Njuguna who was forced into early retirement in August 1995 following much publicised allegations of moral misconduct and misappropriation of church funds.

Among the candidates, 58-year-old Gitari is the senior most diocesan head in the church in terms of the number of years he has served as well as the position he currently occupies. He became bishop of Kirinyaga Diocese in Eastern Province in 1975.

Bishop Wasonga, represents a younger generation of CPK church leaders who are viewed as favourites among the youth members of the church. He comes from Nyanza Province in Western Kenya.

He is also chairman of Kenya's largest grouping of Protestant churches under the 40-member umbrella of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) which includes the CPK itself.

The Eldoret Diocese Bishop Kewasis from the Rift Valle Province, succeeded the late Bishop Alexander Kipsang Muge who died in a car crash in 1991.

Bishop Etemesi was elected the first bishop of the Butere Diocese in Western Province in 1993. With a background in communication, having been a past manager of Uzima Press, Etemesi also served as the Africa secretary of the London-based World Association for Christian Communication (WACC) prior to his appointment and subsequent consecration as bishop.

The composition of the electoral college is aimed at making the election as fair and free as possible. It is made up of all the 22 diocesan bishops of the CPK, eight representatives from each of the dioceses, four being laity and four clergy except in the case of Nairobi diocese which is given four more electors in view of the fact that the archbishop automatically becomes the bishop of Nairobi.

Commenting on the electoral process, retired Archbishop Kuria told this writer from his Buru Buru office of the Jehovah Jire Children's home, that he has no doubt the election will be free and fair. He compared the process to that of electing the head of the worldwide Roman Catholic Church. He at the same time appealed to Christians to pray hard so that God can show them who He has chosen to lead them.

The elections come at a time when the CPK is at crossroads as it moves into the next millennium. First the church has found itself being increasingly challenged to tackle societal ills especially the question of poverty elimination, good governance, the housing crisis, problems of street children, urbanization, diminishing food security and the disabled among a host of other problems.

Some observers say the CPK like other main line churches, has not seen rapid growth in terms of church membership. This slow progress CPK has been blamed on poor leadership and lack of spirituality in the teachings of the church.

Infact, top leaders of the CPK, including retired Archbishop Kuria and Bishop Gitari have openly admitted that the church is facing a kind of moral and social crisis, citing actual incidents as obvious indications of this void.

On the political scene, the CPK has realised that it has to do more than in the past to pressurize the government to bring about the desired political and economic changes that Kenyans are advocating. The church's Justice and Peace programme has had to be strengthened and more funds channelled through the civic education programme.

This of course has not endeared the church to the establishment. The ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party politicians have constantly accused the church of being the "Church of the Politics of Kenya", wanting the clergy to confine themselves to the pulpit.

But the CPK has continued to stress its commitment to the salvation of man in totality -- economically, socially, spiritually and psychologically.

Critics on the other hand have also voiced the need for the CPK to cleanse its house before pointing accusing fingers at others. They point out several instances where the church has not performed to the people's expectations. The delayed enthronement and consecration of Rev.Njoroge of Kajiado diocese, the bishops' failure to speak with one voice on crucial matters such as tribal clashes and the life-styles of bishops themselves, are just a few of the weak areas these critics have focussed on.

When the electoral college meets, the members will have to search hard for the man who can give the CPK a new lease of life. The person to be elected will definitely have a heavy burden to carry in repairing the damage done to the image of the church, by giving it a new vision and mandate to serve Christians in totality.

The huge challenges ahead of the CPK have in the recent past prompted several amendments to its constitution in order to bring it into the reality of today. The election of the third archbishop would not have been possible as the previous constitution had stipulated that all the seats must be filled before the election of the archbishop. Now the two dioceses without bishops can be represented by the vicar-general in the electoral college.

Commenting on the election of the archbishop, the CPK Provincial Chancellor, lawyer Paul Kihara Kariuki, assured APS that all the necessary steps have been taken to ensure that the process is free and fair. He said that the whole exercise is being handled with all the confidentiality possible and that the question of rigging should be totally ruled out.

He at the same dispelled fears of political interference which many Christians to whom this reporter talked to could not rule out. Since the CPK is the largest Protestant Church with a sizeable following, it is viewed as a force to reckon with by politicians and government because of the influence it can have on the faithful. There is no secret that politicians have sought the support and even blessings of the CPK bishops in those areas where the church is strong before venturing into politics. During past elections of the archbishop, some bishops have levelled accusation of political interference.

In the first elections of the church after independence in 1963, Festo Olang beat Obadiah Kariuki.

During the second elections held in November 1979, Manasses Kuria turned tables on a favourite candidate Henry Okullu, taking control of the CPK for the next 15 years.

The November 20 elections will be held at the All Saints Cathedral, Nairobi. The results will be expected to be announced immediately unless unexpected complications arise. The winner will also occupy the grand Anglican Archbishop's residence next to State House, Nairobi.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Continental Church Body Launches Assembly Preparations


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Nairobi - The All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) secretariat has launched preparatory activities for the organisation's 7th Assembly to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia from October 5 to 13, 1997.

At the same time, the AACC has written to all its member churches all over Africa, asking them to launch preparations for the forthcoming Assembly. Speaking to APS, the Assembly co-ordinator Rev. Setri Nyomi disclosed that each member church will have to plan when the launching should take place, " but of course taking into consideration the time left, between now and October next year. 

Dr. Setri, who is also the executive secretary for Christian and Family Life Education Programme, together with the AACC general secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda and his deputy Rev. Phylis Byrd, joined other members of staff in a ceremony to launch activities leading to the 7th Assembly which will meet under the theme, Troubled But not Destroyed.

The events during the launching of the forthcoming Assembly included a moving sermon by Rev. Chipenda, historical facts about the organisation's past assemblies and the symbolic watering of a palm tree, as a sign of " growth and hope" for this pan-African organisation of 142 member churches and affiliated national Christian councils in 39 African countries.

The first AACC Assembly was held in the Ugandan capital, Kampala in 1963 under the theme Freedom and Unity, one month after the Organization of African Unity (OAU) was established.

The second one was held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast (1969) under the theme Working with Christ in Africa Today, Lusaka, Zambia (1974) under the subject Living no Longer for Ourselves... But for Christ, Nairobi, Kenya, (1981) under the theme To Follow the Light of Christ; Lome, Togo (1987) under the theme You Shall Be my Witnesses, while Harare, Zimbabwe, hosted the last assembly in 1992, which discussed the subject, Abundant Life in Jesus Christ.

According to Dr. Setri, the AACC committee, charged with the responsibilities of the preparation and the holding of the organization's next Assembly, has drawn up a budget of US$1.59 million.

Out of this amount, the member churches of the AACC are expected to raise some US$500,000 while the remaining amount will come from ecumenical partners. He also announced during the launching here that the AACC staff members have already raised US$10,000 towards the Assembly.

Addressing the same gathering, which was also attended by Mr. Melaku Kifle, the Coordinator for Refugee and Migration Services at the World Council of Churches (WCC), Geneva and Mr. Lee Holland, the Africa Secretary for United Church of Canada, Rev. Chipenda reminded staff that Africa is "really troubled but fortunately not totally destroyed".

Rev. Phylis Byrd told the congregation that "even in deep troubles, God has always guided His people and therefore the African continent and its people, should continue to embrace God, even when troubles become unbearable."

The climax of the ceremony was the symbolic watering of the palm tree, placed at the AACC chapel, where the ceremony took place. Mr. Elias Nkanata, the longest-serving member of staff at the AACC, Mr. Lee Holland and Ms. Angelique Bell watered the tree.

"Mr. Nkanata represents the history of the organization (he has served AACC for the last 31 years), Mr. Holland, the ecumenical partnership and Angelique Bell, represents the 'new blood' at the AACC, having joined the organization two months ago", explained Rev. Byrd.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


404 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


South Africa;
Meeting Set Between Tutu And Former President Botha


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Johannesburg - The stage is set for a face to face meeting in the coming week between former South African president Pieter Botha and the chairman of the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

On October 30, an apartheid-era security policeman said Brigadier Jack Cronje claimed that Botha was fully aware of police death squads which targeted anti-apartheid activists in the 1980s.

Cronje told the commission that Botha, as chairman of the now- defunct State Security Council, would have been kept fully informed of the activities of the death squads. 

Cronje, a former member of a police death squad based on Vlakplaas farm outside Pretoria, is one of five ex-policemen to confess involvement in 40 murders in testimony to a Johannesburg hearing of the truth commission, which is probing political crimes during the apartheid era.

The previous week, former police commissioner General Johan van der Merwe told the hearing that Botha ordered the 1988 bombing of a Johannesburg religious office in which 23 people were injured and that Botha was behind apartheid-era abuses. Botha has not yet commented on the claims.

Cronje said on November 13 that police hit squads were established to keep in power the National Party (NP), which ruled South Africa under the apartheid system from 1948 until historic all-race elections in 1994, and to combat communism.

"Without the security police, the National Party would not have stayed in government one week," Cronje said.

Asked whether security police hit squads could be considered the "iron fist" of the NP, he replied: "Yes, it could be understood in that way.

"The security police were primarily there for political purposes, and the political purpose of the National Party government."

Cronje earlier told the commission that a crack army unit planned and carried out the 1986 murders of anti-apartheid activist Dr. Fabian Ribeiro and his wife Florence.

Cronje, according to the domestic news agency SAPA, told the hearing that the assassins were two Angolans who were flown to South Africa by the special forces, an anti-guerrilla military unit.

He said he believed Ribeiro had been murdered because of his involvement in recruiting members of the then-outlawed African National Congress (ANC) for training abroad and providing medical assistance to activists.

Ribeiro and his wife were gunned down in their home in Mamelodi black township, near Pretoria, on December 1, 1986.

But on November 13, Archbishop Tutu, visiting the United States, said in Chicago that he hoped to arrange a meeting next week with former South African president Pieter Botha to discuss allegations that he had ordered apartheid-era atrocities.

Botha, now an octogenarian in poor health, was recently approached by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission which Tutu heads to privately provide answers about apartheid-era abuses.

Tutu, who is in the US to attending a general assembly of the National Council of Churches, said he had suggested that the meeting be held last week but said Botha felt this was too soon.

"He (Botha) suggested this coming Friday (November 15). Unfortunately I'm in America," Tutu said. "We are looking for (a meeting) some time...when I get back next week."

In September, convicted police killer, Colonel Eugene de Kock, who has been sentenced to more than 200 years in prison on 89 charges, including six murders, named Botha as having also ordered the bombing of a Johannesburg labour union office in the 1980s.

Botha and his successor to the presidency, Frederik de Klerk were both aware of numerous apartheid abuses, de Kock further claimed but the two ex- presidents have denied knowledge of any apartheid- sponsored abuses.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Algeria;
Algerian Fundamentalists Extend Attacks To Villages


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Bensalah, Algeria - Some 12 people, including four women and three children, were slaughtered early on November 13 in this village in northern Algeria, in an apparent reprisal for opposition to Muslim extremists.

According to eyewitnesses, some 15 members of the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) stole into Bensalah, a small village near the town of Blida, and slit the throats of the 12 civilians, 10 of whom belonged to the same family, witnesses said.

One of the members of the family was a "patriot" of the self-defence group which protects the village from terror attacks, a group whose members the extremist Islamic groups, who have battled the government in Algiers for almost five years, have vowed to kill to avenge resistance to their uprising. 

"They also set fire to a van which alerted the other villagers, who saw the flames," one villager said, adding: "The patriots came out into the night and fired shots into the air. The terrorists fled. We thought they would have then attacked a second family."

A small group from the self-defence unit were guarding the village at the time of the attack, but they said their cover was trenched.

The killings brought to 76 the number of people killed this month. Attacks by Islamic militants have increased in recent weeks as a constitutional referendum called by President Liamine Zeroual looms.

The fundamentalists are opposed to the referendum, which is due to be held on November 28, and which if passed will strengthen presidential powers.

The Blida region south of Algiers was the scene on November 5 of one of the bloodiest attacks of Algeria's war between the army and fundamentalist militants, during which 32 people were slaughtered by Muslim extremists in the mountain hamlet of Sidi El Kabir.

The same day, suspected Islamic extremists slaughtered a family of four, including a pregnant woman in a village near the hamlet, some 50 kilometres south of the Algerian capital, Algiers.

On November 11, a car bomb blast killed 10 people and wounded more than 20 in an Algiers suburb.

The precise motives for the attacks remain unclear, but many fall into the category of revenge operations against the civilian population and against self-defence groups.

Several thousand such groups have been set up, with the encouragement of the Algerian authorities, to ward off attacks by extremists.

The fundamentalists rose up in January 1992 after the army intervened to cancel elections that the now-banned Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) was poised to win. The ensuing violence has left tens of thousands of people dead.

Authorities have been insisting for a year that they are now facing only " residual terrorism."

But part of the opposition disputes the claim, saying that in fact the security situation is worsening and will deteriorate further with the holding of the referendum.

Part of the legal opposition has just launched an "appeal for peace," which has been supported by the FIS, now in exile abroad.

The FIS has also condemned attacks on civilians, but its armed wing, the Islamic Salvation Army, often claims responsibility for attacks on self- defence groups.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Seeks Alternatives To America's Veto


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

New York - Intense backroom lobbying is going on at the United Nations in New York in search of a successor to the current United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros Ghali, 73, of Egypt.

Boutros Boutros Ghali is not ready to retire, but the government of the United States of America has made it clear it will veto any attempt to re- elect the Egyptian for a second term on November 18 (today).

However, because all his predecessors since 1945 when the United Nations was founded - Tygve Lie of Norway, Dag Hammarskjold of Sweden until he died in a plane accident in Congo in 1961, U Thant of Burma, Kurt Waldeheim of Austria and Javier Perez De Cuellar of Peru - all had second terms, African nations have been assured the continent retains its chance to the post for the next five years since the United States has threatened to boot Boutros Ghali through their veto in the security council. 

Earlier this year in Yaounde, Cameroon, African nations underscored their support for the embattled Ghali in the "Yaounde Declaration," wherein they promised to stand by the incumbent despite the threatened veto by the United States.

However, African nations are also aware that if a stalemate results, they may lose their chance to other strong candidates from other continents such as former Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Bruntland, Mary Robinson, the 52 year-old President of Ireland or Japanese Sadako Ogata, the high profile United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

Since the UN Security Council has made it clear that ideally an African should succeed Boutros Ghali, it only makes sense for Africa to back other candidates from the continent in order to forestall any victory by non- Africans.

Fortunately, there are three potential successors to Ghali from Africa. The front runner remains Kofi Annan of Ghana, the UN Under Secretary General for peacekeeping who has strong support from the Americans.

The second candidate is Hamid Ayabir of Niger, currently Secretary General of the World Islamic Conference. But given fears of resurgent Islam, America may shy away from this candidate from Niger.

The third candidate from Africa with a reasonable chance of capturing the seat is Salim Ahmed Salim of Tanzania, the current Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity (OAU).

Much as some (Western) media reports have predicted that Kofi Annan of Ghana will take the post if the United States is adamant about showing Ghali the door, a number of surprise candidates may spring up at the last moment.

With gender issues quite strong at the moment, Graca Machel, the widow of former Mozambican President Samora Machel may be floated as successor to Ghali.

Olara Otunnu, Uganda's former Foreign Minister and current head of the International Peace Institute in New York is also said to be interested.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Sudan;
Destitute Nuba Children Moved, Rebels Threaten Refugees


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Kampala - Forty seven destitute Nuba children rescued from their home area in the Nuba mountains of South Kordofan province in Sudan have been translocated from an orphanage in Pakele, West Nile district of northern Uganda to Masindi area in the west.

The children were rescued from Sudan earlier this year by Bishop Paride Taban of Torit Catholic Diocese as they fled from Sudanese Antonov bombers which sporadically drop bombs in African villages in the Nuba Mountains under the control of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

The bishop told journalists earlier this month that the 47 Sudanese were " desperate children without parents to look after them, but in need of education. We want to help them grow up into useful citizens." 

There have been increasing incidents of rebels fighting the government of President Yoweri Museveni in Uganda, targeting Sudanese refugees in settlements near the Sudan/Uganda/Zaire border. The translocation of the destitute children from the border area by Bishop Taban is seen as a precautionary measure for their safety.

Rebels of the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) led by Colonel Juma Oris renewed their threats to Sudanese refugees in late October/November saying that refugee camps run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and other international relief agencies should be vacated or face violence. The threats have been confirmed by the UNHCR Public Affairs Officer, Wendy Rappeport. "The operations have not been affected but there is some scare."

On October 18, rebels attacked Palorinya refugee camp and killed 16 refugees. There have been a number of attacks on other refugee camps in the north-west and northern Uganda in subsequent weeks that resulted in extensive vandalisation of relief vehicles and equipment.

It is believed that rebels are acting according to Sudan government agenda which is to hit refugees by proxy (i.e. Ugandan rebels) and destroy any potential of the camps serving as supply or resting bases for SPLA fighters.

As part of a peace that Sudan is likely to sign with Uganda in the coming weeks, Sudan is demanding that the more than 150,000 Sudanese refugees in northern Uganda be removed into locations at least 100 kilometres inside Uganda.

Negotiations which could lead to a peace pact between Uganda and Sudan are at an advanced stage, according to Iranian sources. The Iranian President Ali Akber Rafsanjani initiated the talks between Uganda and Sudan after his visit to Africa last September.

However, Ugandan officials late October in Tehran, declined to sign an agreement to end hostilities pending "clarification" from Khartoum regarding border incursions by Ugandan rebels alleged to be operating from inside Sudanese territory.

Other reports in Khartoum, have suggested that Sudanese leader Omar el Bashir may visit Kampala soon to sustain the peace initiative in the region.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Zaire;
Church Body Calls For Peaceful End To Zairean Crisis


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Nairobi - The All Africa Conference of Churches, (AACC) concerned about the plight of hundreds of thousands of refugees from Burundi and Rwanda who are in Zaire and Tanzania, is appealing for a peaceful end to the current crisis in Eastern Zaire.

In a statement here on November 14, the continental church body expressed concern that an "explosive situation exists in the Great Lakes region involving citizens of Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire. Today, we are witnessing the possibility of an open inter-state war that can be avoided."

The statement, signed by the organization's General Secretary Rev. Jose B. Chipenda said the AACC is pleased to see the Heads of State in the Great Lakes region meeting several times to find solutions to the situation which has developed after the death of President Melchior Ndadaye of Burundi in 1993 and Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda in 1994. 

But AACC lamented that the main issues relating to the crisis in the Great Lakes region have not been attended to.

These include the return of refugees, land shortage, citizenship and integrity of national borders.

On the return of refugees, the church organization noted that although the movement of people in Rwanda and Burundi traces back to the late 1950s continuing through the 60s and 70s, it has become more or less a way of life for the people in these two countries to flee home any time civil strife erupts.

The AACC, therefore, requested Heads of State in the region to work closely with the countries concerned to create conducive conditions and welcome back bona fide refugees.

Turning to land shortage, the AACC General Secretary observed that in situations where demographic explosions occur, there is always the need to develop a policy of good neighbourliness in order to encourage and enable citizens find jobs in neighbouring countries.

The AACC therefore, called for the issuing of international travel documents to the people so that they can place their skills in neighbouring countries.

Noting that almost every group in Africa at one time or other came from somewhere, the AACC wondered how many years one should live in a host country before one is entitled to citizenship.

"The situation of the Banyamulenge should be looked into if in reality they have lived in Eastern Zaire for nearly 200 years," the statement added.

The continental church body also acknowledged the wisdom of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in declaring the inviolability of national boundaries inherited at independence, as stated in the OAU Charter and especially the Cairo Declaration of 1964.

AACC thus called on countries in the region to honour the inviolability of national borders and appealed for the ceasing of all cross-border incursions.

The statement also highlighted AACC's stand that "the intervention of forces should not be considered as a measure to solve the problems in the Central African region."


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


409 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
African Lutheran Communicators Call For Networking


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Nairobi - Christian communicators from Lutheran Churches in Africa have called for effective networking in the region.

A group of 21 editors of Lutheran church newsletters attending a seminar on church newsletters here from November 7 to 11, also challenged the churches in the region to facilitate this kind of collaboration.

Unlike in the past, where communicators would work comfortably in " isolation", the situation today has changed, the seminar participants, drawn from 22 out of the 25 Lutheran churches in Africa observed.

During the seminar, participants analysed news contents, lay-out, distribution of their newsletters/magazines and the general working conditions in their respective stations. 

Tanzanian Seth Kitange, who was a resource person during the seminar, noted that although there has been a substantial increase in the number of church newsletters within the Lutheran churches in Africa in the past, "their quality left a lot to be desired.

"While we must commend ourselves for the positive steps we have taken towards the institution of newsletters in our churches, we must also feel challenged to improve on them in the areas of news gathering, lay-out and distribution," advised Kitange who is also the General Secretary for the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT) Northern Diocese.

He singled out readiness to share experiences and ideas and exchange of publications as effective ways of improving the quality of the publications.

The seminar, which preceded a five-day conference of the LWF related Regional Communication Organizations (November 11 to 15), was jointly organised by the recently opened LWF Africa regional office in Nairobi and the department of communication in the LWF-Geneva office.

Addressing participants, Ms. Anneli Janhonen, Director and Editor- in-Chief, LWF Office for Communication Services, Geneva, introduced the forthcoming Ninth Assembly of the LWF, to be held from July 8 to 16, 1997 in Hong Kong.

"Like in the past, the media will be expected to play a vital role in the assembly. You are part of the media fraternity and therefore the world will expect you to play your part effectively. You may not be in Hong Kong, directly, but you will definitely be involved in one way or other," she told the Lutheran church communicators.

The LWF assembly will be hosted by the Hon Kong Lutheran Federation (HKLF), previously called the Chinese Lutheran Churches Hong Kong Association. Some 400 delegates from LWF member churches and a further 1,000 participants representing observers, advisers, ecumenical guests and the press will attend the assembly which also marks the 50th anniversary of the LWF.

Rev. Bernhardur Gudmundsson, the Secretary for Communication Consultancy in the LWF Department for Mission and Development, challenged the Christian communicators to take their "assignments" seriously, as one way to "entice" churches to give more financial and moral support to the communication work.

Dr. Collete Bouka-Coula, the head of the recently instituted LWF regional Office in Africa, addressed the issue of the All-Africa Lutheran Churches Information and Coordination Centre (ALICE), which was created by Lutheran churches in Africa in 1978.

Although the body was created with a good purpose, it faced many problems and at one time had to come to a halt, she told the seminar delegates.

ALICE was initially based in Arusha, Tanzania, under the auspices of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT).

Dr. Bouka-Coula further told the seminar participants that the organization has had its own defects due to lack of flow of information. There has been discontinuity in the secretariat, she added, pointing out that at the same time, some members have not been giving their yearly contributions regularly while others have cut down their commitment altogether.

But on a positive note, Dr. Bouka-Coula said ALICE will be revived and its headquarters moved from Tanzania to Nairobi, Kenya, following recommendations made at a church leaders' meeting held at Limuru, Kenya in 1992.

"The church leaders in Africa decided during their meeting in Limuru, Kenya, in 1992 to evaluate ALICE, and the committee of five made a recommendation to transfer the centre to Nairobi in conjunction with the All Lutheran Coordination Office (today, the Regional Office in Africa)," she added.

She also explained that "the existence of ALICE has never been questioned either by member churches or the LWF secretariat in Geneva. The issue has been how to render ALICE more efficient in serving the churches."

Dr. Bouka-Coula in her presentation cited the high arrears of churches' membership fees, the lack of regular meetings of ALICE Board, the relocation of ALICE headquarters, the appointment of the new Board and the irregularity in sending articles to publish as some of the problems that bogged down this regional communication network for the Lutheran churches in Africa.

"Up to 1993, the only assignment the Executive Secretary had consisted in publishing the Africa Theological journal," she noted.

The LWF Regional Office for Africa became operational in July 1, 1996. Its objectives include the coordination of regional and sub- regional activities of the LWF's Department for Mission and Development (DMD) in Africa.

Dr. Bouka-Coula said the office for Africa, is also charged with responsibilities of projects' write-up and the coordination and consultation on various programmes related to Mission and Cities and Industrial Areas in Africa (MICIAA), leadership training and rural development consultative services.

Dr. Bouka-Coula, a Cameroonian, who formerly worked in the LWF Geneva Office as Assistant Secretary for Africa Region, is designated as the Field Officer, for the new office.

There are an estimated 7.8 million Lutherans in Africa spread out in 17 countries representing 25-member churches of the LWF.

Founded in 1947, in Lund, Sweden, the LWF is a confessional body bringing together 56 million Lutheran in 122 member-churches in 68 countries the world over.

The LWF's highest decision making body is its Assembly which normally meets every six years.

Previous assemblies have met as follows; Lund, Sweden (1947), Hannover, Germany (1952), Minneapolis, USA (1957), Helsinki, Finland (1963), Evian, France (1970), Dar es Salaam, Tanzania (1977), Budapest, Hungary (1984) and Curitiba, Brazil in 1990.

Between Assemblies, the LWF is governed by a 49-member Council which meets annually.

The staff of the LWF is headed by a general secretary, currently Dr. Ishmael Noko from Zimbabwe. Its Executive Committee is headed by a president, presently Rev. Dr. Gottfried Brakemeier from Brazil.


LOAD-DATE: November 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
