Africa News


November 18, 1996


Science and Health;
The African Elephant IS An Endangered Species


BYLINE: Oumar Dieng, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1133 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The African elephant, which has been hunted for a long time for its tusks and meat, or for the damage it causes to crops, now lives in a limited space, following endless encroachment on its habitat by man.

Specialists blame the loss of natural habitat on several human activities such as deforestation, the building of barriers to block the elephants access to water and food, and the fragmentation of their environment.

In East Africa for instance, the territory occupied by elephants has been reduced from 87 to 27 percent between 1925 and 1975, while human population increased at a yearly rate of 2.9 percent. 

The protection of elephants and land disputes between humans were the focus of discussions between African, European and American specialists last week in Dakar.

Wide-scale destruction caused by elephants have led, in a country like Kenya, to the creation of the Kenya Wildlife Service, which is waging a war against poachers and ivory traffickers to protect the endangered species.

In Congo, about 15 scientists, academics and journalists set up in August in Brazzaville a non-governmental organization -- 'Elephant And Hippopotamus International' -- to fight against poaching.

The initiative follows the massacre of over 200 elephants in the northern Congolese region of Sangha.

Led by Antoine Mapangui, a specialist in environmental protection, the Congolese NGO is planning to set up a network for surveillance and warning to international opinion.

The NGO's policy is in line with the preservation measures taken by several Central African countries to protect endangered wildlife.

The elephants' territory has also shrunk in West Africa. Populations are destroying the forest in search of firewood. Animals are now only found in protected areas.

In general, populations have difficulty accepting that wildlife be better protected than humans. In 1992 in Kenya, 48 elephants were culled after they killed 40 people.

However, elephants play an important role in the conservation of biodiversity. They contribute to the regeneration of habitats through the dissemination and germination of seeds.

But some specialists think that the impact of their growing density is rather negative. When their density is high, they have, for instance, managed to eat up the whole foliage in certain areas.

In fact, scientists do not agree on the course of action to be adopted to check the impact of elephant activities.

Advocates of control on elephants have opted for culling as a away reducing their nuisance.

But those who favor protection play down the threat on biodiversity and adopt a rather cautious attitude.


LOAD-DATE: November 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 18, 1996


Zaire;
South African Troops For Zaire Soon


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa is determined to send troops to Zaire, and a contingent could be ready for deployment within a matter of days, President Nelson Mandela confirmed Sunday at a media briefing in the Northern Cape province city of Kimberley.

"We are busy with the matter," he said, "but a great of negotiations are required before we can make any deployment of our troops in that area." 

Mandela said he had discussed the matter with U.S. President Bill Clinton on Saturday, and had also been in touch with leaders from the Great Lakes region, French President Jacques Chirac, Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali

The South African decision to send troops follows a week of intense behind- the-scenes lobbying by international leaders.

Presidential aide Jakes Gerwel said members of the South African National Defence Force would be sent to provide technical support for the Canadian-led force that is being assembled, but would not be available for more high profile duty.

Africa News


November 18, 1996


South Africa;
Ebola Virus In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The dreaded and deadly Ebola virus has struck in South Africa for the first time.

The Director of Communicable Diseases at the National Department of Health, Dr. Neil Cameron, confirmed Sunday night that a 46-year-old nursing sister at a Johannesburg clinic, Marilyn Lehana, had apparently contracted the disease from a Gabonese doctor. It is the first known case of the disease being contracted in South Africa.

Lehana apparently contracted a strain known as Ebola Gabon while performing a procedure on a Gabonese doctor with multi-organ disfunction. The doctor arrived in South Africa late October from Gabon, where an outbreak had just claimed 17 lives. He has since recovered fully and was discharged a week ago.

Although diagnosis of the fever has given cause of concern, experts do not foresee an uncontrollable outbreak of the disease in South Africa.

About 200 people, who have been in contact with Lehana and the Gabonese doctor, are being monitored for symptoms of the Ebola virus. The authorities say monitoring will continue for the next 21 days until the period of possible infection is over.

International disease expert Dr. Bob Swanepoel said "the world and South Africa has been given a wake-up call," pointing out that the ease of movement across the globe meant that an outbreak of Ebola fever could occur anywhere.

Ebola fever was first identified about 20 years ago. There have been about 1,000 victims to date, and death has occurred in 80 to 90 percent of the cases.

It is a hemorrhagic fever spread through close contact with bodily fluids. Early symptoms are headaches and fever and, as the virus advances, uncontrollable bleeding and multiple organ disfunction occurs.


LOAD-DATE: November 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


413 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 18, 1996


Rwanda;
MSF Beefs Up Its Presence In Rwanda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders), has beefed up its teams in Rwanda to deal with the massive arrival of refugees at the border between Zaire and Rwanda, according to a statement from the organization released to PANA Monday in Dakar.

The refugees, from camps in eastern Zaire, started returning to their country in hundreds of thousands late last week. 

To provide relief to the refugees, MSF sent on Monday 22 volunteers and 10 tons of medical and logistic equipment. On Sunday, 13 volunteers and 36 tons of equipment were sent to Rwanda where another consignment from MSF is expected on Tuesday.

MSF teams are setting up supply points for drinking water, food and health care between the Mugunga camp and the eastern Zairean town of Goma.

Inside Rwanda, between Gisenyi and Ruhengeri, relief centers have also been set up by the organization.

There are already 62 MSF volunteers in Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania and Uganda to help Rwandan refugees and displaced Zairians.

Africa News


November 18, 1996


Nigeria;
Black Box Of Crashed Nigerian Jetliner Recovered


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Divers have recovered the black box of the Nigerian private jetliner, which crashed Nov. 8, killing all 143 people on board, officials of the Federal Aviation Authority of Nigeria said in Lagos Sunday.

The jet's three engines have also been found, but not the bodies of the victims. 

Lt. Col. Jerry Oshobunmi, leading the divers, said rescue operation would continue Monday.

Aviation experts said the black box, which records communication between the pilot and the control tower, would assist in investigations into the cause of the crash.

It was recovered Saturday in the lagoon near Ejirin, a fishing hamlet, where the Boeing 727 jet plunged.

The plane, belonging to the private Aviation Development Company, was on a scheduled flight from Nigeria's southeastern city of Port Harcourt when it disappeared from the radar minutes before it was due to land at the Lagos airport.

Africa News


November 18, 1996


Zambia;
Zambians Vote In Second Multiparty Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga and Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondents, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambians began voting Monday in the country's second multiparty elections which have been boycotted by the main opposition United National Independence Party of former President Kenneth Kaunda and several other minor parties.

Polling opened in the 4,610 stations around the country at 0600 A.M. (0400 GMT) and is expected to close at 1700 p.m. (1500 GMT). 

In the capital, Lusaka, voters trickled to the polling stations amid early morning rains which had started pouring in the night.

Early morning reports by Zambian national radio from Mpika in the northern region and Kawambwa, also in the northern Luapula region, said there was enthusiasm among voters who thronged local polling stations immediately voting booths opened.

About one million voters are expected to cast their ballots to choose 147 members of parliament from some 600 candidates representing 11 political parties.

President Frederick Chiluba's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy has so far captured three parliamentary seats unopposed. There are 150 elective seats in the Zambian parliament.

The electorate will also choose the country's president among the five presidential candidates who include Chiluba and his former mines minister Humphery Mulemba of the National Party.

Other candidates challenging Chiluba, who is expected to be re-elected, include Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika of the Agenda for Zambia Party, Dean Mu'ngomba of the Zambia Democratic Congress and Chama Chakomboka, who heads the Movement for Democratic Process.

Early results are expected to be announced Monday night.

Meanwhile, The Organization of African Unity is among the 22 foreign monitors who are observing Monday's general elections in Zambia. Electoral commission officials also confirmed Monday that two officials representing the United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali are also in the country.

Africa News


November 19, 1996


Southern Africa;
Zambia To Apologize To South Africa Over Interference Claims


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 943 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba is to apologize to President Nelson Mandela over claims by one of his top officials that the South African leader was interfering in Zambian domestic issues, according to media reports.

The incident resulted from a meeting between the two leaders in Pretoria last week, after which Mandela suggested that Chiluba delay Monday's general elections in order to sort out the question of participation by former President Kenneth Kaunda. 

The reports say former Zambian Foreign Minister Vernon Mwaanga responded by attacking Mandela for interfering in the country's constitutional affairs, saying Zambia was mature enough to handle its own problems.

He said Zambia could not start receiving instructions from Mandela like school children.

As a result, Chiluba has banned senior party and cabinet members from commenting on the issue. "No-one at the national executive committee of the ruling party, or indeed the cabinet, will be allowed to respond to any statements by any head of state...it will only be commented by me," he said.

Chiluba added that Mandela had always sought peace in Zambia, South Africa and Southern Africa as a whole.

"He has been instrumental in trying to bring dialogue between me and Dr. Kenneth Kaunda to ensure that there is peace in the country," he said, "and that's no interference."

"President Mandela has never at any time sought to interfere in our internal affairs," said the Zambian leader, "and if anything he has tremendous attachment to Zambia."

Africa News


November 19, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Takes Lead In Presidential Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Incumbent Zambian President Frederick Chiluba took an early lead Tuesday against four other presidential candidates in initial results so far announced following Monday's elections.

He appears set to be re-elected after scoring large margins against his rivals in the results that have been declared so far, mostly from the northern Copperbelt region. 

Agenda for Zambia presidential candidate, Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika, had won most of the votes counted in Mongu constituency in his home western region.

Chiluba's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) is also leading in parliamentary seats and its candidates have swept almost all the seats in the northern mining towns.

Those who have retained their seats include home affairs minister Chitalu Sampa and labor minister Newstead Zimba, both in Kitwe. MMD chairman Sikota Wina has also been re-elected in the northern copper-mining town of Chililabombwe as well as former foreign affairs minister Vernon Mwaanga in Luanshya.

However, the ruling party has so far suffered two major upsets in the midlands town of Kabwe and in Lusaka central, which have been won by MMD defectors.

In Lusaka, former minister of commerce and trade Dipak Patel beat MMD deputy treasurer Sylvia Masebo. Patel had resigned his ministerial portfolio in protest against the new constitution barring citizens with alien parents from contesting the presidency.

There were than 600 parliamentary aspirants representing 11 political parties and nearly 100 independents vying for the remaining 147 seats. The MMD had already won three seats unopposed.

The elections were boycotted by the main opposition United National Independence Party of former President Kenneth Kaunda and several minor parties.

Africa News


November 19, 1996


Mozambique;
Rail Transport Records Big Jump In Traffic


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The railway traffic on the Ressano Garcia, Goba and Limpopo lines (which links Maputo, capital of Mozambique, to South Africa, Swaziland and Zimbabwe respectively), in the south, registered a 79-percent increase between January and September 1996, compared to the same period of 1995.

In 1996, the rail services transported 1,849.100 tons of freight, whereas they only handled 1,033.800 tons between January and September 1995. 

'Carruagem', a monthly bulletin of the Mozambican Ports and Railways Company, attributed the growth to member countries of the Southern African Development Community which are now increasingly using the lines to export their products through the port of Maputo.

The publication added that the increase in cargo handled at the terminals of Maputo port between January and October, reached 32 percent, when compared to the same period of 1995.

It said that 1,885.911 tons of cargo were handled in the port, whereas the 1995 figure was 1,483.754 tons.

South Africa heads the list of the countries using the southern Mozambican port and rail network, mainly for the transportation of coal and citrus fruit, it said.

Other countries also using those services are Zimbabwe, exporting mainly chrome, coal and sugar, and Swaziland, to export sugar and molasses.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 19, 1996


Business and Finance;
Nigerian Gas To Last 700 Years


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's estimated gas reserves can last the country more than 700 years, according to official statistics released in Lagos Tuesday.

The figures made available by oil experts at the 14th annual international conference of the Nigerian Association of Petroleum Explorationists, showed that the country currently has a reserve of 110 trillion cubic feet of gas. 

This translates to 20 times of the nation's crude oil reserves with 70 percent of the gas being flared at present.

The gas flaring is expected to end with the take-off of a gigantic liquefied natural gas project for the export of the commodity from 1999 to European markets.

The statistics also put Nigeria's crude oil reserve at 20.8 billion barrels, after Libya in Africa with a reserve of 29.5 billion barrels.

Oil accounts for more than 80 percent of Nigeria's total foreign exchange earnings.

With an average production of 1.87 million barrels of oil daily, the experts estimate that Nigeria's oil reserves can last over 30 years without exploring new ones.

The conference, which has participants from Europe, the U.S., Canada, Japan and other parts of Africa, is focusing on "Oil and Gas in Africa: New Concepts for Exploration and Production."

It ends on Friday.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 19, 1996


Science and Health;
Early Human Fossils Found In Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A team of paleontologists from the United States, Ethiopia and Israel has uncovered remains of early human fossils dating back 2.33 million years in the Hadar area of north-eastern Ethiopia, where the earliest known ancestor of early man, the famous "Lucy" or Australopithecus Afarensis, was discovered in 1974.

The fossils and stone tools were unearthed near the surface of a barren hill close to a dry river-bed at the Hadar site in the Afar highlands close to where "Lucy" was found in 1974.

An announcement by the team working under the auspices of the the Institute of Human Origins (IHO) of the University of California at Berkeley, published Tuesday in newspapers in Addis Ababa, said that an upper jaw of early Homo, the genus to which modern human belong, was recovered with primitive tools. 

These remains may hold clues to the ancestry of living humans, for they represent "the oldest family dated association of stone tools with a fossil of human ancestors," the report said.

The short, flat snout and broad parabolic dental arch that was discovered link the fossil to geologically younger ancestors of Homo sapiens, the IHO statement said. However, it noted that the fossil lacks the long, narrow palate and projecting face that gives the skull of "Lucy" the ape-like visage.

"The main importance of the latest discovery is that it helps plug a gap in the evidence for the early evolution of human lineage and perhaps will help begin to forge links in time to Afarensis," the statement said.

This is in reference to "Lucy," the most complete example of the small brained, big jawed, upright walking Australopithecus Afarensis (after the Afar tribe inhabiting Hadar) which, the IHO statement noted, is not known as yet to have made stone tools. The scientific team co-led by IHO's William H. Kimbel, Robert C. Walter and Donald C. Johanson, had been conducting filed work at Hadar since 1990.

The team will continue to focus its field activities on filling important gaps in the fossil record. "We're virtually starting from scratch in discovering the earliest evolution of our own lineage," Kimbel was quoted as saying.

"As in the past, Ethiopia will play a major role in providing the needed evidence," he added.


LOAD-DATE: November 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


421 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 20, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria, Commonwealth Delegations Begin Talks


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1170 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria and the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group began talks in Abuja Tuesday, amid controversy over the absence of Canadian members of the delegation.

The Nigerian foreign ministry said in a statement two Canadian security men, who were to accompany their country's secretary of state to the meeting were denied visas because of their insistence to bear arms in the country.

The ministry said the visa application for the two officers in question, whose names were not on the original list submitted by Canada, had erroneously created the impression that they were diplomats. 

But the identity of the security personnel was only established following further enquiries by Nigeria, the statement added.

Canada is a member of the eight-nation action group set up last November after Nigeria was suspended from the organization in the aftermath of the execution for murder of nine minority rights leaders, including the author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

The Commonwealth had in a statement ahead of Tuesday's meeting in Abuja, said Canada would not participate because of Nigeria's refusal to grant visas to the two security personnel.

But the Nigerian foreign ministry described the allegation as not only " false," but a misrepresentation of the facts of the situation.

It said the officials had insisted on carrying arms despite efforts to persuade the Canadian authorities that this contradicted the practice in the country.

"In the light of the foregoing, any attempt to suggest other reasons for the non-issuance of the visas to the Canadian security personnel is misleading and mischievous," the statement added.

Nigeria recently closed its diplomatic mission in Canada for economic reasons, although diplomatic sources blamed the action on Canada's tough action against Abuja.

Breaking ranks with the other Commonwealth members, Canada has been pushing ahead with unilateral sanctions against Nigeria, amid press reports that the country was also supporting Nigerian opposition groups.

Meanwhile, the meeting between Nigeria and the Commonwealth delegation led by its chairman, Stan Mudenge of Zimbabwe, was being conducted without opening press statements.

The Nigerian delegation is led by foreign minister, Tom Ikimi, while representatives of Nigeria's five newly-established political parties and officials of the transition agencies are also participating.

The Commonwealth said in its statement that the status of Nigeria's transition programme was on the agenda of the meeting.

The meeting is a follow-up to the one in London in June.

Nigeria had earlier rejected a fact-finding mission by the Commonwealth team, insisting that its suspension from the organization was unfair.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


422 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 20, 1996


Congo;
Congo To Build New International Airport


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - A United States company based in New York, Strategic Partner Holding, is to build a new international airport in Brazzaville, diplomatic sources said on Wednesday.

Two officials from the American company were received on Tuesday by Congolese president Pascal Lissouba who asked them to submit to his government a feasibility study within 60 days, the sources said without giving details. 

The new airport, whose cost and source of funding have not been disclosed, will be built over three years at Mont-Barnier, 23 km (14.4 miles) south of Brazzaville.

It will have the capacity to handle one million passengers a year, which is double the current capacity of Maya-Maya international airport in the Congolese capital.

Due the extension of the town, Maya-Maya airport is now in the middle of neighborhood areas, where people are scared by by the noise of low-flying aircraft.

According to the sources, the two officials from the U.S. company will visit the international airport in Congo's second largest city, Pointe-Noire, on Thursday, to study the possibility of also building a new international airport in the town.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


423 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 20, 1996


Business and Finance;
Zambia;
Oil Pressing Machine Attracts Zambian Peasant Farmers


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A miniature oil extracting machine introduced by Africare to press edible oil from sunflower and other seed has proved popular among Zambian peasant farmers and individual households.

The machine, weighing only 50 kilograms, is known as the "Ram Press" and is manually operated. It was initially designed and developed by an American engineer for an oil processing project in Arusha, Tanzania. 

The Ram Press was first introduced to Zambia some four years ago and is currently being manufactured and distributed by several Zambian companies, according to Africare officials who are the main makers and marketing agents of the machine.

Africare is an American private non-governmental organization engaged in a variety of projects to improve the quality of life in rural Africa.

Africare officials told PANA Wednesday that almost 2,000 of the machines have been acquired so far by peasant farmers in various parts of the country for cooking oil production for both domestic consumption and sale.

"The machine has become so popular that we are not able to keep up with current demand," said an official who works in the marketing department at the Africare Lusaka office.

The Ram Press is designed so that it could be easily moved and operated either outside or indoors. It is operated by raising and pulling down a long handle which drives a steel ram into the slotted cage. This compresses the seed and squeezes oil through openings in the cage. It is capable of producing between 10 and 12 liters (2.6 gallons) of cooking oil from a 50- kilogram (110 pounds) of sunflower seed.

Africare has ensured that all local manufacturers of the ram press also stock adequate spare parts to service the growing clientele. It has in addition trained a cadre of technical staff in various parts of the country to repair and make spare parts for the machine in local workshops.

The organization has recommended a specific variety of sunflower seed called "record" for oil production because of its high oil content of between 28 and 45 percent. The ram press is able to extract up to 75 percent of the oil.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 20, 1996


Sudan;
Rebels Agree To Release Red Cross Officials


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan,PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Rebels in southern Sudan have agreed to the unconditional release Friday of three officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross, according to a joint statement Wednesday by the Red Cross and the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) Bahr Gazal splinter group, controlled by Kerubino Kwanyin.

"Commander Kerubino agreed to release them," it said. 

The deputy director for operations of the Red Cross, Paul Grossrieder, flew to Sudan and met with Kerubino for two days discussing the release of the officials held in Wunrok, near Gogrial, in southern Sudan, the statement added.

"Commander Kerubino agreed to have them transferred to Gogrial where their personal safety could be guaranteed. He also let an ICRC delegate meet with the five SPLA personnel arrested with the ICRC staff," when the plane mistakenly landed in an area controlled by Kerubino's group, thinking it was still held by the mainstream SPLA faction led by John Garang.

"A senior official from the government of Sudan took part in the discussions between Mr Grossrieder and Commander Kerubino and played an active mediating role," the statement said.

The plane carrying the three Red Cross officials was detained Nov. 1.

In April, Kerubino signed a peace pact with the government in Khartoum ending hostilities between them in southern Sudan.

When he seized the plane, Kerubino said he had done so because it was carrying five armed soldiers of Garang's faction and 13 boxes of ammunition.

Despite the release deal, he has maintained that the Red Cross had deviated from its humanitarian mission by transporting weapons and ammunition to the Garang group. The Red Cross has agreed to an investigation to be conducted by independent personalities.

The joint statement said that the parties "will take the necessary measures to prevent the recurrence of such events."


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


425 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 20, 1996


Science and Health;
Zimbabweans' Family Planning Awareness High


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Ninety-nine percent of Zimbabwean married women and 100 percent of its married men know at least one modern method of family planning, the United States-based Population Reference Bureau says.

In its report on an International Demographic Health Survey entitled "Men and Family Planning in Africa," the bureau says more than 80 percent of the men know about withdrawal. Over 60 percent of them, it says, are aware of abstinence and over 40 percent know about vasectomy.

It says that 94 percent of married Zimbabwean women approve of family planning compared to 82 percent of the married men. It adds that 54 percent of the sexually active population in Zimbabwe practice modern methods of family planning with 6 percent using traditional ways.

The survey also notes that 47 percent of Zimbabwe's sexually active population use the female methods of contraception while only 6 percent used male methods.

The bureau says 38 percent of Zimbabwean men engage in sexual intercourse by the age of 18 years.

Like Egypt, Ghana, Kenya and Malawi, the average family in Zimbabwe has four children while West African countries tend to have more children.

The survey also notes a high percentage of polygamous marriages in West Africa and, in particular, Senegal with 37 percent of all marriages being polygamous.

In Zimbabwe, 8 percent of married men are in polygamous marriages. Egypt has the lowest number of polygamous marriages with just 2 percent.

However, the bureau notes that polygamous marriages produce fewer children than in monogamous ones.

For example in Cameroon, the average family size among polygamous marriages is 16 children compared to an average of 10 in monogamous marriages.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


426 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 20, 1996


Zambia;
Zambia Elections Not Free And Fair


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Local Zambian election monitors declared Wednesday that the country's second multiparty elections held Monday were neither free nor fair due to limited voter participation.

Incumbent president Frederick Chiluba and his Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) were reported to he heading for a landslide victory as final result of the polls were being collated late Wednesday. The Committee for a Clean Campaign, which comprises several local election monitors and some civil society organizations, said that the election schedules had also highly disadvantaged the opposition parties and independent candidates. 

Committee Chairman Ngande Mwanajiti said at a news conference that only 2.3 million voters had been registered out of an estimated 4.6 million eligible. But only 1.1 million had managed to collect voters cards for the elections.

He said that lack of inter-party dialogue between the MMD and the opposition had exacerbated a mood of uncertainty and undermined the entire electoral process. "The opposition parties were unable to gain mileage on any of the substantive issues," he said. "Lack of preparedness was also exhibited by the Independent Electoral Commission which had fixed the elections on the day of appointment."

He charged that the commission had failed to win the confidence of the major players. He alleged that the MMD and the opposition Zambia Democratic Congress were involved in rampant vote buying.

"The housing policy of MMD is certainly welcome, but the timing reveals that the exercise had a severe impact on the elections," Mwanajiti said.

The examination of the elections results were determined, he said, by the voter registration, elections schedule, campaign activities, media coverage and election day itself.

He noted that the campaign activities were characterized by misinformation, slander and other practices which are incompatible with democratic practice and acceptable international norms.

About 20 foreign monitors and observers were in the country to oversee the electoral process.

They included the Organization of African Unity, personal representatives of the United Nations secretary-general, and church representatives from Europe, the United States and within Africa. These have not given their views on the conduct of the elections.

But the government has denied it manipulated the polls. The MMD campaign committee chairman, Vernon Mwaanga, told a press briefing that it was not true that the government had failed to register an estimated 4.6 million eligible voters, a figure he said was unrealistic. He said it was unfair for the committee to pass judgement on the elections even before all the results had been declared.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 21, 1996


Swaziland;
Swazi Beauty Queen Arrested For Drugs


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - A Swazi beauty queen and a South Africa man have been arrested in separate incidents in Swaziland on charges of illegal possession of drugs.

Mtombi Mngomezulu, winner of the last year's Swaziland Woman of Africa Award was arrested along with a man and a local taxi driver in Manzini, after she had collected a parcel at the local post office. 

A spokesman said Thursday police acting on a tip off, intercepted the taxi and on examining Mngomezulu's parcel found more than one kilogram (2.2 pounds) of cocaine powder hidden in a secret pocket inside a small leather folder- type handbag.

Mngomezulu and the co-accused are due to appear in Manzini magistrates court on Friday, the police spokesman said.

The penalty for illegal possession of drugs which is a non- bailable offence in Swaziland, is 15 years imprisonment or a fine of 15,000 rands (about 3,363 dollars) for first offenders.

A front page story on the arrests in Thursday's Times of Swaziland said Mngomezulu was due to have left the country on Wednesday as chaperon to the current Woman of Africa' (Swaziland) Miss Sizakele Shongwe, who is featuring at the regional contest.

Police also reported the arrest of a South African, Elvis Manzini, aged 27 years, after he was found with 50 grams (2 ounces) of metaphetamina powder hidden in his clothing as he entered Swaziland from Mozambique at the northern Lomahasha border on Wednesday.

Africa News


November 21, 1996


Zaire;
Zaire Suspends Army Chief-of-Staff


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Gen. Eluki Monga Aungu, Chief-of-staff of the Zairean armed forces, has been suspended, Zairean television announced on Wednesday.

While the reasons for this suspension have not been given, a member of the Zairean information minister's office, who required anonymity, told PANA that "the general's views were too different from those of the government and the ministry of national defence". 

Eluki blamed the recent rout of the Zairean army in eastern Zaire by rebel ethnic Tutsis on the "lack of support from the government".

His statement, made at a news conference, led to the deterioration of relations between the army command and the government.

Recently, Eluki, on an inspection tour of the northwestern provinces of Upper-Zaire and Maniema, near the North-Kivu province, described as "useless the deployment of a foreign force in Kivu, since the Zairean army can recapture the occupied territory", the source said.

Political analysts in Zaire were expecting the general's suspension following the routing of his troops and open differences between the executive and the military hierarchy.

However, the suspension raises fears since the army is seen as the real holder of power in Zaire, where it has the reputation of being "at the sole service of Marshal Mobutu".

It was probably on his recent visit to President Mobutu, who is recovering from surgery for prostate cancer in France, that Prime Minister Kengo Wa Dondo was given the go-ahead to suspend Eluki, sources said in Kinshasa.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 21, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Irregular Sudanese Migrants Denied Refugee Status


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees denied refugee status to some 100 angry Sudanese who thronged its offices on Tuesday demanding to be accorded the right to live in Ghana, an official said.

The irregular migrants, who have been in Ghana since September 1995, are fleeing the 13-year-old civil war between the Sudan Peoples' Liberation Army and the Khartoum government. 

The legal officer in Ghana for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Ron Mponda, told the Ghana News Agency in Accra Thursday, that the migrants claimed to have chosen to live in Ghana because of the peace prevailing here.

However, he said it would be illegal for the U.N. agency to grant them refugee status. Under international law, one can only seek refugee status in one's neighbouring country unless that country is also facing some political upheaval.

"These people have crossed over five boarders to come to Ghana," he said.

He said they could have gone to one of the nine neighbouring countries whose citizens enjoy absolute peace.

"I see no reason why they should travel all the way to Ghana," he added.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa-at-Large;
O.A.U. Appeals For Assistance To Rwandan Refugees


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Organization of Africa Unity Secretary- General Salim Ahmed Salim appealed Thursday for international help for the resettlement and rehabilitation of the hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees returning home.

He said help would also enable the Rwandan government manage the influx of some 500,000 people. 

Salim also expressed appreciation "for the continued role being played" by African non-governmental organizations and international humanitarian organizations in resettling the returnees.

He said that the massive return of refugees might constitute a momentum in the continued efforts to find a peaceful solution to the fighting and political instability in the Great Lakes region, where the refugee drama is taking place.

Meanwhile, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has appealed for 66.9 million U.S. dollars for its emergency operations in eastern Zaire.

The sum includes money needed for the immediate integration of the returning Rwandan refugees, the agency's office in Addis Ababa said. The money will cover reception and settlement of refugees in Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda.

431 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 21, 1996


Zambia;
Chiluba Sworn-In For Second-Term Of Office


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - President Frederick Chiluba was Thursday sworn in for a second five-year term of office following his landslide in Monday's elections.

Chief Justice Mathew Ngulube, administered the oath 1300 p.m. (1100 gmt) at the supreme court buildings in the capital, Lusaka. 

Chiluba polled 835,537 votes, more than 80 percent of the 1,190,025 total votes cast in the presidential elections which was also contested by four other candidates.

Zambia Democratic Congress president Dean Mun'gomba emerged second with 144, 366 votes, and Humphrey Mulemba of the National Party came third with 72,328 votes. Agenda for Zambia leader Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika received 50, 447 votes, while Chama Chakomboka of the Movement for Democratic Process got 35,892 votes.

In his inaugural speech, Chiluba pledged to dialogue with opposition parties in the country.

"I want to promise that during my term in office I will dialogue with any political party that exists, because there is no nation that can exist without dialogue. I therefore invite my colleagues and want to tell them that. ..we must work together," Chiluba said.

He promised that while his administration will uphold the rule of law, it will not comprise with anyone who violates the law.

He also said his government will maintain the friendly relations with neighbouring countries, provided they did not interfere in Zambia's own internal affairs.

Referring to the elections, he said they were transparent and held in a peaceful atmosphere and in spirit of unity.

"The overwhelming turn-out in the elections and the peaceful atmosphere and spirit of unity can be attributed to the presence of Jesus Christ. I...assure you that with God, all things are possible," said Chiluba.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 21, 1996


Sudan;
Sudan's National Congress To Arm Country For War


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan's National Congress, the country's only legal political body, says it will raise 20 million U.S. dollars for arms purchases in response to an American decision to do likewise for three of Khartounm's adversaries.

Meeting in the Sudanese capital Wednesday, the Secretariat for Coordination and Mobilization in the congress called on every Sudanese to help raise the money for the army and popular defence forces.

The government-owned daily newspaper, Al Engaz Al Watani, reported Thursday that public participation in the fund raising drive would demonstrate "that the Sudanese people accept the challenge and are able to resist" their enemies. 

The U.S. Embassy in Khartoum said last week that Washington had earmarked 15 million dollars for military defence equipment for Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda to help them fight anti-government rebels being backed by Sudan.

The newspaper said Sudanese anti-government forces, belonging to the Democratic Alliance Forces, were operating from Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda. Khartoum claims that the alliance has been attacking Sudanese border garrisons from bases in Eritrea.

Political parties dissolved, when President Omar Al Bashir seized power in 1989, have joined hands recently with the Sudan People's Liberation Army, operating in southern Sudan, and the Alliance Forces recently to try and overthrow the government with force of arms.

The secretary for mobilization and coordination of the National Congress, Adil Awad, said that congress was "considering practical arrangements" to boycott products of the countries supporting the punishment of the Khartoum government.

"The measure will be immediately effective if the Security Council issues any more sanctions against Sudan," he said.

This weekend, the U.N. Security Council will consider the implementation of an earlier decision to ban external flights of Sudan Airways. This is in punishment for what the council maintains is Sudan's involvement in a bid to kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, in 1995 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 21, 1996


Mali;
Mali To Reintegrate Former Rebels


BYLINE: Abdoulaye Traore, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - Mali's development partners have released three million U.S. dollars of the 12 million dollars needed for the country's program for the reintegration of former rebels, officials said Wednesday.

The money was used to set up the program and pay for 126 projects for some 1,700 former rebels, Northern Province Governor Mahamadou Diagouraga said at a news conference. 

Initiated in May, the programme aims at reintegrating within 18 months about 9,000 former fighters from the various movements of the Tuareg rebellion and the Ghanda-Koye Black Patriotic Movement.

The plan is a pivotal component of the National Peace Pact signed in April 1992, between the Tuareg rebels and the government in Bamako.

The first phase of the program, which ended Oct. 1, centered on paying demobilization allowances totalling 640 million cfa (1.28 million dollars).

Diagouraga said that each of the 9,000 fighters registered under the peace agreements had been paid 105,000 cfa (210 dollars).


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Business and Finance;
Inflation Pushes Up Bank Rate In South Africa


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's bank rate was increased by 1 percent Thursday, in the wake of a slow but steady increase in inflation.

Chris Stals, the governor of the Reserve Bank (South Africa's central bank), has announced a decision to raise the country's bank rate from 16 percent to 17 percent. This increase will inevitably be followed by increases in mortgage, overdraft and hire-purchase rates, and will more than likely dampen hopes of a bumper christmas spending season. The decision to increase the bank rate was influenced by figures released Thursday by the country's Central Statistical Services. These show that South Africa's inflation rate has reached 9.2 percent and is creeping dangerously close to double figures once again. 

Stals said decisive action had been necessary to depress the inflationary pressures arising from excessive depreciation of the rand over the past year. This had to be done to restore both external and internal financial stability.

Local economists have described the decision to increase the bank rate just before Christmas as a brave step.

"It shows just how serious the country's economic plight is," said a senior banker, "but when everything is considered, I think it is a good decision for the longer term."

The South African Chamber of Business (SACOB) said the decision to increase the bank rate was to be expected but the tightening of monetary policy constituted a severe blow to short-term economic prospects.

"While SACOB appreciates the reason for the step," said Ben Van Rensburg, director of Economic Policy, "a rise in interest rates at this time will have a negative effect on business and consumer confidence."

Stals said that by accepting the disciplines of the market forces, the way would be prepared for an early commencement of the next expansionary phase, when the longer-term economic growth potential of the country would hopefully move to a higher level.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Nigeria;
Commonwealth Mission Fails To Meet Abiola


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group welcomed on Thursday the release of three Nigerian human rights activists, but criticized the military regime in Abuja for denying the group access to meet detained opposition leader Moshood Abiola.

At a press conference in Harare after a two-day visit to Nigeria, the group's chairman and Zimbabwe Foreign Affairs Minister, Stan Mudenge, said the release of the three was a positive development towards Nigeria's respect of human rights.

"We welcome the releases announced yesterday of three detained persons," he said. "At the same time, we regret that we are unable to visit any detainees, including Chief Abiola." 

The three included one of Nigeria's human rights leaders, Gani Fawehinmi, whose wife and the United States government have been lobbying for his release because of ill-health.

The eight-nation group has been calling for the release of all those detained without trial in Nigeria. The Nigerian government has since June released 23 people.

Mudenge said the group comprising Britain, Canada, Ghana, Jamaica, Malaysia, New Zealand, South Africa and Zimbabwe would continue to press for the release of Abiola and other detainees.

Abiola has been in detention on treason charges since June 1994 for declaring himself president on the first anniversary of the election which he claimed to have won, but which was annulled by the former military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida.

While in Nigeria, the group met the military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, traditional rulers, representatives of five opposition political parties, heads of various transitional institutions and chairman of the National Human Rights Commission.

In a statement released after the three-hour meeting, Abacha called "for equity, justice and understanding in handling internal problems of member states in keeping with the original objectives which informed the setting up of the historic body of British colonies."

He urged Commonwealth member states to strengthen the organization and hold regular meetings.

Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth in November 1995 following the execution of a human rights activist and eight other Ogoni leaders.

The Commonwealth Ministerial Group, set up at the November Commonwealth meeting in New Zealand, was mandated to investigate human rights abuses in Nigeria and monitor progress towards a return to democratic and civilian rule.

Mudenge dispelled rumors that the group was divided over the Nigerian issue.

"We are only meeting in the new year to analyze the information we have and make recommendations and it is only then that we might know whether there is a division or not. At the moment, there is no division," he said.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 22, 1996


East Africa;
President Buyoya Leaves For Uganda


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - Burundian President Pierre Buyoya left Bujumbura Friday for Kampala, Uganda, for talks with his Ugandan counterpart, Yoweri Museveni.

Uganda is the second country to be visited by Buyoya since his return to power in a coup on July 25. 

He has visited Tanzania several times for discussions with former President Julius Nyerere, the mediator in the Burundian ethnic conflict.

However, he has not yet managed to meet with Tanzanian officials, whose country is the bridgehead in sanctions against Burundi imposed by the states of the Great Lakes region. They took the measure in protest at the coup on July 25 which overthrew President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.

Meanwhile, the Information Service at the Burundian presidency said a Congolese delegation was expected in Bujumbura later Friday to invite Maj. Buyoya to the next summit of head of states in the Economic Community of Central African States. The meeting is scheduled to take place December 2 in Brazzaville, Congo.

The Community, which is headquartered in Gabon, was set up in 1981 in Libreville and includes Burundi, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe and Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Uganda;
Museveni Warns He Will Pursue Rebels Into Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

KASESE, Uganda (PANA) - President Yoweri Museveni has warned that the Uganda army will pursue rebels of the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) that invaded western Uganda last week to their alleged bases in Zaire.

"If the rebels dared to attack the country again, they will be crushed and followed up to their bases," he told journalists at Mpondwe border post, in Kasese, the last area to be secured by the Uganda Peoples Defence Forces on the border with Zaire. 

The ADF is a combination of Ugandan a Moslem fundamentalist sect reportedly funded by the government of Sudan.

Clad in a military uniform and carrying an AK-47 rifle, Museveni said: "We respect our neighbors sovereignty and territory. But those who attack us will be dealt with severely."

He said his government had got in touch with President Mobutu Sese Seko to arrange a meeting between the two governments. "We want to talk to the Zairean government to find measures to deal with the problem of Zaire-based Ugandan dissidents who attacked the country."

He said more than 200 rebels had been killed during the one week of bitter fighting and several of them arrested. He did not give the number of those rebels arrested.

The security situation at the border, however, remained tense with most of the villages still deserted. But military sources say that security had been beefed up at the border to deal with any incursion.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Africa-at-Large;
Zimbabwe Still Supports Boutros Boutros-Ghali


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe Friday accused the United States of being undemocratic by blocking the renewal of Boutros Boutros-Ghali's bid for a second term of office as United Nations secretary-general.

President Robert Mugabe said his government continued to support the candidacy of Boutros-Ghali despite the U.S. position. 

"We are very critical of the Americans. It is something we cannot accept. How can one nation dictate to the world like this?" Mugabe told journalists. " The world should read from this lesson...the practice is not democratic."

The United States this week voted against a second five-year term for Boutros-Ghali. The other 14 members of the Security Council voted for him.

The American government accused the Egyptian, whose term expires on Dec. 31, of being too slow in pushing U.N. reforms and threatened that his candidacy would further delay U.S. payment of the 1.4 billion dollars it owes to the world body.

The three African members of the Security Council, Botswana, Egypt and Guinea-Bissau, are consulting with African states on the way forward.

Some African countries have started naming alternative candidates following a call by U.S. that the O.A.U. should draw up a list of the alternatives.

Ghana has already said that it would back its national, Kofi Annan, 58, current head of U.N. peacekeeping operations.

The leader of Mozambique's opposition, Alfonso Dhlakama, has backed Graca Machel, widow of the country's former president Samora Machel.

The current thinking is that an African should take the second term since past secretaries general from Europe, Asia and Latin America each held the post for 10 years.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Mugabe Takes A Tough Stance On Dismissed Strikers


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe on Friday said his government will not be "bullied" by dismissed nurses and junior doctors into re-engaging, saying they should first re-apply as directed.

He said the nurses and junior doctors had shown indiscipline by striking in the first place, leaving patients dying in hospitals.

"We cannot be bullied by any arm of the civil service. That is ... indiscipline and we would like to put a stop to it," Mugabe said in an interview with journalists. 

He said the government position was still that the dismissed doctors and nurses should re-apply and go back to work before negotiations can start.

"We expect the nurses to come back to work in the manner we have prescribed. They should write and appeal. Their issue of salaries does not just relate to them, it relates to others in the civil service as well and we are aware of that."

Nurses, went on strike on Oct. 21 demanding that government look into their demands for increased night duty allowances and the introduction of risk allowance. They were joined by junior doctors 10 days later, who want better working conditions and on-call allowances.

But government dismissed 2,000 nurses and 300 junior doctors and so far only 153 nurses and 10 foreign doctors who were wrongfully dismissed, have appealed against their dismissals.

Mugabe said it was up to the dismissed health workers to follow the channels that had been prescribed.

The government, he said, had now committed itself to review the salaries of all civil servants every year with a view of improving them.

"The salaries are low and every year we should be looking to try and improve them," he said. "This is why we have committed ourselves to pay them 60 percent increments staggered over three years since last year. We will continue to do that until we are satisfied."

Meanwhile the dismissed health workers on Friday said they would not re- apply.

They have sent a letter to public service, labor and social welfare minister Florence Chitauro asking for their terminal benefits.

"We wish to advise the government that after exhausting all channels in trying to reach an amicable solution to the health crisis, we feel that time has arrived to ask for our terminal benefits," the letter said.

"We cannot procrastinate this decision as it will compromise health delivery. Re-applying is out of the question as we have stated time and again. "


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


440 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 22, 1996


Swaziland;
Reported Arrest of Former Swazi Beauty Queen Denied


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Mystery surrounds the reported arrest of last year's Woman of Africa (Swaziland) Award winner, Miss Ntombi Mngomezulu, on a charge of illegal possession of the drug cocaine.

Thursday's Times of Swaziland quoted Swaziland police spokesman, Inspector Paul Zishwili, confirming Miss Mngomezulu's arrest in Manzini and that she was being held in custody pending her appearance in court.

When PANA checked with the police independently concerning the Times of Swaziland story the police did not suggest there was any error in the report. 

A senior police drugs unit officer added that Miss Ngomezulu was arrested along with a Nigerian illegal immigrant, Pascal Nelson Nnaboike and a Swazi taxi driver after she had collected an express delivery parcel at the Manzini post office.

On inspection by police the parcel which had been sent from Brazil was found to contain over 1 kilogram (2.2 pounds) of cocaine powder hidden in a secret pocket in a leather folder type handbag.

There was surprise and confusion last night when Mngomezulu, telephoned the Swaziland television studios Thursday night during a news broadcast denying her arrest and stating she was in fact in Johannesburg as chaperon to Swaziland's competitor in this year's Woman of Africa regional contest in Johannesburg, Sizakele Shongwe.

Swaziland police this morning for the first time denied the Times of Swaziland report Thursday that the arrested Ntombi Mngomezulu was the former Woman of Africa.

However, the police denials are countered by the Times sources at the University of Swaziland where the former award winner, Ntombi works in the library.

The paper's editor told PANA Friday they will continue to investigate the possibility of a cover up of the latter's involvement in drugs as she is related to the royal family. Certain members or close associates of the royal family were also rumored to have been involved in drugs smuggling earlier this year.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 22, 1996


Algeria;
Fundamentalists Order Algerians To Boycott Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - One week before the holding of a constitutional referendum in Algeria, the armed wing of the Islamic fundamentalist group (GIA), has issued a statement calling for complete boycott of the polls.

In its 50th bulletin issued on Thursday and cited by the local media, the GIA said its troops would kill anyone found at the polling stations on Nov. 28, the day fixed for the exercise. 

But authorities in Algiers said they would provide maximum security for voters by beefing up troops presence.

"All arrangements have been made to ensure free and calm polling", Interior Minister Ben Mansour said on state television Thursday.

The security measures include the closure of markets. Haulage trucks would also not be allowed during the period, he said.

Some 35,000 polling stations are being set up for the polls. called for popular endorsement of a republican constitution for the troubled north African country.

They will be supervised by 380,000 officials, but there have been no mention of foreign observers monitoring the polls as was the case in Presidential elections held in the country in November last year.

Reports said rallies organized by the government to drum up support for the polls were well attended.

The Front of Socialist Forces (FFS) led by Hussein Ayat Ahmed, who is calling for a "No" vote in the referendum, has held several meetings in its Bejaja stronghold in eastern Algeria.

In the same town, a few hundred people demonstrated against the referendum on Thursday following a call by the Berber Cultural Movement.


LOAD-DATE: November 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 27, 1996


Nigeria;
Nigeria Sets Up Committee To Plan Economic Future


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian military government has named a multi- sectorial 170-member committee to chart a new economic course for the country.

The team, set up Monday to fashion the country's economic blueprint, labelled "Vision 2010," is headed by Ernest Shonekan, businessman and former head of the Interim National Government in 1993.

It has as members 10 serving ministers, as well as former ministers, technocrats, captains of industry, traditional rulers, media representatives and academics. 

The ministers on the committee are those of finance, petroleum resources, industry, national planning, science and technology, agriculture, power and steel, transport, communications and education.

Some 40 economists in the team, include Sam Aluko, Pius Okigbo and at least eight foreigners, among them, Brian Anderson of Shell Petroleum Development Corporation, Jim Massey of Mobil, Ingvar Heide of Elf and Theo Oerlements of the Liquefied Natural Gas of Nigeria.

Among those from the media are Wada Maida, managing director of the News Agency of Nigeria and Peter Enahoro, administrator of the mass circulation Daily Times of Nigeria.

There are also 11 women on the committee including, former Commerce and Tourism Minister Bola Kuforiji-Olubi; Grace Alele Williams, a former university vice-chancellor and Alhaja Abibatu Mogoji, of the Lagos Market Women Association.

Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation with some 100 million people, has since independence in 1960 seen its economy shift from an agrarian to an oil- dependent one, after the country struck the so-called black gold in the 1970s.

Oil now accounts for at least 80 percent of the country's total foreign exchange earnings.

The committee was to be inaugurated Wednesday by Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha.

To strengthen its economic programme, the Abacha regime has held two annual economic summits in which Shonekan, the man Abacha removed from office in November 1993, has served as a key player.

So far, the military government has won qualified support even from critics for its economic reform policies, which have led to a reduction in inflation and relative stability of the national currency, the naira.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 27, 1996


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Trade In Ivory Products To Continue


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe will continue trading in Ivory products even during the forthcoming convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), a senior government official said Wednesday.

Willis Makombe, acting director of national parks, said ivory carvers and traders were bracing up for anticipated high demand during the CITES meeting to be held in June, 1997 in Harare.

"Today Zimbabwe trades locally in ivory that is why we have ivory articles in the shops and each time there is an international conference business is brisk," he told a meeting of the Wildlife Society. 

However, he said, the government was going to put up signs in the shops dealing in ivory to warn foreign buyers that it was possible their articles could be confiscated in their home countries.

"We want the delegates to check with their countries first before they buy the ivory articles," he said.

Ivory trade, especially in Southern Africa, is embroiled in controversy as the international community insists that elephants should remain listed on appendix 1, banning utilisation and trade.

Southern African countries meeting August in Maseru, Lesotho, unanimously agreed to press for the downgrading of the elephant from appendix 1 to 2 which would allow for sustainable utilisation.

Unlike in other African countries where the elephant population is threatened with extinction due to poaching activities and mismanagement of wildlife resources, most of Southern Africa has accrued a huge population that is now resulting in animal-human conflict.

For instance, Zimbabwe has a herd of at least 60,000 while its carrying capacity is about 30,000 elephant.

There are fears the downgrading would trigger illegal trade and poaching would resurface.

"As government, we are aware that there could be repercussions to the downgrading but we are ready for that," Makombe said.

Intensive lobbying among the African countries was underway, he said, and Environment and Tourism Deputy Minister Edward Chindori-Chininga had just returned from a two-week trip to West Africa to drum up support for the downgrading.

Currently, Zimbabwe has ivory stocks worth millions of dollars and the ivory is accumulating at about five tons every year.

"Government believes that wildlife resources should be utilized for the economic benefit of the country," Makombe said.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 27, 1996


Zimbabwe;
New Tourism Boss Targets Europe and Asia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Tourism Authority says it is embarking on an aggressive marketing drive in Europe and Asia to promote the country as a premier tourist destination.

Reporting this Wednesday, the Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency said the authority's newly appointed chief executive, Joseph Chigwedere, has proposed to work on niche market areas.

The major market focus will be on Germany, whose nationals are known worldwide for their passion for travel. The United States and Australia are also targets for Zimbabwe's marketing drive. The authority has identified these countries as likely to be the fastest growing source of tourists for Zimbabwe. 

"We are getting about three flights a week from Australia and we think by the end of the century, we will have daily flights, either ending up in Johannesburg or Harare," Chigwedere said.

The marketing campaign will also be carried out in Britain, still a major source of tourists for Zimbabwe, as well as the Far East, with particular attention being paid to such countries as Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore.

Chigwedere said the authority will also target the Arab world, encouraging wealthy tourists from Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to visit Zimbabwe.

"We also want to develop the regional and domestic market. South Africa, because of its proximity, is still a significant market for us but we have to be selective and identify markets which are high-yielding but low volume," he said.

"The local market is also important and we are trying to instill a culture of taking a holiday, particularly among the young blacks," he added. "It is critical that we develop the local tourists for us to prosper."

He said the authority will be registering all tourist establishment and ensure that standards were maintained.

It will help indigenous Zimbabweans wanting to enter the tourism industry, currently the fastest growing in the country, with annual earnings exceeding 100 million U.S. dollars.

In 1995, at least one million visitors came to Zimbabwe, mostly from Germany, the United States, Britain, South Africa and Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


445 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 27, 1996


Zambia;
Opposition Plans To Fight Chiluba's Government


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's opposition will soon mount non-violent country-wide demonstrations in protest against the newly elected government of President Frederick Chiluba.

Announcing this in a press conference Wednesday, the chairman of the Opposition Alliance, which groups eight political parties, Roger Chongwe, claimed Chiluba's government was "illegitimately" elected.

At the joint press conference also addressed by former President Kenneth Kaunda, Chongwe said the demonstrations were aimed at sensitizing and drawing attention to a 'sham and fraudulent" electoral process. 

Chongwe demanded for an interim government to be formed, saying the alliance will not recognize Chiluba's government.

"Chiluba must earn the respect of the people. We are appealing to the public to agree to the proposal of an interim arrangement to oversee the electoral process," Chongwe said.

He condemned government's continued attack and harassment of the local monitoring teams which have declared the Nov. 18 elections not free and fair.

"The call by Chiluba to put the police and army on alert is abuse of power by those in authority. Since when did Zambians vote with armed para-military officers manning the polling stations? If chiluba was popularly elected, why has he now turned to the military and not the people? It becomes dangerous when a government relies on the military," Chongwe noted.

He charged that the elections were not free and fair and that is why the international community had boycotted monitoring the polls.

He named the United Nations, the Carter Foundation, National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, the European Community, the Netherlands, Sweden, Germany and the West-minister Foundation as some of the organizations that had refused to monitor the elections.

Kaunda charged at the same press conference that the United States, Britain, Japan and Sweden whom the government has accused of funding local monitoring teams to declare the elections not free and fair, were being "insulted" by Chiluba's government for supposedly interfering in Zambia's internal affairs.

"These donors are being insulted by Chiluba right, left and center. Chiluba thinks I am so powerful that I just told the US, Britain, Sweden and Japan that Chiluba is bad, stop giving him aid. How can Chiluba think I am that powerful, who am I?," Kaunda said.

Kaunda who quoted Chiluba's speech at the 1992 OAU summit in Senegal where he had called on the OAU to intervene in African countries which were not practicing good governance, wondered why Chiluba was now criticizing regional leaders who commented on Zambia's political impasse.

The alliance at the same press conference revealed that more people who had not registered had voted during the just-ended elections. Statistics quoted from the Electoral Commission and released at the press conference revealed that the percentage of people who voted were more than those registered.

One of the constituencies cited was the northern Mansa constituency where a total of 12,322 votes were said to have been cast while the total number of registered voters was 10,145.

The alliance, which comprises Kaunda's United National Independence Party and seven minor political parties had boycotted the elections.

The Zambia Democratic Congress which participated in the elections said after the results that the elections were rigged. The congress also announced that it will not recognize Chiluba's government.

LANGUAGE: English
