Africa News


November 27, 1996


Congo;
Congolese Senate Endorses Oil Sharing Contract


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - The Congolese senate has endorsed an oil- sharing agreement between the state and a U.S. company, parliamentary sources said Wednesday in Brazzaville.

Last August, the government issued a licence authorizing Esso, a U.S.-based oil conglomerate, to exploit an oil reserve off the coast of Pointe-Noire in southern Congo. Shell of the U.K. and ELF of France also operate in the same area.

Under the contract, the government would get 40 percent of crude oil when total total production does not exceed 100 million barrels. Esso would retain 60 percent.

But if crude production ranged between 100 million and 200 million barrels, the share of the Congolese state would rise to 42 percent against 58 percent for Esso.

If production is between 200 and 300 million barrels, Congo's quota would be 44 percent and Esso 56 percent, but if the crude exceeds 300 million barrels, Congo would get 46 percent against 54 percent for Esso.

Under another article of the contract, Esso is required to pay Congo a bonus of three million dollars and to contribute funds towards development projects.

The American company is also to provide about one million dollars to finance a social project and a similar amount for development projects in northern Congo's Cuvette Basin.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 27, 1996


Science and Health;
Ebola Prompts Pretoria To Tighten Border Health Controls


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa has tightened its border health control measures after recording its first Ebola-related death Sunday.

The move is aimed at preventing the general spread of deadly infectious diseases to and from the country.

This action follows the death here on Sunday night of the first person in South Africa to contract the dreaded Ebola fever, which results in the death of up to 90 percent of its victims. 

She was a 46-year-old nursing sister - Mrs. Marilyn Lahana - who contracted Ebola fever after treating a Gabonese doctor late October.

The South African National Department of Health has communicated the new regulations to representatives of companies which airlift patients into South Africa from other African countries for medical treatment and with the agencies which organize medical treatment for foreigners in the country.

Further discussions on the measures are to be discussed during meetings on ways of ensuring effective cross-border control of infectious diseases.

The head of the World Health Organisation initiative to revise global measures on how to control infectious diseases across borders - Dr. Brian Gushulak - will address the meetings.

Meanwhile, everyone suspected of having been in contact with either the Gabonese doctor or Mrs. Lahana is still being closely monitored, but none of the 300-plus people involved have shown signs of developing Ebola fever yet.

But the Gauteng Health Department director for AIDS and communicable diseases, Dr. Liz Floyd, has warned that further cases could still develop.

"This is an anxious time for the people on the monitoring programmes," she said. "We have our fingers crossed, but we are not out of the critical 21-day period yet."

Ebola is considered one of the most dangerous viruses in the world because so little is known about it. It is transmitted through close contact with body fluids.

The first major outbreak of Ebola occurred in Zaire in 1995 when more than 250 people died of the disease.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 28, 1996


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Releases Nationalities Of Crash Survivors


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1124 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - With the last two bodies recovered from the wreck of the Ethiopian Boeing 767 jet which crashed Saturday near the island of Grand Comoro, the airline released Thursday, the names and nationalities of the 50 survivors and 125 victims.

Eleven survivors were also flown Thursday to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from Nairobi, Kenya, where they were later discharged from hospital.

Fifteen other survivors have remained in Nairobi for further treatment. Another 23 survivors are under hospitalization in the French territory of Reunion, some 2,400 kilometres south-east of the Comoros. 

The jetliner was hijacked Saturday by three Ethiopians, minutes after it took off from Addis Ababa for Abidjan in Cote D'ivoire. It was to make transit stops in Nairobi, Brazzaville and Lagos.

The hijackers ordered the captain to fly them to Australia. But refusing to believe the captain had fuel only for a flight of one-and-a-half hours, they forced the pilot to remain in the air until the plane ran out of fuel and crashed near Moroni, capital of the Comoros.

The last two corpses recovered were an Ethiopian and a Nigerian. All three hijackers were among the dead.

Ethiopians, with 22 dead, head the list of victims from 37 countries. There were nine Ethiopian survivors, among them the captain and co-pilot. Five flight attendants were among the dead.

Numerically, Nigerians are second on the list of the dead. Only four of the 22 Nigerians on board survived. Among the 21 Indian passengers seven survived, among them an infant. Two of the 12 Malians also survived.

All nine Sri Lankans died as did eight of the 14 Kenyan passengers.

The number of victims from Congo has been revised to three with two survivors. Seven of the eight Israelis died while two of the five Britons survived.

Other survivors were from Italy (4), United States (4) and one dead, Ukraine (3) and one dead, Liberia (2) and two dead, two each from Benin and Sweden survived. One Japanese survived and another died.

The following 18 countries each lost one national:

Austria, Belgium, Canada, Chad, Cote D'Ivoire, Egypt, Germany, Hungary, Korea (south), Lesotho, Liberia, the Netherlands, Pakistan, Sweden, Somalia, Yemen and Zaire.

The remaining task is of positive identification of the remaining corpses. Then, they will be placed in coffins, already purchased in Kenya and South Africa and taken to Moroni. These corpses will then be flown, either from Addis Ababa or Moroni, to the homes of the victims for proper burial.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 28, 1996


Kenya;
Kenyan Photo-Journalist, Amin, Laid To Rest


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Mohammed Amin, the world-acclaimed Kenyan photo- journalist, who died in Saturday aboard an Ethiopian Airlines jetliner that crashed off the Comoro islands in the Indian Ocean, was buried here Wednesday evening.

Hundreds of mourners, including media colleagues, turned up both at the late journalist's residence and at the muslim cemetery in the Kenyan capital, to pay their last respects. 

"This is a man we shall miss in our noble profession," said Reuters global executive director Mark Wood, who had flown from London to pay his last respects. "His professional out-put was excellent."

The burial was also attended by editors of two prominent local newspapers, the Kenya Press Law task force chairman Horace Awori and Reuters TV editor Mark Pain. Also present was former Kenyan constitutional affairs minister Charles Njonjo and the Ethiopian Airways regional manager, Konjit Roufael.

Meanwhile, President Daniel Arap Moi has sent a message of condolence to the president and the people of Hungary following the tragic death of the country's ambassador to Kenya, Antal Annus, in the same plane crash.

Annus was returning to Nairobi from Addis Ababa in the ill-fated plane after presenting his credentials to the Ethiopian government. He was seriously injured in the crash and died in a Nairobi hospital while undergoing treatment.

November 28, 1996


Zaire;
Tshisekedi Returns, Claiming He Is Premier


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zairian radical opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi returned here Wednesday and reaffirmed he has been asked by President Mobutu Sese Seko to form a government of national unity.

His claim was refuted by Mobutu a few days ago. 

On his return, Tshisekedi, the leader of the Union for Democracy and Social progress, was cheered by at least 10,000 of his supporters who had lined up along the Patrice Lumumba Boulevard linking the Ndjili airport to east Kinshasa, where his party's headquarters is located.

The former prime minister returned from a week-long visit in France where he visited Mobutu, who is recovering from prostate cancer surgery in Cap Saint-Martin, near Monaco principality.

The opposition leader's return was being eagerly awaited in the Zairian capital following his claim, after his meeting with Mobutu last Thursday, that he had been given "full powers to form a government of national unity".

He also said the conflict in eastern Zaire was an "internal Zairian affair" which should be settled through talks with rebel leader Laurent Kabila. He finally said that Prime Minister Kengo Wa Dondo's cabinet was a "Government of the West".

Tshisekedi's claim was denied 24 hours after he made it by Ngbanda Atumba, a special advisor to Mobutu. He challenged Tshisekedi to prove that he discussed political issues with the president.

In its reaction to Tshisekedi's call for talks with Kabila, the Zairian government said it had decided to take sue him in court, describing the move as "treason".

However, in a statement read Tuesday on Zairian television, the Zairian information minister, Boguo Makeli, denied a widespread rumor here that Tshisekedi was arrested on his return from France.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 28, 1996


Algeria;
Security Forces Put On Maximum Alert


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Algerian security forces were on maximum alert for Thursday's constitutional referendum in which 16 million voters are to decide on a draft constitution banning political parties based on religious, ethnic, regional or racial background, and widening the powers of the president.

According to reports from Algiers, soldiers, communal guards and self- defence groups have been put on maximum alert and are patrolling towns and villages. 

The forces are very "visible" in the hinterland, especially in the Algiers region, where members of the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) are concentrated.

Observers in the Algerian capital say that unlike during the 1995 presidential election, the army seems to have taken the backstage.

However, communal guards and armed civilians are on the forefront of the alert and their numbers could reach 200,000 men, according to independent sources.

The security forces will be in charge of guarding the 8,000 polling stations. With three million inhabitants, Algiers is the largest constituency.

According to reports, several road blocks have been put up at the entrance to major towns since Monday and were reinforced Thursday by armored vehicles. In Algiers and the Algiers region, the road blocks have been in place for months.

Lately, bloody attacks by armed groups have intensified. In the first three weeks of November, 150 people were reported killed in a series of massacres.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 28, 1996


South Africa;
South Africa To Break Ties With Taiwan


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa will sever diplomatic ties with the Republic of China (Taiwan) and establish full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China (mainland China), next year.

Pretoria's new position marks a departure from President Nelson Mandela's reported undertaking to visiting Taiwanese Vice Premier Hsu Li-teh in August this year that South Africa would not break diplomatic relations with Taiwan in favour of mainland China. 

Announcing the decision Tuesday, Mandela expressed regret because Taiwan had given its support to South Africa's transition to democracy, and to the country's reconstruction and development programme.

Mandela's African National Congress government had inherited its recognition of Taiwan from the white-dominated regime.

According to President Mandela, continuation of this situation was " inconsistent with the country's role in international affairs."

The South African leader said his Government would not abandon relations with Taiwan overnight, but would arrange a smooth transition which would lead to an eventual end of diplomatic relations by the end of next year. He added that all other relations with Taiwan would remain intact.

The president explained that the possibility of dual recognition had been ruled out after it had become evident that this was unacceptable to Beijing.

But the president justified the decision to the fact that the People's Republic of China is a major player in world affairs recognized by virtually all major countries in the world. The two governments would soon hold talks on the establishment of an embassy in South Africa, he added.


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


453 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 28, 1996


Zambia;
President Chiluba Dissolves Cabinet


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba who was re- elected last week for a second and last term in office 10 days ago, dissolved the cabinet on Thursday.

A state house spokesman quoted the president as saying that ministries will be run by permanent secretaries until the a new cabinet is appointed.

His Ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) emerged victorious in the Nov. 18 general elections, in which it scooped 131 of the 150 parliamentary seats at stake. 

Ten seats went to independent candidates, five to the National Party, and two each to the Zambia Democratic Congress and Agenda for Zambia.

Chiluba managed to get almost all his cabinet ministers back into parliament. Only two cabinet and two deputy ministers lost in the parliamentary elections.

The government had lost 11 members of his first cabinet, appointed in 1991, within a period of two years through resignations. Among those who resigned was Vice-President Levy Mwanawasa. The ministers who left alleged that the government was corrupt and that some of their colleagues were involved in drugs trafficking.

Meanwhile, the opposition Agenda for Zambia has called for fresh elections and urgent formation of an interim government to resolve contentious issues.

The party's president, Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika, declared at a press briefing Thursday in Lusaka that the just-ended elections were not free and fair.

"It is a matter of fact and not opinion that the elections failed the test of the democratic process and they were not free and fair or just for all the stake-holders," Lewanika claimed.

He said the Nov. 18 elections, which President Frederick Chiluba had declared as free and fair, were unacceptable and undemocratic to the Zambian people since the electoral process was manipulated to "cheat and get the results that Chiluba desired to have."

"We are requesting that an interim government be established and come up with a new constitution and electoral process and also resolve other outstanding issues before fresh elections take place," Lewanika said.

Lewanika came fourth to Chiluba in the presidential elections contested by five candidates. His party got only two of the 150 parliamentary seats.

The Zambia Democratic Congress and the Opposition Alliance, which consists of eight political parties, have also declared that the elections were not free and fair and that they will not recognize Chiluba's government.

Former President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party, which is a member of the alliance, intends to hold non-violent country-wide demonstrations in protest against the government.

Africa News


November 29, 1996


Science and Health;
WEB FEET: Notes from the Net


BYLINE: Arthur Goldstuck, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Johannesburg - The only game in town right now is the one played by millions and perfected by a small handful, which happens to include Ernie Els and Wayne Westner. I only know that because I checked out the World Cup of Golf site (http://www.wcgolf.com/narrowcast/welcome.ht ml), which went up shortly before the tournament, won by the South African duo.

The site itself earned several hundred thousand visits during its brief stay on top of the South African web hit parade, proving that golfing fans have not neglected the Internet while glued to live TV broadcasts. In fact, when you peruse golfing sites on the web, you notice a strange anomaly: golfing sites consistently boast larger graphics - and often more system- hungry added extras that demand added extra plug- ins for your browser - than almost any other sporting category on the Internet. 

There can be only one conclusions from this observation: the designers of golf sites assume their prospective visitors fall in the income category that dictates fast, high-end computers with high-speed links to the Internet.

If that is the case, then the rest of this column is safe for the golfing classes only. The rest of you can come along, but mind the heavy system demands.

The World Cup of Golf site may have served its purpose, but it remains a useful resource for those who want to go over the action again, or get some insight into just how South Africa ran away with the title. It features Real Audio broadcasts from the tournament, Quicktime Virtual Reality (that's one of the plug-ins you need, and even video footage.

The guide to the Erinvale Country Estate and Golf Club is meant to include 3-D flyovers of each hole, but perhaps my browser was just too low-class to find them.

This weekend, the single most important golfing site in the world is the 1996 Nedbank Million Dollar Golf Challenge (http://www.milliondollar.co.za/). Again, you have to dodge the graphics: the opening menu can only be accessed via a vast image map, no less than 62kb in size, with no text option for the bandwidth-less-abled. The big added extra here is a Million Dollar Golf Challenge screensaver for Windows 95, a mere 11,5Mb in size. That dwarfs the funky map of the course, at a mere 100kb, from which you can access details and photos of any of the holes, drinking holes and accommodation options.

The menu aside, the information design of the site is excellent, with quick access to the basic facts and figures which, after all, is what a site like this is intended to provide. There are many superb international golfing sites on the web (mostly with big graphics), but to find out more you'll have to visit the online version of this column at http://www.mg.co.za/mg/pc/pcrev ie1.htm

Send comments and suggestions to arthurg.@is.co.za

Africa News


November 29, 1996


Business and Finance;
Pulling No Punches at Joburg's Finance Week


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

Johannesburg - Nigel Bruce has been editor of Finance Week for 10 days now after jumping ship from rival publication Financial Mail.

Bruce does not feel he has to excuse his abrupt move uptown to the ailing Finance Week: "I had absolutely no choice."

Days before he handed in his letter of resignation, Bruce and Times Media Limited (TML) managing director Roy Paulson talked about the Finance Week takeover. Against Paulson's instructions, Bruce allowed one of his columnists, David Gleason, who was about to take up the reins at Finance Week, to write a farewell column in the Financial Mail. 

In a dramatic move and after months of speculation and denial, Gleason took over Finance Week and is the single largest shareholder in the company. Bruce, who is now also a shareholder, said at the time of his disagreement with Paulson that it was his prerogative to use whomever he wished for editorial contributions. That brought to a head the already turbulent relationship between Paulson and himself.

"It was clear that I would have to leave TML at some stage as it had become difficult to work there with a board and managing director with no publishing instincts and no idea of the criteria to be used when making senior editorial appointments."

Bruce does not pull any punches as he sits in his stark office, no paintings on the wall, surrounded by simple and cheap office furniture.

He first attacks Johnnic, the holding company of TML which, he says, has a " history" to it, one sure to overshadow the current board.

"The board of directors of TML, on which Johannesburg Consolidated Investments is strongly represented, never appeared to have any interest in the editorial quality of the newspapers or in the political developments that shaped them."

Bruce is adamant that TML's managers do not have their priorities in order. "Instead of investing in Financial Mail and Business Day, they chose to starve the business publications. What do they do? They invest in a popular magazine division and a girlie magazine (Playboy); the latter of which has since closed down. None of those magazines, as far as I know, are making a profit."

Bruce cannot resist picking holes in the stable that he was affiliated to for 21 years, 11 of which he spent at the helm of Financial Mail. "Solid management is lacking all round," he says.

He believes that the takeover by the National Empowerment Consortium (NEC), headed by Cyril Ramaphosa, is likely to be problematic.

"The problems are already beginning to loom ... We have a chairman (Vaughn Bray) and an managing director (Paulson) who form a cosy cabal. We will have to see whom the board decides to appoint as managing director after Paulson retires. Also, the pending Financial Times/ Pearsons Group deal is an issue of dissent," he says.

Bruce argues that "at no point" did the NEC talk to him about its feelings regarding editorial independence. "For over a year, no one came to discuss the issue which concerned all TML editors."

Bruce was involved in drafting an editorial charter long before the deal was concluded in an effort to "preserve the traditions of all the newspapers".

"Only through strong shareholding can the traditions be preserved," he says, adding that that is lacking in the current board's composition.

Bruce does not seem to be liked by many colleagues in his profession. When talking to him you can see why. He comes across as brash, pompous and a strong contender for the "I am always right" award. If he can help it, he does not hand out compliments. He has the following to say about two key people who are the new owners of TML.

On the chairman of Johnnic, Ramaphosa, he says: "He may be a good unionist but when it comes to commerce and business he is an innocent."

On the chairman of New Africa Investments Limited, Nthato Motlana: "If you are not laudatory towards him, he accuses one of racism. He has not got the foggiest idea of what his business is about."

In a first interview since he changed publications, Nigel Bruce spoke frankly about his new role.

What do you plan to do with Finance Week?

I plan to make it a rip-roaring success in the business arena. We plan to cater for those readers with disposable income at the top end of the market. Our coverage of stories will be more controversial, while at the same time, an entertaining read. We also plan to increase our editorial staff but have not as yet approached any of the Financial Mail's (FM) staff.

How much will it cost and how long will it take to overtake the FM on circulation/advertising?

I don't think it will be necessary to overtake the FM in order to make our mark. Yes, our circulation and advertising will be increased in due course but I don't think it is necessary to compete outright with the FM which is aiming, according to Business Day, at reaching a younger and larger black market. Capital is not an issue as the newspaper is well-financed.

What was your biggest failure at the FM?

Not being able to manage shareholders sufficiently to allow them to understand their political susceptibilities which led to their sale of Times Media Limited (TML). I also feel I failed by not seeing TML's business titles become international but I had no support from the managerial staff. I was unable to forge relations abroad as well as edit a publication.

Had TML stayed in white hands would that have affected your decision to stay?

It is not an issue of colour. Secure ownership in accord with the editorial traditions of a newspaper is important. My concern at the time was the editorial independence of TML publications.

After the appointment of Cyril (Ramaphosa), when they made threatening remarks, they did not at any time discuss whatever reservations they may have had with the editors concerned. Had TML remained a secure company, I would have reconsidered.

Who should succeed you at FM and why?

I don't know whom they have in mind but I know that the Financial Times favours Peter Bruce (editor of Business Report) as a likely candidate.

What are you able to do at Finance Week that you were unable to do at the FM?

I am now able to create incentives for colleagues. At the FM I looked after my editorial colleagues in ways about which the managing director knew very little. I was able to use an ambitious and profitable surveys programme, paying my colleagues an additional fee for doing this freelance work.

What are your thoughts on the newly formed South African National Editors' Forum?

It's a bad thing when editors of newspapers want to regulate the industry. It seems they are eager to form some sort of guild. Newspapers have to cater for the demands of the market.

You cannot trade off white editors' concerns about press freedom against unqualified commitments to implement affirmative action when it might not be appropriate in the market concerned.

LANGUAGE: English

November 29, 1996


South Africa;
Media Mad: Profile of Cawe Mahlati


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - Acting chief executive of Bophuthatswana Broadcasting Corporation (BopBC) CAWE MAHLATI sees herself as a 19th-century female warrior from Zimbabwe.

Which television programmes do you watch most often and why? 

I watch Born at the Right Time. It is a youth talk show that is creative and breaks new ground.

Which book have you recently read that you would recommend?

Fingerprints of the Gods by Graham Hancock. It is about old civilisations, particularly in South America, and explores various concepts as to why pyramid structures exist in South America and can also be found in Egypt and elsewhere. Absolutely gripping.

Which radio stations do you listen to and why?

I listen to Mmabatho radio and Radio Bop.

Do you surf the World Wide Web of the Internet and what do you go for in particular?

Yes. I find myself surfing BopBC's web site.

Which is your favourite advertisement and why?

Yebo Gogo. It has pace and is compelling and you cannot switch it off.

Which newspapers and magazines do you regularly read?

I read all the dailies. Magazines: Financial Mail and most of the black magazines including Bona, Tribute, True Love and Black Enterprise.

If you could be any film star or fictional character, who would you be and why?

Mbuya Nehanda, a 19th-century Zimbabwean female who led Shona warriors against the British settlers.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


457 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 29, 1996


South Africa;
What Makes The Top Ten On Television


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Johannesburg - Television news has an average of six Audience Ratings (ARs) and just manages to slip into the All Media and Product Survey (AMPS) figures of the top 10 television programmes on the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) channels.

But six ARs, according to media directors from local advertising agencies, is "just not good enough" for what should be the flagship programmes of SABC.

Despite poor ARs, advertisers are still encouraging clients to buy air time as an advertising spot around the news is regarded as "prime''. 

Lindsay Smithers-FCB media director Tony Banahan says the ratings are " terrible" but the News on SABC is "one of the few programmes that the top end of the market watches.

"The market you are trying to reach is often people with disposable income and they are news and current affairs addicts," he says, adding that the news is the best the SABC has to offer.

"In the old days it would have been in the region of 20 ARs and the ratings we are now getting for the news are not half as good."

The reasons for this are twofold: people are tired of being faced with bad news and badly presented news and the broadcast area of SABC 3 is limited, reaching a small target audience.

Saatchi & Saatchi group media director Julie Dunstan says to monitor the ARs of adults across all channels is "not a true reflection" of the penetration of adverts.

Fragmentation in the market and a drop in ARs was expected following the relaunch of the new national public broadcaster, she says. And advertising around news bulletins depends largely on which target market one was aiming to reach.

"With all the bulletins in vernacular languages, you can plan your target market carefully," she says.

Other comments by media directors on the ratings received by news among adults included: "Appalling ratings but time will tell if it'll improve", " Viewers may watch the news but it is mainly for the headlines as excerpts are far too long" and "The ratings will slowly improve as audiences become accustomed to the changes which have happened and still are happening at the SABC."

Two weeks ago (November 11 to 17), the ARs for the news on SABC 3 were about seven, the same as the ARs for local soapie Egoli on M- Net, which also rated between seven and 7,5.

The highest ratings for that same week went to local comedy Going Up on SABC 1 on Wednesdays, reaching 14,6ARs.

A close second was another locally produced comedy, Suburban Bliss on SABC 2 on Mondays, which topped 13,2 ARs.

The top 10 SABC programmes for children highlighted some interesting factors. The news on SABC 1, which is mainly in Xhosa and Zulu on Tuesdays and Fridays respectively, had high ARs among children - higher than adult viewers in the same language group.

Xhosa news had 15,3 children's ARs, while Zulu news had 14,2 ARs.

Suburban Bliss on SABC 2 (Mondays) and Touched by an Angel on SABC 3 (Tuesdays) were favourites among children, reaching 21,2 and 8,1 ARs respectively.

Even when studying the top 10 programmes of the English and Afrikaans- speaking adults, news only reached about eight ARs.

Furthermore, average viewing time was only two hours per week, whether they were English, Afrikaans or Nguni/Sotho-speaking audiences.

Media directors argue that television programming is no longer compelling viewing and news bulletins are no exception.


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

November 29, 1996


South Africa;
Media In Brief


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Johannesburg - It is understood that the South African Broadcasting Corporation's (SABC) board has decided behind closed doors that 5FM will no longer play music that is older than 10 years. A 5FM staffer who refused to be named for fear of reprisals says the station was informed that its music format will change in a bid to reach a younger target audience. A SABC representative denied that such a decision was made.

SAATCHI & Saatchi Klerck & Barrett's management team is restructuring its business in a bid to gear up for greater growth in light of the recent equity purchase by parent company Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide (SSAW).

SSAW's confidence in the strength and solidity of the South African management team has meant it has not been necessary to bring in any foreigners. Among the new portfolio announcements for management are Sandra Fisher, appointed as deputy managing director of the Gauteng office; William Leach, as South Africa Group chief executive as well as retaining his managing director's position and Tso Modise as joint deputy chair of the group.

NATIONAL PARTY assistant secretary general Marthinus van Schalkwyk this week charged that SABC board chair Dr Ivy Matsepe- Cassaburi should "break her silence about speculation from African National Congress ranks that she could be appointed as Free State premier".

Van Schalkwyk says it cannot be justified that the Parliament's Portfolio Committee on Broadcasting has recommended her for the position of chair of the new SABC board while she is being considered for premier.

LANGUAGE: English

459 of 478 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 29, 1996


South Africa;
Time's Up for Press Council


BYLINE: Jacquie Golding-Duffy, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Johannesburg - The Press Council of South Africa, established in 1992 in response to pressure from former president PW Botha, will finally be dissolved next year following much debate on the future of this adjudicator.

It will be replaced by an ombudsman and an appeal panel which should be up and running by March next year.

Press Council chairman Kobus van Rooyen says there are two main reasons for closing-up shop. 

The first is the historical circumstances under which the Press Council was formed: "Pressure was brought to bear on the press to bring its house in order by the government of president Botha which placed the media under state supervision and that has tainted the council."

The second reason is that it is timely to bring the Press Council in accordance with the Constitution which enshrines freedom of expression: "It has become necessary to make a fresh start within the Bill of Rights and it is necessary to end the perception that since government pressure has led to its founding, that it is not entirely independent and objective."

Van Rooyen also argues that the current council structure is too all- inclusive, adding that a separation of powers is essential. "The powers of adjudicating should be the sole power of the ombudsman and he or she should not get involved in debate concerning press freedom. The main objective should be to remain impartial and allow other structures to take up various fights in the media."

The Press Council and its predecessor, the Media Council, turned out to be a model of independent adjudication and a "shield and sword against government's attempts to gag the press", Van Rooyen said. Yet an ombudsman could do this and more, including assessing complaints from the public.

Advertisements will be placed nationally and nominations will be accepted for an ombudsman and four appeal panel members. A chief justice, or respected professional from the legal fraternity, will be approached to oversee nominations and finally make an appointment.

The successful candidates will have to serve for a period of five years and will be paid a nominal fee.

Freedom of Expression executive director Jeanette Minnie welcomed the move. "Since the mid-Eighties the media has been reluctant to introduce its own voluntary watchdog body in the face of press restrictions and States of Emergencies. Now in a new climate of press freedom it is encouraging and timely to see the role players in media taking steps towards having a body to monitor activities in the industry."


LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
